output - gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20: The incidental train crash, caused by an explosion of 13,000 barrels of oil, occurred last Thursday. Some 200 people, including 70 women and 35 children, were injured, and 20 were killed. Many of the injured are still in the hospital. The fire that ensued was still burning yesterday, but it is thought that the danger is diminishing. The oil was being transported by train from Oklahoma to New York. The train was carrying 30,000 barrels of oil, and the explosion occurred when a spark from the locomotive ignited the oil. The explosion caused the train to derail and explode, sending oil and debris flying in all directions. Transcribed_Text:
1933-5236/47090

        THE IDEAL WORKING MAN'S FLAT AS SUGGESTED
        BY THE MINISTRY OF HEALTH.

               The Ministry of Health are now holding an exhibition of flats
        designed for the working men. They are built on modernistic lines,
        very simple and making for the maximum amount of sun and air to reach
        the interiors. The flats are labour saving and are well planned.
        O.P.S. A view of a block of flats for the City of Manchester,
               Smedley residents showing the terraced effect of the building
        and the flat roofs.                                     196/B. Keystone.

(Stamp, faint)
THE KEYSTONE VIEW COMPANY
COPYRIGHT.
KEYSTONE

BUILDERS SHOW FOR BUILDERS
KIND.

AT PUBLIC BUILDING AND PAVING EXPOSITION HERE.

1983-5236/58588

Industry - Misc - Safety - Protective Wear etc.

FASHION SHOW FOR BUILDERS
QDS K1848 2.2.67.
A FASHION SHOW WAS HELD BY THE MINISTRY
OF PUBLIC BUILDING AND WORKS IN LONDON TODAY
TO TRY TO PERSUADE BUILDERS THAT THEY NEED
NOT HALT WORK DURING WINTRY WEATHER.
WINTER WEAR FOR BUILDING WORKMEN,
EVOLVED BY OFFICIALS AND CLOTHING DESIGNERS,
WAS DISPLAYED AT THIS NOVEL KIND OF FASHION
SHOW.
PHOTO SHOWS:
(LEFT-RIGHT) A BASIC TWO-PIECE
SUIT; MADE IN PROOFED NYLON, WITH EXTENSIVE
VENTING AND ADJUSTABLE SLEEVE AND TROUSER
CUFFS; A BASIC SUIT MADE IN A NEW PLASTIC/
TERY LENE LAMINATE MATERIAL WHICH IS CLAIMED
TO BE BOTH PERMEABLE AND WATERPROOF; A BASIC
NYLON SUIT WITH A HOOD IN PLACE OF THE NORMAL
JACKET COLLAR; AND A NEW TYPE OF DONKEY
JACKET MADE OF A LAMINATE COTTON, FOAM AND
RUBBER WOOL.

PROPERTY OF
SUN
-3FEB1967
PLEASE ->
TO TURN
ART LIBRARY

FLEET STREET 2266/7
This photograph is not sold but a licence is
granted for its publication as a news photograph
only. This print must not be loaned, sold or copied
without our consent.

1983-5236/45153
         D Sketch

NOT TO BE PUBLISHED KKKX BEFORE FRIDAYS DAILIES AUG 15th
XH)
         BRITAINS BIGGEST WHEATFIELD

What is believed to be the biggest field of wheat in
Britain, a 400 acre block, which had not felt the
plough for 20 years and was practically derelict, is
now being out high up on the Sussex Downs.
The field is expected to produce about 17 cwt. of
grain an acre, and 40 Australian binders, handled by
land girls, are harvesting the corn.

Photo shows:- A typical study of a land girl on a
binder cutting the huge wheatfield.

13/8/41                     S               (Topical Press)

REF: NUMBER. Y 2221
NOT TO BE PUBLISHED BEFORE FRIDAYS DAILIES AUG 15th

Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/54453

        ART LIBRARY
        TO
        PLEASE RE
        1 8 FEB 1960
        DAILY HERA
        PROPERTY O

FROM BLACK OF READING

The Duke of Edinburgh's new Harvard training plane gets the five-stars
insignia of Marshal of the Royal Air Force after delivery to White Waltham
(Berks) R.A.F. station.
Pictured here putting the finishing touches to the job is Fairey Aviation
mechanic Peter Barton of Gosbrook Road, Caversham, Reading. With him is
Sgt. James Murray, one of the ground staff who will service the plane.
Delivery of the 200-miles-an-hour American-built Harvard means that the
Duke's training has now progressed beyond the 120 m.p.h. Chipmunk in which
he received his initial flying lessons. When he masters the Harvard, he
will move on to jet planes - probably the 600-miles-an-hour Gloster Meteor.

end

File: DUKE OF EDINBURGH X file training Planes.

IDEAL HOME EXHIBITION AT OLYMPIA
WRT-JXN E11593 5.3.62.
THE 1962 HALLMARK SUSSEX COTTAGE SEEN DURING A PRESS
PREVIEW OF THE DAILY MAIL IDEAL HOME EXHIBITION WHICH
OPENS TOMORROW AT OLYMPIA AND CLOSES ON MARCH 31ST.
HALLMARK HOMES CAN BE SEEN IN SUSSEX FROM HASTINGS
TO BOGNOR REGIS.

output - gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20:
This is a pilot observation report.
The group size is 12 men.
This is probably a training exercise.
The men are wearing green fatigue uniforms.
All of them are wearing tin hats.
The men are exercising in a wooded area.
All of the men appear to be in good health.
The men are seen to be using the following equipment.
(1) A light machine gun, model 1919 A4.
(2) A light machine gun, model 1918 A2.
(3) A sub-machine gun, model Thompson.
(4) A rifle, model M1 Garand.
(5) A rifle, model Springfield.
(6) A bazooka.
The men are in good spirits and are seen to be enjoying themselves.

The observation post is situated on a hill overlooking the exercise area. The area is approximately 1.5 miles long and 0.5 miles wide. The terrain is rolling and covered with trees. The weather is overcast and the temperature is 50 degrees Fahrenheit.

The following observations were made:
* At 10:00 hours, a group of 12 men entered the exercise area. The men were all wearing green fatigue uniforms and tin hats.
* The men were seen to be using the following equipment: (1) a light machine gun, model 1919 A4; (2) a light machine gun, model 1918 A2; (3) a sub-machine gun, model Thompson; (4) a rifle, model M1 Garand; (5) a rifle, model Springfield; (6) a bazooka.
* The men were in good spirits and were seen to be enjoying themselves.
* At 11:00 hours, the men left the exercise area.
* The exercise was completed without any incidents.

Transcribed_Text:
PRO
DAIL
RCD.
PI

PROGRESS ON THE ANGLO-
The great new oil refinery of the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company,
with a projected capacity of 4,000,000 tons a year, is taking
shape. It is due for completion in the summer of 1952,
but the Crude Oil Distillation Unit and its necessary
auxiliaries are expected to be in commission in a few months.
Situated at the Isle of Grain, on the Kent coast, the new
refinery will cost £40,000,000, and its output will be about
one-sixth of the Abadan refinery. It is being constructed
on reclaimed marshland on which a million tons of sand from
the sea bed off the Nore have been pumped in order to stop
the natural sinking of the land, and to prevent the sand
drifting, a mixture of grass and clover has been planted.
New jetties are under construction to accommodate the largest
of tankers, and there will be 160 storage tanks.
The picture shows:

1983-5286/51756

A view of the new refinery site looking south-east from
Cat. Cracker, showing combined blow down stack and tanks
in the foreground, Crude Distillation Unit (left centre),
No.1 Vacuum Unit (right centre), temporary construction
Offices, canteen, concrete batch plant, etc. Centre
background. River seen in far distance.

Indus, Oil Refineries, Isle of Grain.

Transcribed_Text:
1983 - 5236 / 47523

" A MILLION WOMEN MUST COME INTO OUR WAR INDUSTRY -- "
Following Mr. Churchill's dramatic speech, this picture
is of particular interest. He stated that more than a
million women must come forward into our war industry,
into the shell plants, and ammunition works. This picture
was taken at the Paddington Technical Institute, where a
number of Women Engineers are undergoing training. No
doubt many of them will be playing their part in this
war with some valuable work on the home front.

Photo shows- A study of one of the women engineers under
instruction at the Paddington Technical Institute.

FOR. JAN. 30th.40.

SUPPLI
LONDON ST
BY E.C.4

DUPLICATE SENT:
7C JAN 1940 ON.
MANCHESTER.

THEY PLANNED A CITY

Even while Nazi bombs were raining on London, experts with their eyes fixed on the future, were planning a new London that shall do away with the many blemishes that still mar the face of the EmpireÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s capital. How you are introduced to some of the people who are shaping the future of London in this article BY CONNERY CHAPPELL.

Transcribed_Text:
1983 5236/43992

        They Planned A City

Even while Nazi bombs were raining on London, experts with their eyes fixed
on the future, were planning a new London that shall do away with the
many blemishes that still mar the face of the Empire's capital. Now you are
introduced to some of the people who have been working for the future of
London in this article by CONNERY CHAPPELL

OHN HENRY FORSHAW, M.C., the ex-Royal
Engineers officer, who is the chief man behind
the London County Council's Plan for rebuild-
ing London, is forty-seven and earns £2,750 a year.
And while the Plan, to which he contributed more
than any one else has had more space and publicity
than any other single news item since the war started,
Forshaw himself has had practically none. Which is
how he prefers it.

The Plan, of course, has broken all records. It has
gone into a second edition as a book at 12s. 6d. More
than 1,500 people a day have seen models of it at the
County Hall—mostly housewives, service men on
leave and young people who wanted to see the world
of the future—there its exhibition has had to be ex-
tended. Editorial comment on it runs into hundreds
of columns.

In short, after taking two years to prepare, the Plan
is revealed as the biggest thing of its type ever at-
tempted.

It is a Plan, not of lines, but of lives, designed to
take the ugliness out of London, in the words of Lord
Latham, Leader of the Council.
The decision to produce it was taken more than two
years ago, during the big air raids. A special staff
was built up from people in the Town Planning Sec-
tion of the L.C.C.'s big architectural department at
County Hall.
Every one concerned with it carried on with their

normal Civil Defence and Home Guard duties, and
often with their departmental work as well. There were
no privileges, no special favours. It was an enormous
job, frequently done under bad conditions during air
raids.

As consultant, the L.C.C. engaged Leslie Patrick
Abercrombie, Professor of Town Planning at Uni-
versity College, London, who is accepted as Britain's
leading expert on the subject. Wesley Dougill, who
died in February, when the job was nearly done, was
Assistant Planning Officer, and did brilliant work.

The whole thing was produced on an informal con-
ference system, many meetings taking place in the
early hours of the morning during the hectic nights of
1941.

Professor Abercrombie, who was visiting County
Hall several times a week, frequently stayed over and
slept there, and Mr. Forshaw was usually on the spot—
for in addition to his position as deputy architect and
later architect to the council he was also in charge of
A.R.P. rescue work and debris disposal for London.

This involved spending many nights at headquarters
and it was during these sessions, waiting for air raid
alerts, that a lot of the early theoretical work was done.

Gradually, the staff sorted itself out; it never
exceeded thirty and averaged about twenty. It was
enthusiastic, and young, which was as well, for an
enormous amount of groundwork had to be cleared up
before the Plan could reach the drawing boards.
Consultations at what the council calls “officer

    —4 SEP. 1943

title: A document of Industry, Furs
description: A document from the Daily Herald Archive folder: Industry ÃƒÆ’Ã¢â‚¬Å¡Ãƒâ€šÃ‚Â» Furs.
output - gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20:
Mr. Cassells, about M.P. for Dunbartonshire, has informed the secretary of the Scottish Labour Party of his intention to retire at the next General Election.

J. Parkes, of Blackpool, received fatal injuries yesterday when the collapse of a water main trench at South Shore, Blackpool, buried him up to his head and shoulders.

Jarrow Town Council has decided to promote a Bill in Parliament to give it powers to acquire land by agreement or compulsion for industrial purposes and to advance money for buildings.

The Board of Trade announce that a draft Order-in-Council was laid before Parliament on November 22 requiring imported solid-headed pins of brass, iron, or steel to bear an indication of origin.

More than a dozen skeletons were found during excavation for a new cinema at Devizes. They were examined by Captain B. Howard Cunnington, the Wiltshire archaeologist, who said they were of no archaeological value.

Trooper Edward Williams, 4th/7th Dragoon Guards, stationed at Aldershot, died yesterday in the Cambridge Military Hospital, Aldershot. Riding an Army motor-cycle on Tuesday, he came into collision with an Army light tank.

Mr. F. A. Soden, assistant foreman in the L.M.S. erecting shop, Crewe, has been chosen to accompany the company's Coronation engine on its tour of the United States next year; it will be shown at the World's Fair in New York.

At Nottingham yesterday Joseph Hardstaff, the Nottinghamshire and England cricketer, was fined Ã‚Â£10 and ordered to pay Ã‚Â£1 3s. 6d. costs for driving a motor-car in a dangerous manner. His licence was endorsed. He pleaded "Not Guilty."

After refusing for a number of years to send a member to represent the Borough on the Essex Territorial Army Association, West Ham Town Council on Tuesday night decided to reverse its previous decision. The Labour Party selected Councillor A. G. Schnn as a representative and he was elected.

Mrs. Sydney Marsham has been appointed chairman of the executive committee of the Imperial Council of the Girl Guides Association, in the place of Dame Helen Gwynne-Vaughan, who has resigned. Lady Clarendon has been appointed vice-chairman in the place of Mrs. Charles Tufton, who has resigned.

The motor lifeboat which was on view in the lifeboat pavilion at the Empire Exhibition, Glasgow, for six months, leaves the Clyde today, after final adjustments, to take up her real work at Tobermory, Isle of Mull. The boat has cost about Ã‚Â£8,000 and is a gift to the Royal National Life-boat Institution from Miss Margaret Lithgow, of Glengorm Castle, Tobermory, who died a few weeks ago.

NEWS IN ADVERTISEMENTS

The following items are taken from the advertisement columns of this issue of The Times, where details will be found:Ã¢â‚¬â€

Books are required for the formation of a camp library for 400 men at an aerodrome in an isolated area. (p. 1, col. 3)

Applications are invited for the post of matron of Thomas Hall for Men Students, University College of the South-West of England, Exeter. (p. 3, col. 2)

The Community Service Council for Durham County invites applications for the post of assistant homecrafts organizer for work in women's and girls' clubs. (p. 3, col. 1)

An order has been made by the Charity Commissioners for England and Wales establishing a scheme for the regulation of the charity called Cumberland House, Mitcham. (p. 2, col. 7)

Transcribed_Text:
THE FUR STORAGE
VAULT
wavy.
By CALLISTHENES

The other day a charming customer
who brought to our Fur Department
several articles requiring immediate
attention told us of an experience which
may be common to many. Last Spring,
feeling very economical and imagining
that the trifling cost of fur storage might
be avoided, the lady purchased a moth-
proof bag, stored her furs therein and
put the bag away. The receptacle,
unfortunately, was not proof against
the tiny invader, for a carelessly folded
opening admitted the enemy, with the
result that the lady’s furs can only be
saved by the immediate attention we
are now giving them. For protection
is not so much a matter of only moth-
proof bags as the application of storage
conditions that make damage
impossible.

The Fur Storage Vault of ours is a
well-known and enormously patronised
department of this business. We believe
it to be one of the largest fur vaults
of its kind in the world. It is so arranged
that its temperature is maintained
continuously below freezing-point, so
that it becomes impossible for moth
eggs to germinate, even though they be
depply hidden in the fur. But this
precaution against germination is only
a single stage in a carefully planned
campaign against the insinuating moth.
Two or three times during the summer
months—for an entire 24 hours—the
temperature of the vault is allowed to
rise to that of the street. By this means
whatever eggs are left in the furs are
encouraged to hatch out. The trouble-
some insects are then submitted to the
freezing process and eliminated utterly.
It has been noted, by the way, that pelts
treated by this process recover their
original sheen, and seem rejuvenated
after their emergence from cold storage.
Carefully examined before they are
stowed away and no less carefully
re-examined before being handed over,
the pelts return with a newness and a
glossiness which is otherwise lost to
them. The cost of this work is so
small—a matter, really, of a few shillings
—as to represent the most profitable
outlay on one’s wardrobe needs.

We have now arrived at a period of the
year when many of these gems of the furrier's
art are being removed. Yet we feel that our
reference to this fascinating subject is timely,
if only for the moral it points. To incur
avoidable risk to precious furs in the hope
of saving a few shillings for storage is to be
“ penny wise, pound foolish ” in the widest
sense of the phrase.

Selfridge & Co., Ltd.

DNA. 1949

239513       BRIN
TORY M.P.s TAKE T.V. COURSE.


London: Mr. Charles Orr-Ewing, Conservative
Member of Parliament for Hendon, North, sits
in the camera chair when fourteen Conservative
members of Parliament to-day began a B.B.C.
television course, similar to one recently held
for television writers, at Alexandria Palace.
The M.P.'s accepted an invitation from Mr. George
Barnes, the television director, to see something
of technique requirements and production problems
from the inside.
A number of Socialists are also to take the course
at the end of this month.
3rd. October, 1952 PN-d.

by which a British ironworks produces mile upon mile
of cast iron pipes for the public services of gas
and water-which are a prime necessity of civilised life.
A large percentage of these pipes are spun by a centrifugal
process which eliminates defects and gives a close-grained
metal, easily worked and with a high degree of resilience
and resistance to impact. In addition to its own
requirements, the plant also produces pig-iron
for steel manufacture, contributing largely therefore.
to the country's output of armaments.
Workmen diverting the molten iron from the "sow"
"pigs" (sand casts), when a
blast furnace has been tapped. The resulting ingots
are known as "pig iron".

“MOTOpia. A study in
the Evolution of the
Urban Landscape,” by
G. A. Jellicoe. Studio
Books, 42s.

NOT so long ago nearly
everybody thought
that they knew the
answer to the traffic prob-
lem.

We had only to spend a
few hundred millions a year
on motorways, ring roads,
flyovers, road widenings and
multi-storey parking
garages, and Bob would (in
due course) be your uncle.
This innocent illusion, because
successive Governments have
refused to spend anything more
than small change on building
roads, and we were unable to
learn from experience (as the
Americans are now doing) that
the engineering solution opens a
bottomless financial pit, but

—the futuristic town

planned to make

the best of motors

by
Malcolm MacEwen

an official of the Royal Institute of British Architects

does not solve the traffic
problem.
Two cars in every Los
Angeles garage are a sign less
of American affluence than of
the catastrophic collapse of
public transport, of waste on a
vast scale, and of the dispersal
of the city far and wide over
the countryside.
“Motopia” is the name given

by G. A. Jellicoe, the landscape
architect, architect and town-
planner, to his theoretical
design for an ideal motorised
town.

Its great merit is that he
breaks through the fetters of
conventional thinking in an
effort to design a new kind of
town in which we can get the
best of both worlds — the
mobility of the motor car with-
out its dirt, noise, smells, con-
estion and danger.

Motopia consists of a rect-
angular grid of five-storey ter-
races, forming a series of great
own “squares.”

The first four storeys are flats
and maisonettes, some with gar-
lens; the fifth storey is a
“mews storey” for car parking
and vehicular access; and the
roads are on the roof, screened
by plants.

The entire space between the
buildings, and under them, is a
vast park of unending variety
and beauty, in which lie schools
and other public buildings, and
through which one can walk
everywhere in safety.

At the corner of each square
the buildings form a hollow
circle, containing local shops
and other facilities on the
ground floor, and a roundabout
for the rooftop road.

SHOPPING

At one side of the town is a
great multi-level, glassed-in
shopping centre, where people
meet for shopping and pleasure
after parking their cars on the
roof.

It is easy to criticise Mr. Jel-
licoe’s conception. It is a shot
in the dark because nobody has
yet done the basic studies on
traffic generation that would
enable us to discover the practi-
cal limits to the use of the motor
car in towns.

All we do know is that large
towns and cities, if they are to

“Helicopter-view” of
Motopia, showing how the
space that would normally
be taken up by congested
roads is given over to parks
and recreation grounds.

remain reasonably compact
groupings for social intercourse,
must depend largely on public
transport.
In Motopia, this is limited to
water buses on the lakes—
delightful, but of limited prac-
tical value.

To put the traffic on the roof
and the people on the ground is
obviously more difficult than the
opposite, and the widths of
roads and roundabouts are
limited by the width of the
buildings, and cannot easily be
related to the volume of traffic.

EXERCISE

To dismiss Motopia for these
reasons would, however, be to
miss its real point. For Motopia
is an exercise in the imagina-
tion, and opens our eyes to the
possibilities that have still to be
explored in landscape and town
design.

The greater part of the book
illustrates the historical devel-
opment of the urban landscape,
which Mr. Jellicoe wishes to
restore to the place it held in
the 18th century when town and
country were brought together
in the Bloomsbury squares.

We shall not find the answer
to the motor-car problem by
hacking the city to pieces to
make way for it in unlimited
numbers.

We must begin by designing
for people, by setting our archi-
tects and their professional col-
leagues to work to design a new
kind of town in which we can
live civilised lives, using the
motor-car without being en-
slaved by it.

If “Motopia,” which is richly
illustrated and simply written,
jerks some politicians, council-
lors or the long-suffering victims
of the rush-hour out of their
while.

DAILY
13 APR 1961
HERALD

THE FIRST SUBMARINE CONSTRUCTION RECORDED
BELIEVED TO HAVE BEEN THE MOST SUCCESSFUL
WHILE THEY WERE ALL RELATIVELY EARLY.

THE SUBMARINE CONSTRUCTION WAS VERY CRUDE, THE FIRST record OF THE EARLIEST SUBMARINE IS SAID TO HAVE BEEN BUILT BY CORNELIUS DREBBEL A DUTCHMAN IN 1620 TO EXPLORE THE THAMES. WHILE HE WAS EXPERIMENTING WITH THE CONSTRUCTION OF THE SUBMARINE. THE FIRST SUBMARINE construction BELIEVED TO HAVE BEEN THE MOST SUCCESSFUL WAS RECORDED IN 1800 BY THE AMERICAN ROBERT FULTON. WHO WAS COMMISSIONED BY NAPOLEON TO BUILD A SUBMARINE TO DESTROY THE BRITISH FLEET. FULTON CALLED IT THE "NAUTILUS". AND IT WAS A GOOD SUCCESS FOR THE TIMES. THERE HAD BEEN EARLIER EXPERIMENTATION WITH SUBMARINE CONSTRUCTION, BUT FULTON'S CONSTRUCTION. WHEN IT WAS RECORDED, IT WAS THE MOST ADVANCED. FULTON WAS SUCCESSFUL AT THE TIME AS HE WAS ABLE TO CONSTRUCT A SUBMARINE THAT WAS ABLE TO GO FORWARD. AND ALSO TO GO BACKWARD. AND IT WAS ALMOST IMPOSSIBLE FOR THE ENEMY TO HAVE DETECTED IT. THIS MADE FULTON'S SUBMARINE CONSTRUCTION RECORDED AS THE MOST SUCCESSFUL.

THE SUBMARINE WAS LAUNCHED IN 1800. AND IT WAS ABLE TO GO UNDERWATER FOR AN HOUR AT A DEPTH OF 10 FEET. THE SUBMARINE WAS 16 FEET LONG AND 4 FEET WIDE. IT WAS MADE FROM WOOD AND WAS COVERED IN LEATHER. THE SUBMARINE WAS PROPELLED BY MEANS OF A HAND-CRANKED PROPELLER. AND IT WAS ABLE TO CARRY SIX MEN. THE SUBMARINE WAS ALSO EQUIPPED WITH A FIREARM THAT COULD BE FIRED UNDERWATER.

FULTON'S SUBMARINE WAS A SUCCESSFUL DESIGN FOR ITS TIME, AND IT LAID THE GROUNDWORK FOR FUTURE SUBMARINE DEVELOPMENT. THE SUBMARINE WAS ABLE TO GO UNDERWATER FOR AN HOUR AT A DEPTH OF 10 FEET. THE SUBMARINE WAS 16 FEET LONG AND 4 FEET WIDE. IT WAS MADE FROM WOOD AND WAS COVERED IN LEATHER. THE SUBMARINE WAS PROPELLED BY MEANS OF A HAND-CRANKED PROPELLER. AND IT WAS ABLE TO CARRY SIX MEN. THE SUBMARINE WAS ALSO EQUIPPED WITH A FIREARM THAT COULD BE FIRED UNDERWATER.

IN 1801, FULTON USED HIS SUBMARINE TO SINK THE HMS HERSAM, A BRITISH SHIP, IN THE ENGLISH CHANNEL. THIS WAS THE FIRST TIME THAT A SUBMARINE HAD BEEN USED IN WARFARE. THE SUCCESS OF THIS OPERATION CAUSED THE BRITISH TO DEVELOP THEIR OWN SUBMARINES. AND THEY WERE ABLE TO SUCCEED IN THEIR OWN DEVELOPMENT OF THE SUBMARINE. AND FULTON'S SUBMARINE CONSTRUCTION WAS RECORDED AS THE MOST SUCCESSFUL.

THE GERMANS STARTED USING SUBMARINES IN WORLD WAR ONE. AND THEY NAMED THEM U-BOATS. THE U-BOATS WERE VERY SUCCESSFUL IN SINKING ALLIED SHIPS. AND THEY WERE ABLE TO DESTROY ALMOST ALL OF THE BRITISH FLEET. BUT THE ALLIES DEVELOPED NEW TECHNOLOGIES TO COUNTER THE U-BOATS. AND THEY WERE ABLE TO WIN THE WAR. THE SUBMARINE HAS BEEN DEVELOPED MORE AND MORE EVER SINCE.

THE FIRST SUBMARINE CONSTRUCTION RECORDED BELIEVED TO HAVE BEEN THE MOST SUCCESSFUL WHILE THEY WERE ALL RELATIVELY EARLY.

BY THE 1800S, SUBMARINE TECHNOLOGY HAD ADVANCED TO THE POINT WHERE THE SUBMARINE BECAME A VIABLE WEAPON OF WAR. THE FIRST SUBMARINE TO BE SUCCESSFULLY USED IN COMBAT WAS THE CONFEDERATE SUBMARINE H. L. HUNLEY, WHICH SANK THE UNION WARSHIP USS HOUSATONIC IN 1864. THIS EVENT MARKED A TURNING POINT IN NAVAL HISTORY, AS IT DEMONSTRATED THE POTENTIAL OF SUBMARINES AS A WEAPON OF WAR.

THE TECHNOLOGY OF SUBMARINE CONSTRUCTION CONTINUED TO ADVANCE RAPIDLY THROUGHOUT THE LATE 19TH AND EARLY 20TH CENTURIES. BY WORLD WAR I, SUBMARINES HAD BECOME A MAJOR FACTOR IN NAVAL WARFARE. THE GERMANS EFFECTIVELY USED THEIR U-BOATS TO INTERRUPT ALLIED SHIPPING, ALMOST BRINGING BRITAIN TO ITS KNEES. THE SUBMARINE HAS CONTINUED TO BE DEVELOPED AND IMPROVED UPON EVER SINCE.

THE SUBMARINE WAS A VERY ADVANCED PIECE OF ENGINEERING FOR ITS TIME. THE SUBMARINE WAS ABLE TO GO UNDERWATER FOR AN HOUR AT A DEPTH OF 10 FEET. THE SUBMARINE WAS 16 FEET LONG AND 4 FEET WIDE. IT WAS MADE FROM WOOD AND WAS COVERED IN LEATHER. THE SUBMARINE WAS PROPELLED BY MEANS OF A HAND-CRANKED PROPELLER. AND IT WAS ABLE TO CARRY SIX MEN. THE SUBMARINE WAS ALSO EQUIPPED WITH A FIREARM THAT COULD BE FIRED UNDERWATER. FULTON'S SUBMARINE WAS A SUCCESSFUL DESIGN FOR ITS TIME, AND IT LAID THE GROUNDWORK FOR FUTURE SUBMARINE DEVELOPMENT.

FOR FIRST PUBLICATION MONDAY IS EVENING JULY 18th 1949.
BRITAIN LEADS WORL IN MOTOR RUSTPROOFING TECHNIQUE.
JS 18.7.49.
Morris cars coming off the assembly lines at Cowley, Oxfordshire,
are now receiving a 100% anti-rust treatment from a special plant
known as the "Rotodip" which, operated in conjunction with one of
the most up-to-date paint plants, forms an engineering project in
which Britain leads the whole world. Until the advent of this new
technique the procedure for finishing car bodies was to first
to thoroughly clean down the body to remove all grease, and to
finally rinse by hand or automatic spray, followed by a drying
process, after which the primer and finish coats of paints were
added by spray gun. This method, however, did never give complete
protection because many important parts of the body were never
reached.
Now the bodies go through the plant which consists of a tunnel
some 20 feet square and 300 feet long, which they enter in the
plain steel, greasy state, and emerge some 12 houraw later having
been cleaned, rustproofed, and primer-painted inside and out.
entirely automatically.

bodies are mounted on a revolving spit with the bonnet, wings and
boot in position but spaced-inch from the body to allow free
circulation, and is then carried broadside through the length of
the plant on conveyor chains in such a way that the body revolves
on its own axis while passing through the machine. The process
is in two stages - first rustproofing by cleaning, rinsing and
proofing for which the bodies pass through six large tanks, and
secondly, primer-painting during which the body is dried in an
cooled down, and painted.

In their journey through the plant, the

aries of pictures illustrates the remarkable process which
rris engineers are confident will protect the bodies
at corrosion and paint flaking.

SIR HUGH CASSON took a sheet of paper
        from his conference documents and did
        a lightning sketch. There it is above—his idea
        of a seaside pier "for motorists only," where
        the whole family can spend a car-based day
        enjoying the ozone.
        Sir Hugh, the eminent architect, had just given his
        ideas about a new seaside, made-to-measure for the
        motorist, to the people most concerned—200 represen-
        tatives of British seaside resorts. They were meeting
        in London.
        They may have thought
        his ideas fanciful. But he is
        practised in making his
        dreams come true.
        He was chief architect of
        the Festival of Britain.
        "These car piers," he told his
        audience, "should be like the
        conventional seaside pier, out at
        sea on legs and reached by a
        causeway.
        Exciting and

        Expensive
        "They would have two- or
        three-storey viewing decks for
        cars only.
        "They need not look unsightly
        —on the contrary they could
        look most exciting. They would
        be expensive, or indeed an
        multi-storey garages on land,
        but at least there are no expen-
        sive site costs to meet.
        "If the pierhead amenities in-
        cluded such obvious facilities as
        cafes, souvenir shops, lavatories
        and the like then the motorist

        By FRANK
        DAWES

        would not grudge an ap-
        priate charge."
        He told me afterwards
        he picked up the idea
        Chicago, where a car pier is
        being built over the lake to solve
        the parking problem.
        He also suggested the two-
        storey promenade—one level for
        vehicles, the other for strollers.
        Sir Hugh agreed that the
        piers were perhaps suitable only
        for large resorts. He wanted a
        complete ban on motor-cars in
        the smaller resorts.
        Motor cars
        defined
        But before his piers get under
        way he asks for an immediate
        policy of charging for prome-
        nade parking at all resorts.
        After all to the car-borne

        holidaymaker the car is more
        than a vehicle, he said.
        "It is a home base—
        • The place to which the
        family returns for meals.
        • To put the baby down for its
        afternoon sleep.
        • For sun-bathing.
        • Where the children change
        in and out of bathing things.
        • Where Granny snoozes all
        day over her knitting.
        • Or of the pick-nick: a teenage
        daughter, tuned into Radio
        Luxembourg, sits daydreaming
        on her shoulder blades and
        brooding over the injustices of
        her life.
        And the men from Blackpool,
        Brighton, Bognor and Broad-
        stairs and all the resorts in the
        alphabet laughed and ap-
        plauded Sir Hugh's devastating
        description of a typical seaside
        town today.
        It rung bells. Here's an ex-
        cerpt about some place you may
        recognise.
        "The Old Town, cobbled,
        clamorous and smelly, locally
        referred to as the "haunt of
        artists", dominated by a fine
        parish church marooned like a
        stone schooner in a small sea of

        17th- and 18th-century cottages,
        some semi-derelict, a few still
        lived in, some "cutted up" as tea
        shops and junk shops.
        "To left and right, along the
        coast, small groups of regency
        terraces and squares, most of
        them come down in the world.
        minus balconies or cornices and
        looking like a group of elegant
        but shabby old ladies. perching
        upon the cliffs under the glaring
        eye of the local Grand Hotel—
        usually a magnificent Margaret
        Rutherford sort of building,
        mauve-faced, majestic and ex-
        travagantly behatted."

TWICE a week, the faint smell of brewing hops hangs over the Cains-cross ruins with its untamed, water wheel and old stone houses.
Before the gavel falls the ruins sell out when a world sees the Blacksmith and owner of a Jaguar car.
For forty miles along the Urr, to Dalbeattie Brewery, waits a fascinating trail of tales woven through the centuries.
These are the stories of the brewers, distillers and inn keepers
Wilgar Harvey had his Black-Smith Inn and house and 20 acres of land. He sold it for Ãƒâ€šÃ‚Â£1,000 in 1899.
Wilgar and his wife Ann lived in the house until they were too old to get around at 85 and 75 years.
They were the staff of Cains-cross brewery in 1957 when Mr Harvey was 70 and his wife was 60.

LIFETIME
Miss Jean Park and her sister Isobel lived in the house all their lives.
It was built of a fine, handcut stone and had 20 acres of land. The total value was Ãƒâ€šÃ‚Â£1,500. Miss Park told me, "It was my fathers."
The brewery was not in operation in 1968, when Mr John Maxwell came to live in it with his wife Isobel.
They moved in from Ireland when Mr Maxwell retired from the services. He was 57 and she was 50.
Mrs Maxwell told me they had been looking for a place in Scotland that would be out in the country.
"We saw about 12 houses and none of them pleased us," she said.
Then she saw an advertisement for the brewery in the Dumfries Standard.
"We came down, saw it, and bought it," she said.
"We liked the stone, it was beautiful. The size was suitable for us."
The Maxwells had two children, a son and a daughter, but they were grown up.
Their son David Maxwell, a doctor, was in the RAF, and their daughter Janet was married with three children.
The Maxwells told me they had no plans for brewing, but they had a still and a vat.
Mr Maxwell said he made his own wine.
"It is a hobby," he said.
He had retired with the rank of Group Captain.

"I'm the only person left alive that has lived in the brewery, after all the brewers."
It was bought in 1968 by Richard Smith, an electrical contractor from Manchester. He was 30 years old, and had a wife and four children. He had plans to use the building as a store for his electrical business. He told me, "It's a hobby. I'm going to turn it into a store."
He had worked in the family business all his life. His father was still living in 1968. He was 50, and his wife, Jessie, was 47.

TOO BITTER
"Some people say whiskey is too bitter, but it's not. If you put too much peat in it, it can be bitter. It's a question of taste."
Whiskey, a hop concentrate, was the last brew produced at Dalbeattie Brewery, which closed down about 20 years ago.
The brewery was built in 1840, and the last brew was made in 1948. It was a beer that was called "Dalbeattie Beer."
The hops came from a hop farm in Kent. They were boiled and then put into the fermentation vats. The process was called "brewing."
The brewery was owned by a local man, and it was a family business. The owners were called the Maxwells.
The brewery was sold in 1968, and the new owner was a Mr Richard Smith from Manchester. He had plans to use the building as a store for his electrical business.

CHEERS
"It's a hobby, brewing is an art. It's not a science."
A brewer told me, "It's all about taste. You can make it as bitter or as sweet as you like."
He said he had been brewing for 40 years. He had started when he was 20. He had been brewing beer all his life. He had been brewing beer for 40 years. He had been brewing beer for 40 years.
He was 60 in 1968, and his wife was 57. He had two children, a son and a daughter. His son was 30 and his daughter was 28.

E. H. SAVILL.
EDWARDIAN HOUSING. From S.A. 21.10.49.
Edg. H. Two houses at Almorah Estate, Birmingham,
the subject of these notes. The houses at present exist, and consist of two detached residences. The two houses are substantially the same in construction and design, and were erected circa 1908. The houses are built of red brick with tiled roofs. The houses are detached, and are of two storeys in height. The housing consists of the following accommodation: On the ground floor, a reception room, lounge, dining room, kitchen, and scullery. On the first floor, there are three bedrooms and a bathroom. The houses are at present in good condition.

Transcribed_Text:
CHILDREN with flaming torches led a march
        of 2,000 homeless last night—a march
        which ended with a bishop describing the
        plight as "a disgrace to the nation."

        Among the women in the quarter-mile long proces-
        sion which wound slowly from St. Paul's Cathedral to
        Southwark were mothers with babies in their arms
        with toddlers in push-
        chairs.
        At the end of the "croco-
        dile," men bore a huge
        banner which said simply:
        "No room in the inn."
        The two bishops who organ-
        ised the march—Dr. Robert
        Stopford, Bishop of London, and
        Dr. Mervyn Stockwood, Bishop
        of Southwark—took part in it.
        And from his pulpit at South-
        wark Cathedral, hard-hitting
        Dr. Stockwood spoke passion-
        ately about the problem of Lon-
        don's homeless—an emergency,
        he said, as great as the war.
        The cathedral, which holds
        about 1,200 people, was
        packed, and Dr. Stockwood's
        words were relayed by loud-
        speakers to hundreds who
        stood outside in the gather-
        ing darkness.
        The bishop said there were
        80,000 families in London wait-
        ing for homes—families living
        in overcrowded rooms, with
        inadequate facilities and shock-
        ing sleeping accommodation.
        REMEDIES
        And he suggested these reme-
        dies:
        A national housing authority,
        of which housing is now
        by the Government.
        • Priorities based on need,
        and if it is used for offices and
        factory building, it cannot be
        building homes," he said.
        • Control of land. "Is it right
        to leave speculators to deter-
        mine its value?" he asked.
        • In times of war the Govern-
        ment assumes control. Isn't the
        present emergency as grave?
        Among his other suggestions
        were mobile homes in London
        parks and open spaces, and the
        requisitioning of empty houses.

        DESPERATE
        As the bishop finished his ser-
        mon, 28-year-old Mrs. Gwyneth
        Cleaver, mother of two children
        who is living in an LCC centre
        apart from her husband, said:
        "This is our last desper-
        ate hope—that this march
        will move someone's con-
        science. Christmas isn't
        going to be much fun for us."
        Later, Dr. Stockwood, said: "I
        don't want to make this an anti-
        landlord thing. It's a question of
        human cupidity. We're all guilty
        of that—all ready to make a bit
        of money where we can.
        "What really sticks in my gul-
        let is the fact that a single room
        in, say, Hampstead, without
        facilities—water or anything—
        can be offered for £5 a week to
        desperate people.
        "And they are forced to take
        these rooms. They live in war-
        ren-six rooms, and maybe 30
        people in them. It's scandalous."
                                                                    C. Smith.
                                                                    Torchlight march for homeless.

                                                                    as a minister carries a marchers ba˜Y.

title: A photographic print of Industry, Barrels
description: A photographic print from the Daily Herald Archive folder: Industry ÃƒÆ’Ã¢â‚¬Å¡Ãƒâ€šÃ‚Â» Barrels.
output - gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20:
William Ripley is a barrel of monks, the ceremony that is ending after 500 years.
Picture by ARTHUR STEEL

WILLIAM RIPLEY was
formerly an assistant
in the barrel manu-
facture shop, but he
now works with his
father, James Ripley,
and Fred the Eker, in
the brewery. He is seen
on the way to the "Barrel
Monks" at the Churchills.

BY LESLIE DOWD

William Ripley
inherited his job from
his grandfather, who was an
assistant at Churchills.
There are few of us
who can say that we are in
the direct line of descent
from men who held the
same job 500 years ago, but
William Ripley, of
Churchills, can.

only a monk's bad temper
and a nasty disposition
could save him from being
locked in the barrel.
But it didn't happen for the
next 12 hours - not until
after his prayers and his
blessings from the Prior
had been said in the
Churchill Brewery - where
the traditional Barrel
Monks ceremony was to
take place one last time -
before the 500-year-old
custom was to be banished
for ever.
This last ceremony was to
take place on Christmas
Day.

THE LAST

The tradition began when
the monks of Churchill
Abbey produced the beer for
the village and for the
abbey itself and, with it,
the brewery became one of
the most important of the
abbey's many assets.
The abbot of Churchill Abbey
decided that the best way
to see the brewery kept in
order was to appoint a
"Barrel Monk" - a monk who
was responsible for
inspecting the beer barrels
to see that they were kept
in good condition and that
they were filled in the
proper way.
At Christmas Day, the
Barrel Monk had to drink
a barrel of beer in front
of the whole village - and
if he was unable to finish
it, he was locked in the
barrel for 12 hours.
This was not always a bad
thing, as the monks could
get very lonely, and after
a night's drinking it was
not too hard for them to
fall asleep for 12 hours.
But there were also some
monks who just could not
take the taste of the beer
and the barrels could be
very draughty, and William
Ripley's grandfather told
him that he had heard of
monks being half-frozen
when he had to stay in the
barrel overnight.

TRADITION

At a Christmas Day meeting
the monks elected the man
who was to be the Barrel
Monk for the next year. It
was a much sought after
job - not because of the
drinking - but because it
meant that the Barrel Monk
was not allowed to talk to
anyone for 12 hours of the
day in the brewery and had
to live a quiet life, so he
could concentrate on his
prayers.
But the job is being done
away with as the brewery is
being taken over by a new
owner from Sheffield, who
is bringing modern methods
and equipment. He will also
be bringing new beer. And
the monks are very upset.
They have petitioned their
Bishop and he has been in
communication with the
owner to try and preserve
the ancient custom - but
to no avail.

PUBLISHED
JAN 17 1950
RECEIVED

William Ripley in a barrel of muck: the ceremony that is ending after 500 years.
                                                             Picture by ARTHUR STEEL

WILLIAM RIPLEY was      By LESLIE DOWD         deal of treacle and waste
crammed into a hot                             beer.
barrel yesterday by     smothered him for some
Jack, Billy, Bob,       five minutes with all    Then they rolled him round
Charlie, Richard, Les,  manner of things.      the workshop, drew him out and
and Cyril the Sawyer.                          tossed him in the air.
                                                 All this time Mrs. Constance
                          There were bits of rice  Ripley, who gave birth to Wil-
Under the benevolent    and carrots, lots of beans,liam 21 years ago, was straining
eye of the "guv'nor," Mr.some peas and cold canteen to go to his aid.
Les Churchill, they     soup, pig swill, large num-  But she was held back by her
                        bers of feathers and a goodfriend and neighbour Ethel, who
                                                 have been coopers too.
                                                   Otherwise, as she said later,
                                                 "I would have rushed right in.
                                                 I was horrified at what they
                                                 were doing to my boy."
                                                   It was all, of course, what has
                                                 passed for good clean fun in the
                                                 coopering trade for over 500
                                                 years.
                                                   Like countless coopers before
                                                 him, William was suffering the
                                                 ritual "trussing" for complet-
                                                 ing his five-and-a-half
                                                 years' apprenticeship.

                                                 THE LAST

                                                 But because the trend is to-
                                                 barrelmaking craft is dying and
                                                 so is the "trussing" ceremony.
                                                 Truman, Hanbury and Bux-
                                                 ton, the London brewery for
                                                 which William works, are taking
                                                 on no more apprentices. He is
                                                 "the last" in London to be
                                                 "trussed," and probably the last
                                                 in the whole of Britain.

                                                   William, who is nearly 6ft.
                                                 tall and does weightlifting, took
                                                 it all rather well.

                                                   But his mother, Mrs. Con-
                                                 stance Ripley, and his sister
                                                 Constance both cried.

                                                   Mr. William Ripley, Senior,
                                                 who is in the bulk milk trade,
                                                 said later: "Mrs. Ripley was
                                                 getting very upset. I asked
                                                 a lady to hold her back and I
                                                 went across to take care of my
                                                 daughter, who was sobbing."

                                                   But later, when Williams was
                                                 washed and changed to be
                                                 presented with his indentures,
                                                 his parents were both smiling
                                                 proudly.

                                                   Mrs. Ripley said: "The photo-
                                                 graph of the trussing will have
                                                 pride of honour over the
                                                 mantelpiece at our Dagenham
                                                 home."

                                                   "It was silly of me to panic
                                                 during the ceremony but he is
                                                 my only son."

                                                 TRADITION

                                                 As is traditional, the trussing
                                                 was carried out by William's
                                                 seven fellow coopers in their
                                                 workshop.

                                                   Master Cooper Mr. Churchill,
                                                 aged 57, went through it all 36
                                                 years ago. For three generations
                                                 his forefathers, uncles and
                                                 cousins have been coopers, but
                                                 his son is a printer.

                                                   "I suppose this is the last
                                                 trussing I shall ever see," he
                                                 said.

                                                   "They say the craft is dying
                                                 but coopering will never die.
                                                 After all, latching hasn't. And
                                                 whatever the public change dic-
                                                 tates, beer always tastes better
                                                 from wooden barrels."

                                                   William has brewing connec-
                                                 tions from the earliest years,
                                                 having been born in a pub.

                                                   Spruced up half an hour after
                                                 his trussing to receive his inden-
                                                 tures from a director, Mr. Harry
                                                 Buxton, he said: "Our work
                                                 now is just maintaining the
                                                 wooden barrels we still have.
                                                 After that I'll have to move to
                                                 the wine or whisky trade."

YOUTH EXCHANGE DEPARTS TODAY.
TODAY, 6 FILM FEDERATION YOUTH EXCHANGE DEPARTS TODAY.
YOUTH FROM CANADA AND THE UNITED STATES WILL PARTICIPATE IN THE SIX-FILM FEDERATION EXCHANGE PROGRAM WHICH WILL BE CONDUCTED IN ENGLAND. THIS PROGRAM IS SPONSORED BY THE BRITISH FILM INSTITUTE WHICH IS WORKING ON THE EXCHANGE AND HAS ALREADY ARRANGED FOR FILMS TO BE SENT TO THE DELEGATES FROM THE VARIOUS COUNTRIES SO THAT THEY MAY BE ABLE TO MAKE THEIR REVIEWS BEFORE THEY ARRIVE. THERE WILL BE SEVERAL FILMS TO REVIEW AND EACH DELEGATE WILL HAVE TO MAKE THEIR OWN REVIEWS OF EACH OF THE FILMS.
SEVERAL FILMS WILL BE SHOWN ON SUBJECTS RANGING FROM BRITISH HISTORY TO CONTEMPORARY ENGLISH LIFE. THE DELEGATES WILL BE EXPECTED TO COMMENT ON THE FILMS AND ALSO TO MAKE SUGGESTIONS FOR IMPROVEMENTS. THIS IS A PART OF THE OVER-ALL EXCHANGE PROGRAM WHICH IS DESIGNED TO FOSTER BETTER RELATIONS BETWEEN THE UNITED STATES AND GREAT BRITAIN.
THE EXCHANGE PROGRAM WILL RUN FOR THREE WEEKS AND WILL CONCLUDE ON AUGUST 28. ALL ARRANGEMENTS HAVE BEEN MADE FOR THE DELEGATES TO BE HOUSED IN CAMBRIDGE UNIVERSITY AND TO HAVE ACCESS TO THE UNIVERSITY'S FILM ARCHIVES.
THE PROGRAM IS EXPECTED TO BE VERY SUCCESSFUL IN PROMOTING GOODWILL AND UNDERSTANDING BETWEEN THE YOUTH OF THE TWO COUNTRIES.
THE FILM FEDERATION HAS BEEN ORGANIZED TO PROMOTE THE USE OF FILMS AS A MEDIUM OF EDUCATION AND CULTURAL EXCHANGE. THE ORGANIZATION HAS BEEN IN EXISTENCE FOR SEVERAL YEARS AND HAS BEEN SUCCESSFUL IN ACHIEVING ITS GOALS. THE EXCHANGE PROGRAM IS ONE OF THE MANY ACTIVITIES THAT THE FEDERATION HAS UNDERTAKEN TO FURTHER ITS OBJECTIVES.
THE PARTICIPANTS WILL BE SELECTED ON THE BASIS OF THEIR INTEREST IN FILM AND THEIR ABILITY TO COMMUNICATE EFFECTIVELY WITH OTHERS. THE PROGRAM IS OPEN TO ALL YOUTH WHO ARE INTERESTED IN FILM AND WHO ARE WILLING TO PARTICIPATE IN THE EXCHANGE.
THE FILM FEDERATION IS LOOKING FORWARD TO A SUCCESSFUL EXCHANGE PROGRAM AND IS HOPEFUL THAT IT WILL LEAD TO A GREATER UNDERSTANDING BETWEEN THE YOUTH OF THE UNITED STATES AND GREAT BRITAIN.
THIS PROGRAM IS THE FIRST OF ITS KIND TO BE CONDUCTED IN ENGLAND AND IS EXPECTED TO BE VERY SUCCESSFUL.

H E was a very tall, elegant young
  man, the estate agent, and al-
  though we were only going across the
  road from his office he brought his
  brolly.

He fitted perfectly into the scene,
  swinging the brolly round thought-
  fully and saying yes, he would agree
  without doubt, we were walking along
  the most exclusive and expensive spot
  on the face of the earth.

St. James's-place, S.W.1.

It has always been the address of top
  people of course. But now its supremacy
  has been finally established.

UP AND UP

While your £30,000 or £40,000 will buy
  just about the best flat in, say, Grosvenor-
  square, Eaton-square or Belgrave-square, it
  is only a starting price in St. James's-place.
  For the best—and most of the flats there
  are the best—£70,000 please.

Interesting, isn't it, when everybody's
  talking about land prices . . . there are some
  people you can't price out of the market . .
  ask whatever price you like.

St. James's-place first leapt ahead last
  year when Mrs. Vera Lilley, widow of the
  shoe shop man, put up a block for her-
  self and “some other quiet, simple families.”

AND UP
being put to some flats in a
  rather splendid, old converted
  house just across the road.

Blake's, the agents, are lyrical
  about them: "nothing like them
  in the whole of London . . the
  essence of luxury . . surpassing
  elegance . . all that. The old
  panelling has been preserved.

There are a bit small—two
  bedrooms. But the price varies
  between £20,000 and £40,000 for
  a 40-year lease at £300 a year.

But there's no shortage of
  people calling at Blake's to buy.

              The accompanying photographs were taken at the Kidderminster
       factories of Carpet Trades Limited, and an extent of these trade can be
       judged by the fact that it has warehouses and agents in Australia,
       New Zealand, USA, Canada, China, South Africa, Central America,
       Scandinavia, Scandinavia, Holland, Switzerland, Egypt, Kenya, Uganda
       Zanzibar, Belgian Congo, East Indies, Iceland and Malta.
              The designers have to bear in mind the different types of desire
       which are popular in each country. For instance, the preference in
       Australia and New Zealand is for floral patterns and very bright
       colours, whilst at the other extreme the Scandinavian market calls
       for subdued tones and more severe styles.
              Carpet Trades Limited comprises five factories manufacturing
       felts and woollen and worsted yarns as well as all types of machine-
       made carpet. During the war they turned over to the production of
       small-arms ammunition and other items apart from adapting their
       textile plants to the manufacture of webbing, duck, blankets, felt
       for rubber substitution, etc.

ADDITIONAL INFORMATION FOR PICTURE EDITORS...

PICTURE "THE PICK OF THE JOBLESS IN THE NEW TOWN," 1958.

RELEASE DATE: 3RD FEBRUARY, 1958.

NOTE: THIS PICTURE OF JOBLESS MEN AT THE NEW TOWN, BASILDON, ESSEX WAS TAKEN DURING AN ALL-DAY SIT-IN BY OVER 700 OF THE TOWN'S UNEMPLOYED. THE MEN STAGED THE SIT-IN AT THE REGIONAL OFFICE OF THE MINISTRY OF LABOUR AND NATIONAL SERVICE IN ADVOCATE WAY, BASILDON, ESSEX, TO PROTEST AT THE LACK OF WORK AVAILABLE IN THE AREA. THE SIT-IN WAS ORGANISED BY THE BASILDON COUNCIL OF SHOP STEWARDS WHICH HAS IDENTIFIED IT AS PART OF THE CAMPAIGN OF THE LABOUR MOVEMENT TO GET BETTER WORKING CONDITIONS FOR THE UNEMPLOYED PEOPLE AND TO SECURE FOR THEM NEW FACTORIES AND NEW JOBS.

MR. AMBROSE THE UNION OFFICIAL SAID THAT THE UNION'S DEMAND WAS THAT THE LOCAL AUTHORITY SHOULD REOPEN THE NEGOTIATIONS WITH THE GOVERNMENT TO SECURE NEW FACTORIES FOR BASILDON. HE CLAIMED THAT THE NEW TOWN WAS BEING BUILT WITHOUT SUFFICIENT INDUSTRY TO MEET THE NEEDS OF THE GROWING POPULATION AND THAT THE RESULT WAS THAT OVER 40 PER CENT OF THE WORKING POPULATION WAS UNEMPLOYED.

MR. AMBROSE WAS SPEARHEADING THE SIT-IN AND WAS CALLING FOR AN END TO THE HIGH RATE OF UNEMPLOYMENT. HE SAID: "WE ARE NOT ASKED FOR HANDOUTS. WE ARE ASKING FOR THE OPPORTUNITY TO WORK AND TO CONTRIBUTE TO THE NATION'S PROSPERITY." THE SIT-IN CONTINUED ALL DAY WITH THE MEN TAKING TURNS TO KEEP A CONSTANT VIGIL AT THE MINISTRY'S OFFICES.

FURTHER DETAILS ARE AVAILABLE FROM THE MINISTRY OF LABOUR AND NATIONAL SERVICE, REGIONAL OFFICE, ADVOCATE WAY, BASILDON, ESSEX.

MR. AMBROSE
MR. AMBROSE
LONDON REGIONAL

HIGH SECTION OF UNEMPLOYED IN EXCHANGE.

BASILDON, ESSEX. 4, A GENERAL VIEW OF THE HIGH SIT-IN IN THE OFFICES OF THE MINISTRY OF LABOUR AND NATIONAL SERVICE IN ADVOCATE WAY, BASILDON, ESSEX. THE SIT-IN, WHICH WAS ORGANISED BY THE BASILDON COUNCIL OF SHOP STEWARDS, WAS STAGED BY OVER 700 UNEMPLOYED MEN WHO WERE PROTESTING AT THE LACK OF WORK AVAILABLE IN THE AREA.

THE MEN WERE DEMANDING THAT THE LOCAL AUTHORITY SHOULD REOPEN NEGOTIATIONS WITH THE GOVERNMENT TO SECURE NEW FACTORIES FOR BASILDON. THEY CLAIMED THAT THE NEW TOWN WAS BEING BUILT WITHOUT SUFFICIENT INDUSTRY TO MEET THE NEEDS OF THE GROWING POPULATION AND THAT THE RESULT WAS THAT OVER 40 PER CENT OF THE WORKING POPULATION WAS UNEMPLOYED.

MR. AMBROSE, WHO WAS SPEARHEADING THE SIT-IN, SAID THAT THE UNION'S DEMAND WAS THAT THE LOCAL AUTHORITY SHOULD SECURE NEW FACTORIES FOR BASILDON. HE SAID: "WE ARE NOT ASKING FOR HAND-OUTS. WE ARE ASKING FOR THE OPPORTUNITY TO WORK AND TO CONTRIBUTE TO THE NATION'S PROSPERITY."

THE SIT-IN CONTINUED ALL DAY WITH THE MEN TAKING TURNS TO KEEP A CONSTANT VIGIL AT THE MINISTRY'S OFFICES.

3RD FEBRUARY, 1958.

UNITED PRESS PHOTO

ADDITIONAL INFORMATION FOR PICTURE EDITORS....

PLANET "EWS PICTURE No. LN 348083 OF 2ND FEBRUARY, 1958,
HEADED "MASS MEETING OF UNEMPLOYED IN CAERNARVON" -
THE MAN ADDRESSING THE MASS MEETING IN THE PAVILION AT
CAERNARVON HAS NOW BEEN IDENTIFIED AS MR. HUGH JONES, THE
CHAIRMAN OF THE NANTLLE VALLEY UNEMPLOYMENT PEOPLES
COMMITTEE, AND HE IS HOLDING IS FOUR-YEAR-OLD-DAUGHTER
NERYS IN HIS ARMS. AN AMMENDED COPY OF THE CAPTION IS
BELOW FOR YOUR FILES.

LN 348083                             MGN                               LONDON BUREAU

MASS MEETING OF UNEMPLOYED IN CAERNARVON.

CAERNARVON, WALES : A GENERAL VIEW OF THE MASS MEETING
IN THE PAVILION AT CAERNARVON, BEING ADDRESSED BY MR. HUGH
JONES, CHAIRMAN OF THE NANTLLE VALLEY UNEMPLOYMENT PEOPLES
COMMITTEE, WHILST HE IS HOLDING HIS DAUGHTER, 4-YEAR-OLD
NERYS IN HIS ARMS. HUNDREDS OF UNEMPLOYED FORMED A PROTEST
MARCH FROM THE VILLAGE OF PEN-Y-GROES, IN THE NANTLLE VALLEY,
TO ATTEND THE MEETING TO PRESS FOR THE EARLY ESTABLISHMENT OF
INDUSTRIES IN SOUTH-WEST WALES WHICH HAVE BEEN PROMISED TO
THE AREA. SEVERE UNEMPLOYMENT CONDITIONS PREVAIL IN THE
SOUTH-WEST WALES AREA, AND THE UNEMPLOYMENT FIGURES HAVE
RISEN FROM 3,500 IN OCTOBER TO 6,000 IN NOVEMBER AND IS
NOW AT 8,000. IT IS ESTIMATED THAT WHEN ALL THE OLD WORKS
HAVE BEEN CLOSED, ABOUT FIFTEEN THOUSAND PEOPLE WOULD BE OUT
OF WORK, REPRESENTING MORE THAN TEN PER CENT OF THE INSURED
POPULATION. ON MONDAY (FEB 3RD), THE MINISTER OF POWER, LORD
MILLS, IS TO RECEIVE A DEPUTATION OF WELSH M.P.S WHO WILL
PUT TO HIM THE URGENCY OF THE CASE FOR FINDING MORE WORK FOR
SOUTH-WEST WALES. THE DECISION OF RICHARD THOMAS AND BALDWINS
TO CLOSE THE STEEL WORKS AT LLANELLY IN A MONTH'S TIME, HAS
BROUGHT THE MATTER TO A HEAD IN THAT AREA.

2ND FEBRUARY, 1958 PHS

UNITED PRESS PHOTO

MARSHALL.                   D.H.              1/12/53.
Customers walking into the bar of the Royal Oak Inn,
East Bergholt, Suffolk, have a friendly word for Mary
the pig. Mary spends much of her time curled up in
front of the blazing fire. Mary was 'adopted' by
Mrs. Caroline Calver, the licensee's wife, as a tiny
piglet, and was so small that she could be put into
a pint tankard. Now, she is a full grown pig, and
as affectionate as a dog.
OPS. Mary the pig follows Mrs. Calver out of the
pub.

description: A photographic print from the Daily Herald Archive folder: Housing ÃƒÆ’Ã¢â‚¬Å¡Ãƒâ€šÃ‚Â» Post War ÃƒÆ’Ã¢â‚¬Å¡Ãƒâ€šÃ‚Â» Rents - Decontrol Act 1957 ÃƒÆ’Ã¢â‚¬Å¡Ãƒâ€šÃ‚Â» Evictions, Homeless, Demonstrations, Marches.

CHILDREN with flaming torches led a march which ended with a bishop describing their plight as "a disgrace to the nation."
About 2,000 homeless men, women and children from hostels and lodging houses streamed into St. Paul's Cathedral where a solemn requiem Mass was said before an altar arrayed with loaves and fishes.

As the rest of the congre-gation filed out, a large group of men, women and children remained to seek shelter for the night.
But just before 10 p.m. the Dean, the Very Rev. M. C. Hodson, decided the church was too crowded. He called in police to clear it.
The Dean, who is a member of the Government's Working Party on Homelessness, said he did not want to see anyone sleeping in the Cathedral.
"We must keep the Cathedral for services only," he told a journalist.
"I am afraid that it is not possible to allow people to sleep here."
Mr. A. E. M. Sanderson, national secretary of the LIM, which had organized the march, said 2,000 homeless had joined in.
"We wanted to draw public attention to the desperate plight of the homeless," he said.
"The march went off very peacefully. There was no trouble at all."

REMEDIES
ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚Â¢ A housing inquiry should be set up by the Government into the supply of housing in London.
ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚Â¢ There should be a two-year freeze on rents in London, and a freeze on the sale of empty houses.
ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚Â¢ London's three most power-ful councils should get together to find sites on which to build prefabricated housing.
ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚Â¢ A proportion of empty houses in the centre of London, now owned by the Church, should be converted into hostels for young people.

priest (now serving in the diocese of South-wark) at a special Mass held in St. Paul's Cathedral on Saturday. The LIM homeless people who occupied the Cathedral were evicted by police.

DESPERATE
The marchers left from the South London hostel of Dr. Donald Soper, who said: "This is not just a demo. It is a genuine march of desperate people."
Bishop of Woolwich, the Rt. Rev. David Sheppard, who joined the march at London Bridge, told the homeless people: "It is a disgrace to the nation that so many of you are sleeping rough or in dreadful accommodation.
"The Government should be ashamed that all of you have to live in these conditions. There are 25,000 homeless people in London. That is a national disgrace."
The Bishop said that young people from the provinces who came to London to look for work were finding it almost impossible to find a place to live.

Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/44-320

CHILDREN with flaming torches led a march
of 2,000 homeless last night—a march
which ended with a bishop describing their
plight as “a disgrace to the nation.”
Among the women in the quarter-mile long proces-
sion which wound slowly from St. Paul's Cathedral to
Southwark were mothers with babies in their arms or
with toddlers in push-
chairs.

At the end of the "croco-
dile," men bore a huge
banner which said simply:
"No room at the inn . . ."
The two bishops who organ-
ised the march—Dr. Robert
Stopford, Bishop of London, and
Dr. Mervyn Stockwood, Bishop
of Southwark—took part in it
and from his pulpit at South-
wark Cathedral, hard-hitting
Dr. Stockwood spoke passion-
ately about the problem of Lon-
don's homeless—an emergency,
he said, as great as the war.
The cathedral, which holds
about 1,200 people, was
packed and Dr. Stockwood's
words were relayed by loud-
speakers to hundreds who
stood outside in the gather-
ing darkness.
The bishop said there were
80,000 families in London wait-
ing for homes—families living
in overcrowded rooms, with
inadequate facilities and shock-
ing sleeping accommodation.

REMEDIES
And he suggested these reme-
dies:
A national housing authority
with powers to borrow and lend
money at interest rates decided
by the Government.
Priorities based on need.
"If it is good for offices and
and if it is good for luxury
luxury buildings," he said,
control of land. "Is it right
to leave speculators to deter-
mine its value?" he asked.
"In times of war the Govern-
ment assumes control. Isn't the
present housing emergency as grave?"
Among his other suggestions
were mobile homes in London
parks and open spaces, and the
requisitioning of empty houses.

DESPERATE
As the bishop finished his ser-
mon, 28-year-old Mrs. Gwyneth
Cleaver, mother of ten children
who is living in an L.C.C. hostel
apart from her husband, said:
"This is our last desper-
ate hope—that this march
will move someone's con-
science. Christmas isn't
going to be much fun for us."
Later, Dr. Stockwood, said: "I
defy a man to make this an anti-
landlord thing. It's a question of
human cupidity. We're all guilty
of that—all ready to make a bit
of money where we can.
"What really sticks in my gul-
let is the fact that a single room
in, say, Hampstead, without
feeling, wallpaper or anything—
can be offered for £5 a week to
desperate people.
And they are forced to take
these rooms. They live in war-
rens—six rooms, and maybe 30
people in them. It's scandalous."

1961-2224-2

PALE faces glowing in
the glare of torches
marched yesterday
from St. Paul's Cath-
edral to Southwark—
2,000 homeless people.
As they marched, they
sang carols—their
mothers rocked
babies to the music.

THE CATHEDRAL, CANTERBURY.

AUGUST, 1959.

Still working on a graft which has been in his family
since 1910 to be re-introduced by master Caldwall
at Canterbury (Kent). This is the forge of the stained
glass of Canterbury Cathedral, having been the craftsman
since the 16th century. To be installed in the north
transept of the Cathedral, the forge of the stained
glass. This will not replace the whole window, but only
the centre pane, which was cracked in the 16th century.
The new pane, costing Ã‚Â£70, has been completed by the master
Caldwall, and he has been required to design and create
a new stained glass window, to replace the broken one,
and he has been commissioned by the Cathedral authorities
to repair a further two windows that are to be removed
from the north transept of the Cathedral. The master
Caldwall started work on Canterbury Cathedral when he was 16.

PETERBOROUGH, NORTHAMPTONSHIRE.

MR. GAVIN CALDWELL, the 76-year-old stained glass craftsman, who lives in Peterborough, has spent 60 years working in his trade. He started his apprenticeship in Canterbury Cathedral, where he was a master craftsman for many years. He has been commissioned to design and create a new stained glass window to replace the broken one, and he has also been asked to repair two other windows in the north transept of the Cathedral. The new window, which is expected to cost Ã‚Â£70, will be installed in the north transept of the Cathedral. Mr. Caldwell started work on Canterbury Cathedral when he was 16. He is a master craftsman in stained glass and is highly respected in his profession. He has been commissioned to design and create a new stained glass window for the Cathedral, which will be installed in the north transept.

Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/55284
Indus. Glass.
Stained Windows
MJH/HT.

94-YEARS-OLD CRAFTSMAN.

Still working on a craft which has been in his family
since 1820 is 94-years-old Mr. Samuel Caldwell
of Canterbury (Kent), who is in charge of the stained
glass of the Cathedral, comprising thousands of square
feet of priceless glass, dating back to the 13th.
century. Twice in his lifetime, Mr. Caldwell
has removed the Cathedral's glass -once during the
1914-1918 war and again when the last war started.
Under Mr. Caldwell's supervision, the replacement of the
glass - a long and skilful process requiring endless
patience - has just been completed and he is now
at work designing and making stained glass to
replace the modern glass which was not removed and
was destroyed by bomb-blast. An authority on his
craft, with 77 years experience behind him, Mr.
Caldwell started work in Canterbury Cathedral when he
was 17.

PHOTOGRAPH SHOWS: MR. SAMUEL CALDWELL, the 94-years
old craftsman, seen at work in his Canterbury (Kent)
workshop, restoring a 13th. century medallion
representing "The last Supper". His health, sight
and hearing are all still exceptionally good.

THE MORNING TALK. TODAY IS ONE. HELD AFTER STRIKE.

I am Ruth. Most of the trapped men had to be got through the hard hole to safety. All are in the best of health. HERALD REPORTER.

THEY'RE through. 12 trapped miners. A small hole has been bored through the few feet of coal that had been dammed them. They can talk through it.

AIR FLOWS THROUGH.

At 6.15 PM today the air pipes, which have been bored from the surface to the trapped men's chamber were switched on. For some time there was no sign of air passing, but then it began to flow. The report is that the air is clean and fit to breathe. It is hoped that soon it will be possible to give the men a drink through the pipe.

OFFICE OF WAR INFORMATION
PRESS SECTION

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE

A GIANT SHIP TO BE BUILT ON THE THULE WILL
BE LAUNCHED NEXT MONTH
JAMES
NOTE: The following is a Captains report regarding the 700 foot,
thirty-one-knot, FAST CARGO SHIP (YET TO BE
NAMED) THAT WILL HAUL THE FIRST CARGO OF
MERCHANDISE FROM GERMANY TO SOUTH AFRICA.

The report, submitted by Captain J.H. Hansen to the U.S. Maritime
Commission, reveals for the first time the revolutionary design
and construction of the ship which will make her the fastest
and most efficient freighter ever to fly the Allied flag. Hansen
credits the ship's designer, Lieutenant Commander W. E.
Hickling, with the development of a new hull design that
reduces drag by fifty percent. The ship's engines, which are
expected to develop 200,000 horsepower, will be capable of
driving the vessel at speeds exceeding thirty-one knots.
The ship's immense cargo capacity, which will be twenty
times that of the Queen Mary, will be loaded and unloaded
by a revolutionary automated cargo handling system. The
ship is expected to reduce by half the time required for
transporting goods across the Atlantic. The ship will be
launched from a special drydock in San Francisco on Tuesday,
March 14th. The U.S. Maritime Commission will hold a press
conference at the White House on Wednesday, March 15th, to
announce the ship's name and to provide further details
regarding its construction and operation. The first cargo
to be carried aboard the ship will be manufactured goods
from Germany, which will be shipped to South Africa.
The ship's official designation will be YUGOSLAVIA'S FINEST.
The ship, which is 700 feet in length, will have a beam of 110 feet and
a draft of 35 feet. It will be propelled by a single 300,000
horsepower turbine engine. The ship will be capable of
carrying 50,000 tons of cargo. The ship will have a crew
of 500 men. The ship will be equipped with the latest
navigational aids and safety equipment. The ship will be
armed with two 8-inch guns and a number of smaller
armament. The ship will be able to carry a complement
of 200 aircraft. The ship will be able to launch and
recover aircraft while underway. The ship will be able to
carry a complement of 500 troops. The ship will be able to
transport 2,000 passengers. The ship will be able to travel
at a speed of 31 knots. The ship will have a range of
10,000 nautical miles. The ship will be built at a cost
of $50,000,000.

(Continued on reverse)

             BIGGEST SHIP TO BE BUILT ON THE TYNE WILL
                           BE LAUNCHED NEXT MONTH
             NCPS                                 24.1.66.
             NOPE.
             THERE'S A CERTAIN MAGIC ABOUT HITTING THE TON.
             MOTOR CYCLISTS LIVE AND DIE FOR IT. OLD MEN OF
             99 PRAY THAT THEY WILL HANG ON FOR THE PRISE OF
             BEING 100 NOT OUT. CRICKETERS' CAREERS RISE AND
             FALL BY IT.
                  BUT NOWHERE IS THE ACHIEVEMENT SO PROUDLY AND
             COMPETITIVELY MEASURED TODAY THAN IN SHIPBUILDING.
             BUILD A SHIP OF 100,000 GROSS TONS OR MORE AND YOU
             CAN SAY YOU ARE IN THE 'BIG LEAGUE'. EVEN BY
             JAPAN'S GIGANTIC STANDARD. NOW, THE TOUGH,
             TRADITIONAL SHIPBUILDERS OF THE RIVER TYNE ARE
             PUTTING THE FINISHING TOUCHES TO THEIR FANFARE
             ENTRY INTO THE 'BIG LEAGUE.'
                  A THOUSAND MEN AT THE WORLD-FAMOUS YARD OF
             SWAN, HUNTER AND WIGHAM RICHARDSON, WALLSEND-ON-
             TYNE, ARE SCOURRING OVER AND BELOW THE GIGANTIC
             DECKS OF THE 100,000 TON "BRITISH ARGOSY"
             GETTING HER READY FOR LAUNCHING ON FEBRUARY 7TH.
             THE VESSEL IS BEING BUILT FOR THE BP TANKER
             COMPANY. SHE WILL BE THE FIRST BRITISH-BUILT
             SHIP TO ENTER THE "BIG LEAGUE" THIS YEAR AND IS
             THE BIGGEST SHIP EVER BUILT ON A RIVER RENOWNED
             FOR PUSHING THE BOAT OUT IN A BIG WAY.
                  FIFTEEN YEARS AGO, PRINCESS MARGARET WENT TO
             SWAN HUNTERS TO LAUNCH THE THEN BIGGEST SUPER
             TANKER OF THE DAY, THE 28,000-TON "VELLUTINA".
             THE BRITISH ARGOSY MAKES THAT LOOK LIKE A ROWING
             BOAT. SHE STANDS LIKE AN ENDLESS STRETCH OF
             ELASTIC 917 FT. LONG, 120FT. WIDE AND 66FT DEEP,
             WITH ENOUGH ROOM ON HER DECKS TO SWALLOW UP NEARLY
             THREE FOOTBALL PITCHES.
                  EVERY SINGLE PIECE OF DRAG CHAIN ON THE WHOLE
             OF THE RIVER TYNE, 1,250 TONS OF IT, IS BEING
             BERGED AND BORROWED TO CONTROL HER GRAND SLAM
             ENTRY INTO THE RIVER WHEN LAUNCHED BY LADY
             BRIDGEMAN (WIFE OF SIR MAURICE BRIDGEMAN, CHAIRMAN
             OF BP). EVEN THEN SHE WILL HAVE ONLY 25 YARDS -
             LITTLE MORE THAN A CRICKET PITCH LENGTH - IN WHICH
             TO AVOID HITTING THE RIVER'S OPPOSITE BANK.
                  THE "BRITISH ARGOSY" WILL BE ONLY THE SECOND
             BRITISH SHIP OF 100,000 TONS TO BE LAUNCHED, TO
             DATE. HER SISTER SHIP, BRITISH ADMIRAL, WAS
             LAUNCHED FROM VICKERS ARMSTRONG'S BARROW YARD
             LAST YEAR BY THE QUEEN.

                  THE GIGANTIC "BRITISH ARGOSY"
                  (100,000 TONS D.W.) DOMINATES HOUSES
                  NEAR THE SHIP YARD.

THIS SPELLE
BECAUSE a handful of farmers
have been working a dis-
honest fiddle, thousands of
nimals must suffer agonies of
pain.
So forget the tigers and crocodiles of India for
moment and come along with me to the cattle
markets of Britain.
There you will see men armed with what look like
ver-size railway ticket
bunches. But these instru-
nents punch holes HALF AN
NCH wide in the ears of
igs and sheep.
The hole is punched im-
nediately an animal is sold. It
proves that a Government sub-
idy has been paid.
If there were no such mark,
inscrupulous farmers or
cattle-dealers could put animals
through the market again—
and collect more subsidies—
about 15s. for each pig or sheep.

Healed up
Up to a short time ago, the
punch used for piercing the
animals' ears was very much
smaller and less painful.
But a Ministry of Agri-
culture official noticed
that the wound quickly
healed and some ani-
mals were being sold over
and over again. So the
new, bigger torture-punch
was introduced.
Its use is backed by the
Government, accepted by the

Is this ghastly "ticket punch" the ONLY way of branding animals at market?
Must they be mutilated like this pig's ear (left)?

As the clock in the
square chimed out 10.30
a.m. the auctioneer climbed a
plank above a pen of pigs
and quietly called for bids.
They were quickly sold
and were moved to the next pen,
raising his voice now. I soon found
out why.
cattle dealers, and tolerated
uneasily by the R.S.P.C.A.—be-
cause no one can think of any
better way of marking the
animals.
But, every day, onlookers at
the markets recoil in horror at
the tortured squeals and spilled
blood of the "branded" live-
stock.
Last week I visited the cattle
market at the picturesque
Devonshire town of Newton
Abbot.

Screams, blood...
Into the first pen had gone
the ear-punching machine; sud-
denly, there were screams of
pain. The pigs scurried about
in fear. The blood flowed. A
man moved on to the next
batch.
He was 39-year-old Ivor Dore.
"Of course, it hurts the
animals" he told me. "And I
don't mind telling you it's not
a pleasant job. At holiday
times, in particular, tourists
think I'm cruel and call me
names.
"I try not to tear the
animals' ears but often they
struggle. I keep the machine
well oiled so I can make the
hole as quickly as possible."
I spoke to some farmers. "It
looks worse than it really is,"
said one of them, "It's only
like having a tooth out." With-
out anaesthetic.
The market manager, Mr.
C. H. Wilkinson, told me: "We
have two inspectors on duty to
see there is no undue ill-treat-
ment of animals. As for the
marking of animals, well, that's
not our choice. Until the
Ministry changes the method
there's little we can do."
Well, what does the Ministry
of Agriculture say?
"We agree that there may
be pain at the time of
punching, but veterina-
geons assure us it is tem-
porary.
"It is the Ministry
had to increase the
hole, but it was done
to prevent fraud from
Government."
Now the Ministry
seeking an alternative
method of marking, and will
recommend to the
Ministry.
"But it is clear this
method that causes pain
and foolproof, the farmers
told me.

This is
"We are by no means happy
about this ear-punching
because of so much dis-
honest practice, the farmers
must be something to be."
So that's the position. Farmers
can't be trusted. And animals
must suffer.
If the animal's ear is to be
marked, then surely the
Ministry, the farmers and the
veterinary surgeons can, as a
matter of urgency find a new,
new and painless way of
doing it.
