                                   HERE is a picture of peace, and one
                                   also of the very sinews of war—
BRITAIN                          our wheat harvest for 1943 which is
                                   the most vital in British history.
                                     If all goes well with the weather, it
                                   will be the biggest harvest ever garnered
                                   in Great Britain. The fact that this sum-
                                   mer has alternated between rain and sun-
GATHERS                          shine means that crops are not all ripening
                                   sufficiently here and there simultaneously
                                   to give the overworked harvesters a
                                   chance to gather it in good time.
                                     Today, Great Britain is growing two-
                                   thirds of her own food. Since the outbreak
A BUMPER                         of war we have ploughed up six million
                                   extra acres, and the Minister of Agricul-
                                   ture asks for yet another 500,000 acres in
                                   1943.
                                     Such is the magnitude of our harvest
                                   that the increased food production for
                                   1942 will save at least five million tons of
HARVEST                          shipping for other vital purposes.
                                     If the promise of Britain's 1943 harvest
                                   is fully realized we shall have increased
                                   our production of all grain by two-thirds
                                   above the pre-war harvests, of potatoes
                                   by two-thirds, and of fresh vegetables by
                                   fifty per cent.
                                     Moreover, we are doing without im-
                                   ported animal feeding-stuffs to the extent
                                   of between five and six million tons per
                                   year, the entire loss being made good by
                                   farmers growing food for the live stock.
Milk production has been maintained
despite the many wartime difficulties of
food, labour and transport.
All this has been accomplished by the
help of a volunteer labour force gathered
from every strata of society. The call
for landworkers to bring in this bumper
harvest has reached drawing-rooms,
offices, factories and schools everywhere.
The next four weeks will see a race
against time to gather the harvest in its
best condition, and to protect it from
enemy air raids.
There are the Volunteer Land Clubs,
the Women's Emergency Volunteer Land
Corps, soldiers, sailors, airmen, police-
men, firemen, even prisoners of war—all
helping to bring home the harvest. The
countryside is filled with volunteers on
the land. Every inn and farmhouse occu-
pied to the full.

FROM the United States and Canada
comes news of other bumper harvests
to sustain the United Nations in war. In
the ten Great Plains States of the United
States of America the production of small
grains alone is expected to total about
twenty-nine million tons as compared
with nine million tons in 1934.
Canada's harvest is reported to be a
new record of increased production. In
Russia, however, what was planned to be
a mighty harvest had been sadly depleted

HOLLIS TO BE BATTLE AIDED FROM
A TO V ACCORDING TO NEWS RELEASE

HOLLIS TO BE BATTLE AIDED

The Hollis, NH, Battle Aid Project is to be
aided by an additional sum of money by
the United States. Mrs. F. J. O'Brien
of 27 Elm Street, chairman of the Hollis
committee, has announced receipt of a letter
from the United States. The letter said that
the project would receive some of the money
that has been collected in the state for the
aid of Britain and Russia. She also said that
all the money that had been donated in Hollis
had already been sent to the state treasurer.
The Hollis committee have been aiding the
Battle Aid Project for the last year and a
half. The committee is composed of twenty
women. In honor of the "V for Victory"
program, the Hollis committee plans to start
a camapign to collect more money for the
Battle Aid Project. They are hoping to have
this new campaign started by next month.

The development plan for the Liberation
Ship is being worked on by the Committee
of the Hollis Aid Project. This plan is to
raise money for the purchase of Liberty ships
for the Allies. The committee expects to
have at least $22,000 raised for this project
by the end of the year.

The Hollis Battle Aid Project also plans to
build a new laboratory in Hollis for the
purpose of aiding the war effort. The laboratory
will be used to test and improve the arms
and ammunition of the United States. The
laboratory is expected to be completed by
next spring.

The Hollis committee has been actively
involved in many different projects to aid
the war effort. The committee has been
donating blood to the Red Cross, knitting
sweaters for the soldiers, and collecting
used paper and rubber for the war effort.

The Hollis Battle Aid Project has been a
great success so far, and the committee
is looking forward to continue their work
in the years to come.

The Hollis Battle Aid Project is also
planning to start a new campaign to collect
more money for the Battle Aid Project. They
are hoping to have this new campaign started
by next month.

planning to build a new laboratory in Hollis
for the purpose of aiding the war effort.
The laboratory will be used to test and
improve the arms and ammunition of the
United States. The laboratory is expected
to be completed by next spring.

SHELLS IN THE BATTLE AGAINST FEVER
April 28th 1959 PAR 77114-3 (PNR-R)

SHELLS IN THE BATTLE AGAINST FEVER

Amid glittering metal and glass, breathing
'sterile' air and in clothing of surgical
cleanliness, men and women laboratory
workers are producing vaccines to combat
polio and other scourges of mankind and
of animals in new buildings at the
Wellcome Research Laboratories, Beckenham,
Kent, where on May 1 the first two stages
of the three-stage five-year development
plan for the Laboratories will be
officially opened by Sir Henry Dale,
OM, FRS, Chairman of the Wellcome Trust.
Work is already in full swing in the new
buildings, and the Polio building -
Phase I of the scheme - is helping
doctors to cope with the present rush of
young people for inoculation by exceeding
its production target of four million
doses a year.
The development plan for the Laboratories
was begun in 1955 to provide up-to-date
facilities for research and the production
of biological products. When completed,
it will have cost over £2,000,000.
PICTURE SHOWS:- Masked women in sterile
clothing harvesting virus infected chick
embryo for yellow fever vaccine
at Beckenham.

PROGRAMME NOTES ON NATIONAL COAL BOARD MEETING HELD IN MANCHESTER ON MONDAY 30TH JULY, 1951.

Meeting at Town Hall. 10.30 a.m.

The purpose of this meeting was to discuss problems facing the Coal Board in the North-Western division of Great Britain. The delegates included representatives from all the major coal producing areas, as well as members of the National Coal Board itself. The meeting was addressed by Lord Hyndley, the chairman of the National Coal Board, who spoke about the need for increased coal production and the importance of improving the efficiency of the industry. Other speakers included Mr. F. H. Haydn, the secretary of the Ministry of Fuel and Power, and Professor D. T. Davies, the director of the Manchester University Coal Research Unit. The delegates discussed a number of issues, including the need for investment in new mining equipment, the importance of training new miners, and the need for improved working conditions in the mines. The meeting concluded with a vote of confidence in the National Coal Board and a commitment to work together to ensure the future success of the coal industry.

A.3.50

AGAINST POOR QUALITY COAL.
2.1.51.
Housewives today held a protest
meeting at Portchester Hall, against the
poor quality coal and coke sold by the
National Coal Board. Mrs. Carrington
Wood, chairman of the London Housewives
Association, took along samples of stone
and slate which had been paid for at 5s 3d.
a cwt.

TELEPHONE EXCHANGE BLOWN UP AT TAKELY, ESSEX.
The telephone exchange at Takeley was blown
to pieces early this morning when a spark from
a telephone call ignited an accumulation of
gas in a nearby manhole. The exchange was
unmanned at the time.

FLATS COLLAPSE
CANTING TOWN FLATS COLLAPSE IMAGERY
30th MAY 1950
DEATH OF THE FIFTH VICTIM IN EAST LONDON FLATS COLLAPSE
FIFTH VICTIM FOUND IN RUINS
FIVE DEAD
EAST LONDON, MAY 30th. The death toll in the East London Flats Collapses at Canting Town, today rose to five when the body of the fifth victim was recovered from the ruins this afternoon. The building, which was erected last year, collapsed this morning. Mr. J. L. MEEK, Minister of Works, M.P., AND MR. J. EDWARDS, parliamentary secretary for Housing were present at the site this afternoon, and were briefed by the engineers on the collapse. MR. MEEK said that the Government would investigate fully into the collapse of the flats at Canting Town.
THE VICTIMS IDENTIFIED
THE VICTIMS OF THE COLLAPSE AT CANTING TOWN TODAY WHICH CLAIMS FIVE LIVES HAS NOW BEEN IDENTIFIED AS MR. A. BAKER AND HIS WIFE, MR. C. GRIMSHAW AND HIS WIFE AND A BOY, ROY GRIMSHAW. THE FLATS WERE ERECTED LAST YEAR AT A COST OF Ã‚Â£250,000 AND WERE SPECULATED AS BEING THE LAST WORD IN MODERN LIVING BY SIR ALAN COMRIE, THE ARCHITECT.
OFFICIALS INSPECT RUINS
MR. J. L. MEEK, Minister of Works, M.P., AND MR. J. EDWARDS, parliamentary Secretary for Housing, inspected the ruins this afternoon. They were informed by SIR ALAN COMRIE, the architect, that the collapse was due to the faulty construction of the blocks of flats.
THE NEW BLOCKS OF FLATS AT CANTING TOWN ARE TO BE PULLED DOWN AND REBUILT BY THE MINISTRY OF WORKS.
THE CITY OF LONDON WILL BE SHOCK BY THIS DISASTER.
EAST LONDON FLATS COLLAPSE

Transcribed_Text:
F12/D3/POST WAR SLUMS

Housing.. Slums

                                    A HOUSING COMMITTEE chairman has
                                    been officially told that a house owned
                                    by the company he controls is "unfit for
                                    human habitation."

                                    Yet he has so far refused to carry out
                                    the necessary repairs, at a cost of about
                                    £700.
                                    The seven-roomed detached house in
                                    Mount Pleasant, South Ruislip, Middlesex,
                                    is occupied only by 72-year-old Mr. Jacob
                                    James Harris, at a controlled rent of
                                    £2 0s 3d a week.
                                    His landlords are H. W. Cutler Property
                                    and Development Co. Ltd., of which 54-
                                    year-old Mr. Horace W. Cutler is a
                                    director. He is also chairman of the
                                    Conservative-controlled Greater London
                                    Council's Housing Committee, Britain's
                                    biggest landlord.

                                    No. 21, Mount Pleasant, is damp, shabby
                                    and neglected. Roof tiles are missing, gut-
                                    ters are rotting, paint is peeling. Hilling-
                                    don Council ordered the landlords to make
                                    it fit for human habitation by November
                                    23, 1967.
                                    "I could, of course, afford to carry out
                                    the work," bearded Mr. Cutler told me last
                                    week at his office in High Street, Pinner,
                                    Middlesex. "And I may yet do so.
                                    "But all over the country thousands of
                                                                        houses are falling into
                                                                        decay because of the
                                                                        stupidity of the Rent Acts,
                                                                        and that is my point."
                                                                        Mr. Cutler's refusal to
                                                                        carry out repairs is being
                                                                        made in protest against the
                                                                        Rent Acts which, he says,
                                                                        force landlords to spend
                                                                        large sums on repairs with-
                                                                        out any hope of return
                                                                        where rents are controlled
                                                                        and tenants are protected
                                                                        from eviction.

                                                                        'Too large'

                                                                        "Another tragic result of our
                                                                        present laws is underoccupation.
                                                                        It is ridiculous for a house of
                                                                        this size to be occupied by only
                                                                        one man.
                                                                        "Mr. Harris uses only the
                                                                        kitchen and one bedroom. The
                                                                        house is now far too large for
                                                                        Mr. Harris. He should be re-
                                                                        housed by the council."
                                                                        Mr. Cutler, a former mayor
                                                                        of Harrow, said he sympathised
                                                                        with Mr. Harris, who suffers
                                                                        from pneumoconiosis and whose
                                                                        only income is a £4 10s. a week
                                                                        pension.
                                                                        "With this chest trouble I
                                                                        cannot stand the cold," Mr.
                                                                        Harris said. "The house is
                                                                         chilly and damp. I keep wait-
                                                                        ing for the house to be put
                                                                        right."
                                                                        Mr. Harris moved into the
                                                                        house in 1940. Since his wife
                                                                        died several years ago he has
                                                                        lived there alone.
                                                                        Last year Mr. Harris was
                                                                        offered a place in an old
                                                                        people's home run by the
                                                                        council. "He refused it,"
                                                                        said Alderman A. J. Beasley, of
                                                                        Hillingdon Council, "as he is
                                                                        perfectly entitled to do."

Mr. Capps, a family man in the

With the help of his wife and

Mr. Capps says he has found

an ordinary home.

From the air

His idea is to use a windmill-

PRESS THE FINGERS REPORT (See story by Dan Glickman) WORKING OPPORTUNITIES-Seen at work in the Peak Frozen Biscuit Factory.

FOR THE BENEFIT OF THE FAMILY

Wives do get to work that and for instance because they want the money and they don't spend much or it's for basic necessities. But they spend it on "gourmet" on luxuries

What wish it so that their families can have a higher standard of living than that to provide a more secure and, if possible, a more prosperous existence for the childrean, and if a reliable source of their labour, they will never fail them.

What you are looking at now, Mrs.
Elizabeth Murry, aged 35, from
Rochdale, Lancashire, who is doing
out the jobs in the factory. She is
a mother of two children, and she
says "I am doing a job for the benefit
of the family." Mrs. Murry is earning
Ãƒâ€šÃ‚Â£3.2.0 a week, which she uses for
the general expenses of the family.
Mrs. Murry said that she was looking
for a job, which she could do after
the children had gone to school.

NOT AN ESCAPE

It is not an escape from the ordinary
roles of women, but rather an
enhancement of them. What is
being learnt here, the women are
also doing, and their husbands are
also doing. The factory is a place
where women can find the skills and
training that will give them the
capacity to lead a richer, fuller life.
The men who are working in the
factory are also found to be very
supportive of their wives. Mrs. Murry
said that her husband, who is a factory
worker himself, is very proud of her
job and encourages her in every way.
"He knows that I am doing this for
the family, and he is happy that I
am contributing to our lives," she said.
The benefits of this system are also
seen in the children, who are reported
to be well-adjusted and happy. The
women in the factory are also found
to be very supportive of each other,
and they often share tips and advice
on how to balance their work and
family life. The factory has also
introduced a creche service, which
allows mothers to bring their children
to work with them. This has been
a great help to many mothers, as it
allows them to have a job without
having to worry about finding
childcare.

Mrs. Mary Davies,

REMOVAL OF WEST BERLIN RENTALS Law Amendment
Amendment TO LAW RE-OCCUPATION ACT
The West German Diet, July 27, has passed an amendment
to the law on rentals and property occupation in West Berlin.
The amendment which was passed on July 27, 1954, is situated
on one of eight pages of the modified law. The amendment
has affected, for example, the rentals on rented property that
has occupied by persons whom the re-occupation Act has seen
the separation of their family by re-occupation. The amendment
reduces the monthly rentals on these properties by 10 percent.

MORNING POST
A Mod is good fashion
and liberal tastes have
always been a sign of a
successful Mod.
When Mods first
arose they had much
more in common with
earlier, more elegant
periods of fashion than
with the "clean-cut"
image peddled by the
Press.
Revive them we believe
in their new-look guise:
tweed jackets, slim-
fitting trousers, button-
down shirts, and, of course,
bow-ties, all in muted
colours.
This is good fashion,
and liberal tastes have
always been a sign of a
successful Mod.

The right
Mods are by their very
nature rebellious, and for
that reason they are
apt to be rather contemptu
ous of the established
ways of doing things.
This
attitude is
particularly true when
it
comes to dress, for the
modern Mod is not
content to copy his
elders; he has to
out-Mod them.

together in their

and liberal tastes have
always been a sign of a

So domestic
Mods, like Tom, will
also go domestic.
This means that he
won't be afraid of a
smart, new, two-piece
suit, for instance.
And that he, too,
will be ready to do
something about the
state of his home.
When Mods are in their
heyday, it is unlikely that
they will be recognised
by their elders. For

and Mary Thomas, are

 respite at home.

They may be seen
at home wearing their

smart, new, two-piece
suit, and even at
down.

So quoted!
The idea is to "borrow"
vintage control ties, but
this is only a basic
beginning.
Apart from this, Mods
will do well to borrow
some ideas from the
past and mix them
up with their present
ones. This is, of course,
the recipe for the "new
look" which is still very
much on its way.

They will be
seen at home wearing
their own version of the
smart, new, two-piece
suit, and even at
down.

one had very much
respect for the
chicken as a person-
ality.

worth considering,
the symbol of the
coward. Although
even that
symbolism was grado-
grily taken away

ing gained prestige
since they were up-
graded to anti-heroes.
What happened yes-
terday was, quite
simply, the news about
Betsy. She (you cannot
say a chicken like
Betsy an it, and this is
measure of what

for chickens every-

containing seven yolks.
It had never, as far
as was known, been
done before. Septuplets
are as rare among

chickens as they are
among humans.

But it wasn't the
purely biological aspect

world. It was the lim-
iting of this exceptional
field of productivity.
Mr. British replied
ourselves, "As we are
simply as a tribe when

in a great mass of words
from our leaders about

when Betsy came along

Where there was one,

caring. Let there be seven.

For there could be no
material fathers granted

freeze, not even where it

was related to produc-
tivity.
Betsy, it seemed, would
have to continue to
manage with chickens.
Perhaps one of the new
barracks that are soon

up of the matter.
What of Betsy's reduc-

For this is the remark-
able truth: she is a true

Board, she carries no
money.

means of that.
Of course, there will be

parage Betsy's achieve-
ment.
What meaning will
they say has isolated
example of productivity
to a nation which needs

growth?

Betsy, as only you can.

A THOUSAND policemen last night fought a vicious
pitched battle with a screaming 2,000 - strong mob
trying to storm St. Pancras Town Hall. It was violence
such as London has not seen since the hunger marches
of the 'thirties.

More than eight tons of 20 pp. stones, tearing masonry, charged
the pilot mass of people. Women and children fell to the ground covered
in blood. Historically. The streets round the town hall were like a battle-field,
And above the screams and shouts was heard the clang of ambulance bells,
police calls, and the cries of pain. Many of the casualties were
police, eight and nine. A large number of the casualties were treated in St. Pancras Town Hall.
Many police and Specials were hitting up the
casualty list. At least 40 people were believed, to be seriously injured.
15 were arrested, police and a good many civilians.

A second sensational shooting took place, hours after the main battle, when the fire had been in a nearby, dark street, where two uniformed Police were seriously injured.

A second sensational shooting took place, hours after the main battle, when the fire had been in a nearby, dark street, where the two uniformed police were seriously injured. At the shooting in the dark street, a crowd of 30 police and specials were called out to clear the obstruction. They were met by a volley of stones and bricks. Several police were hit and had to be taken to hospital.
One of the officers was reported to be dead. He was an Inspector. He had been hit by a brick and had been taken to the hospital by two of his constables. He was said to be seriously injured.

Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/44331

A THOUSAND policemen last night fought a vicious
pitched battle with a screaming 2,000 - strong mob
trying to storm St. Pancras Town Hall. It was violence
such as London has not seen since the hunger marches
of the 'thirties.

Time and again, lines of 50 constables, waving truncheons, charged
the solid mass of people. Women and children fell to the ground whimper-
ing hysterically. The roads around the town hall were like a battlefield.
And above the screams and shouts was heard the clang of ambulance bells.

Some people said that, after day-long taunts,
abuse and violence against the police, some of the
constables suddenly cracked.

Early today the hospitals were totting up the
casualty list. At least 14 people were injured, in-
cluding six policemen. Sixteen men and a youth
were arrested.

The fantastic, frightening scene flared after demon-
strators outside the two rebel blocks of council flats-
Silverdale House and Kennistoun House-joined forces
and marched on the town hall in a massive, anti-rent
increase protest.

A council committee meeting was hurriedly aban-
doned and hundreds of police reinforcements were
rushed in.

There were roars of anger
when the procession found
themselves facing a
three-deep line of police in
front of the town hall.

Down a half-dozen side-streets
squads of 50 to 100 policemen
were waiting in reserve.

The marchers fell back for a
few seconds, surprised at the
sight of so many police.

Then from the rows behind
the leaders came cries of "For-
ward, forward!"

Thus started a headlong on-
slaught by about 200 of the
young men among the marchers
against the centre of the long
line of police.

An inspector standing on a
bus yelled to the men:
"Stand fast lads, stand
fast."

The last of a group of
demonstrators perched
on a window-sill over-
looking the battle of St.
Pancras is dislodged,
protesting loudly. It is a
woman in slacks. Police
reach out as she drops,
then turn to continue the
struggle.

1960-1475-70

D.H. 22.9.60
ST. PANCRAS RIOTS.

Pancras showing police
dealing with rioters.

The Chinese embrace the new era
The revolution which has swept China over the last few years has meant that the old way of life has been swept away for ever. This is a study of the Chinese people embracing the new era. The photographs are of peasants at work, fishermen, and the modern methods used in fishing and agriculture. The people shown are the people who are now in control of their own destinies, working for the good of the country.
Although it is impossible to give accurate figures, it is estimated that at least 20,000,000 eggs are graded by trained personnel from all over Britain and sold to the best markets in England, France and the United States. Mrs. Dorothy Crouch, pictured above, is one of the 20,000 girls who have been trained as poultry farmers. She has her own poultry farm and is very successful. There are now 500,000 women poultry farmers in Britain, and the industry is expanding all the time.

CENTURIES ago the Chinese discovered
the secret of sexing newly hatched
chicks. Quick to imitate, the Japanese
copied and improved the method. They
became the experts of chick sex-determina-
tion and as such were employed all over
the world. Consequently the outbreak of
war found a number of these Japanese
experts in Britain. They were interned,
but later released because of the import-
ance of their work.
But the secret is known to the British.
Although it is impossible for most breeders
to distinguish cockerels from pullets, there
are British men and women who can sex
four hundred chicks an hour, with ninety-
two per cent accuracy.
Miss Dorothy Hough, pictured above,
twenty-five years old daughter of a farmer,
is one of the few women chick sexers in this
country. She can sex four thousand chicks
in one day and has engagements at poultry
farms all over Lancashire and Yorkshire.
After being taken from breeding hens,
eggs are graded to two ounces and over.
They are placed in special trays and marke
to distinguish breeds. Trays are the

Fertile ones are removed to a lower con
partment; left for three days to hatch.

F194 Indus-Fuel & Power-Coal- Accidents- Cambrian Colliery,Rhondda.
May 1965.
Des Rodes
Rhondda
PIT TOP
WOMEN
N the Valley of Sor-
row hundreds stood
in silence last night to
hear 31 names read
out. This was the
formal, official end to
a day of tragedy.
Under sodden lights in
Clydach Vale, the grim-
faced Rhondda mining
people gathered. The
bereaved wives, mothers
and children. The mates
who were still thinking:
"It could have been us."
In the workmen's
Assembly Hall nearby
were the remains of
the men who had been
blasted to death in
Cambrian Colliery
hours before.
From the loudspeaker
of a police car the list of
the dead rolled out, read
by Glamorgan's Chief
Constable, Mr. Melbourne
Thomas.
Last of all came the names
of the colliery manager, 42-
year-old Ernest Breeze, and
under-manager Leslie
Williams.
morrow: At the Cambrian pithead wives, mothers and daughters wait for news.
Rhondda
700 "L 3/R DEEP.
A GASP
A final gasp went up from
the crowd. Mr. Thomas told
them formally that the
list would be posted up for
inspection.
Then he said, gently:
"Perhaps it would be as well
to disperse to your homes."
Reluctantly the people
drifted home to ponder on
the day of disaster in this
unlovely little cul-de-sac of
In Clydach Vale early
today the front doors are all
open. Some women stand at
their front gates, a few are
still at the pithead.
There is no hope left-and
no doubt.
All the dead miners have
been identified by the num-
bers on their lamps. Nobody
is unaccounted for.
The explosion was in the
mechanised plough face of
the colliery's No. 1 pit - an
up-to-date section of the
colliery.
Thirty-one men in the
immediate area of the blast
were killed instantly.

AGAINST his nature

Trevor Bransington be-

come one of Lord Eakins'

"obese" followers yesterday.

"Fat" and "obese" were the

42nd words John Dodd

(right) used to describe

Trevor Bransington. He

used them to describe

him to Mr. Bransington

at his home in Parramatta.

The reporter was there to

ask Mr. Bransington for

his comments on the re-

port that he was going to

give away his fortune.

After all pleas by the pub-

lic were ignored Mr. Bran-

sington made a sudden

decision and went out

to his private park where

a man was to be seen

sitting on a bench in the

rain. Mr. Bransington

stated that the man was

going to receive the

fortune.

Speaking about his

"obese" followers, Mr.

Bransington said he would

have no more of them.

Mr. Bransington, 48, is still

a "fat" man. Mr. Bransington

had become one of Lord

yesterday. Mr. Bransington

did not like "fat" or "obese"

and he was going to have

no more of them. He was

going to leave them all

behind and would not be

going to have any more

like them. He was going

to have no more than

three. He was going to

have them made to order

and he would be looking

for three people who

He would rather "fat" and

Chin in hand, Mr. Bressington (centre) taking it easy yesterday
AGAINST his nature
Trevor Bressington be-came one of Lord Robens' absentees yesterday.

Instead of going down the 880 yards into Cwm Colliery, near Pontypridd, South Wales, he was asleep in bed.

After 42 years in the pits he has dust on his chest, and a pain across his back which he thinks may be a slipped disc or a chill on his kidneys.

By staying at home in Beddau he joined the 40 per cent. of the coalface workers who failed to arrive for work at Cwm Colliery.

Everyone, except the Coal Board takes the absentee situa-tion philosophically.

SCRAPHEAP

Mr. Bressington, at 56, is still a good worker. He is a member of the pit consultative com-mittee, an apprentice training officer, and he does not like to miss a day's work.

But he—and many others of his age—are finding one thing.
BY JOHN DODD

£10 10s. a week. It is too big a drop from the £19 I get for five shifts at the coal-face.”

In his 42 years down the mines he has lost three close friends in accidents, and nearly died in one himself.

Yesterday, when he should have been working, he sat in a club with other miners, drinking pints and telling stories. Why
weren't the others working? One woke up late, two were on holiday, and two more were suffering from “bumps” and were off sick.

Today Mr. Bressington will be back at work. “Back with the 'donkeys' and the machines.”

Last week Lord Robens, the Coal Board chairman, con-demned absenteeism in the pits as a “national malaise.” He said that voluntary absen-teeism cost the Board the equivalent of 27,000 men's work last year.
They cannot keep up the pace. His union secretary, Mr. Bryn Williams, says: “In the old days a man was on the scrap heap at 45 but he could do his work at his own pace. Now he is expected to keep up with a machine until he is 65.

“They took the horses out of the pits and left the donkeys.” The “donkeys” at Cwm are men—numbering 1,400. Accord-ing to Mr. Williams more than 100 wear belts to support slipped discs in their backs, and 400 are suffering from dust, ranging from 10 to 60 per cent. dis-ability.

EXCUSE

He would rather smother his grandchildren than let them go down the pit.

Mr. Bressington says there are several reasons why men don't go to work on Mondays.

Some have to get up at 4.30 am. to travel 10 miles to the pit; some are fed up with chang-ing jobs down the pit. Others, like him, are feeling the pace of trying to keep up with machines.

And there are those who, if they miss a shift, earn as much from the sickness and compen-sation benefits. He says the best excuse is an accident down the pit.

WORST

Cwm Colliery's absentee figures are among the worst in South Wales. Yesterday 27.8 per cent. of the overall staff failed to turn up, something like 400 out of 1,400.

Production at the colliery averages 26 cwt. per man-shift, compared with a national aver-age of 34. The geographical conditions are partly to blame.

Mr. Bressington works behind a coal-cutting machine, pump-ing up hydraulic pit props and shovelling coal on to a conveyor. He says: “I could ask to do lighter work. But for pushing
coal I would get only

MR. CHARLES PIKE - who
fitted the nut that caused
rt, the disaster - said last
as' night: "I feared every
oal knock at the door.
"Although I knew I was free
of blame, something kept
pricking me which said I had
caused it all."
He added: "I have not been
able to settle down to anything
since, not even a job. My wife
is on the verge of a nervous
breakdown."
Mr. Pike, a 49-year-old
labourer and experienced pipe
fitter, was cleared of any blame
by the inquiry.
The brass nut he had fitted in
the flat which blew up and sent
the others crashing was a faulty
one.
It was sold to him by the Gas
Board so that he could connect
the gas supply to a new cooker
bought by Miss Hodge, one of his
friends.
The nut, 1¼ inches in diameter
and worth less than a penny,
was faulty in three ways-the
depth of chamfer, the thickness
of flange, and the diameter of
the bore recess.
Yesterday a massive hunt was

The nut that caused the blast

under way to find thousands
of similar nuts which may have
been fitted in up to 200,000
homes in the North Thames Gas
Board area - the only area
involved.
Nine other nuts on cookers in
the London area have been
found to be defective in pattern,
though not cracked, like the
one at Ronan Point, it was
learned yesterday.
The board put an immediate
ban on the issue of nuts of the
faulty type the moment the
fault was discovered. Instruc-
tions have been given to the
board's fitters - who make an
average of 6,000 visits a day -
to check the connection if there
is a gas cooker on the premises,
no matter what the main pur-
pose of their call.
If the connector has a
"danger" nut it will be
changed.
Later, Mr. Pike-he lives 100
yards from the wrecked block
of flats-said: "A good deed has
wrecked my life. I'll never fit
another gas cooker as long as
I live."

-30
THESE ARE THE MAIN FINDINGS AND RECOM-
MENDATIONS OF THE RONAN POINT INQUIRY:
PREFABRICATED blocks of flats more than six-storeys should
be examined to see if they are subject to progressive collapse
-the collapse of one flat on top of another. If they are, the
building must be strengthened, and the gas supply cut off
until this has been done.
NO CASE has been made out for a permanent ban on the
use of gas in tall blocks.

1983-5236/41235

e nouse
that LEONARD
built...

FARM-WORKER Leonard
Algar claims a housing
record of his own.
In the little village of Carl-
ton Colville, near Lowestoft,
stands a well-built house, with
three bedrooms, three rooms
downstairs, bathroom, elec-
tricity, hot and cold water, and
three-quarters of an acre of
garden.

Built more than fourteen
months ago, this house is be-
lieved to be the first to be
erected under the Govern-
ment's scheme which helps
farm workers to have houses
built for themselves on their
own land.

Over their own front gate the
Algars chat with Farmer
Newson.

DAILY
18 FEB 1950
HERALD

His employer, Farmer Stan-
ley Newson, of Grove Farm,
told me about it. "Leonard
bought the land, had the house
built, and got married," he
said. "I think a lot of farm
workers would do the same if
they knew that the facilities
were available."
"What are these facilities?"

Up to 85 per cent. of the total
cost of building a house can be
borrowed at the rate of 3½ per
cent. interest, repayable within
30 years.
For example, if the house

cost £1,100 (the price Leonard
paid for his) as much as £935
could be borrowed, if necessary.
The cost of interest and re-
payment over this period would
then average less than £1 per
week, and less still, of course,
if the sum borrowed were
smaller.

SE 15/8x 2/2 PZ (DH)

The scheme also provides an
annual grant, increased by the
Labour Government to £15 for
40 years, a total of £600, for all
such houses occupied by farm
workers.
And no development charges
are made where these houses
are concerned.
The first step for a farm
worker to take is to apply to
the clerk of his rural district
council. Those councils that
administer the Small Dwellings
Acquisition Act, which deals
with this matter, should pro-
perly give priority in the grant-
ing of building licences to men
working on the land.
The farm worker who is a
member will find that his
union is always ready to help
him deal with the formalities.

The kitchen—light, modern,
well-equipped.

B. A. Steward

Y OF
ALD

PRESS INFORMATION
FROM REINFORCED PLASTICS LIMITED

REINFORCED PLASTICS LIMITED DEVELOP 3,000 GALLON
UNDERGROUND PETROL STORAGE TANK FOR ES SO

In recent years the larger oil companies have been seeking ways
of increasing safety and cutting storage costs for petroleum spirit.
One of the major elements in the storage costs is the tank itself, and
also its concrete assessment.

Working to a specification from Esso Petroleum Company Limited,
Reinforced Plastics Limited have developed a 3,000 gallon, glass
reinforced plastic, underground storage tank measuring 7ft. in Diameter,
by 13ft. long, constructed entirely of Douglas glass fibres and Artite
polyester resin. The glass reinforced plastic construction of this
tank shows considerable advantages over other forms of storage tanks.
It resists bacterial and soil attack and will neither corrode nor leak.
It has a low installation cost, and because of its comparative light
weight, savings are made both in transportation and handling charges.

Tests have been carried out by Esso Petroleum and the Butterstan
College of Technology with the tank above-ground in a testing frame, and
buried in the ground to simulate all loadings to which the tank would be
subjected in service. The results show that the tank would be satisfactory
when installed in a single excavation, and butt-filled. In normal practice
where a tank is installed under the Forecourt of a service station it is
protected by a 9-inch re-inforced concrete slab. To test the effect of
normal vehicle loadings the road slab was deliberately made weaker, and
the tank successfully withstood the observed stresses.

These tanks can be made in sizes from 2,000 to 5,000 gallons
capacity, and in single and multiple compartment versions.

CAUTION: Technicians at the REINFORCED Plastics Limited, Cooberley,
Surrey, factory assembling a 3,000 gallon glass reinforced plastic
storage tank. This are recently undergone extensive testing by the Esso
Petroleum Company Limited, and the Butterton College of Technology.

23rd August, 1965
Transcribed_Text:
1953-5236/52647
PRESS INFORMATION

RECEIVED
24 AUG 1965
SUN EDITORIAL DEPT.
FROM BTR INDUSTRIES LIMITED

BTR REINFORCED PLASTICS LIMITED DEVELOP 3,000 GALLON
UNDERGROUND PETROL STORAGE TANK FOR ESSO

        In recent years the larger oil companies have been seeking ways
of increasing safety and cutting storage costs for petroleum spirit.
One of the major elements in the storage costs is the tank itself, and
also its concrete encasement.
Industries.. Plastics.
        Working to a specification from Esso Petroleum Company Limited,
BTR Reinforced Plastics Limited have developed a 3,000 gallon, glass
reinforced plastic, underground storage tank measuring 7ft. in diameter,
by 13ft. long, constructed entirely of Deeglas glass fibre and Artrite
polyester resins. The glass reinforced plastic construction of this
tank shows considerable advantages over other forms of storage tanks.
It resists bacterial and acid attack and will neither corrode nor leak.
It has a low installation cost, and because of its comparative light
weight, savings are made both in transportation and handling charges.

        Tests have been carried out by Esso Petroleum and the Battersea
College of Technology with the tank above-ground in a testing frame, and
buried in the ground to simulate all loadings to which the tank would be
subjected in service. The results show that the tank would be satisfactory
when installed in a simple excavation, and back-filled. In normal practice
where a tank is installed under the forecourt of a service station it is
protected by a 9-inch re-inforced concrete slab. To test the effect of
normal vehicle loadings the road slab was deliberately made weaker, and
the tank successfully withstood the abnormal stresses.

        These tanks can be made in sizes from 2,000 to 5,000 gallons
capacity, and in single and multiple compartment versions.

CAPTION: Technicians at the BTR Reinforced Plastics Limited, Camberley,
Surrey, factory assembling a 3,000 gallon glass reinforced plastic petrol
storage tank. This has recently undergone extensive testing by the Esso
Petroleum Company Limited, and the Battersea College of Technology.

23rd August, 1965

INDIA'S GREATEST RAILWAY TOURIST, PRINCESS TARMINE
AND JOHNNY BOYD OF U.S.A. HAVE BEEN TRANSFORMED
OVERNIGHT IN NEW DELHI DURING THEIR THREE-DAY STAY IN
THE SWAMPING TIMES OF INDIA'S SMALLEST COUNTRY, PEOPLE SEEM
TO NEVER BELIEVE INDIA HAD RAILWAY.

EIGHT MONTHS AGO, CHILDREN HAVE BEEN BORN AND LIFE'S
ENTIRE MEANING HAS COMPRESSED INTO AN THIRTEEN-YEAR-OLD
PLATFORM MAN IN OPEN SEATINGS ARRANGEMENTS BETWEEN TWO
STATUTES AND DEPARTURE.

THEY ARE ALL INDIA TOURIST, PAUL, CELESTIAL, TELEGRAPHICALLY
SEVEN HAS SEEN SERIOUS WORKERS, WHO ARE DOING GREEN GRASS
PLANTINGS, COMPRESSED PROTECTION FEET UPON TO PAKISTAN AND HAS
BEEN ASKED FROM AHMED LATTAH PALACE TO WESTERN CAPITAL
CARRIER OF STAFF.

THE STAFF IS DOING WONDERFUL WORK TO HAVE TEN THOUSAND
RATE THAT TWENTY-FIVE BOATS HAS BEEN BUILT INSTALLED AT THE POINT OF

COMPARTMENT. WHENEVER THEY HAVE BEEN ABLE TO SEE THE JOURNAL AND THE

Transcribed_Text:
INDIA'S GREATEST RAILWAY TERMINI TRANSFORMED INTO
CAMPING GROUND FOR 6,000 MUSLIMS
18.10.47

India's greatest railway termini, Victoria Terminus
and Bombay Central in Bombay, have been transformed
overnight into camping grounds for 6,000 Muslims as
the sweeping tides of displaced minority peoples glow
in terror between India and Pakistan.
Eight men have died, children have been born and life's
entire meaning is compressed into an existence on bare
platforms and in open station enclosures between train
arrivals and departures.
They are all India Government, rail, postal, telegraphic,
income tax and customs workers, who on being given the
choice, expressed preference to work in Pakistan and are
being moved from inland Indian points to that capital
through this port.
The shift is being made by sea, but so heavy is the
rush that thousands have been inokloosed at the point of
embarkation, and have made their detraining stop their
temporary homes. Their descent on the two termini and the
natural demands have entirely dislocated sanitation and
hygiene in hitherto model and gigantic depots.

I.N.P. PHOTO SHOWS:- Some of the 6,000 Muslims who have
made India's greatest railway termini,
Victoria Terminus and Bombay Central their
temporary homes while enroute to their new
homes in Pakistan. Their descent on the two termini
and their natural demands have entirely dislocated
sanitation and hygiene in hitherto model and
gigantic depots. Eight men have died and children
have been born while thousands of people have been
crowded into primitive quarters like these. Screens
of clothing can be seen strung up to shelter the
usually screened and secluded Muslim women from a
traveller's wondering gaze.

35/M/11645 INTERNATIONAL NEWS PHOTOS

Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236 / 45511
1.6.54
BURCHELL. BRISTOL
1954-709-3
HERALD REPORTER
VILLAGERS blinked in surprise when a 3,000-
gallon milk tanker drew up by their disused
coal mine. They wondered why. But they were
not left wondering long—for the milk was poured
to the bottom of the pit.
The tanker came again and again and the people of
Tunley, near Bath, found that their pit had been
turned into a 60,000-gallon “milk bottle.”
The tanks had been sent by the Wilts, United Dairy. Last
night a spokesman at the Trowbridge office explained:
“The pit milk was skimmed—it had been left over from
butter-making.
1 Increased production had left the company with an
abnormally large amount of skimmed milk on its hands.
2 There was a lack of demand for tinned condensed
skimmed milk.
3 Transport and other difficulties make it impossible to get
rid of all the skimmed milk to farmers and others who
could use it for animal fattening.
1954-709-1
“We are not allowed by law
to sell it as a liquid for human
consumption,” added the spokes-
man.
‘IN DEMAND’
A Ministry of Agriculture
official commented: “Skimmed
milk is a most important contri-
bution to the feeding of calves
and is much in demand. This
is the first we have heard of this
case and inquiries will surely be
made.”
And a local farmer thought
that many pig-keepers would be
glad to have the skimmed milk
delivered to their farms.
He pointed out that the
tankers were travelling more
than 20 miles—from Trowbridge
— “They might just as well be
using the petrol and labour to
bring it to the farmers.”
In Tunley, the villagers shake
their heads.
FUMES?
Mrs. Eileen Palmer, a miner’s
wife, said: “Surely something
better could be done with it?
One of my children brought
some home and it made a very
nice rice pudding.”
Mrs. Ethel Benwell, a village
shopkeeper, asked: “What about
the fumes when all that milk
goes sour?”
The point was put to a Coal
Board official. If there was any
unpleasant smell, he said, “no
doubt the villagers of Tunley
will get in touch with us.”
1954-709-4
1954-709-2

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
FOR NEWS REPRESENTATIVES

From: Public Relations Department, Bairds & Scottish Steel Ltd.
Date: 26 March 1935

THOMSON'S DALRY DILTORR CARPET WORKS
Thomson's Dalry, Ltd. Carpet Factory was founded in the
village of Dalry, Scotland, in 1835 by William Thomson,
a weaver, who started with ten weavers. The factory received its
Royal Charter from King William IV. in 1837, and annually
exports about 200,000 pounds sterling worth of carpets to all
parts of the world, including the United States, Canada, and
Australia. The carpets are made from wool and are hand-tufted
in a variety of designs and sizes. The factory employs about
200 people, the majority of whom are women.
Thomson's Dalry, Ltd. is the only factory in Scotland that
produces hand-tufted carpets, and is one of the largest producers
of hand-tufted carpets in the world. The factory is known for
its high-quality products and its commitment to fair labor
practices. The factory is a significant contributor to the
local economy, and is a source of pride for the village of Dalry.

1983-5236/55438

FOR PUBLICATION MONDAY'S EVENING, March 18th

THE WORLD'S OUR MARKET FOR CARPETS.
18.3.46.
The famous Royal Wilton Carpet Factory was founded in the
17th century near Salisbury in a district noted for its
weaving since Elizabethan days. The factory received its
Royal Charter from William of Orange in 1701 and shortly
after, two Frenchmen, Anthony Dufessy and Peter Jemavie,
were said to have been smuggled over from France in
barrels to take charge of the factory. These Continental
weavers were masters of their trade, and the smuggling of
them was necessary owing to the strict laws of France
against craftsmen taking away the secrets of their trades
to foreign countries.
Hand-made carpets have been made at Wilton for many
important buildings in this country and throughout the
world, and now that the factory is released from war work,
it is busy on order from the United States, Canada and
South America etc. This picture taken recently at the
factory shows
Girls putting the finishing touches to handmade carpets
at the factory. They are for export.

File Indus - Household - Carpets

the building to a private developer
would be the first option. He
pointed out that any buyer would
have to be prepared to demolish
the block and replan it. This, he
said, would be a considerable
expense.
"The Ministry is obliged to build a
station at Marylebone," he said.
"This site is considered the most
suitable. We are at present
negotiating for the demolition
of the office block, which was
built about two years ago. A
decision will have to be made by
the end of October."
The Minister is to meet the
leader of Westminster City Council
today to discuss the matter. The
council has been assured that
any building erected by the Ministry
will be designed so that it will
have no adverse effect on the
surrounding buildings, and that
there will be no objection to its
erection.
The Ministry is understood to
be prepared to pay compensation
to the original builders, but this
figure is not yet known. The
original builders were Messrs. Walter
Smith (Contractors) Ltd., of
Walworth. They completed the
block in April, 1966.
They are thought to have built
the block for a figure of Ãƒâ€šÃ‚Â£200,000
to Ãƒâ€šÃ‚Â£220,000, and it has been
standing empty ever since.
The block has been standing empty
ever since.

a £200,000 office block, not yet completed, may
have to come down to make way for a Multi-Story

O.P. the office block in Wells St. W.1.

NEW £200,000 OFFICES
MAY COME DOWN

A SEVEN-STOREY office block in Wells-street, Mary-
lebone, which has cost more than £200,000 to
build, may be pulled down
without ever having been
occupied.
The block, due to be completed
by October, is the subject of a
public inquiry opening at St.
Marylebone Town Hall on Mon-
day.
The local council is to ask the
Minister of Housing and Local
Government to confirm a com-
pulsory purchase order for the
site.
The council wants to build a
multi-storey garage for 200 cars
on the site. The Ministry in-
spector conducting the inquiry
will be told that the owners
of the office block will claim
more than £700,000 compensa-
tion—about £70 a square foot.
COMPENSATION
A council spokesman said to-
day: “At the time the council
agreed to put forward a compul-
sory purchase order the site
area in Wells-street was clear.
We knew, however, that plan-
ning permission had been ob-
tained from the LCC for the
erection of an office block there.”
If the purchase order is con-
firmed, but compensation can-
not be agreed, then the matter
must be referred to the Lands
Tribunal.
Estate agent Mr. R. Wilks, a
partner in the firm concerned,
said to-day: “The land has been
lying idle for something like 25
years before we sought and ob-
tained planning permission.”
Before building work began,
the site, owned by a Government
department, was a car park.
Workmen continue to put the
finishing touches to the offices.
To-day they were completing
the roof.

FILMS ON BIOLOGICAL OPERATIONS,
AS OF APRIL 1, 1974.

Between February 28 and April 1, 1974, production
continued on the films of biological operations. These
films are being edited and will show the medical and
biological effects of agent C0565, the effect of agent
C0565 on animals, the effect of agent C0565 on the
environment, laboratory and clinical effects of agent C0565.
In addition, the films will show the various operations
and facilities involved in biological operations. The
films are about one-half completed and approximately
three of them have been tentatively titled. They are
"The Effects of C0565 on Humans", "The Effects of C0565
on Animals", and "The Effects of C0565 on Plants".
The remaining two films will cover the various aspects
of the biological operations, the facilities involved
and will discuss the various scientific and medical
personnel involved in the biological operations.
The films will also include information on the
safety measures and precautions being taken to protect
the personnel involved in the operations.
The films will be completed by May 1, 1974.

By Denis Fits
IT happened yesterday, in
the smallest room of a
small house in Lambeth ...
Coloured Mrs. X ("Ah'd hofe
for any of ma folks back in
Saint Lucia to hear about it; so,
please, mister, don't say ma
name") was powdering her
nose, in a manner of speaking,
and thinking about her island in
the sun.
"Ah pulls the chain," she said.
"And wham, bam, slam and
Beelzebub, the whole place
starts falling round ma ears."
She didn't know just then,
but the two rear walls of the
house in Trigon road had
cracked, crumbled and tumbled
down—as quickly as it has taken
you to read this.
The scene—when the dust

cleared away—is pictured above.
And six families—all from
Saint Lucia in the West Indies
—paying £2 a week each for
single-room apartments in it
were made homeless.
Two women, both expectant
mothers, were taken to hospital
with shock.
Said one of the tenants, food
worker Peter Herrle: "I heard
a loud crackling noise and
shouted, 'Let's get out of here!' "
"But before I could start pack-
ing, my bedroom wall wasn't
there."
Chain-pulling Mrs. X said:
"Me, ah just held on to that
chain and said a little prayer."

Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/51188

        TWENTY MINUTES after a gas fitter left a semi-detached house
        yesterday it blew up, killing the 74-year-old owner and injuring
        his wife.
        Retired gardener Tom Kearly was buried beneath the debris for
        an hour before being pulled free by firemen, police and workmen.

        He died on the way to
        Ashford Hospital, in Mid-
        dlesex.
        Mr. Kearly's 73-year-old
        wife Mabel was trapped be-
        neath a pile of bricks after
        the blast at their home in
        Spelthorne Lane, Ashford.
        She kept crying: 'Get me out,
        get me out,' as rescuers fought
        to lift the debris.
        Finally, a mobile crane being
        used by 40 workmen behind the
        house pulled Mrs. Kearly clear.

        BATHROOM

        She was treated on the spot
        for severe burns and cuts by a
        doctor and nurses from Ashford
        Hospital.
        Mrs. Kearly was taken to West
        Middlesex Hospital. Last night
        a spokesman there said she was
        on the "danger list."
        The blast hurled dozens of
        bricks into the kitchen of the
        Kearlys' next door neighbour,
        Mrs. Pamela Dear, who had
        been washing up with her five-
        year-old son Christopher only
        minutes before.
        Said Mrs. Dear: 'I had sent
        Chris into the front room to
        play and I was in the bath-
        room. It's just as well I did.'
        Mr. Fred English, a 58-year-
        old electrical contractor, whose
        house adjoins the Kearey home,
        said: 'It was just like a bomb
        going off. I was almost knocked
        down the stairs.'

        GAS COOKER

        A spokesman for the North
        Thames Gas Board said a full
        investigation was being made
        into the cause of the explosion.
        It is understood that the gas
        fitter had been to the house to
        repair a wash boiler and to
        move a gas cooker.

        An elderly couple were found
        dead in a gas-filled room at
        their home in Bridge Road,
        Uxbridge, Middlesex, 34 years
        after the gas supply was dis-
        connected.
        The gas that killed 76-year-old
        Harold Wilson and his 81-year-
        old wife Annie came from a leak
        in a gas pipe that had rusted,
        the Uxbridge inquest was told.
        Verdict: Accident.

BEGINS TODAY. ALTHOUGH THE POST-WAR BOOM, CAUSED
BY WORLD-WIDE SHORTAGE OF OIL AND MEAT, IS OVER,
WHALING IS STILL A HIGHLY COMPETITIVE BUSINESS. LAST
SEASON 27 WHALING EXPEDITIONS (FACTORY VESSELS WITH
CATCHER SHIPS) OPERATED IN THE ANTARCTIC.

them from the private. Because of
this danger the International Whaling
Commission, of which 12 whaling nations
representatives were set up in 1946 to control the
Industry.
The Commission set a limit on the number
of whale that may be caught, so that the stock
on the seas would not be depleted, because it is
believed that the whale would become extinct
if they continue. They also ruled that the killing of
whales of the species under a certain size would be

THE "WHALE" OF THE WHALING FLEET IS THE FACTORY SHIP, WHICH IS A FLOATING REFINERY WHERE THE WHALE IS PROCESSED.
THE AIM OF THE FLEET IS THE BLUE WHALE, WHICH IS THE LARGEST ANIMAL THAT HAS EVER LIVED. THE BLUE WHALE IS ABOUT 70 FEET LONG AND WEIGHS 150 TONS.
THE FLEET HAS A NUMBER OF SMALL BOATS CALLED WHALING BOATS, WHICH ARE USED TO HUNT THE WHALES. ONCE A WHALE IS CAUGHT, IT IS BROUGHT TO THE FACTORY SHIP FOR PROCESSING.
THE BLUE WHALE IS USED TO MAKE WHALE OIL, WHICH IS USED IN A VARIETY OF PRODUCTS, INCLUDING MARGARINE, SOAP, AND CANDLES.
THE BLUE WHALE IS ALSO USED TO MAKE WHALE MEAT, WHICH IS A SOURCE OF PROTEIN.
THE BLUE WHALE IS A HIGHLY ENDANGERED SPECIES, AND THE HUNTING OF THE BLUE WHALE IS NOW PROHIBITED.
THE BLUE WHALE IS A VERY IMPORTANT ANIMAL TO THE ECOSYSTEM OF THE OCEAN.
THE BLUE WHALE IS A VERY BEAUTIFUL ANIMAL, AND IT IS A VERY IMPORTANT ANIMAL TO THE PLANET.
THE BLUE WHALE IS A VERY IMPORTANT ANIMAL TO THE HISTORY OF WHALING.

● The main international Antarctic whaling season
begins today. Although the post-war boom, caused
by world-wide shortage of oil and meat, is over,
whaling is still a highly competitive business. Last
season 21 whaling expeditions (factory vessels with
catcher ships) operated in the Antarctic.
Slol.
MEN have hunted whales for centuries
and have threatened to exterminate
them in the process. Because of
this danger the International Whaling
Commission (of which 18 nations are now
members) were set up in 1949 to control the
industry.
The Commission set a limit on the number
of whales that may be caught in the Antarc-
tic, the main hunting ground, each year, and
lay down the dates between which they may
be hunted. They also forbid the killing, any-
where, of the nearly extinct grey whales and
all undersized, young and pregnant whales.

27 OCT 1966

1983 - S236/41340

Betsy yesterday, proud symbol of free-enterprise productivity.
Picture by Ron Burton

1966 - 2820

UNTIL yesterday no
one had very much
respect for the
chicken as a person-
ality.

It was, if it was
worth considering, the
symbol of the coward.
Although even that
symbolism was gradu-
ally being taken away
from it, cowards hav-
ing gained prestige
since they were up-
graded to anti-heroes.

What happened yes-
terday was, quite sim-
ply, the news about
Betsy. She (you cannot
call a chicken like
Betsy an it, and this is
a measure of what
Betsy has accomplished
for chickens every-
where) laid an egg
containing seven yolks.

It had never, as far
as was known, been
done before. Septuplets
are as rare among

chickens as they are
among humans.
But it wasn't the
purely biological aspect
of Betsy's achievement
that so impressed the
world. It was the tim-
ing of this exceptional
feat of productivity.
We British regard
ourselves as sophisti-
cated, but we are as
simple as a tribe when it
comes to seizing on an
event which sums up our
national predicament.
Here we were wallowing
in a great mass of words
from our leaders about
the economic situation,
when Betsy came along
to express the solution in
a simple, forceful gesture.
Where there was one,
Betsy seemed to be
saying, let there be seven.
How was she to be
rewarded?
The solution she had
provided to one problem
seemed to pose another.
For there could be no
material favours granted
in the period of the
freeze, not even where it

was related to produc-
tivity.
Betsy, it seemed, would
have to continue to
manage with chicken-
feed.

Perhaps one of the new
honours that will soon
be announced will take
care of the matter.
What of Betsy's posi-
tion in regard to organ-
ised labour?
For this is the remark-
able truth: she is a free
enterprise chicken, out-
side the well regulated
authority of the Egg
Board. She carries no
card.
It will be interesting to
see what Mr. Macleod
makes of that.
Of course, there will be
knockers ready to dis-
parage Betsy's achieve-
ment.
What meaning, they
will say, has one isolated
example of productivity
to a nation which needs
a consistent pattern of
growth?
Answer these cynics
Betsy, as only you can.
You must do it again.

Industry Potteries - Finished articles

WEEP
FOR YOUR
OLD
WILLOW
PLATE
By Robert Bickford
A DINNER PLATE which
tells a fairy tale of young
love and parental wrath—
the world-famous Willow
Pattern—is threatened with
extinction.
The old plates will gradu-
ally disappear until they are
collectors' pieces. But the
story, told to generations of
children, will live on.
That "ancient Chinese legend"
began in the English potteries
during an 18th-century craze
for Oriental knick-knacks.
This delicate Oriental-style
crockery will no longer be pro-
duced by Coalport China Ltd.,
the Stoke-on-Trent firm which
introduced it to the world in
1772.
An enterprising potter imitated
a well-known Cantonese design.

ELOPEMENT
It showed a mandarin's country
house. On a bridge near a
weeping willow were the ill-
starred lovers and the girl's
father.
An English magazine writer who
had been no further east than
Essex invented a story to go
with it.
It told how Li-Chi, the man-
darin's daughter, eloped with
Chang, her father's humble
secretary, and how the couple
hid from the angry old man be-
fore finding sanctuary.
Like the chinaware, the story has
been a success ever since.
Now Coalport and another firm,
The Cauldron Pottery, have
announced that they are ceas-
ing production but not going
into liquidation.
About 300 workers have been
dismissed. But Mr. Stanley
Harrison, boss of the two com-
panies, said yesterday he hoped
that another factory "with
more economic conditions"
would take over.
So someone may yet step in to
save the Willow Pattern.

Calcraft
M/S.
THE BAD SADDLE?

One would think that 30-year-old Keneth Howard,
a saddler and harness maker of Freslingham,
Suffolk, would be pleased with life. He has just
commenced three months' leave from the Army. But
to Keneth this three months' leave means work! From
7 in the morning until 9 at night. This work is the
accumulation of 9 months' horses collars, harness
pads, bridles, binder canvasses, the property of
local farmers. They are all waiting for his expert
hands to repair them, ready for the busy time
ahead.

Nine months ago Keneth Howard ended another such
3 months leave as he did in 1941. Farming equipment
is even more important today than it was then.
The Suffolk War Agricultural Committee were responsible
for obtaining Keneth his leave, but the 3 months
granted is not sufficient time for Keneth to get
through the work owing to the fact that new harness
is almost non existent and the harness now in use
is in poor condition. By the time Keneth gets
through with them his 2 months is up, leaving no
time to cope with the binder canvasses that will be
needed to gather the coming harvest.
What worries Keneth is the fact that 33 years ago
he enlisted as a soldier and up till now he has not
even seen an Army horse, let alone a set of harness!
The Howard's have been saddler and harness makers
since 1805 in and around Freslingham, as Keneth feels
he would be of more use if left to carry on. He
repaired at one time repaired 8 harness collars. These
went when the war came. His mother carried on the
business when his father died ten years ago. He is
now the sole worker.
He has a brother in the R.A.F. and two of his sisters
are nursing. His job in the Army is repairing
equipment.
C.F.G.L. Keneth Howard re-padding with rye straw
one of the many collars. These he also covers with
wool blanket cloth; a repair usually lasts two
years.
11.3.43

THE SAD SADLER
One would think that 30-year-old Keneth Howard,
a sadler and harness maker of Framlingham,
Suffolk, would be pleased with life. He has just
commenced three months' leave from the Army, but
to Keneth this three months leave means work! From
7 in the morning until 9 at night. This work is the
accumulation of 9 months' horses collars, harness
pads, bridles, binder canvasses, the property of
local farmers. They are all waiting for his expert
hands to repair them, ready for the busy times
ahead.
Nine months ago Keneth Howard ended another such
3 months leave as he did in 1941. Farming equipment
is even more important today than it was then.
The Suffolk War Agricultural Committee were responsible
for obtaining Keneth his leave, but the 3 months
granted is not sufficient time for Keneth to get
through the work owing to the fact that new harness
is almost non existent and the harness now in use
is in poor condition. By the time Keneth gets
through with them his 3 months is up, leaving no
time to cope with the binder canvasses that will be
needed to gather the coming harvest.
What worries Keneth is the fact that 3½ years ago
he enlisted as a sadler and up till now he has not
even seen an Army horse, let alone a set of harness!
The Howard's have been sadler and harness makers
since 1853 in and around Framlingham, so Keneth feels
he would be of more use if left to carry on. The
Howards at one time employed 2 harness makers. These
went when the war came. His mother carried on the
business when his father died ten years ago. He is
now the sole worker.
He has a brother in the R.A.F. and two of his sisters
are nursing. His job in the Army is repairing
equipment.
O.P.S.1. Keneth Howard re-padding with rye straw
one of the many collars. These he also covers with
wool blanket cloth; a repair usually lasts two
years.

HEIGHT INDUSTRIALIZED FLATS IN THE MIDLANDS

The Bison Wall Frame industrialised building system of high
flat construction has been chosen for two 24-storey skyscraper blocks
to be erected for the City of Leicester Corporation. These will be
the highest 'factory-made' blocks of flats to be built in the Midlands.
They will contain 256 one-bedroom flats, with six flats on each floor.
The contract is valued at Ã‚Â£550,754 for the complete development, including
a car park.

Concrete Limited, manufacturers of the Bison Wall Frame system,
will begin erection early in 1965. Production of the concrete components
a Bison Wall Frame flat comprises 25 separate units - will be carried out
in the Factory of Concrete (Midlands) Limited at Lichfield.

The Bison Wall Frame system has been used for multi-storey flats
in the Midlands at Birmingham, Kidderminster, Rugby, Bilston, Lichfield
and Willenhall, as well as on many other sites to England and Scotland.
Already 25 blocks on 20 sites have been either completed, started or
ordered amounting to nearly 5,000 flats. The total cost is almost Ã‚Â£6
millions. Current production of Bison Wall Frame flats is now running
at a rate of 4,000 flats per annum.

Concrete Limited have factories at Dunmose, Tilbury, Iver,
Lichfield, Leeds, Polkit, and another under construction at Fleetwood,
Cheshire.

FOR FIRST PUBLICATION MONDAY'S EVENINGS JULY 18th 1949.
BRITAIN LEADS WORLD IN MOTOR RUSTPROOFING TECHNIQUE
JS 18.7.49.
Morris cars coming off the assembly lines at Cowley, Oxfordshire,
are now receiving a 100% anti-rust treatment from a special plant
known as the "Rotodip" which, as rated in conjunction with one of
the most up-to-date paint plants, forms an engineering project in
which Britain leads the whole world. Until the advent of this new
technique the procedure for finishing car bodies was to first
to thoroughly clean down the body to remove all grease, and to
finally rinse by hand or automatic spray, followed by a drying
process, after which the primer and finish coats or paints were
added by spray gun. This method, however, did not give complete-
protection because many important parts of the body were never
reached.

Now the bodies go through the plant which consists of a tunnel
some 20 feet square and 300 feet long, which they enter in the
plain steel, greasy state, and emerge some 1½ hours later having
been cleaned, rustproofed, and primer-painted inside and out,
entirely automatically. For their journey through the plant, the
bodies are mounted on a revolving spit with the bonnet, wings and
boot in position but spaced-inch from the body to allow free
circulation, and is then carried broadside through the length of
the plant on conveyor chains in such a way that the body revolves
on its own axis while passing through the machine. The process
is in two stages - first rustproofing by cleaning, rinsing and
proofing for which the bodies pass through six large tanks, and
secondly, primer-painting during which the body is dried in an
oven, cooled down, and painted.
This series of pictures illustrates the remarkable process which
the Morris engineers are confident will protect the bodies
against corrosion and paint flaking.

1172 - 12/12/1962
Indust. Fuel. Power. Oil Terminals.

B.P. INSTALLS EXPERIMENTAL BUOY AT HOSE.
B.P. G. 11513 7th December 1961.
A new type of mooring buoy for use in the loading
and discharge of tankers inconditions where conventional
berthing cannot be used, is being tested by British
Petroleum in the Thames Estuary. The prototype,
designed to enable tankers to be moored at a single
point, is being installed at the Nore about five
miles from the Kent Refinery of B.P. The work of
laying the buoy is being carried out by the Port of
London Authority.

The new buoy, which wasbuilt at Harland's
& Wolff's yard at North Woolwich, hasbeen designed
to eliminate some of the disadvantages associated
with existing single point moorings where varying wave
and tidal conditions cause deterioration of hoses, hindering
the movement of the buoy. The pendants or anchor hawsers
are one chain of the new buoy are of
a fixed length and are connected to an anchor bay set
into the seabed and filled with mud, stones. The bay is also
held by ground tackles. The pendants are always in tension
which restricts the movement of the buoy at all states of
the tide.
The hoses from the buoy are bolted to pipes secured
to the anchor heel by employing this arrangement the flexib-
le hoses are kept as short as possible and are at all
times clear of the seabed, thus avoiding deterioration
and wear. The pendants are led through the buoy well within
its diameter to the anchorbow. Consequently it is not
possible for a vessels hull to foul. They should fit in
the port at changes of tide.
If the experiments prove to be successful the
buoy could be used in areas where it is not possible to
construct conventional berths and where there is
insufficient depth of water at existing berths a buoy
may be sited in deeper water to accommodate the larger
vessels.

Transcribed_Text:
FOR FIRST PUBLICATION MONDAY'S EVENINGS JULY 18th 1949.
BRITAIN LEADS WORL IN MOTOR RUSTPROOFING TECHNIQUE
JS 18.7.49.

Morris cars coming off the assembly lines at Cowley, Oxfordshire,
are now receiving a 100% anti-rust treatment from a special plant
known as the "Rotodip" which, operated in conjunction with one of
the most up-to-date paint plants, forms an engineering project in
which Britain leads the whole world. Until the advent of this new
technique the procedure for finishing car bodies was to first
to thoroughly clean down the body to remove all grease, and to
finally rinse by hand or automatic spray, followed by a drying
process, after which the primer and finish coats of paints were
added by spray gun. This method, however, did never give complete
protection because many important parts of the body were never
reached.

Now the bodies go through the plant which consists of a tunnel
some 20 feet square and 300 feet long, which they enter in the
plain steal, greasy state, and emerge some 1½ hours later having
been cleaned, rustproofed, and primer-painted inside and out,
entirely automatically. For their journey through the plant, the
bodies are mounted on a revolving spit with the bonnet, wings and
boot in position but spaced-inch from the body to allow free
circulation, and is then carried broadside through the length of
the plant on conveyor chains in such a way that the body revolves
on its own axis while passing through the machine. The process
is in two stages - first rustproofing by cleaning, rinsing and
proofing for which the bodies pass through six large tanks, and
secondly, primer-painting during which the body is dried in an
oven, cooled down, and painted.
This series of pictures illustrates the remarkable process which
the Morris engineers are confident will protect the bodies
against corrosion and paint flaking.

Police chief
hurt in riot

TWO HUNDRED police battled with demonstrators
outside a factory last night. Nine demonstrators
were arrested and three policemen were injured.
One of the injured police-
men was 52-year-old Mr.
Tom Walker, deputy chief
constable of Stockport,
Cheshire.
He was taken to hospital
with a broken arm and a
chest injury.
The battle between police
and demonstrators started
outside the Roberts-Arundel
factory at Stockport during
a union protest meeting
against "American
methods."
Tempers flared among the
1,000 at the meeting after
union officials claimed that
automated production
methods introduced at the
American-owned factory
were "a threat to British
trade unionism."
Later, as the crowd surged
towards the factory gates
which were guarded by
police, union officials ap-
pealed for order.

PICKETS
Mr. Walter Burke, the
shop stewards' convenor at
the factory, said : “The
trouble started because the
police shoved our lads
against the wall when they
were trying to picket em-
ployees coming out of the
factory.
“If we had been allowed
to talk to the people at the
factory there would have
been no fuss. But police
came here determined not to
let us near them.”
Mr. Burke added: “Six
policemen got hold of one
lad, pulled him by the
hair and banged his head
on the police van door. Then
they flung him into the van.”
Disputes began at the fac-
tory 18 months ago when it
was taken over by an Ameri-
can textile firm.
In November 140 men
went on strike and were
dismissed by the firm.
Then the A.E.U. declared
the firm “black.” Union
pickets have been on duty
outside the factory gates for
12 weeks.

ART MOVES OUT... AND THE
PROPERTY MEN MOVE IN
C CHELSEA, once a name to be mentioned with the Paris
Left Bank and New York's Greenwich Village, has
become too fashionable and too expensive for artists.
Many have gone to Battersea and Fulham as property developers
have bought their premises.
ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚Â¢ The latest victim is the
Chelsea Pottery, where the
general manager is Peter
Gillam. The art is moved
out and a new Chelsea
Pottery. Mr. Gillam says:
"He will move the pottery
to another site. He says:
"It's the best of both
worlds. He says:
"It will be a 'Chelsea'
Pottery in every sense."
He says: "It's a step
in the right direction."
Mr. Gillam has been
working on his plan for
the past five years.
He says: "We're moving
from the King's Road
to a new site at Fulham."
"It's a very big move."
"We have to move all our
kilns, our clay, our
equipment. It's a massive
operation."
The lease on his King's
Road premises expires on
June 24. A spokesman for
the landlord, George
Rylands, says: "It's a
good time to buy. Prices
have gone up by 25 per
cent in the last year
alone."
Other Chelsea-based
art ventures are also
moving out. The
Chelsea Art School
has closed, and the
Chelsea College of
Art has bought new
premises in Clapham.
The Chelsea Theatre
School is also on the
move. A spokesman
for the school says:
"We're looking at
sites in south-east
London."
There is also a decline
in the number of art
galleries in Chelsea.
Many have closed, and
others have moved
further east to Mayfair
or west to Kensington.
"It's a sad day for
Chelsea," says Mr. Gillam.
"We've been here for
25 years, and it's always
been a great place for
artists. But it's just
not practical anymore."

CHELSEA, once a name to be mentioned with the Paris
Left Bank and New York's Greenwich Village, has
become too fashionable and too expensive for artists.
Many have gone to Battersea and Fulham as property developers
have bought their premises.
The latest victim is the
Chelsea Pottery, where such
diverse characters as Peter
Ustinov (this pot is rever-
ently preserved), monocled
actress Heather Thatcher
and transatlantic balloonist
"Bushy" Elloart, have
messed about with clay.
The lease on this former
coachworks in Radnor-walk,
off King's-road, expires on Sat-
urday.
Then unless a last-ditch
move to rouse public opinion is
successful, the kilns, the pot-
tery wheels and a vast assort-
ment of bowls, vases, animals
and figures will have to go to
make way for a block of luxury
flats.

Mrs. Richard Rossiter, who had
