SIX CHILDREN, THE ELDEST ONLY EIGHT YEARS
OLD, ARE CRYING PITIFULLY IN NORTH
MIDDLESEX HOSPITAL, EDMONTON, N., FOR THEIR
MOTHER, MRS. GRACE SMITH, WHO VANISHED
AFTER LEAVING THEM AT A HOUSE IN ENFIELD ON
FRIDAY.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Be good till mummy comes back,Ã¢â‚¬Â were her last words
to them. Ernest, the eldest, had seen her weeping earlier in
the day.

But where is she now?
The police have sent out detailed descriptions of her.
She is only 34 years old, about
3ft. 6in. tall, slim, has dark brown
bobbed hair, a pleasant expression,
but looks rather worried.

Stockingless

When last seen she wore neither hat
nor stockings, but was fashionably
dressed in a brown frock trimmed with
a yellow woollen collar, and white shoes.
The story of her last moments with
the children was told to the "Daily
Herald" yesterday by Mrs. Richard
Rossiter, of Percival-road, Enfield.

"About half-past two on Friday,"
she said, "Mrs. Smith knocked at my
door and asked for her father, Mr.
John Curtis, who used to live here. She
appeared to get a shock when I told
her he had left.

"Then she said her car had broken
down, and would I look after her children
until it was repaired. She assured me
that she would return for her family in
10 or 15 minutes.

"Before she went away she lifted the
children, four boys and two girls, on to
a sofa, saying, 'Be good till mummy
comes back.'"

Sent For Police

Next morning she sent for the police,
and the children were taken to hospital.
They said that their mother had
worked as a barmaid in a Sudbury
hotel; that two weeks ago Mrs. came
and took away all the furniture at their
home and that they slept on the floor.
Then they went to live at Elstree.
Their father is said to be an unem.

pendent for his Parliamentary majority,

plan for putting things right.

be buried for five years. At the end of

Transcribed_Text:
HERALD
SEVEN firemen were in
seriously, and 11 oth-
flying glass when an expi
in Collier's Wood, S.W., las
Neighbouring works were
shattered. Roofs were
stripped, walls blasted and
ceilings blown down in 22
cottages.
Windows and doors caved in a
quarter of a mile away.
The firemen were fighting an
outbreak at the British Gener-
ators, Ltd., in the High-street,
when the flames spread to an
acetylene cylinder.
Sub-officer Jenkins carried the
cylinder up from the basement
into the factory yard. Thirty
seconds later it exploded.

Like a bomb
Mr. R. Robins, proprietor of the
Royal Standard Hotel, said: "The
explosion was terrific, like a
bomb."
Mr. F. H. Clements, proprietor
of the Red Lion, said: "The doors
of my Lotei 200 yards away were
blown open. The damage might
have been caused by a V2."
Hundreds of people rushed to
the works and watched as
stretcher-bearers brought out the
injured.
Frames were held up in a quarter-
mile line. One of them, which
had been emptied of its passengers
just before reaching the works,
was shattered by the explosion.
Late last night the 22 families in
damaged Waterfall Cottages were
patching their homes with wood
from the wreckage and shovelling
debris into the road.

Home gone
White-haired Mrs. L. Few
opened up her grocery shop to
supply them with new gas mantles
Caretakers of British Genera-
tors, Mr. Ron. Butler, aged 51, and
his wife, Jean, 41, who live in a
flat above the factory, lost their
home.
Next door, Mr. and Mrs. Robert
Courteen, of the Waterfall Laun-
dry, returned two hours after the
explosion to find their home and
furniture wrecked.
Leading fireman James Gibb,
who went through all the London
blitzes, found that his home in
Waterfall-road had "received as
good a blitzing as I have ever
seen."
Mrs. Louise Senior, aged 72, who
was ill in bed next door to the
factory, was buried beneath debris
but dug out uninjured.

185475-78 HM
"THE 'CROWNING GLORY'" - AS SUPPLIED BY BRITAIN'S
HEALTH SCHEME.

London: A woman's crowning glory is her hair, so the
more male is led to believe - but like other feminine
charms these days, it may be false. In part or in whole,
Britain's comprehensive Health Service, aids and abets
the deception regarding hair, and teeth, but few would
deny the benefits it confers on both male and female.
Over eight thousand people have taken advantage of free
wigs obtained under the health scheme, and although the
number of women applying is not known, a considerable
number of the applicants are believed to be men who
have lost all or part of their 'crowning glory'.
Of the applicants some 2,500 have so far been supplied
with wigs. One well-known London firm of wig-makers
who export a considerable number of wigs to the United
States each month, have had 1,500 National Health
Service customers up to date, against their monthly
average of 50 private customers.

reading clover fingers and a sharp eye, for when men
compete with nature, nature usually wins, and to make
a wig which will deceive at close quarters is more than
difficult.
Most of the hair used for wig-making is obtained from
Western Europe, Italy, France and Germany contributing
a great part. Prices of the hair varies according to
the quality and colour, and this price affects the
cost of the finished wig. The most expensive wigs to
buy, owing to the difficulty of obtaining the hair, is
a white one, the price of which lies between 25 and 100
pounds.
PHOTO ADVICE: With skillful hands June Jackson and Irene
Wall knot hair into wigs. Apart from wigs supplied by
the Health Scheme and wigs for private customers, wig-
makers do a lot of work for stage and films.

Transcribed_Text:
186475-78 HUM
THE 'CROWNING GLORY' - AS SUPPLIED BY BRITAIN'S
HEALTH SCHEME.

London: A woman's crowning glory is her hair, so the
mere male is led to believe - but like other feminine
charms these days, it may be false, in part or in whole.
Britain's comprehensive Health Service aids and abets
the deception regarding hair, and teeth, but few would
deny the benefits it confers on both male and female.
Over eight thousand people have taken advantage of free
wigs obtained under the health scheme, and although the
number of women applying is not known, a considerable
number of the applicants are believed to be women who
have lost all or part of their 'crowning glory'.
Of the applicants some 2,600 have so far been supplied
with wigs. One well-known London firm of wig-makers,
who export a considerable number of wigs to the United
States each month, have had 1,500 National Health
Service customers up to date, against their monthly
average of 50 private customers.
The making of wigs is a complicated and skilled art,
needing clever fingers and a sharp eye, for when man
competes with nature, nature usually wins, and to make
a wig which will deceive at close quarters is more than
difficult.
Most of the hair used for wig-making is obtained from
Western Europe; Italy, France and Germany contributing
a great part. Prices of the hair varies according to
the quality and colour, and this price affects the
cost of the finished wig. The most expensive wig to
buy, owing to the difficulty of obtaining the hair, is
a white one, the price of which lies between 25 and 100
pounds.
PHOTO SHOWS: With skillful hands June Jackson and Iren
Kadd knot hair into wigs. Apart from wigs supplied by
the Health Scheme and wigs for private customers, wig-
makers do a lot of work for stage and films.
3rd. August, 1949 PN-d.

- 3 AUG 1949 RBCA

Transcribed_Text:
1983-5206/48416
Plants.. Trees.. Fruit Apples

O NE of the most pleas-
ing jobs in the garden
is picking your own
fruit. Even a small garden
should have a few apple
and pear trees.

Many gardeners, however,
make the mistake of ordering
standard or half-standard
trees, which are best suited
for an orchard.

These take up far too much
room, produce an unusable
glut of fruit and are difficult
to prune and spray.

Apple and pear trees can
now be bought to fit the space
available, thanks to modern
methods of grafting on dwarf-
ing root stocks.

Dwarf bush
Take for example apple and
pear cordon trees. These are
grown in the form of a single,
slim, main stem with short,
fruiting branches. These trees
can be planted only 3½ft.
apart, either in a row to form
a division between the flower
and vegetable garden or run-
ning alongside a path.

The next size is the dwarf
pyramid which calls for 4ft.
between trees, followed by a
dwarf bush (apples) at 12ft. to
15ft. apart or semi-dwarf bush
(apples) at 15ft. to 18ft. apart.
Having decided how many
trees you can find room for,
the next question is which
varieties to order. You can
have early, mid-season and
late-ripening.

Perhaps the most important
point to bear in mind is that
many fruit trees, certainly
apples, must have a suitable
" mate" growing nearby so
that cross-pollination of the
blossom takes place. Other-
wise little or no fruit.

To help you in your choice,
here are the best varieties for
garden culture:
EATING APPLES: Laxton's
Advance (Aug.), James Grieve
(Sept.), Lord Lambourne
(Oct.), Egremont Russet
(Nov.), Sunset (Nov.), Ribston

' Mating' is all-important. The
right half of this apple tree wasn't
cross-pollinated. Result: no fruit.

Pippin (Dec.), Adams Pear-
main (Jan.), Sturmer Pippin
(Apr.).
COOKING APPLES: Arthur
Turner (July), Geo. Neal
(Sept.), Rev. Wilks (Oct.),
Lane's Prince Albert (Nov.-
Jan.), Bramley Seedling
(dwarf bush) (Oct.-Mar.).
EATING PEARS: Williams
Bon Chretien (Sept.), Confer-
ence (Oct.), Packhams
Triumph (Nov.), Josephine de
Malines (Jan.).
COOKING PEARS: Im-
proved Fertility (Dec.-Jan.),
Bellisime d'Hiver (Oct.-Mar.).

FOR FIRST PUBLICATION THURSDAY JUNE 12TH
FIRST MOBILE OIL DRILLING PLATFORM IN U.K.
12.6.58.
WORK PROGRESSES IN THE CONSTRUCTION OF THE FIRST MOBILE
OIL DRILLING PLATFORM IN THE UNITED KINGDOM, BEING BUILT
AT THE STEEL STRUCTURES LTD. WORKS WHICH WERE CREATED IN
TWO MONTHS AT SOUTHAMPTON.
THE PLATFORM WILL BE READY FOR LAUNCHING BY THE END OF THIS
MONTH, SIX MONTHS SINCE WORK BEGAN. FROM AUGUST THE
SHELL COMPANY WILL USE IT FOR DRILLING OPERATIONS
OFF BORNEO. IT IS DESIGNED FOR TOWING HALFWAY ROUND THE
WORLD AND FOR OPERATIONS IN 125 FT. OF WATER.
THE DE LONG CORPORATION OF AMERICA ORDERED THE PLATFORM NORTH
SEA, FROM STEEL STRUCTURED LTD., ONE OF THE HOWARD GROUP OF
COMPANIES. THE OTHER TWO PLATFORMS IN EUROPE WERE ALSO
ORDERED BY THE DE LONG CORPORATION FROM GERMANY. BRITAIN'S
FARED GERMAN COMPETITION IN TIME AND COST. SOUTHAMPTON WAS
CHOSEN AS THE SITE BECAUSE OF ITS PROXIMITY TO THE CONTINENT
(THE BULK OF STEEL WILL BE IMPORTED FROM GERMANY) AND ALSO FOR
ITS GOOD PORT HANDLING FACILITIES.
STATISTICS: 3,000 TONS OF STEEL USED; 190 FT. LONG; 106 FT.
WIDE; 16 FEET DEEP; AIR-CONDITIONED ACCOMMODATION
FOR DRILL CREW OF 30; DRILLING CAPACITY OF 15,000FT
BELLAM SEA BED HELICOPTER PLATFORM; HULL HAS FOUR
LEGS WHICH CAN BE RETRACTED TO TOW AWAY TO ANOTHER
POSITION.
PIE'D SHOTS: RECENT PICTURE TAKEN AT SOUTHAMPTON SHOWS
WORKMEN WELDING STIFFENING RINGS IN 10FT.
DIAMETER TUBES. THE RINGS FORM THE 175FT. LEGS
OF THE PLATFORM.

SHILLINGS N.Z., WILL BE THE MAIN UNIT. THE
DOLLAR WILL BE DIVIDED INTO 100 CENTS, EACH
WORTH 1.2 PENCE.

SIX COINS ARE BEING MINTED, THE ONE AND TWO
CENT PIECES OF BRONZE, AND THE FIVE, TEN,
TWENTY AND FIFTY CENT PIECES OF CUPRO-NICKEL.
IN ADDITION ABOUT HALF A MILLION COMMEMORATIVE
DOLLAR COINS, ALSO OF CUPRO-NICKEL, ARE
BEING STRUCK.

THE DESIGNS FOR THE REVERSE OF THE COINS
WERE DECIDED BY THE GOVERNMENT AFTER A LONG
PUBLIC CONTROVERSY OVER THE SELECTION FROM
A WIDE VARIETY OF DESIGNS. ALL SIX OF THE
MAIN COINS WERE DESIGNED BY A NEW ZEALAND
ARTIST, MR. JAMES BERRY, OF WELLINGTON. THE
DESIGN OF THE REVERSE OF THE COMMEMORATIVE
DOLLAR WAS PREPARED BY MR. WILLIAM GARDNER,
A.S.R.C.A., F.S.I.A. OF WITTERSHAM, KENT. THE
OBVERSE OF ALL SEVEN COINS-CARRIES THE NEW
EFFIGY OF THE QUEEN BY MR. ARNOLD MACHIN,
R.A., OF LONDON, AND APPROVED BY HER MAJESTY
IN 1964.

is nearing completion at the plant of the Bristol Aeroplane
Company at Filton, Bristol.
Designed to be the aerial counterpart of the 'Queen Elizabeth'-
and to travel seven seas' - the plane is the 'Ambassador'.
The gigantic machine of which are almost ready for final assembly.
It is expected that the 130-ton monster will take the air
for the first time in May or June and may upon
deliveries to owner will be flying in the London-New York service
of British Overseas Airways by 1948.
The Ambassador is a low-altitude, long-range sleeping airliner
comprising which will accommodate up to 100 sleeping passengers
or 130 sitting passengers in the utmost comfort.
The plane could pull 10,000 payload to maintain an equivalent
gross minimum of 3,000 feet with flying at 25,000 feet.
This will render it, including fuel records.
Dimensions of the aircraft is 230 feet - almost twice that
of Britain's largest bomber, the Avro Lincoln - and the height
from the ground is 70 feet.
Eight Bristol "Theseus" 4-cylinder, sleeve-valve, air-cooled
turbine engines, each rated at 5,000 brake horsepower for
take-off, will give a maximum level speed of over 300
miles an hour at 25,000 feet, an economical cruising speed
of 300 miles an hour at the same altitude, and a staging range

Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/42274

126-TON 'BRABAZON' NEARS COMPLETION, WILL FLY THIS SUMMER.

Under the hands of 700 workers, the world's biggest landplane
is nearing completion at the plant of the Bristol Aeroplane
Company at Filton, Bristol.
Designed to be the aerial counterpart of the 'Queen Elizabeth' -
world's greatest ocean liner - the plane is the 'Brabazon I'
the gigantic sections of which are almost ready for final assembly.
It is expected that the 126-ton monster will take the air
for the first time in May or June and that three other
Brabazons on order will be flying on the London-New York service
of British Overseas Airways by 1950.
The Brabazon is a high-altitude, long-range low-wing cantilever
monoplane which will accommodate 70 to 100 sleeping passengers
or 120 sitting passengers in the utmost comfort. The
143-feet cabin will be pressurised to maintain an equivalent
cabin altitude of 8,000 feet while flying at 25,000 foot.
Crew will number 13, including five stewards.
Wingspan of the aircraft is 230 feet - almost twice that
of Britain's largest bomber, the Avro Lincoln - and the hoight
over the rudder is 50 foot.
Eight Bristol 'Centaurus' 18-cylinder, sleeve-valve, air-cooled
radial engines, each rated at 2,500 brake horsepower for
take-off, will give a maximum level speed of more than 300
miles an hour at 25,000 foot, an economical cruising speed
of 200 miles an hour at the same altitude, and a still-air range
of 5,000 miles. Initial service ceiling will be 25,000 foot,
increasing as fuel is consumed.
PHOTO SHOWS.- A general view in the Brabazon's workshop at
Filton. Contro foreground is one of the hugo outer wing soctions
and on right is the loading edge of the wing. Loft background
is the mighty fusolago.
AND March 31st 1947 P.M..

34 SIPS OF
CIDER
FAIL HIM
Herald Reporter
BRISTOL, Thursday.
HARRY PHILLIPS, 58-
year-old bespectacled
boiler-maker, of Ebbs Vale,
and Monmouth County
Councillor, is a man with a
mission.

He took a gulp of strong
rough cider while haymaking on a
Welsh hill farm as a boy. He has
been searching for a smooth, sweet
cider.

"If only the right blend of
sweetness could be found it might
take the place of beer in all the
pubs in Monmouth," he says.

Shade too sharp

So today the Ebbs Vale boiler-
maker went to Bristol for the
annual cider-tasting day at the
Long Ashton Agricultural Re-
search station. With growers and
cider experts from all parts of the
country, he sniffed and sipped 34
glasses of sharp bitter-sweet and
sweet varieties.

Clearing his palate with a piece
of dry biscuit after each taste, Mr.
Phillips tried hard to find his
ideal, but his taste was too dis-
cerning.

Even those with fine sounding
names such as Foxwhelp, Chisel
Jersey, Dymock Red, and Pisley
Hangdown, brought the same com-
ment. "No, it's just a shade too
sharp. It's the tang I don't like."

Lot to tell

Shaking his head as he left, he
said, "I've a lot to tell our educa-
tion committee, but I don't think
I found the cider I have been look-
ing for."

Prof. Bertie T. P. Barker, past
director of the Institute, told the
experts of experiments to cure
"cider sickness," which ruins the
taste and aroma of sweet cider. It
is caused by a family of microbes
which experts have been trying to
isolate since 1907.

His tip to cider makers was:
"Hand as soon as possible with
a sharp cider with a high acid
content."

Herald
right
legraph.
-544-1

AGENT

Day at Song Ashton
Bristol

R.C. Ridley of Chelford

AGENT

4-2

Ridley. Wastling

34 SIPS OF
CIDER
FAIL HIM
Herald Reporter
BRISTOL, Thursday.
HARRY PHILLIPS, 58-
year-old bespectacled
boiler-maker, of Ebbw Vale,
and Monmouth County
Councillor, is a man with a
mission.
Since he took a gulp of strong
rough cider while haymaking on a
Welsh hill farm as a boy, he has
been searching for a smooth, sweet
cider.
"If only the right blend of
sweetness could be found it might
take the place of beer in all the
pubs in Monmouth," he says.

Shade too sharp
So today the Ebbw Vale boiler-
maker went to Bristol for the
annual cider-tasting day at the
Long Ashton Agricultural Re-
search station. With growers and
cider experts from all parts of the
country, he sniffed and sipped 34
glasses of sharp bitter-sweet and
sweet varieties.
Clearing his palate witt a piece
of dry biscuit after each taste, Mr.
Phillips tried hard to find his
ideal, but his taste was too dis-
cerning.
Even those with fine sounding
names such as Foxwhelp, Chisel
Jersey, Dymock Red, and Pixley
Hangdown, brought the same com-
ment. "No, it's just a shade too
sharp.fl Its the tang I don't like."

Lot to tell
Shaking his head as he left, he
said, "I've a lot to tell our educa-
tion committee, but I don't think
I found the cider I have been look-
ing for."
Prof. Bertie T. P. Barker, past
director of the Institute, told the
experts of experiments to cure
"cider sickness," which ruins the
taste and aroma of sweet cider. It
is caused by a family of microbes
which experts have been trying to
isolate since 1907.
His tip to cider makers was:
"Blend as soon as possible with
a sharp cider with a high acid
content."

TO LOOK FOR LABOUR.

LONDON. Battersea Power Station, first modern
power station in London, will soon be London's
biggest electricity producer. Situated on the
south bank of the Thames, between Chelsea
and Battersea railway bridges, this 25 million
pound station, is getting into its stride.

FILE - Indus - Fuel & Power - ELECTRICITY - Power Stations - BATTERSEA
1983 - S236/S0936

8410 AND LONDON BUREAU
NEW LOOK FOR LANDMARK.
LONDON: Battersea Power Station, first modern
power station built in London and massive landmark
familiar to Continental travellers arriving at
Victoria Station, is getting a new look.......
another chimney. Towering above railway lines and
river, the chimney is rapidly stretching up to the
337 feet of its three fellows. The power station
consists of two parts. Construction of the second
part was held up by the war and post-war shortages.
The new chimney will complete this second section.
Combined capacity of the two sections will be
503,000 kilowatts.
Power Stations are often blamed for the killing smog
which grips London during the fog season. (the
City of London has decided to obtain statutory
powers to reduce smoke in the City) but Battersea
and other modern power stations can plead 'not guilty'.
The towering chimneys emit no smoke, only steam
and vapour, for they are fitted with gas washing
and grit arresting plant.
PHOTO SHOWS: The view of Battersea Power Station,
with the new chimney on the right, seen from a
nearby gasholder - the tallest in London. Landmarks
cutting the skyline (in background) are the tower of
Westminster Cathedral (left); Westminster and Big Ben
(above new chimney) and St. Paul's Cathedral (right).
September, 1953 PN-d.

-

-
Washing Machines.

FOR FIRST PUBLICATION THURSDOYS DAILES FEB 25TH

BOOMING BRITAIN

JS 23.2.60
THE MASS PRODUCTION OF WASHING MACHINES MAY BE SAID TO TYPIFY
THE BOOM WHICH BRITAIN IS EXPERIENCING TODAY, AND WHERE THE
BETTER CAN THE LARGEST OF THE FACTORIES PRODUCING THIS HOUSEWIVES
BE SITUATED THAN IN THE ONCE DEPRESSED AREA OF MERTHYR TYDFIL,
IN SOUTH WALES, HERE IN THIS VALLEY, WHERE THE LOCAL POPLACE
ONCE DEPENDED FOR ITS LIVING ON THE IRONWORKS - LONG SINCE
DISMANTLED - AND THE FAMOUS STEAM-COAL. AND WHERE DURING THE
PRE-WAR DEPRESSION 80 OUT OF EVERY 100 WERE OUT OF A JOB, NEW
LIGHT INDUSTRIES HAVE BEEN ENCOURAGED DURING POST-WAR YEARS,
BUT IT IS STILL ONE OF THE BLACK NAMED BY THE GOVERNMENT AND
TO WHICH THEY WILL TRY TO ATTRACT NEW INDUSTRY, FOR EVEN NOW
THE UNEMPLOYMENT IS FOUR AND A HALF PER CENT OF THE WORKING
POPULATION - MORE THAN TWICE THE NATIONAL AVERAGE.
THIS PROBLEM, HOWEVER, IS BEING HELPED BY THE
GREAT HOOVER FACTORY AT MERTHYR, WHERE WASHING MACHINES ARE TURNED
OUT AT THE EXTRAORDINARY FIGURE OF ONE EVERY 20 SECONDS OF THE
DAY AND NIGHT ON ONE OF THE MOST UP-TO-DATE ASSEMBLY EVER
REVISED, OUTPUT OF WASHING MACHINES, VACUUM CLEANERS, AND OTHER
HOME APPLIANCES BY THE HOOVER ENTERPRISE WAS DOUBLED IN 1959,
AND CONFIDENCE IN 1960 AND THE FUTURE IS DEMONSTRATED BY THE
FACT THAT THEY ARE TO SPEND £2,000,000 ON A FURTHER EXPANSION
OF THE FACTORY.
TODAY, WEDNESDAY, THE HOOVER DIRECTORS WILL
PRODUCE THEIR FIGURES AND REVEAL THEIR FINANCIAL DIVIDEND
PAYMENTS IN THEIR REPORT TO SHAREHOLDERS.
THIS PICTURE IS ONE OF A SERIES JUST TAKEN
AT THE GREAT HOOVER FACTORY AT MERTHYR TYDFIL, AND SHOWS
MEN ASSEMBLING THE HOOVERMATIC WASHING MACHINE AND SPIN
DRYER.

SORTING NEWSPAPERS ON THE NIGHT SPECIAL

AN EXPERIMENT STARTED RECENTLY BY
A JOINT GROUP OF WHOLESALE NEWSAGENTS IN PORTSMOUTH,
SOUTHSEA, AND CUSTOMERS IN THE VILLAGES AROUND
ROMSEY AND THE SOUTH COAST ARE RECEIVING THEIR
BUNDLES OF NEWSPAPERS AN HOUR EARLIER THAN THE
OLD METHOD.

THE FIRM, WHITS AND DISTRIBUTION
CENTRE AT DEREFORD, HAVE ONE CONTRACTOR WITH
BRITISH RAILWAYS FOR THEIR OWN SORTING CARRIAGE
WHICH IS ATTACHED TO THE END OF THE 10.00 PM FROM
LONDON BRIDGE EACH NIGHT. ONE OF THE MEMBERS
OF THE DISTRIBUTION STAFF SORT THE NEWSPAPERS
INTO THE REQUIRED BUNDLES (ABOUT 10,000 PAPERS
NIGHTLY) AND BY THE TIME THE TRAIN ARRIVES AT
PORTSMOUTH TWO HOURS LATER THE NEWSPAPERS ARE READY
FOR DELIVERY BY THE 0.25 AM WHITS WAITING.

THIS SHOWS A SAVING IN TIME OF
OVER AN HOUR, FOR THE NEWSPAPERS WERE PREVIOUSLY
TAKEN TO THE REGIONAL DISTRIBUTION CENTRE WHERE
THEY WERE SORTED AND BUNDLED.

IT IS SOMEWHAT SIMILAR TO THE
G.P.O. 'A PARCEL SPECIAL' FOR THE DELIVERY OF
MAIL - AND IT IS BELIEVED TO BE THE FIRST TIME
THAT SUCH AN OPERATION HAS BEEN CARRIED OUT WITH
NEWSPAPERS ON A TRAIN GOING A LONG RUN.

THE NEWSPAPERS AT WORK ON THE TRAIN COUNTING OUT
PAPERS FROM BUNDLES (AS DELIVERED BY THE VARIOUS
NEWSPAPER OFFICES AT LONDON BRIDGE) AND MAKING
THEM READY FOR DELIVERY BY THEIR OWN VANS (BUNDLES
ON RIGHT) ON ARRIVAL AT PORTSMOUTH.

THEY SERVE WHAT LOOKS LIKE CHRISTCHURCH, LYMINGTON,
NEW ROMNEY AND LITTLESTONE HALL WITH THEIR MORNING
PAPERS IN THE SOUTHAMPTON AREA.  MR. ADDISON (PORTSMOUTH) LEFT
LONDON BRIDGE AT 10.00PM ON THE "NIGHT MAIL" TRAIN,
WHICH TRAVELS UP TO LONDON ON THE 11.55PM SOUTH COAST
NIGHT AND GOES AGAIN ON THE 0.25 PM "SPECIAL" TRAIN.
AM.30 OXFORD PRESS 13/1/54 JOHN HORNER

FOR FIRST PUBLICATION THURSDAY'S EVENING, July 26th.,
SILK NEWS THAT HELP BRITAIN'S EXPORTS
24.7.47.
A BRIEF but very important aid to British export trade is
being given by about six million silk worms which are being
reared at Lullingstone Castle Silk Farm, run by COM. LAIRDLAN MACDONALD, near Tonbridge, Kent. The ai and object of the
farm, which is now getting going again after the war, is to
develop and assist production of raw silk in this country, the
Dominions, and the Colonies, and what started off as a girl's
hobby, developed on a business footing in 1929, is now a
flourishing industry housed in one of Britain's ancient homes.
The Lullingstone silk-worms are known all over the world for
millions of them have been exported, and it was from their silk
that the Coronation robes for the Queen and the Princesses
were made. One of the difficulties at present being ex-
perienced is the lack of mulberry leaves on which to feed
the worms, for the eighteen acre plantations at Lullingstone
is only producing about half the number of leaves required
to feed six million tiny mouths.
It is interesting to note that the method of using the silk
weapon for spinning and weaving was first known in China at
least 3,000 years B.C. It was James I who endeavoured to
encourage silk worm rearing in this country by ordering the
importation and planting of thousands of mulberry trees, but
the Royal scheme was a failure. George 7 then took a keen
interest in the silk industry and in 1718 he granted a
patent to a certain John Appleton for silkworm rearing.
Striking down a batch of cocoons to find the leading
threads for the reeling machine after reeling.

FOR FIRST PUBLICATION THURSDAY'S EVENINGS, July 24th.,

SILK WORMS THAT HELP BRITAIN'S EXPORTS
24.7.47.
A small but very important aid to British export trade is
being given by about six million silk worms which are being
reared at Lullingstone Castle Silk Farm, run by ZOE, LADY
HART DYKE, near Eynsford, Kent. The aim and object of the
farm, which is now getting going again after the war, is to
develop and assist production of raw silk in this country, the
Dominions, and the Colonies, and what started off as a girl's
hobby, developed on a business footing in 1932, is now a
flourishing industry housed in one of Britain's ancient homes.
The Lullingstone silkworms are known all over the world for
millions of them have been exported, and it was from their silk
that the Coronation Robes for the Queen and the Princesses
were made. One of the difficulties at present being ex-
perienced is the lack of mulberry leaves on which to feed
the worms, for the eighteen acre plantation at Lullingstone
is only producing about half the number of leaves required
to feed six million tiny mouths.
It is interesting to note that the method of using the silk
cocoon for spinning and weaving was first known in China at
least 5,000 years B.C. It was James I who endeavoured to
encourage silk worm rearing in this country by ordering the
importation and planting of thousands of mulberry trees, but
the Royal scheme was a failure. George I then took a keen
interest in the silk industry and in 1718 he granted a
patent to a certain John Appleton for silkworm rearing.
Shaking down a batch of cocoons to find the leading
threads for the reeling machine after boiling.

SHALE FOR SITE OF NEW HOVERPORT.
Lorries unloading shale from Chislet Colliery, Kent, at Pegwell Bay
where it will be used in the construction of the new international
hoverport. Half of Chislet's north west tip (about 150,000 cubic yards)
is being removed to form the base for the 12-acre landing and
launching pad.
Both black and red shales, which conform to Ministry of Transport
specifications for general fill, are obtainable from colliery sites.
The red shale - which has been used extensively for road making - is
becoming scarce but the black shales of the type used at Pegwell Bay
are in plentiful supply.
The National Coal Board sell shale from site and contractors are
responsible for collection. Contractors operating on colliery sites
have to conform with the Board's regulations regarding work on tips, but
the Board will advise on methods of working.
More than 6 million tons of shale was sold from pithead sites last
year and the demand is increasing. A small section dealing with sales has
been set up under Mr. M. Little, Marketing Department, National Coal
Board, Hobart House, Grosvenor Place, London, S.W.1.

An enterprise which is enjoying the success is
well deserved is that begun by Mrs. F. Franklin
of Salisbury. Four years ago Mrs. Franklin had
no home, learned from her old friend in London, who
taught her the rudiments of the art of rush weaving.
She was highly skilled, but in the time available could
only glean a fraction of her knowledge on rush. Franklin
however, with the little she had learnt, Mrs. Franklin
with great determination, carried on to herself
this business, which she soon turned to the time when
rushes are spread on the floor for carpeting. Then
put any capital she took a little shop in East Street
Salisbury where she produced such articles as waste
paper baskets, table mats, seats for chairs and stools,
baskets for yoga, jugs, fruit, etc., all made from
platted rushes. These proved so popular that her business
is looking for larger premises. Mrs. Franklin collects
rushes herself, from the rivers of forest and elsewhere,
and she has had many dealings when parting or waiting to

to be dried and before being stored for subsequent use

Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/42508

A "RUSH" OF BUSINESS.

MJH/S. 28.

An enterprise which is enjoying the success it
well deserves is that begun by Mrs. N.E. Franklyn
of Salisbury. Four years ago, Mrs. Franklyn had
an hour's lesson from an old man in London, who
taught her the rudiments of the art of rush weaving.
He was highly skilled, but in the time available could
only pass on a fraction of his knowledge to Mrs. Franklyn.
However, with the little she had learnt, Mrs. Franklyn
with great determination, carried on to teach herself
this ancient craft, which goes back to the time when
rushes were spread on the floor for carpeting. Then
without any capital she took a little shop in East Street
(Salisbury) where she produced such articles as waste
paper baskets, table mats, seats for chairs and stools,
baskets for `ogs, dogs, fruit etc. etc. all made from
plaited rushes. These proved so popular that her business
steadily grew until today she employs a staff of four
and is looking for larger premises. Mrs. Franklyn collects
the rushes herself, from the rivers of Dorset and elsewhere,
and she has had many ducklings when rowing or wading to
harvest them. After the rushes have been cut, they have
to be dried out before being stored for subsequent use
and must be very carefully handled to prevent damage.
As far as can be ascertained, it is believed that there are
only two other businesses like Mrs. Franklyn's in the
whole country.

PHOTOGRAPH SHOWS: MRS. N.E. FRANKLYN seen practising
the ancient craft of rush weaving at her premises in
East Street, Salisbury, while her pet dog sits in a
basket made from rushes by his mistress. Mrs. Franklyn's wares are all in their lovely natural
colours of pastel gold green and yellow.

150,000 VOLT SUBMARINE POWER CABLE FOR VANCOUVER.
At their Trafford Park, Manchester, factory, British
Insulated Callender's Cables, Ltd., have completed the
first stage of an order valued at over three million dollars,
for the supply and installation of 138,000-volt submarine cable
for the British Columbia Electric Company, to link their
high-voltage supply system in the southern part of Vancouver
Island, with the unexploited hydro-electric resources on the
mainland of British Columbia. The cable system consists of
single-core cables, each 16 miles in length, with similar
cables in nine long for the island-island section, four
inches in diameter and weighing 50lbs a yard, this will be
largest continuous long-length power cable ever installed.
Special testing and transport arrangements are necessary for
cables of this length and weight.

PHOTOGRAPH SHOWS. The main sight of approximately
61,000,000 worth of cable in one place at one time, seen
in the Calling Down Shed which has been specially built
for the storage of the nine submarine cables which have been
manufactured by British Insulated Callender's (Submarine Cable
Ltd. at Trafford Park, Manchester, for the British Columbia
Electric Company. This shed is 350 feet long, 74 feet wide,
and 43ft. 6ins. high, providing an unobstructed floor area
of some 26,000 square feet. Total weight of this cable is
3,000 tons.

DAILY
24 MAR 1961
HERALD
Canadian police say,
are the best forgeries they have
ever seen.

Found in the
spy HQ after
it was searched

By SIDNEY WILLIAMS

ALMOST as great a mystery in
the Krogers' activities in their
Ruislip House of Secrets was the
way in which MI 5 agents searched
the house for days—and then left
behind vital evidence.

It was left to a friend of Gordon
Arnold Lonsdale to uncover the evidence
which confirmed that Lonsdale was part
of the Portland spy ring—FIVE WEEKS
AFTER MI 5 MEN HAD CLEARED THE
HOUSE.

Mr. Michael Bowers, co-
director with Lonsdale in a
Sophisticated eering firm, found
forged Canadian pass-
ports produced at the
Bailey after he had been
authorised by Lonsdale to
pick up "personal" posses-
sions from the Kroger
bungalow.

With the passports were in-
structions explaining the mean-
ing of the various stamps in the
passports—so that if the Krogers
had to use them their stories
would be watertight.

Lonsdale wanted to stop MI 5
getting hold of the two perfect
forged counterfeit passports—faked for
the Krogers—by placing them in

8090

AN
2
1

the care of the unwitting Mr.
Bowers. But Mr. Bowers took
them to the police when he
found them—quite easily—by
tearing away a silk and card-
board lining inside a leather
writing wallet.

The passports have been sent
by Scotland Yard to the Royal
Canadian Mounted Police head-
quarters in Ottawa.

From Ottawa last night,
RCMP Deputy Commissioner
George McClahan spoke to me
on the telephone and expressed
amazement at the perfect detail
of the counterfeits.

"Only a laboratory test
showed that they were not the
real thing," he said. "The
watermarks and paper are first
class reproductions — the pass-
port numbers and issue dates
are the same as two which were
issued to two genuine people,
who did not know the Krogers."
"The watermarks, covers, seals
and binding thread are all coun-
terfeit.

The passports were
hidden in the lining
of a wallet found in
the Krogers' Ruislip
bungalow.

FRY, BRISTOL 13.8.46
SQUATTERS AT WHITE CITY CAMP, ASHTON GATE,
BRISTOL WHICH WAS FORMERLY AN ARMY CAMP
OPS. Mrs. Edna THOMPSON, aged 20, with her
6-weeks old son Raymond, cooking her
dinner over the stove which had been left
in the hut which she has taken over.
Her husband, Fred, is in the R.A.O.C.,
India and is due out next Feb. Mrs.
Thompson, who has been married 13 months,
has been unable to find accommodation
for herself and has been moving from
relative to relative.

File - General - Housing.
Service huts etc, seized by Homeless.
27 AUG 1946

FRY, BRISTOL 13.8.46
SQUATTERS AT WHITE CITY CAMP, ASHTON GATE,
BRISTOL WHICH WAS FORMERLY AN ARMY CAMP
OPS. Mr. and Mrs. PADFIELD outside the hut
(Nissen type) which they have taken
over. Mr. I. PADFIELD has been
demobbed since last April after serving
6½ years in the D.A.R. Regiment as
a Sgt, having seen service in Cairo,
Italy, France, Germany and Holland.
Having failed to find a place of their
own, they have been living in one room
since Mr. Padfield's discharge. They
have taken this step to solve their
troubles.

FRY, BRISTOL 13.8.46
SQUATTERS AT WHITE CITY CAMP, ASHTON GATE,
BRISTOL WHICH WAS FORMERLY AN ARMY CAMP
OPS. Mrs. THOMPSON moving in her bed for
tonight as she slept on a mattress
on the floor last night frightened

steel plate, 12,000 feet deep in the Pacific Ocean, where a team of
recently lost U.S. Navy and C.I.A. ships together with an Israeli
submarine are searching for a missing U.S. Navy sub. The USS SCOTCH
TAPE, a nuclear submarine. The sub vanished more than two years ago
in an area known only as "The Dragon's Triangle", a location notorious
for all the ships that have gone missing there for all time, and no
one knows what happened to them or the "Scotch Tape" or the crew of
129 men. It is believed to have been hit by a falling meteorite, which
apparently left a very long gash in the ocean floor that could lead
to the Earth's core. Most likely it was hit by another force, more
like the "The Bermuda Triangle" force, but no one on "The U.S. Scotch
Tape" would ever believe that, it was known to travel everywhere, and
these incidents were known to cause a catastrophic atmosphere, but no
one, absolutely no one, ever understood, sort of what it was and what
they did to them. No men or vessels or aircraft have ever been found.
And now there is a team searching for them but they have not found
them at all. What makes this so mysterious? We have no idea of what
is out there, but the pattern of without it is a "mysterious" force.

Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/59081

STRANDED EX-CONVICTS FIND A HOME IN A CHURCH
A NEW USE FOR EMPTY PEWS IN KENSINGTON

In the Royal Borough of Kensington there is a church where
every night stranded ex-prisoners and other unfortunate wrecks
of humanity find a place to sleep and call their temporary home.
In the gallery over the pews, and with a view of the altar and
the organ, they roll out their mattresses and get a peaceful
night's sleep, their washing strung out on a line from side to
side of this unusual place of worship. Theirstomachs are well
filled with sausage and mash cooked by one of their number in
the church kitchen. No charge is ever made for all this, and
many of them are enabled by thus having an "address" to get
public assistance and then employment - so difficult for a
man with nowhere to go when he leaves his prison after paying
society's price, or for those other men who have fallen on
hard times and for whom the Welfare State doesn't cater.
The Rev. Bertram Peake - known in the war as "The Tin Hat
Pastor"-who refused all honours for his work among the blitzed
Londoners,- has found this new use for his old church a
satisfactory continuation of his good, although to some minds,
unorthodox, work of caring for men's bodies as well as souls.
No man is refused at Golborne Church. No charge is made.
Men stay there on average six six weeks. For many hope and faith
are renewed, and jobs found before they move on. But there are
always more who come to take their place in the gallery of
comfort in this Kensington Church.

14.9.54

By ANTHONY CARTHEW

YOU could call her the Esther Williams of the chicken
run—a couple of lengths of the swimming pool
before breakfast and she's happy for the day. Why the
chicken run? Well, Esther
is a 14-week-old pullet.
But no ordinary pullet.
Esther's a chicken who can
swim.
She learned the art at the
tender age of nine weeks
when most pullets are fully
occupied with the business of
pecking an existence.
And her teachers? A couple
of brown, rather aloof ducks,
her best friends.
The swimming chicken's
story is a success story. When
she arrived at Four Winds
Farm in the little village of
Chedburgh, near Bury St.
Edmunds, Suffolk, she was a
week-old outcast. All the
other 99 pullets pecked her.

EFFORTLESS

Came Esther's turn to chirp
when Mr. John Plummer, the
30-year-old farmer and his
pretty 24-year-old wife Ann,
an ex-Land Army girl, put
Esther with the ducks for
safety.
"When with ducks, do as
ducks do," thought Esther
and in no time she had taken
to the pool and was swim-
ming as effortlessly as—a
duck.
Her feet move in the same
motion as the ducks' and
when she needs a rest from
swimming, up she goes on to
one of her friends' backs—a
down-covered raft.

When it's time to dry her
feathers out, the ducks get to
work with their beaks with a
system that must feel like the
chicken's idea of a Swedish
masseur.
So Esther's happy in her
pool. And she has the last
laugh on the 99 land-lubbing
pullets who used to peck her
back in the chicken run.
And she only cost a shilling
like the rest.

A GIFT VIEW WAS HELD THIS AFTERNOON OF
THE NORTHERN REFUGEE EQUIPMENT EXHIBITION WHICH OPENS
AT OLDHAM COURT ON SATURDAY.

DEMONSTRATION. YESTERDAY, THE NORTHERN CONGREGATION of the Latter-day Saints held a special demonstration at Oldham Court, which opened the Northern Refugee Exhibition yesterday, when they were able to raise Ãƒâ€šÃ‚Â£500 towards the Ãƒâ€šÃ‚Â£3,000 needed to purchase the house.

The exhibition, which will remain open for a fortnight, features a wide range of articles manufactured by the refugee workers, including garments, furnishings and toys. The organisers are appealing for the public to support the exhibition, which is aimed at assisting refugees from Europe.

The demonstration included a concert, a fashion show and a sale of goods. Many local dignitaries were present, including the Mayor of Oldham, Councillor James Mellor, who expressed his support for the exhibition.

The exhibition has already received a great deal of publicity, and the organisers are hopeful that it will be a great success. It is estimated that the exhibition will attract thousands of visitors, and the funds raised will go towards the purchase of the house at Oldham Court, which will be used to provide accommodation for refugees.

There are approximately 2,000 refugees in the United Kingdom who are in need of assistance, and the Northern Refugee Exhibition aims to provide them with a helping hand. The organisers are appealing for the public to donate generously to the cause.

cealed in their rightful place in

ALMOST as great a mystery as
the Krogers' activities in their
Ruislip House of Secrets was the
way in which MI 5 agents searched
the house for days—and then left
behind vital evidence.

It was left to a friend of Gordon
Arnold Lonsdale to uncover the evidence
which confirmed that Lonsdale was head
of the Portland spy ring—FIVE WEEKS
AFTER MI 5 MEN HAD CLEARED THE
HOUSE.

Mr. Michael Bowers, co-
director with Lonsdale in a
Soho engineering firm, found
the two forged Canadian
passports produced at the
Old Bailey after he had been
authorised by Lonsdale to
pick up "personal" posses-
sions from the Kroger
bungalow.

With the passports were in-
structions explaining the mean-
ing of the various stamps in the
passports—so that if the Krogers
had to use them their stories
would be watertight.

Lonsdale wanted to stop MI 5
getting hold of the two perfect
counterfeit passports—faked for
the Krogers—by placing them in

Bowers. But Mr. Bowers took
them to the police when he
found them—quite easily—by
tearing away a silk and card-
board lining inside a leather
writing wallet.

The passports have been sent
by Scotland Yard to the Royal
Canadian Mounted Police head-
quarters in Ottawa.

New Delhi:

description: A photographic print from the Daily Herald Archive folder: Industry ÃƒÆ’Ã¢â‚¬Å¡Ãƒâ€šÃ‚Â» Agriculture ÃƒÆ’Ã¢â‚¬Å¡Ãƒâ€šÃ‚Â» Ploughing - Radio Controlled.
output - gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20:
RADIO-CONTROLLED PLOUGH IS NEW HOPE FOR BRITISH FARMERS.

A radio-controlled farm tractor, developed by a British firm, (Tractors (London) Ltd.) in co-operation with the Automatic Control Section of the Royal Aeronautical Establishment is undergoing trials at recent, Hertfordshire.
Radio-control, normally used in the "power test", the target plane devised by anti-aircraft artillery practice, has been adapted for use in the tractor, which can be employed for ploughing and other farm operations.
Receiving radio signals operate sensitive electrical relays in the receiver, so that by means of compressed air servomotors the tractor can be made to run on a straight course, or to turn left or right. The plough can be raised when the tractor turns at the end of a furrow, the plough-raising system being cut out when other implements are attached to the tractor.
The radio-controlled tractor is so much lighter than the conventional type that fuel normally consumed in one hour is sufficient for a whole day's work.
P.s./p.e.--The radio-controlled tractor ploughing a field at Hareat, Hertfordshire, as farm dogs bark their annoyance at a strange contrivance which has no need of a ploughman.
3 October PN 1940 P.P.

RADIO-CONTROLLED PLOUGH IS NEW IDEA FOR BRITISH FARMERS.
A radio-controlled farm tractor, developed by a British firm,
Tractors (London) Ltd., in co-operation with the Automatic
Control Section of the Royal Aeronautical Establishment is
undergoing trials at Barnet, Hertfordshire.
Radio-control apparatus used in the 'Queen Bee', the target
plane devised for anti-aircraft artillery practice, has been
adapted for use in the tractor, which can be employed for
ploughing and other farm operations.
Incoming radio signals operate sensitive electrical relays in the
receiver, so that by means of compressed air servomotors the
tractor can be made to run on a straight course, or to turn
left or right. The plough can be raised when the tractor turns
at the end of a furrow, the plough-raising system being cut out
when other implements are attached to the tractor.
The radio-controlled tractor is so much lighter than the
conventional type that fuel normally consumed in one hour is
sufficient for a whole day's work.

at Barnet, Hertfordshire, as farm dogs bark their annoyance
at a strange contrivance which has no need of a ploughman.

description: A photographic print from the Daily Herald Archive folder: Industry ÃƒÆ’Ã¢â‚¬Å¡Ãƒâ€šÃ‚Â» Glass ÃƒÆ’Ã¢â‚¬Å¡Ãƒâ€šÃ‚Â» Miscellaneous.
output - gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20:
Not for publication until Monday 8.A.M., June 25th.

SIR HARRY PILKINGTON ANNOUNCES
NEW Ã‚Â£5,000,000 FLOAT TANK

In a simultaneous release in 50 countries Sir Harry Pilkington, Chairman
of Pilkington Brothers Ltd., the glass manufacturers, today (Monday,
June 25th) announced that a new Ã‚Â£5,000,000 float glass tank - the largest
the firm have ever built - is now operating at St. Helens and marks
a turning point in the development of this new high quality glass.

"The introduction of float glass is the biggest change introduced into
the flat glass trade for generations," said Sir Harry. "The process has
spelt the doom of the traditional grinding and polishing method for all
major purposes."

The statement went on to point out that although the traditional grinding
and polishing method will still be necessary for many fringe products for
probably many years to come, as a method of producing the bulk requirements
of plate glass it was made out of date as soon as Pilkington were able to
prove - as they now have without a doubt - that the float process could
produce flat, undistorted glass just as good in appearance as the traditional
product and serving the same purposes as plate glass.

"The plate process," said Sir Harry "requires a very high capital outlay
and very high maintenance costs; the float bath is a much smaller piece of
equipment, much less costly and fundamentally a much simpler means of
achieving the same objective."

The new tank, costing Ã‚Â£5,000,000 took two years to build, and into it has
gone all the float glass experience gained over the past years.

                                        NEW £5,000,000 FLOAT TANK

In a simultaneous release in 56 countries Sir Harry Pilkington, Chairman
of Pilkington Brothers Ltd., the glass manufacturers, today (Monday,
June 25th) announced that a new £5,000,000 float glass tank - the largest
the firm have ever built - is now operating at St. Helens and marks
a turning point in the development of this new high quality glass.

"The introduction of float glass is the biggest change introduced into
the flat glass trade for generations," said Sir Harry. "The process has
spelt the doom of the traditional grinding and polishing method for all
major purposes."

The statement went on to point out that although the traditional grinding
and polishing method will still be necessary for many fringe products for
probably many years to come, as a method of producing the bulk requirements
of plate glass it was made out of date as soon as Pilkingtons were able to
prove - as they now have without a doubt - that the float process could
produce flat, undistorted glass just as good in appearance as the traditional
product and serving the same purpose as plate glass.

"The plate process," said Sir Harry "requires a very high capital outlay
and very high maintenance costs; the float bath is a much smaller piece of
equipment, much less costly and fundamentally a much simpler means of
achieving the same objective."

The new tank, costing £5,000,000, took two years to build, and into it has
gone all the float glass experience gained over the past years.

FOR FIRST PUBLICATION WEDNESDAY'S EVENING'S, Sept 21st.
FAREWELL TO ANOTHER GREAT BATTLESHIP 21.9.49.
Another great battleship - HMS "NELSON", once the pride of the
British Navy, is being reduced to a shapeless shell at the hands
of the shipbreakers at Messrs Thos. Ward's Yard at INVERK_ITHING,
on the Forth. Completed in 1927, HMS NELSON performed great
service during the war, and now sold for scrap, she has gone
to the same yard as her sister ship HMS "RODNEY" and HMS "RIV_INGE".
The picture shows the 15" forward guns of HMS "RIVINGE"
in process of being cut up for scrap, while laying in the back-
ground is the half-dismantled "NELSON".

description: A photographic print from the Daily Herald Archive folder: Housing ÃƒÆ’Ã¢â‚¬Å¡Ãƒâ€šÃ‚Â» Miscellaneous ÃƒÆ’Ã¢â‚¬Å¡Ãƒâ€šÃ‚Â» Futuristic Ideas - Sea Cities.

A LOOK AT THE CITY OF THE FUTURE

Sea City - designed by a team of Britain's leading architects and engineers
as a logical 21st century successor to the present-day mainland city - was
unveiled today (February 20) at the London Hilton by the Minister of
Technology, Mr. Wedgwood Benn.

The imaginative concept, produced by the Pilkington Glass Age Development
Committee and designed by architect Hal Moggridge and engineers John Martin
and Ken Anthony, embraces a self-sufficient community of 30,000 living in
comfort and safety many miles out to sea.

The picture shows how Sea City would look from the air. Built on concrete
stilts and protected by a floating breakwater (seen in the foreground) and
by a curved 100 foot high city wall, it could be built in any of the shoal
waters that exist over 10 per cent of the surface of the ocean.

The majority of its inhabitants would live in attractively designed and
adequately serviced flats, as the picture shows. The floating islands
visible in the central lagoon, artificially heated by waste cooling water,
carry both public and private buildings providing the educational, social
and cultural facilities required by modern civilisation.

Outside the walls (right-foreground) special articulated container ships
berth in the "moat" of calm water to unload stores, while a hovercraft
heads for the harbour entrance to discharge its human cargo.
- end -

Issued on behalf of
Pilkington Glass Age Development Committee
February 20, 1968

Sea City - designed by a team of Britain's leading architects and engineers
as a logical 21st century successor to the present-day mainland city - was

Technology, Anthony Wedgwood Benn.

The imaginative concept, produced by the Pilkington Glass Age Development
Committee and designed by architect Hal Moggridge and engineers John Martin
and Ken Anthony, embraces a self-sufficient community of 30,000 living in
comfort and safety many miles out to sea.

The picture shows how Sea City would look from the air. Built on concrete
stilts and protected by a floating breakwater (seen in the foreground) and
by a curved 180 foot high city wall, it could be built in any of the shoal
waters that exist over 10 per cent of the surface of the ocean.

The majority of its inhabitants would live in attractively designed and
adequately terraced flats, as the picture shows. The floating islands
visible in the central lagoon, artificially heated by waste cooling water,

and cultural facilities required by modern civilisation.

NOT TO BE PUBLISHED BEFORE 11.30AM.
DAILIES 8TH FEBRUARY, 1962.
FIRST VICKERS VC 10 IS NEARING COMPLETION
Φ S
THE FIRST VICKERS VC 10 LONG-RANGE JET AIRLINER
IS NOW STRUCTURALLY ALMOST COMPLETE AND SYSTEMS
AND FLIGHT TEST EQUIPMENT ARE BEING INSTALLED
AT THE VICKERS-ARMSTRONGS (AIRCRAFT) WORKS AT
WEYBRIDGE, SURREY. THE VC 10, THE FIRST BIG JET
AIRLINER WITH REAR-MOUNTED ENGINES, IS SCHEDULED
TO MAKE ITS FIRST FLIGHT IN MAY.
THE VC 10 IS THE BIGGEST SINGLE AIRCRAFT
PROJECT EVER TACKLED IN EUROPE. WITH ITS FOUR
ADVANCED-MODEL ROLLS-ROYCE CONWAY ENGINES IT WILL
BE THE WORLD'S MOST POWERFUL AIRLINER (ALTHOUGH
NOISE PROBLEMS WILL NOT BE INCREASED DUE TO THE
BETTER TAKE-OFF AND CLIMB PERFORMANCE OF THE CLEAN-
WINGER VC 10; IN FACT, IT WILL BE LESS RESTRICTED
BY AIRPORT NOISE REGULATIONS THAN CURRENT BIG JETS).
THE VC 10 CRUISES AT UP TO 600 M.P.H. ITS MAXIMUM
RANGE WITH 100 PASSENGERS AND RESERVES IS OVER
5,000 MILES, OR 4,400 MILES WITH FULL PAY-LOAD.
ORDERS HAVE BEEN ANNOUNCED FOR 34 VC 10S -
42 FOR BOAC, FIVE FOR RAF TRANSPORT COMMAND, FOUR
FOR BRITISH UNITED AIRWAYS AND THREE FOR GHANA
AIRWAYS.

wood furniture, tattered
rags of curtains—this is all
that remains of two homes.
And, until dark last night, gas
and fire chiefs probed among
the debris to find a reason for
the mystery explosion, which:
KILLED 19-year-old shorthand
typist, Mavis Kay as she lay
sleeping in an upstairs bedroom;
INJURED her 52-year-old
father, Bill Kay, her mother,
May, 47, and their next-door
neighbour, Mrs. Lillian Jobson, a
58-year-old cripple;
DEMOLISHED the two homes
in Liverpool-street, Salford,
Lancs, scene of five gas explo-
sions in recent years.
The blast, which happened

Only the
basement
left

early yesterday, rocked the
district. Mrs. Jobson, who has a
broken leg, was said to be
"comfortable but ill" last night.
A lucky escape came for her
husband Tom and her 60-year-
old sister Mrs. Jane Beswick.
Mr. Jobson is recuperating at
Hope Hospital, Salford, after an

operation. Mrs. Beswick had
been helping her sister prepare
for her husband's homecoming
until late on Saturday night.
Then she decided against the
spending the night in Liverpool-
street because she had promised
her family at Darwen, Lancs, to
return home.
Mr. John Wilson, Manchester
regional manager of the North
Western Gas Board, said last
night: "We do not yet know
whether gas was in any way
responsible for the explosion."
A fire officer said that when
the clearing up was over, only
the basements would be left.
The Kays had converted
their tiny terraced home into
the only all-electric one in the
street—they did not like gas.

**PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT REGULATIONS 1967**
**NOTICE OF PROPOSED AMENDMENT TO THE METROPOLITAN REGIONAL SCHEME**

NOTICE is hereby given that the Metropolitan Planning Authority has prepared a proposed amendment to the Metropolitan Regional Scheme. The purpose of the proposed amendment is to introduce an additional **INNOVATIVE INDUSTRIAL ZONE** on Lot 122, and part of Lot 121, being the property on the eastern side of Balcatta Road, north of the junction with Erindale Road, Balcatta, which will facilitate the development of modern, high technology industries by the introduction of special zoning provisions.

Copies of the proposed amendment to the Metropolitan Regional Scheme are available for inspection at the offices of the Ministry of Town and Country Planning, 13th Floor, Westralia Plaza, 141 St Georges Terrace, Perth, and at the City of Stirling, 25 Cedric Street, Stirling, during normal office hours.

Objections to the proposed amendment must be made in writing to the Metropolitan Planning Authority, addressed to the Secretary, Ministry of Town and Country Planning, 13th Floor, Westralia Plaza, 141 St Georges Terrace, Perth, within 60 days of the publication of this notice.

FOR FIRST PUBLICATION WEDNESDAY'S DAILIES, Sept. 27th.
HIGHLAND ELECTRIC SCHEME ALMOST COMPLETE.
26.9.50.
The LOCH SLOY Scheme of the North of Scotland Hydro-Electric
Board is almost complete, and will be opened by the Queen
this autumn. The Scheme, which is part of a big plan to harness
the Highlands to provide electric power through Scotland,
will provide much needed additional electricity for Glasgow
and the surrounding districts. This new photograph shows
the power station built on the bank of Loch Lomond with the
pipes carrying the water from Loch Sloy coming down the hill-
side from the tunnel, which is 2 miles long and runs under
BEN VORLICH. The pipes are 7 feet in diameter and lead straight
down to the power station which is equipped with four tur-
bines driving alternators of 32,500 kws each.

BUILDING UP OUR TIMBER STOCKS.

MJH/HT

During the two World Wars, our woodlands were
seriously denuded of timber. Today, the Forestry
Commission and private woodland owners are pressing
ahead with the vital task of forming new forests and
re-stocking the old. The year 1956 has marked a milestone
in the history of the Forestry Commission, for it has
seen the planting by the Commission of the one
millionth acre of new woodland. Thus the area of woodland
planted to date by the Commission is more than 1,500
square miles - an area larger than Kent, nearly
twice the extent of Glamorgan and nearly two-thirds
of Perthshire. This million acres is made up of some
500 forests, which are well distributed over the length
and breadth of Britain. In recent years, well over
100-million trees - including more than 10 million hardwoods -
have been planted annually by the Commission and many of
the forests are now producing timber in substantial
quantities; in 1955, the total production amounted to
600,000 tons. Today there is hardly a county without
a national forest and scenes such as these, in the
Commission's Rendlesham Forest in East Anglia, are typical
of what is to be seen in many other parts of the country.

DUPLICATE SENT
23 AUG 1956 ON

and RALPH POTTLE seen at work in the Rendlesham Forest
(Suffolk) cutting pit props with a power circular saw,
with finished props piled on the left. This is a very
skilled job in selection and measurement.

Transcribed_Text:
GET OUT!
AFTER 60
YEARS IN
HER HOME

By Ken James
AN 80-year-old widow came
back from a seaside holi-
day at her son's expense to
the terraced house that has
been her home for 60 years.

Lying on the mat was a regi-
stered envelope containing the
Rent Act Form S—telling her
she must quit the house she
went to as a bride.

Last night white-haired Mrs.
Alice Thomas told me: "All I
want is to stay here until my
days come to an end. Yet they
mean to make me go."

The rent of the eight-roomed
house in Hatchard-road, Upper
Holloway—£11 18s. a quarter—is
paid partly by Mrs. Thomas'
married daughter, who lives up-
stairs.

No comment
But Mrs. Thomas pays the
rest and the £17 14s. 8d. a year
rates out of her only income, £2
a week pension. Rateable value
is £42—£2 over the maximum
under which a tenant is pro-
tected.

"If they'd only let me stay I'd
be willing to find a few more
shillings for a higher rent," she
said.

"I love my children very much.
But I'll sleep under an arch
sooner than live with them. I've
given myself blood pressure with
worry."

Hooper and Jackson, Padding-
ton estate agents who handle the
property, refused to comment
last night, or reveal the land-
lord's name.

With eight other tenants in
the road—the others have dif-
ferent landlords—old Mrs.
Thomas will be among the first
of the homeless in October, 1968.

See Rent Rev.
Mrs Alice
Thomas

THE INDUSTRY. METALS GOLD
KR. 52

2389) THE LOST GOLD, MINE OF YARROW FOUND.

The Ancient workers closed down their Gold mine and
thoroughly camouflaged the workings until every
particle of Quartz was hidden.
Huge s tones were erected to mark the place and a
chart would probably be made. Centuries have
passed and now it has been re-discovered by Mr.
John Nicol of Glem Cafe, St. Marys Loch, Yarrow.
In 1933 an article by a German about mining appeared
in a Canadian paper remarking about the lost Gold
mine of Yarrow. Was this mine worked by foreigners in
long ages past and information handed down through
the generations.
The Gold is both Alluvial and native(io. in the Sand
of the streams as well as in Reefs)
Back tracking was first noticed in the HENDERLAND
BURN (Backtracking for alluvial mining) as well as the
COM SIKE but particularly in the MILEHOPEBURN where
extensive sluicing had been carried out at two
distinct period s. The Gold is not free in the Rock
area, it is combined with other Reef Ores including
Manganese Copper, Gold and Silver.
Preliminary samples drawn from decomposed back of
Reef Assays showed 2.4. Dwts of Gold per ton of 2240
lbs or 53 grains to the Ton as well as 0.36 ozs of
silver and also included Manganese and Copper.
St. Mary's Lock is a very well known and beautiful
loch and a great many visitors are to be found there
in peace time. The situation is between Selkirk and
Moffat. It is in Selkirkshire and 18 miles from
Selkirk.

DURHAM PRODUCES DOLLAR-SAVING PIPELINE

Q/TAN

One of the biggest contracts for large diameter steel
pipes ever placed in Britain has just been secured by
South Durham Steel and Iron Company, an old established
Teesside firm. The order, from the Basrah Petroleum Co.
(an associate of the Iraq Petroleum Company) is for the
manufacture of 80 miles of 24-inch pipe weighing 17,000
tons to be laid next year from the Zubair oilfield in
Southern Iraq to the port of Fao on the Persian Gulf,
near Basrah. In addition to opening new and increasing
markets for the British steel industry, the £900,000
order will mean a saving of some 2½ million dollars, as
hitherto most large diameter oil piping has been obtained
from the United States.

PHOTO SHOWS: To make the piping the 26-foot-long steel
plates are placed in this machine in order to bend the
edge before it is cold rolled into the shape of the pipe.

Transcribed_Text:
1983-5286/46869

THE GREAT JIB: STAR OF THE MACHINE AGE
Oct 31st 1951 PAR 26718-1 (V-K)

THE GREAT JIB: STAR OF THE MACHINE AGE

Billed as "The Biggest Walking Drag-
line in the World, incorporating The
Great Jib", a machine that can certainly
qualify as one of the eight wonders of
the technical world made its debut at
Corby, Northants., today (Wednesday).
The machine, titled officially W.1400,
took Messrs. Ransomes & Rapier four
years to build on the site. It weighs
1,600 tons, has electric motors that
give over 3,000 motor horse power,
works for 20 hours a day, actually
walks -- with seven-foot steps -- and
is controlled by one man. Its purpose:
to remove strata covering the ironstone
bed down to a depth of one hundred feet.
Ironstone sells for a little over seven
shillings a ton; the W.1400 is designed
to uncover 400,000 tons of it each year.
For this reason, huge machine that it
is, it must "walk" over the area. After
settling in a spot, the machine swings
out with the great jib -- an arm 282
feet long, the tip of which is 175
feet above the ground. Then it drops a
22 ton scoop, lifts and drags away 27
tons of spoil. Within 60 seconds, the
scoop has emptied and is back, digging
in once more. PICTURE SHOWS: The biggest
walking drag-line (W.1400) in the world
seen here from the top of the great jib
at/its Corby (Northants.) site today.
Oct 31st 1951 PAR 26718-1 (V-K)

Housing - Flats
ARCHITECT TO LIVE IN HIS GLC FLATS
AEW 13.2.68.
LEADER OF THE GLC,MR. DESMOND PLUMMER, IS TO
OPEN THE EAST END'S TALLEST BLOCK OF FLATS
ON THURSDAY, 22ND FEBRUARY, AND THEN CALL ON
THE COUNCIL'S MOST UNUSUAL TENANT WHO WILL
BE LIVING AT THE TOP OF THE TOWER.
THE TENANT - MR. ERNO GOLDFINGER, THE
ARCHITECT WHO DESIGNED THE BLOCK - IS
MOVING INTO ONE OF THE 26-STOREY FLATS AS A
SOCIOLOGICAL EXPERIMENT. HE WILL STUDY THE
LIVING CONDITIONS WHICH HE HAS PRODUCED FOR
GLC TENANTS, AND USE THE KNOWLEDGE GAINED
WHEN DESIGNING FURTHER HOMES.
SAID MR. PLUMMER: "MR. GOLDFINGER TOLD
ME THAT HE THOUGHT IT WOULD BE ADVANTAGEOUS
TO HIS FUTURE DESIGNS IF HE COULD LIVE FOR
A FEW WEEKS IN ONE OF THE FLATS, SO I
INVITED HIM TO MOVE IN."
MR. GOLDFINGER WILL PAY APPROXIMATELY
£11 10s. A WEEK RENT, EXCLUSIVE OF RATES,
BUT INCLUDING CENTRAL HEATING. THIS IS
THE COST WITHOUT ANY SUBSIDY FROM THE
RATEPAYER OR TAXPAYER. THE SUBSIDISED RENT
FOR THE FLAT WILL BE £4 15S 6D., INCLUDING
HEATING, BUT EXCLUSIVE OF RATES.
HIS FOUR-ROOMED FLAT WILL BE AT THE TOP
OF THE 26-STOREY BLOCK AT ROWLETT STREET,
POPLAR, NAMED BALFRON TOWER, THE NAME
BALFRON - A TOWN JUST NORTH OF GLASGOW -
PERPETUATES SCOTTISH ASSOCIATIONS WITH THE
AREA.
THE 26-STOREY BLOCK, CONTAINING 36 FLATS
AND 10 MAISONETTES, IS PART OF A DEVELOPMENT
ON A 23-ACRE SITE SITUATED AT THE NORTHERN
APPROACH TO BLACKWALL TUNNEL. THERE ARE
ALSO 12 OLD PEOPLE'S FLATS, AND A SHOP WITH
LIVING ACCOMMODATION ABOVE - ALL OF WHICH
HAVE BEEN OCCUPIED FOR MORE THAN A YEAR -

1953 (504/41/1
DAILY
HERALD
LIBRARY
Sep 18 1953

It would not be everybody's choice of a way to spend a honeymoon...
...but that is where newly married steeplejack Harry Hales has just spent his.
Steeplejack Harry, who is pictured on his way up the towering 200-foot chimney stack at Battersea power station, said yesterday: "I hardly have been home. At least the view is nice."
Harry and two colleagues were given a three-week deadline to paint the chimney stack.
ON SCHEDULE
He explained: "The job was due to start the day after I got marriedÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â‚¬Âso I had to postpone my honeymoon and speed it up the chimney instead."
As he finished the finishing touches
to the cream-coloured chimney, 49-year-old Harry, of Dagenham, Essex, added: "Keep on schedule. Now my wife Hilda and I can go to Southend for our real honeymoon."
The four huge chimneys at Battersea are painted as five-yearly ballet. It takes 150 gallons of paintÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â‚¬Âa special rubberised mixture to with-stand weather conditionsÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â‚¬Âfor each one.
SECRET FEAR
But no ordinary painter would attempt to work up thereÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â‚¬Âeven with a 20-mile sure to compel him. The work has to be done by steeplejacks.
Said Harry: "This game is in the blood. Falling? We don't think about it."
But he did admit to one secret fear. "I am terrified of traffic, and hate crossing the road."

1983-5286/50658

HERALD
D. I.
24 OCT 1962

IT would not be everybody's choice of
a way to spend a honeymoon—
perched in a decorators' cradle 350ft.
above the Thames. But that is where
newly married steeplejack Harry
Walker has just spent his.

Honeymooner Harry, who is pictured
on his way up the towering, 350-foot
chimney stack at Battersea power
station, said yesterday: "It could have
been worse. At least the view is nice."

Harry and two colleagues were given
a three-week deadline to paint the
chimney stack.

ON SCHEDULE

He explained: "The job was due to
start the day after I got married—so
I had to postpone my honeymoon and
spend it up the chimney instead."
As he daubed the finishing touches

to the cream-coloured chimney, 49-
year-old Harry, of Dagenham, Essex,
added: "Bang on schedule. Now my
wife Doris and I can go to Somerset
for our real honeymoon."

The four huge chimneys at Batter-
sea are painted at five-yearly inter-
vals. It takes 110 gallons of paint—a
special rubberised mixture to with-
stand weather conditions—for each
one.

SECRET FEAR

But no ordinary painter would
attempt to work up there—even with
a 20-mile view to tempt him. The work
has to be done by steepleja
Said Harry: "This game is in the
blood. Falling? We don't think about
it."

But he did admit to one secret fear
—"I am terrified of traffic, and hate
crossing the road."

HAMBLE
1968

THEY'RE BAKING BOATS FOR MASS PRODUCTION
FEBRUARY 18th 1968 FAB 90070-1 (No.4)

THEY'RE BAKING BOATS FOR MASS PRODUCTION

As sailing has gained popularity as a sport,
new mass production methods derived from
those developed during the war for making
wooden aircraft are being applied to the
manufacture of boats at the Hamble, Hampshire
factory of Fairey Marine Ltd., a subsidiary of
the Fairey Aviation Company.
The craft are "hot-moulded" from plies of
wooden veneer, a method which eliminates the
old and laborious method of boat-building by
individual craftsmen.
The shell of each boat is composed of layers
of planks applied in a mould to form 'a
glued together'. Each shell is baked by
steam heat up to 300 degrees Centigrade for
about half an hour. Then it is taken out of
the oven and removed from the mould.
The resulting boat, it is said, will last a
lifetime and is proof against all the normal
ills which affect boats built by other methods.
More than 1,000 boats were produced at Hamble
in 1967, ranging from 7 ft. 9 in. dinghies to the
19 ft. Alalunga sailing cruiser.
Over one-third of the output is exported.
PICTURES SHOW:- Hulls of Firefly, Finn and
Albacore craft awaiting finishing in the
central assembly hangar at Hamble.
The men on the foreflex are working on boats.
February 18th 1968 FAB 90070-1 (No.3)

BATTLING FOR BRITAIN'S FORESTS.
168852 (DAW.) NEW GOVERNMENT RESEARCH STATION AIDS RECOVERY OF COUNTRY'S WOODLANDS.

FARNHAM, ENGLAND: At the Forestry Commission's new research station at Alice Holt Lodge, near this Surrey town, where
once the country's greatest struggles fought for the lives
of Allied war wounded, another type of "doctor" is battling
to save something more than Britain sacrificed in the war
effort. Degraded by urgent demands for timber during the
war, much of Britain's forest land has vanished, and what is
left is endangered by pest and disease, and here scientists
are battling to preserve Britain's woodlands.
Not only do they battle foresty pests - they actually
cultivate insects for export - certain insects are beneficial,
they prey upon parasites that infect trees.
The Research station at Alice Holt Lodge, an old mansion
standing in some 2,000 acres of former Crown woodlands, has
an extensive library, laboratories, photography, and pathology
sections.
PHOTO SHOWS:- The Entomologist uses a suction tube to
collect parasites from brooding cages, in which parasites
and their young have been cultivated.
Under normal conditions, harmful insects are kept in check
by natural enemies. This calls for the introduction of
parasites to control the new pests. Natural enemies of
harmful insects are insectivorous birds and mammals, and
a large variety of parasites and predatory insects which destroy
a large proportion of eggs, larvae and pupae.

31st March, 1948. 2.
Transcribed_Text:

FARNHAM, ENGLAND: At the Forestry Commissioners now research
station at Alice Holt Lodge, near this Surrey town, where
once the country's greatest surgeons fought for the lives
of Allied war-wounded, another type of 'doctor'is battling
to save something more than Britain sacrificed in the war
offort. Denuded by urgent demands for timber during the
war, much of Britain's forest land has vanished, and what is
left is endangered by pest and disease, and more scientists
are battling to preserve Britain's woodlands.
Not only do they battle forestry posts - they actually
cultivate some for export - certain insects are beneficial,
they prey upon parasites that infect trees.
The research station at Alice Holt Lodge, an old mansion
standing in some 2,000 acres of former Crown woodlands, has
an extensive library, laboratories, photography, and pathology
sections.
PHOTO SHOWS:- The Entomologist uses a suction tube to
collect parasites from brooding cages, in which parasites
and their enemies have been cultivated.
Under normal conditions, harmful insects are kept in check
by natural onomies. This calls for the introduction of
parasites to control the new pests. Natural enemies of
harmful insects are insectivorous birds and mammals, and a
large variety of parasites and predatory insects which destroy
a large proportion of eggs, larvae and pupae.
31st March, 1948. PN-s.

THE PROPERTY OF THE
"DAILY HERALD" ART LIBRARY
AND MUST BE RETURNED UNDAMAGED

title: A photographic print of Industry, Textiles - Cloth, Man-made - Nylon Stockings
description: A photographic print from the Daily Herald Archive folder: Industry ÃƒÆ’Ã¢â‚¬Å¡Ãƒâ€šÃ‚Â» Textiles - Cloth ÃƒÆ’Ã¢â‚¬Å¡Ãƒâ€šÃ‚Â» Man-made - Nylon Stockings.
output - gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20:
THE BATTLE FOR NYLONS - AND HAS FACTORIES CAN TURN OUT
MILLIONS OF WOMEN'S TIGHTS.

The English city of Nottingham, famed for its lace, is now
one of the key points in the battle against one of the
most irritating post-war shortages endured by Britain's
women - the lack of nylon stockings.
These pictures were taken in a Nottingham group of
factories which before the war were turning out stockings
at the rate of nearly a million dozen each year.
Now, after long experiment, overhaul of machinery and
adjustment of plant to handle nylon yarn, they are
striving to cope with the apparently insatiable demand
by millions of women eager for filmy, glamorous nylon hose.
The factories are equipped to produce stockings at the
pre-war volume, but to-day women who stand vainly in line
at shops Lord Hallamden, a leader of the British hosiery
industry, imparts this sad information: "The short
supply of nylon yarn prevents us producing ample supplies
of nylon stockings."
The yarn shortage is inadequate capacity at the
"twisting" stage of manufacture.
For the future, Lord Hallamden sheds a ray of hope - he
predicts full supplies of yarn by the beginning of 1948.
"THE DALY MIRROR" - An operative works the pre-boarding machine.
The machine subjects the nylon stockings to steam treatment
which "sets" the loop formation so that it is maintained
throughout the life of the stockings; this is one of the secrets
of nylons' durability.
9th November 1946 H.P.r.

FILE- Index Clothing - Nylons

THE BATTLE FOR NYLONS - BRITISH FACTORIES CAN TURN OUT
MILLIONS AS WOMEN YEARN.

The English city of Nottingham, famed for its lace, is now
one of the key points in the battle against one of the
most irritating post-War shortages endured by Britain's
women - the lack of nylon stockings.
These pictures were taken in a Nottingham group of
factories which before the War were turning out stockings
at the rate of nearly a million dozen each year.
Now, after long experiment, overhaul of machinery and
adjustment of plant to handle nylon yarn, they are
striving to cope with the apparently insatiable demand
by millions of women eager for filmy, glamorous nylon hose.
The factories are equipped to produce stockings at the
pre-War volume, but to angry women who stand vainly in line
at shops Lord Hollenden, a leader of the British hosiery
industry, imparts this sad information: 'The short
supply of nylon yarn prevents us producing ample supplies
of nylon stockings'.
Cause of the yarn shortage is inadequate capacity at the
'twisting' stage of manufacture.
For the future, Lord Hollenden sheds a ray of hope - he
predicts full supplies of yarn by the beginning of 1948.
PHOTO SHOWS:- An operative works the pre-boarding machine.
The machine subjects the nylon stockings to steam treatment
which 'sets' the loop formation so that it is maintained
throughout the life of the stockings; this is one of the secrets

POST MORTEM EXAMINATION OF SERGEANT H. A. ROBERTS.

POST MORTEM BY DR. A. H. McKECHNIE, GOVERNMENT PATHOLOGIST, GIBRALTAR.

ON 24TH. JUNE 1926.

HISTORY.

The body of the above deceased Sergeant H. A. ROBERTS, R.A. F., was identified by Lieutenant W. G. BRIGHT, R.A.F., who stated that the deceased was found dead in the Officers' Mess, Gibraltar Aerodrome, on the morning of 23rd. June 1926. It is suspected that the deceased was poisoned by his wife, who according to Lieutenant BRIGHT, had been in the habit of administering poisons to her husband. There is no history of any acute illness.

AUTOPSY FINDINGS.

The body is that of a well-built man aged 30 years. Rigor mortis is well marked. There are no external marks of injury. The stomach contains about 8 ounces of partially digested food. The intestines are normal. The liver, kidneys and heart are healthy. There is no sign of any disease. There is no evidence of any injury or disease which could account for death.

In view of the suspicions expressed by Lieutenant BRIGHT, that the deceased had been poisoned by his wife, the organs of the body were preserved and sent to the Government Analyst for further examination for any toxic substances. This examination will be completed as soon as possible and the results will be reported on later.

No other cause of death is suspected.

Signed:-

A. H. McKECHNIE,

Government Pathologist,

Gibraltar.

POST MORTEM RESULTS FROM GIBRALTAR

FILE REF. 21421/ 24.

Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/50908

FOR WEDNESDAY'S DAILIES...JAN. 21
LONDON'S LATEST POWER STATION.

JS 21.1.53
London's new power station, at Bankside, opposite
St. Paul's, has now begun to supply electricity.
In spite of great opposition by official bodies, the
decision to build this power-station opposite the
cathedral was pressed ahead. It has been designed by
Sir Giles Gilbert Scott, OM. When finally
completed, will comprise four 60,000 kw generating
sets in a steel-framed structure faced with bricks.
The main building is 840 ft. long, 240 ft. wide and
90 ft. high, and the single chimney is 300 ft. high.
Bankside is the first to be designed for oil burning,
and a river jetty has been built for oil tankers,
the fuel being pumped into storage tanks at the rear
of the building. This picture shows
high pressure end of No. 1 turbine, showing
governor gear and instrument panel. 28

Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/56602

OLD CORNISH COPPER MINE YIELDS URANIUM ORE. MJH/P. 1.

Wheal Edward Mine, on the edge of the cliffs at St. Just,
three miles from Land's End, Cornwall, may have a new lease
of life as the result of the work now being carried out their
by new modern prospectors with geiger counters. For years
the mine was worked for copper in the hey-day of Cornish
mining, but the financial structure of the old mineral companies
made no provision for the time when underground exploration
was necessary or when thinner lodes were met and by 50 years
ago, most had closed, until today only two are working, both
for tin. Wheal Edward, however, attracted the attention of a
prospecting geologist, Mr. Richard Rumbold of Streatham (London)
who was surveying the whole of West Cornwall for radio-active
materials, combining this work with the field testing of modern
prospecting equipment. His geiger counter ticked encouragingly
when samples of ore were produced from the ancient mine and by
scrambling down the cliff edge, he found a fairly easy means
of access. Otherwise an elaborate winch gear would be needed to go
down the vertical main shaft, which disappear dramatically
into the dark ground. Now it is likely that a company will
be formed to re-open the old mine for uranium ore.

PHOTOGRAPH SHOWS; MR. E. C. MURRAY and MR. RICHARD RUMBOLD
seen testing the native rock 120feet down the old heal Edward
Mine at St. Just, Cornwall, for uranium, with a gieger counter.

BUILDING UP OUR TIMBER STOCKS.
M/N/UT
During the two World Wars, our woodlands were seriously depleted of timber. To-day, the Forestry Commission and private woodland owners are pressing ahead with the vital task of forming new forests and re-stocking the old. The year 1955 has marked a mile stone in the history of the Forestry Commission, for it has seen the planting by the Commission of the one millionth acre of new woodland. Thus the area of woodland planted to date by the Commission is now more than 1,500 square miles - an area larger than Kent, nearly twice the extent of Glamorgan and nearly two-thirds of Perthshire. This million acres is made up of some 500 forests, which are well distributed over the length and breadth of Britain. In present years, well over 500-million trees - including more than 70 million hardwoods - have been planted annually by the Commission and many of the forests are now producing timber in substantial quantities; in 1955, the total production amounted to 600,000 tons. Today there is hardly a county without a national forest and some, as is shown, in the Commission's Bedgebury Forest - Kent Anglia, are typical of what is to be seen in many o her parts of the country.

PHOTOGRAPH SHOWS: MR. CHARLES B. YALLINGTON, HEAD FORESTER, seen inspecting a 9-years-old tree in the experimental section of a plantation of Hybrid POPLARS in the Bedgebury Forest (Suffolk).
