Transcribed_Text:
1953-5236/54094

BUILDING UP OUR TIMBER STOCKS.
MJH/HT
During the two World Wars, our woodlands were
seriously denuded of timber. Today, the Forestry
Commission and private woodland owners are pressing
ahead with the vital task of forming new forests and
re-stocking the old. The year 1956 has marked a milestone
in the history of the Forestry Commission, for it has
seen the planting by the Commission of the one
millionth acre of new woodland. Thus the area of woodland
planted to date by the Commission is more than 1,500
square miles - an area larger than Kent, nearly
twice the extent of Glamorgan and nearly two-thirds
of Perthshire. This million acres is made up of some
500 forests, which are well distributed over the length
and breadth of Britain. In recent years, well over
100-million trees - including more than 10 million hardwoods -
have been planted annually by the Commission and many of
the forests are now producing timber in substantial
quantities; in 1955, the total production amounted to
600,000 tons. Today there is hardly a county without
a national forest and scenes such as these, in the
Commission's Rendlesham Forest in East Anglia, are typical
of what is to be seen in many other parts of the country.

PHOTOGRAPH SHOWS: MR. CHARLES H. WELLINGTON, Head
Forester, seen inspecting a 2-years-old tree in
the experimental section of a plantation of Hybrid
Poplars in the Rendlesham Forest (Suffolk).

"TOPPING-OUT" FOR ENGLAND'S TALLEST FLATS
DNY.
26.2.59.
TOMORROW, FRIDAY, THE TRADITIONAL "TOPPING-OUT" CEREMONY
WILL BE HELD ON A BLOCK OF THE TALLEST FLATS YET DEVELOPED
IN ENGLAND, ON THE L.C.C. BRANDON ESTATE AT KENNINGTON
PARK. THE CEREMONY IS THE TRADITIONAL ONE OBSERVED WHEN THE
FRAME OF A BUILDING HAS BEEN COMPLETED, AND THE BLOCK ON THE
BRANDON ESTATE IS THE FIRST OF SIX 18-STOREY BLOCKS EACH
CONTAINING 64 TWO-BEDROOM FLATS AND FOUR PENTHOUSES. THESE
SIX MAMMOTH TOWER BLOCKS SCHEDULED FOR COMPLETION BY 1960
WILL EVENTUALLY DOMINATE THE CHANGING LONDON SKYLINE. THEY
WILL COST £1,138,343, WILL HAVE BALCONIES, CENTRAL HEATING,
AND HIGH SPEED LIFTS. THE BRANDON ESTATE WAS THE FIRST LARGE
SCHEME OF REHABILITATION AND REDEVELOPMENT APPROVED BY THE
LONDON COUNTY COUNCIL; IT COMPRISES ABOUT 36 ACRES, OF WHICH
26 ARE BEING REDEVELOPED ON THE LINES ILLUSTRATED HERE, AND
THE REMAINING TEN REHABILITATED BY THE CONVERSION OF 182
HOUSES INTO SELF-CONTAINED FLATS. IT MARKS A GREAT STEP
FORWARD IN THE WORK OF SLUM CLEARANCE. THE PICTURE SHOWS
ONE OF THE TYPE OF OLD HOUSES WHICH HAVE BEEN DEMOLISHED
MAKE WAY FOR THE TALL MODERN BLOCKS ONE OF WHICH IS SEEN
IN THEBACKGROUND.

DAILY
12 SEP 1950
HERALD

11/9/50

No hope remains of saving
the 13 miners missing in
Knockshinnoch Castle Col-
liery. Sir Andrew Bryan,
Chief Inspector of Mines,
announced this last night.
Attempts to explore the work-
ings will go on. But Sir Andrew
added: "We must make sure
that we do not risk further
lives."
Heavy rain yesterday poured
into the crater left by the sub-
sidence that trapped 129 men
last Thursday. The water
caused two fresh subsidences.
One almost blocked the hole
through which teams had been
entering the mine. Rescue
workers were switched to the
task of improving drainage with
high-powered pumps (above).
Down the neighbouring Bank
Pit workings, through which 116
men were rescued during the
week-end, efforts to clear the
poisonous "black damp" gas
continued.
Mr. Philip Noel-Baker, Minis-
ter of Fuel, visited both pits
yesterday. News of the disaster
reached him in Greece and he
decided immediately to fly home.
Only two of the miners who
were saved are now in hospital.

FIRE SERVICE
PUMPING WATER AWAY
FROM THE CRATER'S DIRECTION

GROWING YOUR INDUSTRY. PROTECTING YOUR TOWNS AND
TOWNS. AN industrial project which has aroused con-
siderable interest is the preparation for
this month's All-Inclusive" "Great Britain"
exhibition of the entire output of the nation's
leading industries. There, at Olympia, the public will
see an exhibition of the vital part played by the
nation's power stations and their contribution
to the welfare and prosperity of this country.
Among the many exhibits are models of the country's
principal power stations and photographs of the
lovely countryside which the nation's electricity
supply has helped to make more prosperous and the
homes that have been made more comfortable by
its clean, healthy and efficient service. The
importance of this national asset can be gauged
by the fact that the nation's electricity supply,
which has always been a cheap, clean and efficient
service, will be represented by a comprehensive exhibit
from a London power station, showing the way in
which electricity is generated and distributed.
The exhibit, which is expected to attract crowds,
will include a model of the station, a demonstra-
tion of how the electricity is generated and dis-
tributed, and samples of the coal used. This
will be the first time that such an exhibit has
been staged. All these will go to prove how the
nation's electricity supply has helped to make
this country prosperous.

BANKSIDE.

244490 SKI
BANKSIDE POWER STATION: PRODUCTION GETS UNDER WAY

London: An industrial project which has aroused much
controversy from the time of its conception has just gone
into operation. It is the Bankside Power Station, at
which the first 60,000-kilowatt turbo-alternator, of
about 80,000 horse-power, has started to supply electricity.
The project was allowed, on condition that oil and not
coal was to be burned. Other conditions which had to
be observed were that the building must be set back
far enough from the Thames so as not to interfere with
the projected road and promenade.
Opposition to the power station was so strong that in
January, 1947 a public inquiry was held, with the result
that the scheme has given Government sanction.
On completion the Bankside Power Station will comprise
four 60,000-kilowatt generating sets, the oil
consumption at full-load (10-hour day) being 67 tons
an hour, consuming in one winter's day about 850 tons.
PHOTO SHOWS:- The pump house at the river jetty which has
been built to accommodate tankers and barges. The oil will be
brought up the river mainly by self-propelled barges from
which it will be discharged by these pumps through a tunnel
to underground storage tanks at the rear of the power
station.

January 1953 PN-b

THE RETURN OF THE SWORD
Coronation Brings It Back to Popularity

The sword, ancient weapon of defence , has now
become a token of ceremony. It will be much in
evidence during the Coronation festivities.
Many sword cutlers have sixs gone out of business
in this age of the atom, but one firm, The
Wilkinson Sword Company, of Acton, London, have
kept up the ancient industry. At present they
have orders for 2,000 swords. They are busy making
officers' ceremonial swords or refurbishing old ones
that will be used in the Coronation.
Some of the orders received have come from overseas.
The firm has the market largely to itself
- evening American manufacturers appear to have
gone out of business.
Ceremonial swords have not been a standard item
of officers' equipment in the Army since before the
war. Many orders have been placed by the Ministry
of Supply and service-owned swords are issued to
officers as required from a pool formed by
regiments. Nevertheless, many officers still possess
pre-war swords and hundreds of these have been
sent for renovation, which mostly involves
replating. The average cost of this work is about
£5..
Many existing swords, including those belonging
to the Yeomen of the Guard, are being sent to the
firm to be "brought up to date" - to be embossed
with the Queen's cipher.

I.N.P. PHOTO SHOWS:- THE ONLY WOMAN in the sword
factory is Mrs. May Fry, storekeeper and finisher.

Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/42860
'DOORMAT' STRETCHER CAN AID MINE RESCUES
October 8th 1963 PAR 105646-1 (PNR/P-R)

'DOORMAT' STRETCHERS CAN AID MINE RESCUES

An old piece of colliery conveyor belt that
was once used as a doormat looks like
revolutionising mine rescue work in the
South Yorkshire coalfields, and may win a
National Coal Board Divisional award for
50-year-old JACK HUBY of Carcroft, near
Doncaster, fire and rescue officer at
Bullcroft Colliery, near Doncaster.
Jack started experimenting with the 3/8in.
thick belt four months ago and came up with
a new type of stretcher which he is seen here
(on right) demonstrating.
In a recent demonstration, miners saw Jack
dragged by an engine along a rough railway
track at 10 miles an hour. Then, still
strapped in the stretcher - which fits snugly
around the patient - he was pulled through
a 3ft.6in. water pipe.
Mr. Albert Wilds, the Bullcroft Colliery
manager, said: 'There's no doubt it is a
real step forward in mine rescue work.
This stretcher can be used extensively in
underground coal seams where rescue teams
find it impossible to take conventional
stretchers. It will get injured miners
up from the coal face quicker than any other
type.'
Cost of making the Huby Stretcher is
negligible.
October 8th 1963 PAR 105646-1 (PNR/P-R)

FOR FIRST PUBLICATION IN EVENING
PAPERS OF WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 9th.

SERVICE.

FORD PRODUCES TENTH MILLIONTH TRACTOR

The millionth Fordson tractor to be manufactured since production in Great Britain was resumed twenty-three years ago, left the production line at Ford's Dagenham factory today.
The tractor, which was driven off the line by Mr. J. Kilgour, Dagenham Councillor at the Irish Embassy in W. London, is earmarked for shipment this week to Henry Ford & Son Ltd., Cork, Ireland. It will be the 100,000th to be sent from Ford's British tractor factory. The new manufacturing of Fordson tractors in the United Kingdom.
In 1928 the entire tractor manufacturing plant of Ford Motors was shipped to Cork, then in 1930 production again at Dagenham.
Ford tractors were built in the period of Cork production. One hundred sixty were built at Cork.
It is confidently anticipated that the millionth Fordson should be exported to Cork, birthplace of the Fordson production.

A CENTURY TO FORDSONS

Among those present, as seen in this picture, to watch the tractor leave the line today were three Ford employees who have worked on tractor production since the early days at Cork and whose combined service with Ford totals 130 years. They are Mr. Harry Stone, Superintend of Tractor Assembly (35 years), Mr. John Blow, Assistant Superintendent (35 years) and Mr. Doug Rose, Foreman (35 years).

Dale.

London-March 20th. 1953.

Transcribed_Text:
19.83-5236/40559

FORD'S PRODUCE THEIR MILLIONTH TRACTOR

The millionth Fordson tractor to be manufactured since
production in Great Britain and Ireland began forty-three
years ago, left the production line at Ford's Dagenham
factory today.
The tractor, which was driven off the line by Mr. J.
O'MAHONY, Economic Counsellor at the Irish Embassy in
London, is earmarked for shipment this week to Henry
Ford & Son Ltd., Cork, Ireland. It was at Cork in 1919
that the late Henry Ford built his first factory for the
manufacture of Fordson tractors in the United Kingdom.
In 1928, the entire tractor manufacturing plant of Ford
America was shipped to Cork, then in 1933 production moved
to Dagenham.
39,049 tractors were built in the period of Cork pro-
duction; the remainder have been built at Dagenham.
It is appropriate, therefore, that the millionth Fordson
should be exported to Cork, birthplace of UK Fordson
production.

A Century in Tractors

Among those present, as seen in this picture, to watch
the tractor leave the line today were three Ford employees
who have worked on tractor production since the early days
at Cork and whose combined service with Ford totals 101
years. They are Mr. Jerry Keane, Superintendent Tractor
Assembly (39 years), Mr. Dave Finn, Assistant Superinten-
dent (33 years) and Mr. Jimmy Quinn, Foreman (29 years).

Ends.

London-March 21st. 1962.
JP
WITH COMPLIMENTS OF FORD TRACTOR GROUP
NO REPRODUCTION FEE

Transcribed_Text:
1983 - 5236/55155
Ind - Glass - Bottles.

DEMAND FOR GLASS CONTAINERS ON THE UP AND UP. AP/TRU

Reasons for the rapidly increasing demand for glass
containers were outlined today, Wednesday 21st May
1969, by Mr James B. Livingston, DSC, Deputy President
of the Glass Manufacturers Federation and Vice-Chairman
of Rockware Glass Ltd., in London, The four
main reasons for the growing success of glass containers
in the face of increasing competition from other materials
were 1. The nature of the material - good for display, and
clinically clean; 2. The low price per unit, due to low
cost basic raw materials; 3. Technology - lightweighting
and strengthening; and 4. The advent of one-trip bottles.
A new, colourful film entitled "Glass Coloured Spectacle",
which promotes the advantages of glass containers, was
also premiered today. In the five years since the
Glass Manufacturers Federation made their first glass
container film, sales of bottles and jars have leapt
from 4854 million units in 1964, to 5652 units last year.
Picture shows

Mr James B. Livingston points out how technology has
assisted the increased demand for glass containers, and
in particular, milk bottles, which, as will be seen
from the diagram, are being made lighter and lighter.
It may soon be possible to drop such bottles and they
will bounce, rather than shatter, thus helping to keep
costs yet again.
FOX PHOTOS LIMITED. 21st May 1969.
RECEIVED
22 MAY 1969
GLASGOW HERALD

Erected on the same site as the old buildings dating from
1924, the new Grangemouth Oil Refinery was built on the
Firth of Forth by Scottish Oils Ltd., a subsidiary of the
Anglo-Iranian Oil Company. Started in 1949, it went into
operation in 1951, with maximum annual crude oil capacity
of 2,500,000 tons, helping to counteract the Abadan collapse.
Its main objective is high-grade motor spirit, and it also
supplies the raw material for the production of petroleum
chemicals. To cope with its capacity of 30,000 barrels, or
just over 1,000,000 gallons a day of imported crude oil, it
was decided to establish an installation at Finnart on Loch
Long, and run a pipeline from there to the refinery, this
being more convenient than using the old Grangemouth Docks
exclusively. The approximate cost of the combined project
was £15,000,000.

NO HEAVY SHORTAGE
Science Reporter
OUT of the silvery March Sea
yesterday shot a 60ft. fountain
of flame-high enough to Kindle
the hopes of every money-minded
housewife in the land.
For when Gas come to be
Europe's 'chief fuel, there will
be nothing to prevent the
burning of every pint of natural
gas.

GAMBLING TIMES
Playing with gas that has run for
400 years, some are prepared to
gamble that it can be turned to
profit. This is enough to remind
the public of the shortage of
gas in Europe. In the past, three
quarters of world-wide gas have
been obtained from coal but this
supply is only for a short time.
Now, the new gas which has
arisen from the sea, has come to
help us. Gas from the sea is
now of great interest to the world
and has now been made available
for use.

SECOND CALLING
This is enough to remind the
public of the shortage of gas. For
the past, three-quarters of the
world gas have been obtained from
coal, but this supply is only for
a short time. Now, the new gas
which has arisen from the sea has

Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/51385
Industry.. Fuel and Power.. Oil.. From Sea Bed... North Sea 'Sea Gas'

BY HENRY STANHOPE
Science Reporter
OUT of the silvery North Sea
yesterday shot a 40ft. fountain
of flame—high enough to kindle
the hopes of every money-minded
housewife in the land.

For behind that flame is gas.
Enough in a day to cook the dinners
and heat the sitting rooms of a
300,000 people.
And enough to allow British Petro-
leum, who have been drilling for gas
deep under the North Sea along with
7 other strike-hungry companies, to
announce cautiously: "We are
optimistic."

DIAMOND TIPPED

Yesterday was flare-test day on Sea
Gem, BP's 5,600-ton, 136ft.-high boring
rig, whose diamond-tipped drills first
struck a reserve of natural gas two
miles under the North Sea last
September.
Engineers who have been busily
constructing a well to draw up the
precious fuel, brought up their first
large "bucketful" to sample it for quality
and quantity.
Their announcement: excellent gas,
and enough of it to provide 10million
cubic feet a day, "a very encouraging
start."

SECOND DRILLING

This is enough to satisfy the needs
of a town the size of Nottingham. Or,
of course, 10 towns of 30,000 each.
I flew in a Heron plane, 200ft.
of the gaunt, black skeleton of Sea
Gem, 42 miles east of the Humber, and
the yellow spindle of flame burning off
the surplus gas as it emerged.
BP's North Sea project co-ordinator
Bob Holroyd said that a
second drilling would start
before the end of the year
in a spot two miles west of
Sea Gem.

If that one shows equal
promise, there will be a
third, and a fourth, and a
fifth. "Until, in fact, BP are
satisfied they can find the
500million cubic feet of gas a
day they regard as the
minimum to make their
North Sea scheme a going
concern.
Pipelines would follow, pump-
ing the gas into the kitchens of
Britain, at the lowest price to
consumers yet. It will be
some of the purest gas discovered.
And if the Gas Council fer-
vently hope, one day may mean
us cheaper prices, lower bills
every quarter.
Last week Continental Oil
ended drilling because their
North Sea strike showed insuffi-
cient promise.

On the plume of flame marking
6.85.
STRIKE IN NORTH SEA.
icopter passenger looks down.
strike.

Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236 / 50945
INDUSTRY, FUEL AND POWER. ELECTRICITY. POWER STATIONS
FERRYBRIDGE . YORKSHIRE.
THREEX 350-ft. cooling towers
were blown down and a
huge oil rig was torn from its
moorings yesterday as gales of
up to 100 mph. swept Britain.

At least seven people were killed
and scores were injured.

In the cooling tower collapse at a
£70million power station, hundreds
of workers escaped—because they
were on a tea-break.

Last night another tower at the
power station in Ferrybridge, York-
shire, was in danger of collapsing.

FALLING CONCRETE

The station is due to come into
operation this year and is one of the
biggest in Europe. Only three men
were slightly hurt by falling concrete
as the towers crashed into rubble.
Damage is estimated at £2million.

But the luckiest men alive today
are the 30 workers aboard the
£21million oil rig Ocean Prince which
snapped a dozen steel hawsers at
Middlesbrough, Yorkshire, and
floated into the River Tees before
dawn yesterday.

Four times the men escaped death.

Escape No. 1 came when
the rig crashed into the side
of an oil tanker.

Escape No. 2 came a quarter
of a mile downstream when the
rig's crane sliced through two
power cables strung across the
river lighting up the sky with
huge flashes.

Escape No. 3 happened as the
rig bore down on a small dredger
in the river. Aboard the
dredger was 2,000lb. of gelignite
—but the dredger crew towed it
to safety and then took to their
boats to escape. Finally came:

Escape No. 4, when the oil rig
bit deep into a mudbank with-
in sight of the open sea and
almost capsized.

Last night, after the men had
been rescued by launches, the
River Tees was closed to ship-
ping with the oil rig blocking
the sea route. Tugs were stand-
ing by.

Today an attempt will be
made to tow the rig back up
river, where she is being fitted
out before joining the North
Sea oil and gas hunt.

In London, nine people were
injured when sheets of corru-
gated iron crashed from the
roof of a restaurant at Victoria
station on to a bus queue. Two
were detained in hospital.

TWO KILLED

1983-5236 / 46443
THEY'RE BAKING BOATS FOR MASS PRODUCTION
February 15th 1958 PAR 69070-4 (Wo-R)
CHESTER
NO 8003 17 FEB 1958
DUPLICATE SENT
THEY'RE BAKING BOATS FOR MASS PRODUCTION

As sailing fast gains popularity as a sport,
modern mass production methods derived from
those developed during the war for making
wooden aircraft are being applied to the
manufacture of boats at Hamble, Hampshire,
factory of Fairey Marine Ltd., a subsidiary of
the Fairey Aviation Company.
The craft are 'hot-moulded' from planks of
wooden veneer, a method which eliminates the
old and laborious method of boat-building by
individual craftsmen.
The shell of each boat is composed of layers
of planks applied to a mould to form 'skins'
glued together. Each shell is baked by
steam heat up to 100 degrees Centigrade for
about half an hour. Then it is taken out of
the oven and removed from the mould.
The resulting boat, it is said, will last a
lifetime and is proof against all the normal
ills which affect boats built by other methods.
More than 1,000 boats were produced at Hamble
in 1957, ranging from 7ft.6in. dinghies to the
26ft. Atalanta sailing cruiser.
Over one-third of the output is exported.
PICTURE SHOWS:- Workers at Hamble laying on
a 'skin' for a 9ft.10in. 'Duckling' general
purpose dinghy. The wood is drawn from the
oven in background which keeps it at even
temperature.
February 15th 1958 PAR 6907 0-4 (Wo-R)

F194 IDI
Industry food & drink
Meat
A HULL butcher yesterday
gave away his entire stock
of ewe mutton, worth £6, as
a protest against Food Ministry
“dictatorship.”
Wrapping up a chop for a cus-
tomer, bespectacled Mr. Ron Wil-
son said: “Even then some custo-
mers said they would not have it
at any price.”
His action followed protests by
butchers all over the country
WILSON.9
MUTTON
CHORS
FREE
NO CHARGE
BUTCHER WILSON'S OFFER
against a Ministry order that
butchers who refuse ewe mutton
should have their entire supply
stopped.
A Ministry statement last night
said that ewe mutton now being
issued was 3.5 per cent.—one
twenty-eighth—of the rationed
supply. This was just half of the
proportion allocated to butchers in
recent months.
MORE LATER?
It added that the order against
which butchers were protesting
had been in operation for 13 years,
but was suspended temporarily, so
far as mutton was concerned, in
November last year.
“Unless supplies of imported
ewe mutton are cleared regularly,”
said the Ministry, “supplies will
build up and there will be a much
greater proportion of the ration
in ewe mutton later in the year.”
The executive council of the
National Federation of Retail
Meat Traders' Associations will
meet in London today to discuss
what to do. West Wiltshire
butchers decided last night to
await this decision before taking
action.
Somerset butchers will hold pro-
test meetings throughout the West
Country at the weekend.

description: A photographic print from the Daily Herald Archive folder: Industry ÃƒÆ’Ã¢â‚¬Å¡Ãƒâ€šÃ‚Â» Agriculture ÃƒÆ’Ã¢â‚¬Å¡Ãƒâ€šÃ‚Â» Poultry - Eggs.

OIL-DIP FOR LONG STORAGE

A special process is now being used in the packing stations
of the Yorkshire Egg Producers Limited, Bridlington,
Yorkshire, to preserve eggs during storage. This process,
known as "egg dipping", has so far only been carried out on
a small scale in the U.K. although it is widely used in the
U.S.A., Canada, Denmark, Holland and Australia. In 1949, the
Food Ministry carried out large-scale trials of the process.

Deterioration of eggs is caused mainly by bacterial
infection through the shell and partly by the escape of
moisture and carbon dioxide, causing the albumen to break
down. The colourless, odourless and tasteless mineral oil,
in which the eggs are dipped before being placed in cold
storage, fills the pores of the shell and prevents microbial
invasion and greatly reduces the loss of moisture and carbon
dioxide. The Shell Crude recommended for this application is
Shell Ondina Oil 17.

The Yorkshire Egg Producers Ltd. handle approximately
1/25th of the total eggs packed in the U.K. (in 1953, this
represented nearly 200 million eggs). They possess 9 packing-
stations, at which eggs are sorted, "candled" to detect
interior flaws, graded by weight, stamped and repacked for
delivery to retailers.

PLEASE RETURN
TO
ART LIBRARY

OIL-DIPPING AIDS EGG STORAGE

A special process is now being used in the packing stations
of the Yorkshire Egg Producers Limited, Drighlington,
Yorkshire, to preserve eggs during storage. This process,
known as "egg dipping", has so far only been carried out on
a small scale in the U.K., although it is widely used in the
U.S.A., Canada, Denmark, Holland and Australia. In 1949, the
Food Ministry carried out large-scale trials of the process.

Deterioration of eggs is caused partly by bacterial
infection through the shell and partly by the escape of
moisture and carbon dioxide, causing the albumen to break
down. The odourless, colourless and tasteless mineral oil,
in which the eggs are dipped before being placed in cold
storage, fills the pores of the shell and prevents microbial
invasion and greatly reduces the loss of moisture and carbon
dioxide. The Shell grade recommended for this application is
Shell Ondina Oil 17.

The Yorkshire Egg Producers Ltd. handle approximately
1/19th of the total eggs packed in the U.K. (in 1953, this
represented nearly 200 million eggs). They possess 9 packing-
stations, at which eggs are sorted, "candled" to detect
interior flaws, graded by weight, stamped and repacked for
delivery to retailers.

PICTURE SHOWS:- Trays of eggs being lowered into the oil bath.
Operated by 3 assistants, the oil-dipping machine can dip up to
750 dozen eggs per hour.
(A Shell Photograph - 1954)
(E-123-6)

Housing - Misc.

HERALD REPORTER
A 16TH-CENTURY house made 20th-century history
yesterday by being moved in one piece from the
place where the Tudor builders put it up. Crowds
watched it trundling up a slope towards its new site
300ft. away.
The move will cost Exeter Council £8,000. Originally
they took over the house—in Frog-street—with the idea
of pulling it down to make way for the city's new inner
by-pass. But there was a
storm of protest.
The Ministry of Works told
the council to move it to
another site. For more than
a month workmen "crated"
the 30 - ton, three - storey
house in 10 tons of timber.
And yesterday looking as
stately as possible on its
special wheels, it was winched
up a one-in-ten gradient.

TOP-HEAVY
At first two winches were
used. But the house moved too
fast and the removal team
switched to one.
Spirit levels were used to
make sure the house was
kept on an even keel.
Mr. David Nye, the London
architect, who has advised the
council on the move, watched
id the operation.

construction, so it must be kept
absolutely level during the move

ping over," he said.

e house moved 40 yards in two
d hours.

ing: "I'm very satisfied with our
progress."
In fact it reached the top of
the slope ahead of schedule. To-
day it will be put in place on its
new site.

THE PROGRESS OF A NEW TOWN

JS 16.8.50.
HARLOW is one of eight New Towns designed for the reception of
population and industry from the crowded areas of inner London,
and which are expected to take about 230,000 Londoners. Harlow's
contribution to this will be an increase in population of
55,000.
HARLOW recently reached a distinct stage in its development with
the commencement of work in building in the MARK HALL area -- a
step which marked the beginning of work on the New Town proper
and the end of preparation which has lasted since the approval of
the Master Plan. This Master Plan was the first to receive
official approval despite the fact that the Harlow Development
Corporation was by no means the first to be set up. Much work
has also been done in the Chippingfield area where terraced and
semi-detached houses have been erected, and some of which are
already in occupation by members of the Corporation's staff and
employees of the contractors.
This series of pictures recently taken give some idea of the well-
ned lay-out of the New Town, the types of houses under cons-
tion, together with something of the HQ of the Corporation.
droomed terraced houses at CHIPPINGFIELD with working
dining-sitting room. In the right background are 2-
ees adjacent to children's playground. Rents are
d 23/7d a week inclusive.

ENGLAND HAS EUROPE'S BIGGEST OIL REFINERY
Mac 5.10.50.
Overlooking Southampton Water at FAWLEY, an army of men is engaged in
erecting what will be the biggest oil Refinery in Europe, which when
in full operation will contribute to 25 per cent of the total refining
output of this country – alone will set bigger plants anywhere in
the world.
This vast new enterprise of the Anglo-American Oil Company represents
close co-operation between the two countries. It does not involve
Marshall Aid, and will save millions of dollars annually. The project
will cost approximately £37,500,000, and will employ 2,000 people,
and is expected to turn out more than 5,000,000 tons of petroleum
products per year. Britain's dependence upon the United States for
petrol and other products of crude oil will be greatly eased. The
pipeline store the pipes which will carry the products of the new
refinery to the existing pipelines...

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE

PRESS INFORMATION

NEW YORK - THE CITY OF NEW YORK - THE REPUBLICAN NATIONAL COMMITTEE

PROVISIONAL APPOINTMENT OF COMMITTEE CHAIRMAN - 2001

Mr. R. M. "Bob" Perry was today provisionally appointed Chairman of the Republican National Committee by acting Committee Chairman, Ms. Mary Ellen Kilpatrick. This appointment will be effective immediately and is provisional pending official confirmation by the full Committee at its next scheduled meeting in September.

Mr. Perry, a businessman from Texas, replaces Mr. William "Bill" Harris who resigned from his post last week to pursue private business interests. Mr. Perry is a well-known figure in Republican circles and has served in various capacities within the party at both the state and national levels.

"I am honored by this provisional appointment and I look forward to working with the Committee to further the goals of the Republican Party," said Mr. Perry. "We have a lot of work ahead of us, and I am eager to get started."

Ms. Kilpatrick expressed her confidence in Mr. Perry's ability to lead the Committee during this transition period. "Bob Perry has the experience and the dedication to lead the Republican National Committee," said Ms. Kilpatrick. "I am confident that he will do an excellent job."

Further details regarding the committee's upcoming meeting and any other business will be announced at a later date.

FIRST PUBLICATION MONDAY'S EVENINGS 8th July 1946.
BRITAIN'S 80-BERTH AIR LINER ON THE STOCKS

Revolutionary in design, and of a size which necessitates
her being built on stocks just like an ocean liner, the BRISTOL
BRABAZON I is approaching completion at Bristol, England.
This magnificent craft is designed to fly direct between
London and New York or Montreal at a cruising speed of 350 mph
higher than 35,000 ft. Her range will be 5,000 miles. 177 ft long
and 50 ft high at rudder and with a wing span of 230 ft, her
all-up weight will be 126 tons, and there will be sleeping
berths for 80 passengers for night travel.
Eight gas-turbine units coupled in pairs will drive four
airscrews, only the bosses of the latter being visible, the
power units themselves being buried in the wings and accessible
for servicing during flight. The picture shows:

The BRISTOL BRABAZON I on the stocks; aircraft plants
become increasingly like shipyards.

THE OXEN HOLDING THEIR YOUNG.

Auckland - Appropriately to the Orange Ocean Race, the
oxen, Elizabeth, in her tightly bound yoke, has
arrived in harbor. A new arrival at the glass conservatory,
though a living relic of the age of the great sea
beasts, is the family of the Oxen. The male, a brute
of immense size, is of the ancient breed of which
only a few are left on earth. This ox, with his
mate, has been living for a long time in this private
conservatory for a long time. This private conservatory
has been built by the British people in honor of the
Oxen. This ox is said to be a survivor of the Great
Oxen of the Pacific Ocean.

This ox is said to have been captured in the year
1930, near the Hawaiian Islands, where it was
living in a cave, and then brought to this country.
The young ox is said to have been born on board the
ship. The ox can not get out of the barn.

The ox is now on exhibition in this private conservatory.
It has also been exhibited at the zoo.

This ox, Elizabeth, has been taken to the home
of the owner for safety, in order to prevent her
from being killed in the war.

In the year of 1930, the ox, Elizabeth, was one of the
few of the breed that was left in the world.

The ox, Elizabeth, is now being taken to the country,
in order to prevent her from being killed in the war.

This ox is said to be one of the only survivors
of the breed of ox that was left in the world.

THE QUEEN ELIZABETH TAKES SHAPE.

Britain's sister-ship to the famous Queen Mary, the
Queen Elizabeth, is now rapidly taking shape on the
stocks in John Brown's yard at Clydebank. The new
vessel, which is to be launched by the Queen on Sept.
27, will weigh 43,000 tons, and will be 1,032 ft overall.
Her official gross tonnage of 90,000 tons tops that of
the Queen Mary by some 91,000 tons. She will also be
entirely new method of increasing a ship's speed by re
friction set up by the passage of the hull through the
water is being employed.

Photo shows- A new picture of the giant Cunarder, taken
from a passing boat. It can be seen that she has already
received a coat of paint and the plimsoll line is in
position.

Seventeen policemen were injured on Sunday (9-8-70) when a black Panther march in London erupted into a bitter street battle. Eight hundred loads of police were called in to control the violence as demonstrators hurled bricks, broken milk bottles and beer cans. Nineteen people were arrested and will be appearing in court on Monday. Fighting flared after 200 Black Panthers set off on an anti-police protest march in London's Notting Hill. 17 POLICE INJURED IN A MOB ATTACK.
Seventeen policemen were injured on Sunday (9-8-70) when a Black
Power march in London erupted into a bitter street battle. Eight
coach-loads of police were called in to control the violence as
demonstrators hurled bricks, broken milk bottles and beer cans.
Nineteen people were arrested and will be appearing in court on
Monday. Fighting flared after 200 Black Panthers set off on an anti-
police protest march in London's Notting Hill. They carried the
heads of slaughtered pigs on poles and chanted: "Kill the pigs!"
outside two local police stations. The Panthers were on their way to
a third police station when escorting police tried to make them form
into an orderly column, in a street in Paddington. A scuffle broke
out. Then, as one policeman said later, "All Hell broke loose."
Police, coloured and white demonstrators punched, kicked and dragged
each other to the ground. Young coloured girls screamed and beat at
policemen struggling with Panthers in the gutters. As the police
reinforcements arrived to join the battle, demonstrators fled
down side streets and over garden walls as the police slowly gained
control.

D.D. YOLM 15/7/69
Oil scare at Formby

A group of experts urgently sent from the
oil fields of the United States have come here
to the drill a rival to which the client
NIS is fixed.

SEARCH FOR OIL IN LANCASHIRE.

Somewhere beneath the sand-dunes of the Lancashire
coast, seven miles from Southport, lies a huge
untapped supply of oil.
Sixteen engineers who have just sunk a bore hole have
to find it before their instruments register 7,000 ft.
They cannot go any deeper than that with their present
equipment and if they have not found it at that depth
they will try somewhere else.

An official at the G.Y.R. Exploration Co. who is doing
the drill, said "For two years we have been getting 400
tons of oil a year from eight "nations wells" at
Formby, but these wells are only 100 ft deep and we are
confident that a large oilfield, much deeper is
supplying them."
They tried three times before at "earichment and
"luminosity, but although they went down to 7,000 ft
they could not find the source.
"Owing to a thick, silty fluid coming out of a large
pipe crossing the steering carriage on the key site,
John Glason the drilling experimentlist explained
"that is the stimulating fluid which we pump down the
centre of the drill pipe. It sweeps through the drilling
bit and brings up the small pieces of rock formation."
After the formation has been cleared out, the mud goes
down the drill pipe.

Oil seare at Formby

4 A gang of experts mostly men from the
oil fields of the midlands make adjustments

Bit is fixed

SEARCH FOR OIL IN LANCASHIRE.
Somewhere beneath the sand-dunes of the Lancashire
est coast, seven miles from Southport, lies a huge
untapped supply of oil.
Sixteen engineers who have just sunk a bore hole hope
to find it before their instruments register 7,500 ft.
They cannot go any deeper than that with their present
equipment and if they have not found it at that depth
they will try somewhere else.
An official at the D'Arcy Exploration Co, who is doing
the work, said "for ten years we have been getting 400
tons of oil a year from eight 'surface wells' at
Formby, but those wells are only 100 ft deep and we are
confident that a large oilfield, much deeper is
supplying them".
They tried three times before at Scarisbrick and
Bickerstaffe, but although they went down to 7,600 ft
they could not find the source.
Pointing to a thick, pinky fluid oozing out of a large
pipe alongside the towering derrick on the new site,
John Gibson the drilling superintendant explained
"that is the circulating mud which we pour down the
centre of the drill pipe, it seeps through the drilling
bit and brings up the small pieces of rock formation".
After the formation has been sieved out, the mud goes
back down the drill pipe.
ROOM
15 JUL 1949
A. M.

1963-F236/T2730

A NEW TUNNEL UNDER THE THAMES.
17.3.40.
A new tunnel, driven under the river Thames from Battersea
Power Station to Chelsea, will carry cables between the power
station and a new sub-station in north-west London. The
2,800 ft tunnel - one of the most modern in the engineering feats
in London - takes 500-ft-radius bends to miss the piers
of the Victoria Railway Bridge, but in spite of this
it was only 2/8-inch out when it connected with the pit dug at
the Chelsea end. Continuous shifts working day and night
since in st September have averaged 80 feet per week, and
pressurised air is had to be used to keep the engineers going.
At one point the tunnel air pressure of 10lb per square inch
had to be increased to 30lb to stop the water from bursting
through. The internal diameter of the tunnel is eight feet
and it is being lined with 1,900 tons of cast-iron lining.
It is 76 feet below ground level on the south bank, and 28
feet under the river bed at the highest point.
The picture shows:- the end of the tunnel at Chelsea
Bridge Road showing the airlock manhole.

A workshop in the Sutherland Shire, at Menai, will help men who formerly have no hope of employment to learn useful and productive skills and assist them in personal adjustment.
The Menai Vocational Centre, near the National Fitness camp, will

Disabled men get new start in life

While most of the work is concentrated on assembling and manufacturing articles, a lot of skill and patience must be learned in the workshop.
Many of the men have gone through a lot of hardships, but are now eager to get on in life.
The first 20 men all live at the centre, but there are plans to expand it to 60 men, 40 of whom will be "living out" in the Shire.
Mr. John Williams, the general supervisor, said:

Wonderful

"Also, the community is gradually to be drawn into the work, so far as possible, Mr. Williams said.
"We want them to feel that the centre is part of the Shire, and not a place where men are "put away".
"Many people in the Shire have donated money for this project, and many have offered to help in an honorary capacity. This will give them a chance to work with the men at the centre, not just give money."
The secretary of the centre is the Shire Clerk, Mr. L.T. Archer.
The committee of management includes Aldermen S.G. Munro and H.F. Matty, and Mr. D.H. Stephens (acting district officer of Social

VISITORS to the Gorseinon factory of Swears and Wells, Ltd.,
yesterday saw 80 processes through which raw pelts are put
before they become fur coats. Here, mannequins Pat Scott (left)
and Johnny Johnson show what the finished product looks like.
Disabled men
get new start
in life
WHEN silicosis forced 60-
year-old Ivor Davies to
give up colliery work, he never
dreamed that he would one
day become an expert on furs.
But Ivor got a job at the first
fur factory in South Wales, and
like many other disabled men at
Gorseinon, he has begun to live a
new life.
Wonderful
Now, he is learning his craft as
a fur "topper"—and likes it. As
visitors crowded the factory to see
a mannequin parade yesterday, he
said: "I never imagined I would
ever get a job like this. It's fine."
Charge hand in the finishing
room is Tal Evans, for 22 years a
Gorseinon steel-worker. He was
injured by a furnace explosion
and spent over three years in hos-
pital.
The chairman of the company,
Mr. Cyril Ross, said of the workers:
"They are wonderful. Their fin-
ished work is a credit to them and
their team spirit is inspiring."

AND BOTTLING PLANT

The largest and most modern plastic film
producing and bottling plant in the world will
be opened at 10:00 A.M. on Friday,
June 27, 1958, by Governor Luther Hodges of North Carolina
and Charles A. Thomas, President, (Monsanto).
Built at a cost of over $18 million
for the film plant, plus $2 million
for the bottle plant, for a total of $20 million,
it stands on a 50-acre
site at Kernersville, a mile North of
Reidsville. The film producing facilities
occupy a 10-acre site with 110,000 square
footage on the main floor. In appearance
and size, the main film producing plant
resembles the main building of the huge
textile mill in the Triad. It is the North
Carolina site. The beginning in 1956 of
the site was researched for future expansion.

*FIRST* in North Carolina (Lowpoint) and
the most modern in the Carolinas' plastics
film producing plant. The total footage in the
main plant is 110,000 square feet. The total
floor from which the plastic film is extruded
and bottled is 110,000 square feet, all on the

1983-5236 / 48978

SCOTLAND'S BIGGEST WHISKY BLENDING
AND BOTTLING PLANT.

The largest and most modern plant for
blending and bottling Scotch whisky will
be opened on Friday June 15 by Lord
Polwarth, Chairman of the Scottish Council
(Development and Industry).

Built at a cost of over £1½ million
for the 116-year-old firm of John Dewar
& Sons, the plant stands on a 50-acre
site at Inveralmond, a mile north of
Perth. The new headquarters occupies
24 acres of a 50-acre site with a 400-yard
frontage on the main A9 road to Inverness
and near the main railway services,
including the new £2 million Perth
marshalling yard for freight to the north
of Scotland. The remaining 26 acres of
the site are reserved for future expan-
sion.

Picture shows - Bob Watson (right) and
Tom Swan at work in the Dewar Blending
Road at Inveralmond. Behind them can be
seen three of the four giant blending
vats from which the whisky is run off into
casks to lie for a period of 'marrying'
on the storage floor.

NOT FOR PUBLICATION BEFORE
MORNING PAPERS FRIDAY JUNE 15 1962

NO PUBLICATION FEE. ISSUED WITH THE
COMPLIMENTS OF JOHN DEWAR & SONS LTD.

AMIDST THE WORLD WAR, SCIENCE STILL HELPS THE FARMER.
WORLD FAMOUS STATION CELEBRATES JUBILEE IN 1943.
The ROTHAMSTED EXPERIMENTAL STATION, situated at
HARPENDEN, Herts, has now almost completed a century
of scientific work on agricultural problems, mainly
concerned with soil fertility and plant desease.
Today, the ROTHAMSTED EXPERIMENTAL STATION is world-
famous. It is the recognised centre of soil
research for this country, and its influence is felt
throughout the British Empire.
The famous fields on which the correct use of
fertilisers was first worked out by the founder of the
station, Sir JOHN LAWES and since demonstrated to
several generations of farmers, are still maintained
they are visited by agriculturists from all over the
world. The Station has a large and excellently
equipped laboratory for the detailed study of the
chemistry, physics and biology of soils and crops.
Mr. J. B. (afterwards Sir John) LAWES, started the
is estate at ROTHAMSTED in 1843.

NEW CREPE & RAYON INDUSTRY IN NORTHERN IRELAND.
A new industry which has sprung up in Northern
Ireland is the preparation and weaving of
rayon crepe and other rayon fabrics.
Crepe Weavers Ltd., of Newtownards, Co. Down,
which commenced in 1946 occupies part of Newtownards
Airport which was originally built for the production
of aircraft.
It employs 125 people at present but will employ 200
people by the end of the year when the mill is fully
equipped.
Owing to the male unemployment situation in the
district it is the intention of the firm to employ
60 per cent men and 40 per cent women.
The production target for the end of the year is 30,000
yards of Rayon fabrics per week, of which between 50
and 60% will be for export.
Most of the workers engaged are trainees formerly
agricultural labourers and laundry workers.
Care has been taken not to engage workers from linen
textile mills in the district which would have added
to the production of the new firm but would have
caused difficulties in the established firms.
OPS. One of the employees works on an improvised
fixture which operates the drawing in preparation of
the works for the looms.
This fixture is a temporary measure until automatic
machines for this purpose arrive.

DAILY HERALD COPYRIGHT PHOTOGRAPH
MUST NOT BE REPRODUCED WITHOUT
WRITTEN PERMISSION

24 NOV 1953
MANCHESTER

GREAT NEW TOWER CRANE.
JODRELL BANK. THE NEW BRITAIN'S BUILDING....

LONDON. Driver Ken Oslve, of Peterborough,
who was formerly an organist, lifts from
the cabin of the giant full-capacity Tower
Crane delivering concrete on the top floor
of a six-storey building at Jodrell Bank,
Cheshire. This cable-operated crane, designed
to lift 750 lbs to a height of 100 ft. per minute.
The new kind of crane designed at the Government Building Research
Station, may double the speed of brick building.
It is based on a similar device used on the
Continent. The British prototype is expected
to enable big strides to be made in overcoming
the "new" building labour.
Main difference from the tower crane, which runs
on rails, is that the jib instead of rising
diagonally from the beam, works horizontally
from the main structure - pushing materials
not only to be lifted vertically, but served
horizontally across the building site to the
spot where the craftsmann needs them.
The number of bricklayers working on a site
can be doubled - with the extra men delivery
of bricks to them, with the aid of the new cranes,
which is used to remove excavator earth, unload
material from lorries, lifting floor joists and
window and door frames, roofing timbers and tiles,
and in general speed-up all building.
In November, 1953-4.

Jodrell Bank Building

BY ARTHUR OSMAN
block of flats was ordered to be
closed yesterday after five people fell
when a balcony collapsed under them.
All five were taken to hospital with head and
leg injuries. Four of them were detained.
The flats, part of a £235,000 development at
West Bromwich, Staffs., were handed over to the
local council only this week.
Tenants were due to move in early next week.
After the accident,
technicians and de-
signers began a close
inspection of the col-
lapsed balcony and
others in the four-
storey block at Ten-
score Straight, West
Bromwich.
The contractors, Sir
Alfred McAlpine's, said:
“We are preparing an
urgent report.”
West Bromwich Council
ordered a full-scale in-
quiry and called in all keys
which had been handed to
tenants.
INJURIES
A spokesman said: “No
one will be allowed to enter
until inquiries are com-
pleted.”
The five people were
inspecting a new flat
when the second-floor bal-
cony collapsed.
Mr. Horace Hall, aged 59,
is in hospital with head
injuries, his wife Minnie,
55, with leg injuries, their
daughter, Mrs. Margaret
Greenhalgh, 33, with back
injuries, and her 10-year-
old daughter, Deborah,
with a fractured skull.
NO WARNING
Also hurt was Mr. and
Mrs. Hall's other daughter,
25-year-old Mrs. Barbara
Timmins, who went home
after treatment for leg
injuries.
She said last night:
“The balcony collapsed
without warning. We had
no time to get off.
“My sister and I were
going to clean the new flat
for my mother, who was
going to move in next
week. Now she says she
does not want it.”

BESPOKE BOOTMAKERS CLOSE DOWN THROUGH LACK OF CRAFTSMEN.
Last week saw the closing down of the World-famous
bespoke bootmakers Peal & Co.Ltd. of Wigmore Street.
Up to the end the business was still being run by
father and son directors Mr.C.PEAL and Mr.RODNEY PEAL,
fifth and sixth generation of the family who founded
the business 174 years ago. Among it's clients, are
EARL MOUNTBATTEN, the DUKE OF WINDSOR, the late SIR
WINSTON CHURCHILL, for whom they made boots and shoes
for 40 years up until his death, and host of Royal and
other prominent personages. Although they have been
getting about 1,000 new clients every year, they are
closing because they just cannot get the skilled
craftsmen essential to maintain their high standard.
Most of the clients had their own lasts, from which
shoes were made, measurements being exact to the
millimetre, and the lasts are now being sold to the
customers for 3 guineas each.

PHOTO SHOWS:
At PEAL'S, 71-year-old MR.W.L.PIGGOTT,
of Bechen, Sussex, who has been with the firm for 57 years,
during which he has made 150 crossings of the Atlantic in
the course of his duties. He is seen sorting out lasts
for return to customers. The one he is holding is the
DUKE OF WINDSOR'S.

RATIONING OF PETROL AND OIL FOR USE IN PRIVATE MOTOR CARS.

The following information, with regard to the rationing of petrol and oil for use in private motor cars, has been supplied by the Ministry of Transport. The national interest in the conservation of petrol and oil is recognised. Therefore, it is requested that all owners of private cars should, if possible, restrict the use of their vehicles to essential purposes only. The owners of motor cars which are at present taxed, have already received, or will shortly receive, a questionnaire from the Ministry of Transport and it is important that they should fill it in and return it as soon as possible, since it is necessary for the Ministry to have complete information about the number of cars in use and the extent of their use for purposes other than those of essential national importance.

C.A.V. (CAV) Ltd. of Acton, London, have equipped a number of vehicles with generators for the purpose of operating a small electric motor from the engine's dynamo. This motor drives a small fan which, if switched on, will blow cold air around the occupants of the car. This device is known as the "Aerofoil" electric fan and is available from the firm in question for 50s. Od.

1983-5236/56564

MACE FOR BRITISH JEWELLERS' ASSOCIATION 26.1.55.

The British Jewellers' Association, which
represents nearly 2,000 manufacturing and
wholesale jewellers, has become a patron
of its own trade. The Central Council of the
Association recently decided that the ancient
art of silversmithing was in serious danger
of extinction without public support.It was
decided that the Association should commission
a special piece every year, thus building up its
own collection of fin silver-ware and, at the same
time, setting an example to similar organisations
who might become patrons to the trade. The first
piece,amodern silver mace for use upon ceremonial
occasions, has now been completed, designed by the
well-known designer R.H.Hill, and made by a london
firm of silversmith's.

I.N.P.PHOTO SHOWS:- A close-up of the 21 inch solid
silver mace, which employs the three
motifs of the sun, moon and mercury, which
figure in the Associations coat-of-arms.

Picture by Reg.Palmer

1983-S236/41343
UNLESS someone comes up
with an effective cockerel-
silencer, Albert Owen will have
to silence his cockerels, Mat-
thew, Mark, Luke and John,
for good.
(Here he is, on the left, with
John).
Two neighbours of Mr. Owen,
who lives in Rippoth-road,
Bow, E., took their cockerel
complaints to Thames Court
yesterday.
Said Mr. Charles Baker:
"They start crowing at about
4.30 in the morning and it is
impossible to get any rest.
Sometimes they crow in the
night."
Mr. Albert Jefferies had a
slightly different complaint: "I
have seven children," he said,
"and one boy is a very light
sleeper.
ROOM TO CROW
"The cockerels wake HIM up
--and he wakes the family up
by running round the house
every morning."
Mr. Owen, who pleaded not
guilty to keeping noisy animals
which caused a serious nuis-
ance, said that, on advice, he
had raised their perches and
covered the front of the run.
He was fattening the cockerels
for Christmas.
"If they have room to stretch
their necks, they can crow,"
pointed out the clerk of the
court.
The magistrate, Col. W. E.
Batt ("I should be very angry
if I was disturbed before
eight on a Sunday morning")
adjourned the case for two
weeks if Owen would under-
take to keep the cockerels
quiet-or kill them.

SEARCH FOR OIL AT AUGHTON.
Inaccurate talk of the discoveries of the Lancashire
oilfield apart, seven miles from Southport, lies a huge
untapped supply of oil.
Skilled engineers who have just sunk a bore hole have
to find it before their instruments register 7,000 ft.
They cannot go any deeper than that with their present
equipment and if they have not found it at that depth
they will try somewhere else.
An official at the O'erby Exploration Co. who is doing
the work, said "For ten years we have been boring and
some of it is very deep over 'surface wells' at
Formby. Our three wells are only 1400 ft deep and we are
searching hard a large oilfield, much deeper in
theing."
They tried three times before at Aughton,and and
Birkencough, but although they went down to 7,000 ft
they could not find the source.
Pointing to a thirty-penny drill coming out of a large
pipe alongside the Howard's derricks on the new site,
Formby shows the drilling equipment, an explanation
"That is the revolving rod which as you see the
centre of the drill pipe. It sways through the drilling
and any sludge or the small pieces of rock formation".
After the formation has been blown out, the mud does
then flow the drill pipe.

13 JUL 1949

DARK
13 JUL 49

SEARCH FOR OIL IN LANCASHIRE.
Somewhere beneath the sand-dunes of the Lancashire
XXXXXXX coast, seven miles from Southport, lies a huge
untapped supply of oil.
Sixteen engineers who have just sunk a bore hole hope
to find it before their instruments register 7,500 ft.
They cannot go any deeper than that with their present
equipment and if they have not found it at that depth
they will try somewhere else.
An official at the D'Arcy Exploration Co, who is doing
the work, said "for ten years we have been getting 400
tons of oil a year from eight 'surface wells' at
Formby, but those wells are only 100 ft deep and we are
confident that a large oilfield, much deeper is
supplying them".
They tried three times before at Scarisbrick and
Bickerstaffe, but although they went down to 7,600 ft
they could not find the source.
Pointing to a thick,pinky fluid oozing out of a large
pipe alongside the towering derrick on the new site,
John Gibson the drilling superintendant explained
"that is the circulating mud which we pour down the
centre of the drill pipe, It seeps through the drilling
bit and brings up the small pieces of rock formation".
After the formation has been sieved out, the mud goes
back down the drill pipe.

DAILY HERALD
196 21964

A 15TH-CENTURY house made 20th-century history yesterday by being moved in one piece from one place down the Tyne. Builders put it up. Crowds watched it trundling up a slope towards its new site.
The house will seat Forbes Council in 1946. Originally May took over the house-in-Progressville-with the plan of pulling it down to make way for the city's new Plaza by paid, but there was a of protest.
The Ministry of Works gave the the house at once-that its charming gables were a school.
TOP-HEAVY
At first the house was feared that it would be too heavy on one side, but the skilled movers succeeded in maintaining an even balance. Special tools were used to make sure the house was kept on an even keel.
Says Mr. David Rio, foreman of the moving contractors: "It was a tricky job, especially when it was at the steepest part of the climb."
The house is an historic building, and was originally owned by a wealthy merchant. Its great charm is due to the strong architectural character and simple lines of the building.
It is hoped that the house will stand as a monument to the spirit of enterprise and progress of the city, and as a reminder that the new Plaza will not mean the end of all the city's fine old buildings.
Not easy! A piece of old England puts going on wheels.

HOUSING- HOUSES- MISC

HERALD REPORTER
A 16TH-CENTURY house made 20th-century history
yesterday by being moved in one piece from the
place where the Tudor builders put it up. Crowds
watched it trundling up a slope towards its new site
300ft. away.
The move will cost Exeter Council £8,000. Originally
they took over the house—in Frog-street—with the idea
of pulling it down to make way for the city's new inner
by-pass. But there was a
storm of protest.
The Ministry of Works told
the council to move it to
another site. For more than
a month workmen "crated"
the 30-ton, three-storey
house in 10 tons of timber.
And yesterday looking as
stately as possible on its
special wheels, it was winched
up a one-in-ten gradient.
TOP-HEAVY
At first two winches were
used. But the house moved too
fast and the removal team
switched to one.
Spirit levels were used to
make sure the house was
kept on an even keel.
Mr. David Nye, the London
architect who has advised the
council on the move, watched
the operation.
Haul away! A piece of old
England gets going on wheels.

DAILY HERALD
22 JUL 1961

"The house is top-heavy in

ping over," he said.

In fact it reached the top of
the slope ahead of schedule. To-

A CONCRETE slab crashed on the radiator of the Queen's Rolls-Royce as she drove with Prince Philip through cheering crowds in Belfast today. The 25lb. slab was dropped from the 50ft.-high fourth floor of a partly-built office block.

The Rolls did not stop. The Queen seemed unaffected by the incident.

Prince Philip's only reaction was to crane his neck to see where the missile came from.
But there was uproar among the crowd.
An angry group tried to get into the building from which the concrete was thrown, and someone cried: 'Bring him up!'

CALMED
Police blocked the entrance, and the crowd were filmed by an announcement that a man had been arrested.
A woman in the crowd said: 'I was horrified when something sailed over our heads and crashed on the car. But the royal couple seemed to remain very calm.'
The rear hood of the Rolls had been removed for the drive through the city, but a transparent plastic shield covered the rear of the car.
A few minutes before the concrete slab crashed, a bottle of beer was thrown at the Rolls. The bottle smashed on the road under the car.

Police arrested a woman from Salford, Lancashire.

- ALERT

Transcribed_Text:
A CONCRETE slab crashed on the radiator of
the Queen's Rolls-Royce as she drove with
Prince Philip through cheering crowds in Belfast
today. The 25lb. slab was dropped from the
50ft.-high fourth floor of a partly-built office
block.

The Rolls did not
stop. The Queen
seemed unaffected
by the incident.
Prince Philip's only
reaction was to crane
his neck to see where
the missile came from.
But there was uproar
among the crowd.
An angry group tried to
get into the building from
which the concrete was
thrown, and someone cried:
"String him up."

CALMED
Police blocked the
entrance, and the crowd
were calmed by an
announcement that a man
had been arrested.
A woman in the crowd
said: "I was horrified when
something sailed over our
heads and crashed on the
car. But the royal couple
seemed to remain very
calm."
The rear hood of the Rolls
had been removed for the
drive through the city, but
a transparent plastic shield
covered the rear of the car.
A few minutes before the
concrete slab incident, a
bottle of beer was thrown at
the Rolls. The bottle
smashed on the road under
the car.
Police arrested a woman
from Salford, Lancashire.

ALERT

PRINCE PHILIP TO OPEN NEW STEEL PLANT NEXT
WEEK.
25.10.67.

THE NEW Ãƒâ€šÃ‚Â£30,000,000 CONCAST STEEL CONCENTRATION WORKS
AT TINSLEY PARK, SHEFFIELD, SOUTH YORKSHIRE, WHICH
HRH PRINCE PHILIP TO-MORROW (OCT. 26) IS CALLED TO OPEN,
THE MOST ADVANCED PLANT OF ITS KIND FOR THE
MANUFACTURE OF SPECIAL ENGINEERING STEELS.

THE PLANT REVOLUTIONISES THE MAKING OF CARBON
AND ALLOY STEELS WHICH HITHERTO HAVE BEEN
PRODUCED IN CONSIDERABLY SMALLER QUANTITIES. THE
NEW WORKS, ON THE 400-ACRE SITE OF A COLLIERY
TIPPING, HAS CAPACITY OF UP TO 1,200,000 TONS OF BILLETS
A YEAR. IT EMPLOYED 3,500 MEN AND HAS SIX FURNACES
FOR THE STEEL MAKING. THE TINSLEY PARK WORKS
HAS ALREADY BEEN RESPONSIBLE FOR A RECORD PRODUCTION
OF 82,000 TONS OF INGOTS IN ONE WEEK, AND IS NOW
IN SIGHT OF ITS DESIGNED CAPACITY OF 20,000 TONS
OF STEEL A WEEK, IN WHICH BILLETS WILL BE PRODUCED
FOR A WHOLE RANGE OF PURPOSES, FROM RAILS TO THE

IN THE WINTER PALACE FOR THE DINNER

FOR FIRST PUBLICATION TUESDAY'S DAILIES
15TH OCTOBER, 1963

PRINCE PHILIP TO OPEN £26M. STEEL PLANT TODAY
JS 15.10.63.
THE NEW £26,000,000 ENGLISH STEEL CORPORATION WORKS
AT TINSLEY PARK, SHEFFIELD, WHICH WILL BE OPENED
BY PRINCE PHILIP TODAY (TUESDAY), IS CLAIMED TO BE
THE MOST ADVANCED PLANT IN EUROPE FOR THE
PRODUCTION OF SPECIAL ENGINEERING STEELS.
THE PLANT REVOLUTIONISES THE MAKING OF CARBON
AND ALLOY STEELS WHICH PREVIOUSLY HAVE BEEN
PRODUCED IN COMPARATIVELY SMALL QUANTITIES. THE
NEW WORKS, ON THE 500-ACRE SITE OF A DISUSED
COLLIERY, CAN PRODUCE UP TO 385,000 TONS OF BILLETS
A YEAR WITH AMPLE PROVISION FOR FUTURE EXPANSION.
FOR THE FIRST TIME, THE TINSLEY PARK WORKS
PUT SPECIAL STEEL PRODUCTION ON A FLOW BASIS. ONE-
HUNDRED-TON ELECTRIC-ARC FURNACES MELT STEEL WHICH
CAN THEN BE FED DIRECTLY TO MODERN ROLLING MILLS
IN INGOTS OF 2½ TO 5 TONS - WELL IN EXCESS OF THE
SIZE PREVIOUSLY USED FOR THE ROLLING OF ALLOY AND
SPECIAL CARBON STEELS. EVERY TECHNICAL INNOVATION
HAS BEEN INCORPORATED TO ENSURE THE GREATEST
POSSIBLE ECONOMY AND TO MAINTAIN A HIGHER QUALITY
OF STEEL THAN HAS BEEN POSSIBLE BEFORE.
PHOTO SHOWS:

IN THE CONTROL PULPIT FOR THE 20-INCH
BAR MILL SHEKES THIS OPERATOR, AIDED BY
CLOSED-CIRCUIT TELEVISION, CONTROLS THE
MOVEMENTS OF THE BILLETS TO THE FURNACE.

1983-5236/47639

A FARM WITH A DIFFERENCE.
MJH/HT.

A farm with a difference is that run by Mr. T. Donnellan
at Warsash, Southampton. For on his farm Mr. Donnellan
has no cows, horses, pigs or sheep - his "stock" consists
of crabs, lobsters, crawfish, prawns, oysters etc., for he
is a sea-food farmer. His "fields" are 4,000 sq. yards
of water where thousands of sea-animals caught by Hampshire
and Cornish fisherfolk are kept in salt-water storage ponds
for 30 days before being sent away to end up on a plate.
Mr. Donnellan's two daughters Catherine (9) and Mary (7)
love to help on this fascinating farm and are not the least
bit frightened of the crabs, lobsters etc. - on the contrary
they love them and can name all the 5,000 different species
and varieties of sea animals, worth £4,000 kept on the farm.
The little girls even wade in the ponds at low water in bare
feet and are X not the least afraid of getting their toes
nipped.

PHOTOGRAPH SHOWS: Bare-footed CATHERINE (9) and MARY (7)
are seen helping their father MR. T. DONNELLAN, who is holding
a giant crawfish, to collect crabs, lobsters etc. for
despatch to various hotels, restaurants, etc. on their
farm at Warsash, Southampton. Mr. Donnellan also supplies
many ocean liners with fresh crabs, lobsters etc.
FOX PHOTOS SEPTEMBER 14TH. 1955. 525895.

FOR FIRST PUBLICATION THURSDAY'S EVENINGS - 27.11.47.

AIDING THE AIRCRAFT DESIGNER OF THE FUTURE AND
BRITISH FAME FOR THOROUGHNESS.
27.11.47.

A new altitude chamber has been built at Hatfield
works of the de Havilland Aircraft Co.Ltd., makers of
the famous jet aircraft, etc. The purpose of this
chamber is the research into the use of equipment at
high altitudes - altitudes that may be in common use
in the future as more and more knowledge is gained of
the stratosphere and jet engine performance. The main
chamber is 35 feet long and 14 feet in diameter, and in
it conditions of atmospheric pressure, temperature and
humidity can be reproduced of varying altitudes up to
80,000 feet. A team of technicians controls the tests ;
a number of the observers are stationed inside the
chamber, and a two-way system of communications with
those outside enables a complete check to be made of the
happenings to whatever material is being subjected to
the tests. Confirming these reports is a complicated
system of strain gauges and other indicators, supplemented
by a microphone which amplifies the sounds of structure
breaking up, and transmits them to the outside
observers. The following pictures show

a general view of the main chamber. The end cover is
attached by means of the hinged bolts seen around the
periphery of the cylindrical portion.

Indus Aircraft-Research. Altitude Chamber.

description: A photographic print from the Daily Herald Archive folder: Industry ÃƒÆ’Ã¢â‚¬Å¡Ãƒâ€šÃ‚Â» Agriculture ÃƒÆ’Ã¢â‚¬Å¡Ãƒâ€šÃ‚Â» Poultry - Birds + Farms - Miscellaneous.

A BROWN-AND-WHITE
hen, nesting in half an
orange-box last night in a
backyard at Barr-road,
Gravesend, looked quite
ordinary.

But, said her owner, carpenter
Charles Woodbine, she has laid six
eggs in one day-three times.

Experts are astonished. Four
eggs in a day is the record, they
say, and the normal for a fast
layer is an egg every 25 hours.

Said Mr. Woodbine: "I'm used
to people not believing me. But
none of my neighbours keeps hens
and I am satisfied no one is put-
ting eggs in the nest for a joke."

He said he discovered he had a
"wonder bird" in February when
she was put in a pen away from
his other birds because she was
pecking at them.

Kept a log

One day he found six eggs in her
nest and started keeping a log.
This is what it shows:

March 1 to 14, one egg a day;
March 15, four (between 8 a.m.
and 6 p.m.)

March 16 to 18, two, three and
three.

Then a few "nil" days, followed
by a routine one, two or three, and
another four. But on Monday it
happened again six between
breakfast and bedtime.

Mr. Woodbine showed me a
bowl of six eggs, saying: "She
laid these today. Each had a
small dent in the crown.

The hen is a crossbreed-Rhode
Island Red and Sussex. Mr. and
Mrs. Woodbine got their poultry
knowledge from books. The "won-
der bird" was one of a batch of
six-week-old chicks they bought in
January.
Transcribed_Text:
A BROWN - AND - WHITE
hen, nesting in half an
orange-box last night in a
backyard at Barr-road,
Gravesend, looked quite
ordinary.

But, said her owner, carpenter
Charles Woodbine, she has laid six
eggs in one day—three times.

Experts are astonished. Four
eggs in a day is the record, they
say, and the normal for a fast
layer is an egg every 25 hours.

Said Mr. Woodbine: “I'm used
to people not believing me. But
none of my neighbours keeps hens
and I am satisfied no one is put-
ting eggs in the nest for a joke.”

He said he discovered he had a
“wonder bird” in February when
she was put in a pen away from
his other birds because she was
pecking at them.

• Kept a log

One day he found six eggs in her
nest—and started keeping a log.
This is what it shows:

March 1 to 14, one egg a day;
March 15, four (between 8 a.m.
and 6 p.m.);
March 16 to 18, two, three and
three.

Then a few “nil” days, followed
by a routine one, two or three, and
another four. But on Monday it
happened again—six between
breakfast and bedtime.
Mr. Woodbine showed me a
bowl of six eggs, saying: “She
laid these today.” Each had a
small dent in the crown.
The hen is a crossbreed—Rhode
Island Red and Sussex. Mr. and
Mrs. Woodbine got their poultry
knowledge from books. The “won-
der bird” was one of a batch of
six-week-old chicks they bought in
January.

1983-5236/84039 14.7.39
AT 5.30 yesterday evening Thomas
Atkinson tidied up his desk in the
counting house of a London store and went
home to Landseer-street, Battersea Park,
S.W.
This morning he will walk into the
barracks of the Queen's West Surrey Regi-
ment at Guildford, and become for six
months Militiaman Thomas Atkinson.
He will be one of 30,000 men, the first batch of
conscripted militiamen, who to-day leave their jobs
and their families to begin their military training
in dozens of barracks and camps.
Since, whether he wants to or not, Thomas Atkin-
son is making history, you ought to watch him
closely.
Militiaman
Thomas Atkin-
son bids six
months' fare-
well to his
office desk be-
fore going into
training with
the first batch
of the 20-year-
olds to be
called up.
Every day next week, and after that
from time to time, I am going to describe
his training. But first I should like to
give you a clear picture of Thomas Atkin-
son.
He told me when I spoke to him yester-
day that his grandfather, who fought in
the Boer War, died a few days ago at the

D.H. TUES. 20-10-50
DEBRIS OF COLLAPSED
A three-storey empty bombed house in Hertford Street, Mayfair collapsed to the rubble pile high debris not belonging to Mr-Peter-Broadhurst on a sports car belonging to him he had only bought four days ago.
The wreaked car will filmend about.

A young authoress who pushed her husband's sports car into the road to prevent it being damaged by high winds, saw him- self and the car narrowly miss being buried under a pile of bricks and rubble 20-ft. high.

A three-storey empty bombed house collapsed on to the road, but its high bricks had crashed right on to the car.

The owner of the car, Mr. Peter Broadhurst, of Leverett Manor, Her- tford, was in his car at the time, with his wife. He had bought the car only four days ago. "I just got out of the car," he said, "when the house collapsed and only by the mercy of God escaped myself and the car from under the debris."

Mrs. Maureen Johns, 27, authoress, was helping Mr. Broadhurst to push the car round to park. "I couldn't get the car round," she said, "and jumped out of the car as the whole house crashed behind."
She covered the whole scene with a blanket.

P.S. 3rd

A YOUNG ex-Navy pilot
parked his newly-bought
sports car in Hertford-street,
Mayfair, last night while he
went for a drink. Half an
hour later he found the car
buried under a pile of bricks
and rubble 4ft. high.
A three-storey empty
bombed house had collapsed.
Bricks had crashed right
across the road, but no one
was hurt.
The owner of the car, 24-
year-old Peter Brodhurs, of
Leamington-avenue, Morden,
Surrey, said when he saw his
wreck: “I’m furious. I only
bought the car four days ago
with my gratuity. I was
invalidated out of the Navy a
week ago because of a
crash.”
Miss Harriet Johns, TV
actress, was driving along
Hertford-street to park as the
house fell. “I couldn’t see
anything for dust,” she said.
Police roped off the area as
firemen (pictured above)
cleared the debris.

DAILY
21 DEC 1955
HERALD

D.H. TANNER. 20.12.5
DERELICT HOUSE COLLAPSES.
A three-storey empty bombed house in Hertford
Street, Mayfair, collapsed, the rubble pile high
on a sports car belonging to Mr. Peter Brodhurs
24 yrs. of Morden, Surrey, which he had only
bought four days ago.
P.S. The wrecked car with Firemen about.

One of the 200 homes to choose from in the 15s. book

MOST frustrated house-hunters day-
dream at some time of having their
home built specially for them.
But the problems — finding the land,
choosing the architect, battling with the
builders — can make the prospect as
nightmarish as the old slog around estate
agents and properties.
These problems are considerably
reduced by services supplying books of
plans, like Planahome.
Another help indeed, has just published its
hensive edition of plans.
This new book is supplied at 15s. by a
company called Architectural Services
Planning Partnership. It contains draw-
ings of 200 actual houses (not architect
designed), with a ground plan for each
drawing.
The plans of any of these designs are
available for 25 guineas, complete with
construction details, specifications for the
builders and a choice of garage plans.
The company also supply monthly lists
of building sites through the country and
recommend a builder in the area chosen.
Most of the builders they recommend are
members of the National House Builders'
Registration Council.
Lots more useful reading in the book
tells about such essential matters as
planning permission; it gives information
about other services, such as a profes-
sional interior design scheme for your
home.
The 200 pictures cover an enormous
variety of house types, all pretty sensible
and none wildly outlandish. Personal
variations are allowed for, too.
Alterations to a standard plan can be
made for an extra five guineas. If the
alterations are so big that practically a
completely new plan is needed, the extra
fee is 10 guineas.
Standard plans from the book are
delivered within seven days.

CORNISH TIN MINE

IN the Battle of Malaya, the richest
tin field in the world has fallen into
Japanese hands.
Britain, therefore, will have to look
round for new supplies of a metal
vital to her war industries.
And in this survey, the position of
the Cornish tin mines must come up
for early consideration.
Strangely enough the mining for tin

is Britain's oldest occupation. It has
been carried on for over 1,000 years by
Cornishmen; and at the start of this
century over two hundred mines were
working.
Now there are only three, because,
judged by peace time standards, pro-
duction is "uneconomic."
For, unlike the tin fields of Malaya,
where cheap labour and alluvial
deposits—that is to say deposits left

on the surface by the passage of run-
ning water—make production possible
at very low costs, Cornwall must mine
her tin.
And the miners themselves receive
twelve shillings and sixpence a day.
By no means a vast sum but naturally
much more than native labour in the
Far East commands.
But "economics" is not necessarily

Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/42967
PITHEAD SHALE FOR SITE OF A HOVERPORT.

Lorries unloading shale from Chislet Colliery, Kent, at Pegwell Bay
where it will be used in the construction of the new international
hoverport. Half of Chislet's north west tip (about 180,000 cubic yards)
is being removed to form the base for the 12-acre landing and
launching pad.

-------------

Both black and red shales, which conform to Ministry of Transport
specifications for general fill, are obtainable from colliery sites.
The red shale - which has been used extensively for road making - is
becoming scarce but the black shales of the type used at Pegwell Bay
are in plentiful supply.

The National Coal Board sell shale from site and contractors are
responsible for collection. Contractors operating on colliery sites
have to conform with the Board's regulations regarding work on tips, but
the Board will advise on methods of working.
More than 6 million tons of shale was sold from pithead sites last
year and the demand is increasing. A small section dealing with sales has
been set up under Mr. N. Little, Marketing Department, National Coal
Board, Hobart House, Grosvenor Place, London, S.W.1.

BATTLING FOR BRITAIN'S FORESTS.
15305 (etc.). NEW GOVERNMENT RESEARCH STATION AIDS
RECOVERY OF COUNTRY'S WOODLANDS.

FARNHAM, etc: At the Forestry Commission's new research
station at Alice Holt Lodge, near this Surrey town, where
once the country's greatest surgeons fought for the lives
of Allied war-wounded, another type of 'doctor' is battling
to save something more that Britain sacrificed in the
war effort. Damaged by urgent demands for timber
during the war, much of Britain's forest land has vanished,
and what is left is endangered by pest and disease, and
here scientists are battling to preserve Britain's woodlands.
Not only do they battle forestry pests - they actually
cultivate some for expert. Certain insects are beneficial.
They pray upon parasites that infect trees.
The research station at Alice Holt Lodge-an old mansion
standing in some 2,000 acres of former Crown woodlands, has
an extensive library, laboratories, photography, and pathology
sections.
PHOTO GROUP:- Fungi from cultures is inoculated into a
young tree by the Pathologist at the Forest Research Station.
Injection is made to ascertain whether the resulting disease
symptoms agree with those originally recorded in the forest.
The Pathologist is here, inoculating a young elm with elm
disease. 31st March, 1948. P.8.

ROYAL WEDDING AND REIGN OF THAILAND
THEIR MAJESTIES, THE KING AND QUEEN OF THAILAND, WILL CELEBRATE THEIR NUPTIALS BY THE PRESENTATION OF AN EXQUISITE ROYAL PORCELAIN SET TO THE ROYAL FAMILY. THE PRIVATE CEREMONY TOOK PLACE AT THE ROYAL PALACE, AND THE GIFT WAS PRESENTED TO REPRESENT THE RECOGNITION OF THE KING'S MARRRIAGE BY THE NEWLY WED MONARCH. THE ROYAL PORCELAIN SET CONSISTS OF TWELVE PIECES, EACH HAND-PAINTED WITH GOLD AND SILVER. THE SET IS A TESTAMENT TO THE HIGHLY SKILLED ARTISANS OF THE WORLD-RENOWNED SANKYO PORCELAIN FACTORY, WHICH HAS BEEN IN OPERATION SINCE 1705. THE FACTORY HAS BEEN PRODUCING HIGH-QUALITY PORCELAIN FOR CENTURIES, AND THEIR PIECES ARE HIGHLY SOUGHT AFTER BY COLLECTORS WORLDWIDE. THE SANKYO PORCELAIN FACTORY IS ALSO KNOWN FOR ITS INNOVATIVE DESIGNS AND TECHNIQUES, WHICH HAVE SET THE STANDARD FOR THE INDUSTRY. THE ROYAL PORCELAIN SET PRESENTED TO THE KING AND QUEEN OF THAILAND IS A PRIME EXAMPLE OF THE FACTORY'S COMMITMENT TO EXCELLENCE.

Transcribed_Text:
ROYAL PRESENT FOR KING OF THAILAND. 26.4.50.

For their wedding present to the King of Thailand,
their Majesties, have chosen a service of Worcester
Royal Porcelain. The pattern chosen is known as the
Royal Lily Pattern and is printed in underglaze blue
and enriched with gold. The design was originally adapt-
from the Chinese in the Worcester factory between 1757
and 1788, and was selected by King George. III and Queen
Charlotte when they. visited the works in 1788.
Throughout its 200 years history, the Worcester factory
has produced distinguished underglaze blues. The Worcester
factory was one of the first to be established in England
in the middle of the eighteenth century. European potters
were discovering how to produce porcelain similar to the
Chinese ware, and its early products rank with those of
Bow and Chelsea in the "Golden Age" of English porcelain.
The craftsmanship inherited from those days has helped
to produce this royal present.

I.N.P. PHOTO SHOWS. Part of the Royal Lily Service
which forms the wedding present
of their Majesties, to the King of
Thailand. It is a complete dinner
service for 36 people and includes
coffee cups and saucers.
