Transcribed_Text:
FOR FIRST PUBLICATION EVENING PAPERS MARCH, 12th, 1946.

THE REVIVAL OF THE BRITISH COTTON INDUSTRY.
The world hunger for cotton goods and textiles of all kinds,
together with the Government's realisation that maximum exports
are necessary if Britain is to recover the war years, have
given a new lease of life to the mills of Lancashire, which
represent Britain's greatest export industry. Cotton being
even more important in peace than in war, a constant and
sustained demand is anticipated, and it is good to know that
the bitterness of the years of depression is being eliminated
by regular work, and such in improvements of holidays with pay
and better working conditions, and up-to-date plant and machinery.
This old industry is once again attracting youth, because there
are now more opportunities for promotion than ever before, for the
boy willing to study, and for the bright girl who has always been
essential in the mills. These photographs illustrate how youth is
taking over from age in Lancashire, and how the chimneys are
smoking again after years of depression idleness. They include the
operations of spinning and weaving in two mills. The picture shows:-
Mrs E. Cocker, aged 50, with 35 years in the cotton industry,
9 instructs the young idea in the art of piecing up on the ring frame.
Her assistant is Miss Edith Croasdale, aged 15. They work at the
Talbot Spinning and Weaving Mills at Chorley, Lancs.

(38) EAST KENT STRINGING COMPETITION

Believed to be the only contest of its kind in the world,
the annual Hop Stringing Competition, organised by the
East Kent Hop Planters Association, took place
to-day at Spitsbrook, Collier Street, Kent. About 40
Kentish farmworkers, all experts in hop stringing, and
most of them coming from families which have worked in
the hop gardens for generations, took part. The
stringer's job is to prepare hop gardens for the next
crop by putting up a complicated pattern of strings which
the hops can climb. He works from with a pole 30 feet
long, guiding the string (drawn from a bag slung over
his shoulder) from hooks in the ground to others hanging
on wires overhead. He is followed by a "mandrier"
(usually female) who binds together the groups of
vertical strings over-riding a "hill." In the
competition, each stringer completes a "bay" of 800 -
900 hills. Some 40 miles of string are used in the process.
Competitors - re points for speed, neatness and economy
in the use of string. The object of the competition is
to 'stimulate interest in the effort and to encourage
all... to a highly skilled branch of Agricultural work.

FLUSH SHOT: Mr. F. Page stringing during the
Competition.

10/6/38 Topical Press (T 28591)

Indus Agriculture. Hoppicking, planters.
Transcribed_Text:
1953-5236/45233

XH) KENT HOP STRINGING COMPETITION

Believed to be the only contest of its kind in the world,
the annual Hop Stringing Competition, organised by The
Weald of Kent Ploughing Match Association, took place
to-day at Spitzbrook, Collier Street, Kent. About 40
Kentish farmworkers, all experts in hop stringing, and
many of them coming from families which have worked in
the hop gardens for generations, took part. The
stringer's job is to prepare hop gardens for the next
crop by putting up a complicated pattern of strings which
the hops can climb. He works from with a pole 10 feet
long, guiding the string (drawn from a bag slung over
his shoulder) from hooks in the ground to others hanging
on wires overhead. He is followed by a "bander in"
(usually female) who binds together the groups of
vertical strings comprising a "hill". In the
competition, each stringer completes a "cant" of 200
hills. Some 40 miles of string are used in the process.
Competitors score points for speed, neatness and economy
in the use of string. The object of the competition is
to stimulate interest in the craft and to encourage
ability in a highly skilled branch of agricultural work.

Photo shows:- Mr. F. Bond stringing during the
competition.

Transcribed_Text:
BY ANNE BUILER
ARCHITECT Mr. Eric Lyons tried to design ultra-modern houses when he
planned a small estate of 51 houses. And he succeeded—say the experts.
So well, in fact, that he has just received one of the principal awards in this
year's Good Housing Design Competition.

The competition was organised jointly by the Ministry of Housing and the Royal
Institute of British Architects to “promote the highest standards of design in
housing schemes.” Both local authorities and private developers competed.

The 1961 design for living

But what do the people
living in Lyons-designed
houses think of them?

I went to Waldegrave-park,
Twickenham, Middx, yesterday
and the verdict from the people
who live in them was over-
whelming. They like them.

Mrs. Kathleen Kaye, 32-year-
old wife of a civil engineer,
listed her likes:

Safety—for my children. The
garages are behind the
houses. And the houses are built
round a green cut off from any
traffic.

Refuse collection: easy, with
dustbins hidden near back gates.

Every house is roomy. Small
by accepted standards, but they
seem spacious.

There is under-floor electric
heating. There are no open
fires. And we don't miss them.

I am impressed with the way
every inch of space is utilised.
Instead of walls between the
bedrooms, there are large roomy
cupboards. And the lavatory
door opens
outwards.

Redheaded Mrs. Kaye, who
has two children, Timothy,
three, and Stephen, 10 months,
added: “The house is ideal for
children.”

A neighbour, 32-year-old Mrs.
Honor Brown, mother of two,
said: “When I'm in the kitchen
I can watch the children at
play through a glass partition.”

The first of these prize-win-
ning houses was occupied a year
ago. It cost about £4,500. Only
one family has moved out—
they made a handsome profit of
£1,000.

NNER-WINNING HOUSE DESIGH. DH
ign for 51 Terrace Houses and garages at Fieldend,
ickenham, has won Architect Eric Lyons a prize for
bod housing design.
PS Exterior of the terrace houses.

Transcribed_Text:
1988-5236/48653
Food 131
Meat & Sausages
INDUSTRY. FOOD. MEAT

SPICER
THE SKIN is lifted off
Britain's beloved
banger in an all-revealing
report issued today.
And the verdict after
a massive survey of
sausages is: They're
better than ever.
Which?, the Consumers'
Association magazine, did
the survey.
They say that sausages—
also known as hangers,
snarlers, dogs, wallies and
snorkers—are bursting with
popularity.

60 TYPES
Every man, woman and
child in Britain eats an
average of three-and-a-half
sausages a week—a total of
9,000million in a year.
But what exactly are they
eating?
Which? tested 60 varieties
of large, fresh pork sausages

MORE MEAT AND VALUE
THAN THERE USED TO BE
and found that their meat
content varied from 55 to 96
per cent.
All but three brands had
more than the 32-and-a-
half per cent. minimum of
lean meat laid down by the
Food Standards Committee
eight years ago.

RICE
Sausage fillers analysed
by the experts included
wheat, rice, potato, skim
milk powder and soya.
Which? say: "Sausages
are better now—as far as
the amount of meat is con-
cerned—than they were
eight years ago.
"Prices now bear more
relation to meat content.
With a few exceptions, the
more you pay the more
meat there is." The experts
say there is a strong case
for having a compulsory
standard of meat content or
for sausage makers to print
the content on labels.

'DEFEAT'
About a third of the saus-
ages were considered to
have a slight, or very slight,
taste of pork and 11 brands
had a strong pork taste.
But when it came to pick-
ing the best sausage on sale,
the experts had to admit
defeat.
They say: "We obviously
can't make up your minds
for you about which saus-
age you prefer.
"Pork sausages, thank
goodness, have no standard
taste."

FOR FIRST PUBLICATION FRIDAY'S DAILIES, Oct 6.
ENGLAND HAS EUROPE'S BIGGEST OIL REFINERY
Mas 5.10.50.
Overlooking Southampton Water at FAWLEY, an army of men is engaged in
erecting what will be the biggest oil refinery in Europe, which when
in full operation will contribute 25 per cent to the total refining output of this country - there will be fewer bigger plants anywhere
in the world.
This vast new enterprise of the Anglo-American Oil Company represents
close co-operation between the two countries; it does not involve
Marshall Aid, and will save millions of dollars annually. The project
will cost approximately £37,000,000, and will employ 2,000 people, and
is expected to turn out more than 5,000,000 tons of petroleum pro-
ducts per year. Britain's dependence upon the United States for
petrol and other products of crude oil will be greatly eased. The
picture shows floating roof crude oil storage tanks. On the left is
the 800ft long maintenance building which contains one of the most
up-to-date machine tool shops in the country. In background Southampton
Water.

In the best
Beeton tradition
the recipe
begins. . "take 18
wild rabbits and
remove the skins."
More perplexingly,
you then forget about
the rest of the
rabbits and
concentrate on the
skins. Take a dome-
shaped mould about
the size of a dustbin
and get the skins to
stick to it by blowing
them on . . with
something
considerably more
powerful than a hair-
drier.
If you have followed
these instructions
carefully then you
are well on your way
to making a simply
delicious policeman's
helmet.
The authority for all
this comes from the
firm of Christy and
Co. in Stockport,
Cheshire. If you
knock off a police-
man's helmet in
Britain, you have a
three-in-four chance
of hitting one of theirs
-they make nearly
10,000 a year.
Back to the recipe.
At this stage the
helmet should look
like the thing Mrs.
Kay Bennett (who
works for Christy's)
is wearing in the
picture on the left.
Next it is laminated,
steamed, shrunk,
varnished and given a
final covering of
rabbit skin. And
before it looks any-
thing like the ones in
the picture on the
right, it is proofed, put
briefly under a gas-
jet and given a shave
with fine sandpaper.
The finished object
sells for from 48s. 6d.
to £5, depending on
how elaborate the
trimmings and silver
badges are. Most
policemen get a new
one every other year-
although, as
Mr. Donald Woodman
of Christy's pointed
out: "Some do get
damaged much
earlier."
Roland Hollin.

Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/52666

(XM) L.C.C.'S NEW PAINT-TESTING LABORATORY

In order to enable a systematic check to be maintained
on the qualities of the 200,000 gallons of paint used
annually by the London County Council the chemical
laboratories at County Hall, London, S.E., have been
extended and re-equipped at a cost of about £2,000.
The Public Health Department's Chemist-in-Chief has for
some years been responsible for testing paints used by
the Council on its housing estates, schools and other
establishments. The large quantities of paint now
needed and the increasing complexity of materials used
in manufacture have made it necessary to improve testing
facilities and to instal modern equipment for measuring
such qualities as weathering, hardness and anti-corrosion.
The new paint laboratory has been equipped to supplement
the examination of decorative and protective coatings
which has been made hitherto. The L.C.C. spends
considerably more than £1,000,000 each year in
its painting programme.

Photo shows:- "Mr. K.F.W. Doughty, a chemist in the
L.C.C. Paint-testing Laboratory, putting a sample of
paint in the accelerated weathering machine. This is
designed to produce the effect of years of exposure
to weather in a relatively short time.

February 1st. 1964 PAR 107806-1 (Sh-B)

TO CUT THOSE TELEPHONE DELAYS
With an increasing emphasis being put on
communications in a competetive world, the
General Post Office is turning more and more
to micro wave radio links for increasing
telephone call, radio and television
channel capacity.
Evidence of this is coming in the shape of
a slender steel, concrete and glass tower,
one of which – see picture – is now nearing
completion on the hills at Sutton, near
Macclesfield, Cheshire, to become the subject
of comment by passing motorists.
Two hundred and fifty two feet high, it is
one of 120 similar towers which will
eventually cover the country with radio
and television signals.

ISSUED BY THE CENTRAL OFFICE OF INFORMATION, LONDON.

EMPLOYMENT EXCHANGE JUBILEE.

The 50th. Anniversary of the establishment of the Employment
Exchanges takes place on Monday, 1st. February, 1960. On that
date in 1910, 80 exchanges in England, Wales and Scotland were
opened for business and many other were started in the following
months. The Labour Exchanges (as they were then called) had
been set up as a result of legislation piloted through the Houses
of Commons by Sir Winston Churchill who was then President of the
Board of Trade. To-day there are nearly 1,000 Employment Exchanges
and the Ministry of Labour has been responsible for their
administration since 1910. An average of over 2,000,000 jobs a
year have been filled by the Exchanges since the were set up.

S. PRIMER.
An interior view of the most recently opened Employment Exchange.
It is in the new town of Hemel Hempstead, Hertfordshire, and
was brought into use on the 16th. November, 1959. The building
is shared with other Government Departments.

DUA Housing Temp - NISSEN HUTS

9 - AUG 1946

MORE FURNITURE GOES INTO ARMY HUTS DESPITE QUIT NOTICES.

A policy of 'sit tight' and await developments has been adopted
by ex Servicemen who, with their wives and children, have moved
into unoccupied military huts in St. Paul's Road, Peterborough,
Northamptonshire, because they were unable to find other
accommodation as a result of the housing shortage. Notices to
quit have been served on some of the 'squatters', and German
prisoners have been brought in by the military authorities to
start pulling down huts on the site scheduled for demolition.
Among the families installed are Mr. and Mrs. Harry Joseph Vines
and their 3½-year-old daughter Patricia. Mr. Vines, now an
inspector in a Diesel factory, is a former Petty Officer in the
Navy who won the British Empire Medal for bringing a lifeboat
safely to land after it had been 39 days in the Atlantic following
the torpedoing of a troopship. Whilst recovering from his
ordeal in New York he met Caroline - now his wife - who comes
from Brooklyn.
PHOTO SHOWS:- Mr. Derek Mottram, former paratrooper, pushing a
truck laden with some of his belongings to one of the Nissen huts.
Assisting him are Mrs. Caroline Vines (right), holding Patricia's
hand, and Mrs. Helen Holmes (left). Both women are occupying huts.
LUD August 9th 1946 P.N.r.

First turf on the site of a London County Council
community estate, to cater for higher as well as lower
income groups, was cut by Mr. I.J. Hayward, a leader of
the L.C.C.
The 79 "single-house" houses included in the St Paul's
Cray estate will be built in pairs, each with a garden
back and front, a drive and garage.
Downstairs there will be a hall, cloakroom, large
sittingroom and lounge separated by sliding doors,
dining room and modern kitchen.
Upstairs will be four large bedrooms and bathroom
The houses will be let at an economic rent of between
Ãƒâ€šÃ‚Â£150 and Ãƒâ€šÃ‚Â£180 a year, exclusive of rates.

ESTATE FOR ALL INCOMES.
First turf on the site of a London County Council
community estate, to cater for higher as well as Lower
income groups, was cut by Mr. I.J. Hayward, a leader of
the L.C.C.
The 72 "middle-income" houses included in the St Paul's
Cray estate will be built in pairs, each with a garden
back and front, a drive and garage.
Downstairs there will be a hall, cloakroom, large
sittingroom and lounge separated by sliding doors,
dining room and modern kitchen.
Upstairs will be four large bedrooms and bathroom
The houses will be let at an economic rent of between
£130 and £150 a year, exclusive of rates.
The 570 acre estate will have 3,883 dwellings altogether
and include three-storey blocks of flats, five modern
schools, churches, shops, a cinema, public-house, parks

1983-5236/13090
INDUSTRIES - UNEMPLOYED - DEMONSTRATIONS
LN 348082
MGN
LONDON BUREAU
UNEMPLOYMENT MARCH TO CAERNARVON.
CAERNARVON, WALES : BEARING PLACARDS, UNEMPLOYED WITH
THEIR FAMILIES AND SYMPATHIZERS, MARCH ALONG THE CAERNARVON
ROAD FROM PEN-Y-GROES TO CAERNARVON WHERE THEY ATTENDED A
MASS MEETING IN THE PAVILION THERE. SOME FIVE THOUSAND
PEOPLE MARCHED ONTO CAERNARVON FOR THE MEETING TO PRESS
FOR THE EARLY ESTABLISHMENT OF INDUSTRIES WHICH HAVE
BEEN PROMISED TO THE AREA. WITH THE SEVERE UNEMPLOYMENT
CONDITIONS IN CAERNARVONSHIRE, UNEMPLOYMENT IN THE SOUTH-
WEST WALES AREA HAS RISEN FROM 3,500 IN OCTOBER TO 6,000
IN NOVEMBER AND IS NOW6,000, REPRESENTING SEVEN PERCENT OF
THE INSURED POPULATION, AND WHEN ALL THE OLD WORKS HAVE BEEN
CLOSED, ABOUT FIFTEEN THOUSAND PEOPLE WOULD BE OUT OF WORK,
REPRESENTING MORE THAN TEN PERCENT OF THE INSURED POPULATION.
MATTERS WERE BROUGHT TO A HEAD RECENTLY ON THE DECISION OF
RICHARD THOMAS AND BALDWINS TO CLOSE THE STEELWORKS AT
LLANELLY IN A MONTH TIME, AND THE MINISTER OF POWER, LORD
MILLS, IS TO RECEIVE ON SUNDAY (3RD FEB) A DEPUTATION OF
WELSH M.P.S WHO WILL PUT TO HIM THE URGENCY OF THE CASE FOR
FINDING MORE WORK FOR SOUTH-WEST WALES.
2ND FEBRUARY, 1958 PNLS
PROPERTY OF
DAILY HERALD
-3 FEB 1958

Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/43948

FLL. Housing, Pennant - Harlow Estate.

FOR FIRST PUBLICATION WE, August 18th.
THE PROGRESS OF A NEW TOWN
JS 16.8.50
HARLOW is one of eight New Towns designed for the reception of
population and industry from the crowded area of Inner London,
and which are expected to take about 250,000 Londoners. Harlow's
contribution to this will be an increase in population of
55,000.
HARLOW recently reached a distinct stage in its development with
the commencement of work in building in the MARK HALL area - a
step which marked the beginning of work on the New Town proper
and the end of preparation which has lasted since the approval of
the Master Plan. This Master Plan was the first to receive
official approval despite the fact that the Harlow Development
Corporation was by no means the first to be set up. Much work
has also been done in the Chippingfield area where terraced and
semi-detached houses have been erected, and some of which are
already in occupation by members of the Corporation's staff and
employees of the contractors.
This series of pictures recently taken give some idea of the well-
planned lay-out of the New Town, the types of houses under con-
struction, together with something of the HQ of the Corporation.
P.S. The dining-kitchen is a 3-bedroomed type house (terraced) at
CHIPPINGFIELD.

COAL STOCKPILE AT PAGONIA BAY.

Large quantity stocks of PICHTED colliery, Coal, and Coke were
delivered to Pagoda Bay, Wales. It will be paid to the construction of new
and inter-national airports. Coal of CHTED's stocks will than (about 10,000
cubic yards) is being cleared so that has now for two months- loading and
stocking out.

Both black and red shales, which conform to Ministry of Transport
specifications for general fill, are obtainable from colliery sites. The
red shale - which has been used extensively for road making - is becoming
scarce but the black shales of the type used at Pagoda Bay are in
plentiful supply.

The National Coal Board will obtain free site and contractors are
responsible for collection. Contractors operating on colliery sites have
to conform with Board's Regulations regarding work on tips, but the Board
will advise on methods of working.

More than 6 million tons of shale and coal from pithead sites last

1983-5236/42969

PITHEAD SHALE FOR SITE OF NEW HOVERPORT.

Lorries loading shale at Chislet colliery, Kent, for the 10 mile
journey to Pegwell Bay, where it will be used in the construction of the
new international hoverport. Half of Chislet's north west tip (about 280,000
cubic yards) is being removed to form the base for the 12-acre landing and
launching pad.

Both black and red shales, which conform to Ministry of Transport
specifications for general fill, are obtainable from colliery sites. The
red shale - which has been used extensively for road making - is becoming
scarce but the black shales of the type used at Pegwell Bay are in
plentiful supply.

The National Coal Board sell shale from site and contractors are
responsible for collection. Contractors operating on colliery sites have
to conform with Board's regulations regarding work on tips, but the Board
will advise on methods of working.

More than 6 million tons of shale was sold from pithead sites last
year and the demand is increasing. A small section dealing with sales has

Hygienic
Russian women's training school
(Photo Caption)
"Hygienic" - From top left, the girls are running off from a "school" after being "contaminated" by a group of the "unemployed workers" shown in background. This is the first year this training school has been operating in the Soviet Union.

ROBOT MOTHERS: FIVE
ROBOT MOTHERS: FIVE
Five robot mothers, built and
trained to rear babies, have been
produced by American scientists
and placed in experimental
homes. The aim is to learn
whether artificial mothers can
provide the emotional needs of
a child, as well as the physical.
The robots, operated by a
television set and a sound amplifier
can move, rock a baby, change
diapers, and sing lullabies. If
they are successful, they may
be available to the public in
10 to 15 years.

ROOM FOR 1-6
The robots, called "RoboMoms"
are equipped with a video screen
that shows the child a picture
or a story. They can also play
music, speak and even cry if
the child is crying. They have
been tested on babies aged 1 to 6
years old and have proved to be
quite successful. Researchers are
hopeful that the RoboMoms will
help alleviate the shortage of
childcare workers in the United
States. The project is funded by
the National Science Foundation.

ROBOT MOTHERS FIVE

FIVE-WEEK-OLD orphan
piglets, seen “having one
for the sty” in this picture, are
pioneering an experiment
which may increase Britain's
bacon and pork chop output.

Their milk bar is the inven-
tion of 33-year-old Mr. John
Percy, a pig-breeder, of Chisle-
hurst, Kent. It took him three
years to perfect.

ROOM FOR 14

Into a heat-controlled tank
goes a mixture of “milk” with
all the nutriment of sow's milk,
plus ingredients which no sow
could supply, to make piglets
into super-healthy, fat pigs.

There is room for 14 piglets—
two more than the average sow
is provided with by Nature.

The baby pigs can be weaned
at two days with the machine,
instead of eight weeks with a
sow.

Diseases transmitted from

sow to piglets are avoided and
the machine needs far less
space than a sow with a litter.

Mr. Kenneth Shillam, 24-
year-old manager of a research
station at Stoke Mandeville,
Bucks, where the experiment is
being made, says: “If it is suc-
cessful, it will revolutionise pig-
rearing.”

One thing worried the in-
ventor. Would the piglets,
like crumbs from the machine
upset the piglet economy?

noises off. But they

follow.

RADIO-CONTROLLED PLOUGH IS THE IDEA FOR BRITISH FARMERS

A radio-controlled farm tractor, developed by a British firm,
Tractors (London) Ltd., in co-operation with the automatic
control section of the Royal electrical establishment is
undergoing trials at Barmet, Hertfordshire.
Radio-control apparatus used in the "Queen Box", the target
plans devised for anti-aircraft artillery practice, has been
adapted for use in the tractor, which can be employed for
ploughing and other farm operations.
Including radio signals operate sensitive electrical relays in the
tractor, so that by means of compressed air accumulators
the tractor can be made to run on a straight course, or turn
left or right, and at plans can be raised when the tractor
comes near and can be raised when the tractor comes near and
is in operation. No further plans are attached to the tractor.
The radio-controlled tractor is so soon larger than the
conventional type that it can normally be operated in one hour is
sufficient for a whole day's work.
When the tractor with radio-control apparatus, and
the transmitter (on ground in foreground). This can be right
is holding the tiny tractor switch by means of which the
tractor is controlled.
G October 7th 1940. P.N.O.
Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/45989
*8 OCT 1946

RADIO-CONTROLLED PLOUGH IS NEW IDEA FOR BRITISH FARMERS.

A radio-controlled farm tractor, developed by a British firm,
Tractors (London) Ltd., in co-operation with the Automatic
Control Section of the Royal Aeronautical Establishment is
undergoing trials at Barnet, Hertfordshire.
Radio-control apparatus used in the 'Queen Bee', the target
plane devised for anti-aircraft artillery practice, has been
adapted for use in the tractor, which can be employed for
ploughing and other farm operations.
Incoming radio signals operate sensitive electrical relays in the
receiver, so that by means of compressed air servomotors
the tractor can be made to run on a straight course, or to turn
left or right. The plough can be raised when the tractor
turns at the end of a furrow, the plough-raising system being
cut out when other implements are attached to the tractor.
The radio-controlled tractor is so much lighter than the
conventional type that fuel normally consumed in one hour is
sufficient for a whole day's work.
PHOTO SHOWS:- The tractor with radio-control apparatus, and
the transmitter (on ground in foreground). The man on right
is holding the tiny master switch by means of which the
tractor is directed.
G October 7th 1946 PN.r.

A new altitude chamber has been built at the
Hatfield works of the de Havilland Aircraft Co.Ltd.,
makers of the famous jet planes, etc. The purpose
of the chamber is the research into the use of
equipment at high altitudes - altitudes that may be
in common use in the future as more and more know-
ledge is gained of the stratosphere and jet engine
performance.
The main chamber is 35 feet long and 14 feet in
diameter, and in it conditions of atmospheric pressure,
temperature and humidity can be reproduced of vary-
ing altitudes up to 80,000 feet. A team of observers
control the tests; a number of them are stationed in
the chamber, and a two-way system of communications
with those outside enables a complete check to be made
of the happenings to whatever material is being put
to test. Confirming these reports is a complicated
system of strain gauges and other indicators, supple-
mented by a microphone which amplifies the sounds of
structure breaking up, and transmits them to those out-
side. The following pictures show

FOR THE CORONATION GOWN.-The fine, 8,000 year old art of silk farming, revived at Lillingstone Castle, East, by Lady Mary Dyer, is producing the silk which will be used for the purple velvet Coronation gown for the Duchess of Gloucester and Queen. It is a century old custom in England to make the coronation gowns from the silk of England's own silkworms.
Transcribed_Text:
AY ENGLISH SILKWORM FARM PRODUCES SILK FOR
DUCHESS' CORONATION GOWNS.
,000-YEAR-OLD ART MASTERED AT KENT CASTLE

The only English silkworm farm, established at
Lullingstone Castle, Kent, by Lady Hart Dyke,
is producing the silk which will be used to make
the purple velvet Coronation gowns for the
Duchesses of Gloucester and Kent.
The 5,000-year-old art of cocoon reeling has
been mastered at the farm and five years after
its foundation millions of silkworms are bred.
The brooding and feeding rooms occupy the entire
west wing of the Castle and to food the worms
27,000 mulberry bushes are grown.
The silkworms spin their cocoons on straw
structures producing one thin thread up to
half a mile in length in 48 hours.
PHOTO SHOWS: Reeling the silk from the cocoons.

ESTEN ILLUS. 10.6.42
LAND GIRL DISCOVERED AS WATER DIVINER.
It has taken the Women's Land Army to find out
that Miss Littler, a volunteer in the employment
of the Flintshire War Agricultural Executive
Committee possesses the gift of water divining.
Miss Littler joined the Women's Land Army March 1941
and is one of 9 girls employed on gang work.
Recently they were working on a piece of land which
was constantly being flooded by a hidden spring.
Mr. J.T. Richards, the Executive Officer of the
Flintshire War Agricultural Executive Committee, had
made extensive efforts to have the spring located.
Finally, he asked the 9 members of the Women's Land
Army, who were clearing the land, to try with a
hazel stick to see if they could divine this spring.
Miss Littler was found to be the only one who
possesses this unusual gift. 1942-1950/6682
Since Flintshire farmers have heard of this there
have been many requests for her services, to help
in reclaiming flooded land and so save hundreds
of pounds in drainage. Also farmers wish to use
her to help to discover water for sinking wells.
O.P.S.1. The first step to becoming a Diviner
is to cut a forked twig from a hazel tree.
Miss Littler who is 19 years of age is seen on
right.

photocall
features
Pictures:
Art, White & Ken Gibbs
Reporter:
David Wright

48 Shelton Road, Westminster, London, S.W.1 Phone 83-530 1390 Radio Link Bug 2502 (Blue 1-4-5)

The day the flats collapsed. June 18 1968
(Picture story : Pringle/Photocall).

MISS IVY HODGE, grey haired and marked
by the memory of Ronan Point flats disaster, was helped
into a packed Newman Town Hall yesterday (Tuesday)
to re-live those moments of horror.

"I went to bed at 10.45 - and read a little,"
said the 55-year-old woman, released especially from
Poplar Hospital to give evidence at the inquiry.
"At 2.25 I was awake and I went into the
kitchen to fill the kettle for a cup of tea ... I
can't remember any more. There was a flash across the
ceiling and then the ceiling began to flake."

The inquiry was hushed as Miss Hodge
who lived in a 19th floor flat at Ronan Point - and
is still alive - chose her words. Asked if she
smelt gas she replied : "I didn't smell any gas
and I have a good sense of smell."

She nodded at the end of giving evidence
and was helped back to hospital by two friends.
She is under treatment for burns to her
face arms and legs.

---ends---.

Pictures show Miss Hodge giving evidence -
close-up and overall shot.

LORD ROBENS SEES 'FANTASTIC' NEW
COAL-CUTTING MACHINE
March 12th 1962 PAR 95059-2 (Sh-R)

LORD ROBENS SEES 'FANTASTIC' NEW
COAL-CUTTING MACHINE

LORD ROBENS, Chairman of the National
Coal Board, is pictured (centre, right)
as he watched a revolutionary new mining
machine, the Collins Miner, being demonstrated
to-day (Monday) at the Swadlincote
(Derbyshire) Test Site of the Board's Central
Engineering Establishment.
Seen with Lord Robens is Mr. H.E. COLLINS,
National Coal Board Member for Production,
who pioneered the project.
Lord Robens, who described the machine as
'fantastic', said that manned by 20 men for
three shifts it could produce 1,000 tons of
coal a day, normal output of 300 miners.
The Collins Miner, a cutting and loading
machine which has already cost £100,000 to
develop, has been designed to extract coal
from thin seams where narrow, confined spaces
make conditions exhausting for men.
It consists of a train of special vehicles
run on rails into an underground roadway.
A boring machine remotely controlled by one
man, thrusts into the coal seam feeding the
cut coal back to an extending conveyor belt.
March 12th 1962 PAR 95059-2 (Sh-R)

Indus. Coal. Underground. Coal cutting by machinery.

LOSS OF CLERION SERVICE
CHELTENHAM BOOK IN BOOK TO BE PRESENTED TO FRENCH ISLAND.

Mr. Edgar Turner, who worked on the Bible uses at the
Coronation Service, hand-tooled the design on the front
cover of the book containing a facsimile reproduction of the
Loss of Clerion, which is to be handed over by the
Royal Navy for presentation to the small French island of
Claron at St. Paul's Cathedral on June 1st.
The Service, attended by H.R.H. the Duke of Edinburgh, marks
the sixth centenary of the foundation of the Admiralty Court
of England and the eighth centenary of the promulgation of the
Loss of Clerion.
The Loss of Clerion were based on decisions of the Merchant
Court of the Island, and certain aspects of modern maritime
law can be traced directly to them.
The book, which will be contained in a silver gilt casket,
is being produced by Bangarani and Suteliffe, hand-craft
book binders of Poland Street, London, W.1. It has been made
from a 15th. century manuscript book belonging to the Admiralty
Court and now housed in the Public Record Office.
MAY 1960. A.54307.

TOUGH GUY IN THE MUD OF BRIGHTEY
July 13th 1953 IM 0494-1 (R3-B)

TOUGH GUY IN THE MUD OF BRIGHTEY

For at least seven centuries, the manufacture
of nets, ropes, sails and other ocean
products has been the staple industry of
the town of Bridport. Today,
of Bridport's present-day population of about
6,000, over a thousand - many of them young
women - are engaged in the industry,
directly or indirectly.
At one time locally-grown flax and hemp were
used, but nearly all the raw material is
now imported.
It is recorded that all the ropes and sails
for King John's Navy (the ropes) from
(1199-1216) were made at Bridport. And the
expression 'stabbed by a Bridport dagger' for
a person who had been hanged was current
in 1538, when King Henry VIII reigned.
This picture was taken in the Bridport works
of Joseph Gundry and Co. Ltd., a firm founded
in 1662 and still controlled by lineal
descendants of its founder. There were
Gundrys engaged in the trade as early as 1540.
PICTURE SHOWS: - a modern girl of Bridport
dries a motor-boat-oil trade. She is

1983-5236/47957
MODERN GIRL IN THE WEB OF CENTURIES
July 13th 1953 PAR 36404-1 (BKS-R)

MODERN GIRL IN THE WEB OF CENTURIES

For at least seven centuries, the manufacture
of nets, ropes, sailcloth and other hempen
products has been the staple industry of
the town of Bridport, Dorset.
Of Bridport's present-day population of about
6,000, over a thousand - many of them young
women - are engaged in the industry,
directly or indirectly.
At one time locally-grown flax and hemp were
used, but nearly all the raw material is
now imported.
It is recorded that all the ropes and sails
for King John's Navy (he reigned from
1199-1216) were made at Bridport. And the
expression 'stabbed by a Bridport dagger' for
a person who had been hanged was current
in 1530, when King Henry VIII reigned.
This picture was taken in the Bridport works
of Joseph Gundry and Co.Ltd., a firm founded
in 1665 and still controlled by lineal
descendants of the founder. There were
Gundrys engaged in the trade as early as 1580.

FILTER WIRE TESTING
Arm-board. cellulose paper incorporates temperature
indicator. After warming up, the iron should be
placed on the indicator and left for 30 seconds.
If it does not change colour, temperature is correct.
If indicator turns black, the iron is too hot, and
should be adjusted to a lower temperature and
allowed to cool before trying another indicator.

Section 2.
Commence ironing lengthwise along the least access-
ible edge, following the guide lines from edge to
edge, and allowing 70 sec. per space. Work
six spaces, press and rub down vigorously with rolled
cloth, thus completing the bond as the glue cools.
Repeat the process widthwise. Pay particular attention
to edge. In the event of a mishap, the process may
be repeated at that spot.

Technical Note
The bond strength of Self Stik under conditions
of heat is comparable with that of Impatt
adhesives at present on offer in the general
public.

TEMPER TURE TESTING

Arm bord release paper incorporates temperature
indicators. After warming up, the iron should be
placed on the indicator and left for 30 seconds.
If it does not change colour, temperature is correct.
If indicator turns black, the iron is too hot, and
should be adjusted to a lower temperature and
allowed to cool before trying another indicator.

IRONING

Commence ironing lengthwise along the least access-
ible edge, following the guide lines from space to
space, and allowing 20 seconds per space. Work
six spaces, pause and rub down vigorously with rolled
cloth, thus completing the bond as the glue cools.
Repeat the process widthwise. Pay particular attention
to edges. In the event of a misbond, the process may
be repeated at that spot.

Technical Note

The bond strength of Self Stik under conditions
of heat is comparable with that of impact
adhesives at present on offer to the general
public.

1983-S236/43933

NEW HOUSING SITE AT
DASHWOOD VILLAGE.

MW/MWE

North of the A.40 trunk road between
High Wycombe & West Wycombe and
on a site covering 6 acres of rolling hills overlooking
the National Trust property of West Wycombe Park, a new
housing site is going up on Dashwood Village. There will
be 600 dwellings, with a shopping centre, playing fields
and a village hall. The dwellings will consist of linked,
detached and terraced houses with 3-4 bedrooms. There will
also be one roomed Mini Houses and a variety of flats.
The developement is divided into four stages and is expected
to take a further five years to lete.

Photo Shows: Janet Rauch relaxing in the dining/living room
of a Balcony House on the Dashwood Village site. The Balcony
houses have two storeys with 3 bedrooms and an open-plan
ground floor. All the Balcony Houses are split level owing to
the fall in ground, which gives two heights of floor to the
dining/living room. They cost about £6,250. Like the other
houses on the estate they have carports, garages, patios, full
central heating, wired in TV, gas fired warm air ducts in each
room and waste disposal kitchen units.

A BULLSEYES IN THE EXPORT MARKET.
N.Y./Th.

Crossing the Atlantic by the ton are British-made
darts and dartboards which are proving a very
valuable export in the dollar market. For a dart-
craze is sweeping America and the British version of
the game is gradually becoming popular, believed to be
due to the influence of G.I's who took a liking to the
"British pub" game while stationed in this country. However
to cater also for exponents of both the British version
and the American variation in the U.S.A., one London
manufacturer (Thomas Salter, Ltd. of Finsbury Hill) is
exporting "Anglo-American" dart boards, which have the
British board on one side and the American -style board
on the reverse side.

PHOTOGRAPH SHOWS: MISS M. BARNARD, a secretary at a
Finsbury Hill Games and Toy Factory (Thomas Salter, Ltd)
showing the dart boards which are proving such a valuable
dollar export. The board she is holding is turned to
show the "American-style" dartboard, while above it, is a
similar board turned to the reverse side, which has the
British version of the dartboard on it. The game of
darts as played in this country is becoming very popular
in the U.S.A.
FOX PHOTO XXXX MARCH 1ST. 1956
536365

SCOTLAND'S LARGEST TRUCK SEMISHAULING AND BOTTLING PLANT

The largest and most modern plant for semisnauling and bottling Scotch whisky will be opened on Friday June 13 by Sir John Pryde, Chairman of the Scottish Council Development and Industry.

Built at a cost of over $10 million for the 110 yard-long site of bush tower & road, the plant stands on a virgin site at Girrawheen, 6 miles north of Perth. The new headquarters occupies 24 acres of a 20-acre site with a 400-yard frontage. On the main road is a new railway carriageway, the new railhead now reaching two-thirds of the way to Perth. Two lines of railway have been built, and the new rail carring facility is now connected to the main railway system.

The new plant itself will cover 10 acres of the site and will be erected in four stages. This is the first of its kind to be built in Australia for the purpose of semisnauling and bottling Scotch whisky.

PICTURE above : Seen from the air is the new bush tower plant at Girrawheen, Perth.

SCOTLAND'S BIGGEST WHISKY BLENDING
AND BOTTLING PLANT.

The largest and most modern plant
for blending and bottling Scotch whisky
will be opened on Friday June 15 by
Lord Polwarth, Chairman of the Scottish
Council (Development and Industry).
Built at a cost of over £1½ million
for the 116-year-old firm of John Dewar
& Sons, the plant stands on a 50-acre
site at Inveralmond, a mile north of
Perth. The new headquarters occupies
24 acres of a 50-acre site with a
400-yard frontage on the main A9 road to
Inverness and near the main railway
services, including the new £2½ million
Perth marshalling yard for freight to
the north of Scotland. The remaining
26 acres of the site are reserved for
future expansion.

Transcribed_Text:
IN SOME WAYS Beaconsfield
Buildings, just a short bus ride
from the glitter of Piccadilly
Circus, could be considered a
showplace.

For to film producers at least, the
grey-bricked, five-storey blocks of flats
seem to have an irresistible fascina-
tion.

There was Max Bygraves in Cry From
the Streets, and Spare the Rod and
Spoil the Child. There was Joe Brown
in What a Crazy World. And Jess
Conrad in The Boys.
Each finding in the rows of miserable
flats—known without affection as The
Crumbles—the perfect setting for a film
about slums.

For today Beaconsfield Buildings has
about as much in common with the
affluent gadget world of 1964 as it did
when Prime Minister Disraeli laid the
foundation stone in 1875.

The plumbing is still Victorian. There
are few separate kitchens, few bath-
rooms, and landing lavatories shared by
between five and eight families.

On Sunday 200 of the 440 tenants
marched five miles from the flats in
Randall's Road, near King's Cross, to the
Chelsea home of Housing Minister Sir
Keith Joseph. To ask him to pull The
Crumbles down.

Their case? Well, it can be found in
the story of just three families.
CASE ONE: Mrs. Bridget Welsh, aged 45,
wife of a labourer, lives in three rooms
and a partitioned kitchen at £1 14s. 2d.
a week. Her flat is spotless.
She said: "Six weeks ago my girl
Geraldine—she's 10—caught dysentry.
Not from our lavatory because I clean it
constantly, and not from her school be-
cause she was the only one.
"I'm afraid she caught it round the
Buildings—from open dustbins, bad, smelly
drains, or dirty walls."
CASE TWO: Mrs. Bridget Sullivan, aged
26, wife of a factory worker, with children
Michael, 3, Theresa, one, in two rooms, no
kitchen, at £1 6s. 10d. a week. Her flat
is spotless.

The article highlights the bravery of the British crew and the importance of international cooperation in maritime emergencies.

PICTURES FROM THE AIR - R.A.F. PILOT EXPOSED TO PIT DISEASES AT
SINGAPORE CHEMICAL COMPANY

Five massive vultures FIGHT THEIR WAY THROUGH THE SMOG, one
choking on the fumes of the Singapore Chemical Company, is a
search for oil and trapped by an explosion.
Flag-waving and excited, women rushed out from far away, as
childless and weary women waited at the piles, being
coaxed and wearing masks.
One hundred and fifty men were in the pit when the explosion
bursts. Firemen helped out the injured and rescued the others.
However, five women were killed by the rescue police.
R.A.F. Air view of the wreckage of the pit from a
jet William Pitt, the Director of the Singapore Chemical Company, was killed by the explosion, along with his wife and their two children.
Pictures taken by R.A.F. pilot Mr. L. C. Taylor at the Singapore Chemical Company disaster. The photographs were taken during the air rescue operation and show the damage caused by the explosion. The pilot also captured images of the aftermath of the disaster, including the rescue efforts and the damage to the surrounding area.

26 AUG 1947RCD

PICTURE FROM THE AIR - 111 MEN ENTOMBED IN PIT DISASTER AT
WHITEHAVEN, CUMBERLAND.

Five rescue parties fought their way through the under sea
workings of the William Pit, Whitehaven, Cumberland, in a
search for 111 men trapped by an explosion.
Nine doctors, and ambulances summoned from as far away as
Carlisle-40 miles distant- waited at the pithead , among
shaken, and weeping women.
One hundred and twenty men were in the pit when the explosion
took place. Ten of that number are known to be safe, and seven of
that number remained below with the rescue parties.
PHOTO SHOWS:- An air view of the scene of the disaster at
the William Pit, Whitehaven, Cumberland. Lines of ambulances
and queues of rescue workers and anxious relatives and friends
wait for the latest news of the rescue efforts.
And August 16th 1947 PN

TITLE: MEXICAN GIRLS HOE ON POOLSIDE
STORY: BEAUTY OF A MEXICAN VILLAGE

MEXICAN girls wearing huge straw hats hoe weeds
on the rim of a big pond in San Miguel Allende.
One is the daughter of Don Luis, owner of
the ranch. The other is the daughter of a hired
hand. That high adobe wall behind them is
part of a centuries old Hacienda, now belonging
to Americans. San Miguel Allende, Guanajuato,
Mexico, is an old charming little mountain
town, which is often said to be much more
European in character than is typical in this
continent. The flat cars are quite picturesque.
People here have big friendly smiles and are
polite, even to strangers. Many Americans, out
of work, have moved here to live very cheaply.
The San Miguel area, which was very unproductive
in the past, has recently received 40% government
subsidy for agriculture -- and many formerly
poor Mexicans, engaged in hand crafts, now
have big bank rolls. People work by an ancient
rule: 9:00AM on the job is considered late.
Life is simple and incredibly sweet.

MORE INFO: The horse tank holding the milk,
Dr. L.H.Holton (Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries)
has to meet a bank examiner for not.
UACRL. H. (Kansas Press).
Transcribed_Text:
1983 - 5236 / 45134
DUP SENT.
7- AUG1940 ON.
MANCHESTER.

XD) AUSTRALIAN BINDER AT WORK ON FORMER
PARKLAND. REMINDER OF A FORMER INVASION
THREAT.

Delving back into history when Europe was dominated
by Napoleon and England stood on the waiting list,
the fine old park lands at Bushy Park, Hampton,
Middlesex, were turned over to the needs of agricul-
ture and food production. After that period they
became park lands again up till to-day. Now
invasion threatens again and once more food production
must be served. To-day, the McKay Massey Harris
Sunshine Binder - new importation to this country
from Australia - is at work on the park lands: gave
interesting demonstrations to officials and Dominion
representatives. Fine oats are being grown on the
fields which were first ploughed up last November and
cross-harrowed in March. Yield is now 60-80 bushels p
per acre. Wheat and barley are also being grown.
The new binder, which should prove very satisfactory
to the English market, has a six-foot cut; refinements
include grease-gun pressure lubrication; gun-metal
bearings for the packers; enclosed oil-bath for the
main bevel gear drive. The big wheel is all metal,
wood is replaced in the decks by galvanized steel.
The sheaf carrier is simplicity itself.

Photo shows:- The horse team cutting the oats.
MR. A.R.MANTHYLLOW (Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries)
can be seen at back examining the cut.

7/8/40. M. (Topical Press).

Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/56567
XB)
HOUSE OF COMMONS GIFT TO RHODESIA AND
NYASALAND
MACE IN THE MAKING

Craftsmen employed by a 74-years-old firm of London
silversmiths are now engaged on a task which is a
test of their skill - the production of the massive
mace to be presented by the House of Commons to the
new parliament for the Federation of Rhodesia and
Nyasaland. 100 ounces of silver are being used for
it and seven different categories of craftsmen are
putting their knowledge and skill into its
completion. 20 separate pieces are being soldered
together to make the finished piece. When completed
it will be 32 3/4 inches long. Nobody yet knows how
much the mace will weigh as it cannot be estimated
in advance how much gold will be required to guild
it. Only a single piece is being made to the design
and the craftsmen have no completed "article upon
which to base their calculations. The mace, which
is an exact replica in outline of the historic
House of Commons Mace, has been designed by Mr. R.H.
HILL, an instructor at the London County Council
Central School of Arts and Crafts.

Photo shows:- Parts of the mace receive a final
polish before being assembled.

23/6/54 Topical Press (AA 4488)

DAILY HERALD
REC. 14 JUN 1964

It's getting to the stage, in Britain,
46, when housewives don't
know which weird figure is going
to appear next on their doorstep, ask
if they've got a packet of Whalbit
in the kitchen and hand them a free.

Pleasant this may be. But it might
be as well to give the nation advance
warning that these hip-breasted
chicks will be waddling up paths in
300 towns next month.

Fear not. The Things in inflatable
yellow costumes, tights, beak-shaped
bonnets and claw-style shoes are
really just drama students
hired by the Egg Marketing Board
for a big publicity drive.

The chickens, pictured in London
yesterday crossing a road, of course,
will call at homes and ask-
"Are you eating an egg?"
If you are, you get a Ãƒâ€šÃ‚Â£1 Premium Bond.
If you're not, you get (what else?)
told a dozen eggs.

There do appear to be slight problems
in the plan, though. The chicks
will be very early birds, calling
at homes at what some people regard
the unearthly hours between seven
and nine in the morning.

And so they may expect some
(garden the pan) hard-bolled cracks
at their eggs. Cracks like: "But
I went to work on an egg yesterday.
And it broke down in the High Street."

WAR ON THE COLORADO BEETLE.

Drastic measures are being taken to combat the threat of invasion of the Colorado Beetle, and for has been declared by the authorities responsible for the protection of the crops in Great Britain.
The agricultural areas around the airports, where aircraft from overseas laden with potatoes are grown, are being sprayed as a precaution against this pest.
Members of the National Fire Service are rendering valuable assistance by carrying the water used to make the spray.
A solution of lead arsenate, deadly to the beetle but not harmful to the crops, is sprayed over the blume of the potatoes from much like at the back of the tractors.
The beetles stow away in aircraft from the Continent, and, as they live only on potatoes, make for the nearest field of them.
These photographs were taken near Stainos and Sccondsworth, to our North and South of the London Airport at Heathrow.
PHOTO SHOWS:- The spraying in action against the Colorado beetle in a thirty acres field of potatoes in the Bermondsworth area. Behind is a National Fire Service water-carrying team.

Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/40569

RECORDED 17 JUL 1947

WAR ON THE COLORADO BEETLE.
Drastic measures are being taken to combat the threat of invasion
of the Colorado beetle, and war has been declared by the authorities
responsible for the protection of the crops in Great Britain.
The agricultural areas around the airports, where aircraft from
overseas land, where potatoes are grown, are being sprayed as a
precaution against this pest.
Members of the National Fire Service are rendering valuable
assistance by carrying the water used to make the spray.
A solution of lead arsenate, deadly to the beetle but not harmful
to the crops, is sprayed over the halms of the potatoes from multi
jets at the back of the tractors.
The beetles stow away in aircraft from the Continent, and, as they
live only on potatoes, make for the nearest field of them.
These photographs were taken near Staines and Harmondsworth, to
the North and South of the London Airport at Heathrow.
PHOTO SHOWS:- The sprayers in action against the Colorado beetle
in a thirty acres field of potatoes in the Harmondsworth area.
Behind is a National Fire Service water-carrying team,
G.A.I. 17th July, 1947. PN-s. (FULL.)

Housing-accidents--flats Disaster at Canning Town, London
May 1970.
F.S.N.A.
MISS IVY HODGE (56)
in hospital
"severe burns"
A GAS explosion in a kitchen
where a woman was making
a cup of tea is believed
to have caused yesterday's
collapse of skyscraper flats in
East London.
Those people died, and 11
were injured, as a wing of the
22-storey block broke away from
the rest of the building and
crashed to the ground "like a
pack of cards."
One of the injured was the
woman making a cup of tea, 56-
year-old Miss Ivy Hodge. Last
night she was recovering from
burns in hospital.
As injuries into the
escape went on last
night, a total of 11 people
were confirmed injured, six of
whom were taken to hospital,
and three people were still
missing.
Mr. Jones, Detective the
Fifth Fire Brigade, said.
"It's amazing that anybody
escaped from the whole thing.
It is the worst disaster that
I can remember in this part of
London."
At present, three other flats
in the 140ft high block had to be
evacuated due to structural
damage. The London Fire Brigade
said.
"The cause of the explosion
is unknown. But it is thought
to have been caused by a gas
leakage. The fire brigade is
investigating."
Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/44033
Housing--Accidents--Flats Disaster at Canning Town,London
May 1968.
F S.N.A
MISS IVY HODGE (56)
in hospital
6 severe sms?

A GAS explosion in a kitchen
where a woman was making
a cup of tea is believed to
have caused yesterday's
collapse of skyscraper flats in
East London.
Three people died, and 11
were injured, as a wing of the
22-storey block broke away from
the rest of the building and
crashed to the ground "like a
pack of cards."
One of the injured was the
woman making a cup of tea, 56-
year-old Miss Ivy Hodge. Last
night she was recovering from face
burns in hospital.

As inquiries into the
collapse went on last
night scores of families
evacuated from the
block's 110 flats said they
never wanted to live in a
skyscraper flat again.

Mr. James Callaghan, the
Home Secretary, went to the
flats a few hours after the
collapse and appointed a
team of experts to make a
preliminary report to him by
lunchtime today.

At least three other in-
quiries will be held—one of
them by the Taylor Wood-
row firm who built the block,
and others like it, in the
London borough of Newham.

The cause of the explosion
was confirmed by Com-
mander Arthur Milbury,
head of the eastern area of
the London Fire Brigade.

He said: “There appears
to have been a gas explosion
in one of the flats. Gas fit-
tings were completely blown
away."

MISS IVY HODGE, the
woman who was making a
cup of tea when the ex-
plosion came, lay in a
hospital bed last night
(above) and told of her
miracle escape.

She said: "I had just
filled the kettle when I
suddenly found myself on
the floor.
"I managed to stagger
to the door and people
helped me down to safety."
Miss Hodge, who lives in
Flat 90 on the 18th floor,
said she could not remem-
ber turning on the gas or
striking a match.

178804 AND
'COOKED ON THE SPIT'.
WORLD'S FIRST ROTODIP PLANT GUARDS BRITISH CARS AGAINST
RUST.
Coventry, Eng: The turnspit went out with the stage-
coach but the idea has been revived in the great
Fisher and Ludlow plant - subsidiary of Standard Motors -
near here to protect bodies of the latest 'Vanguards'
from rust.
'Spitted' on a revolving ro d 20 feet long by four
inches in diameter, the bodies pass through the
world's first Rotodip plant of six process tanks each
holding five to seven thousand gallons of cleaning
and phosphating liquids.
From this section the bodies pass into the hot-air
drying oven then into the primer paint compartment.
Throughout the journey the bodies are evenly rotated
until reaching the baking oven.
Full complement of the 300 feet by 20 feet plant is
33 bodies, processed at the rate of 18 an hour.
Treatment time is one hour fortyseven minutes.
PHOTO SHOWS: 'Spitted' Vanguard bodies pass into the
Rotodip at the Coventry plant. Rollers at the end
of the spit engage on the traction chain passing
the bodies through the Rotodip.
January 20th 1949 FN.g. Pl corr.

"ROLL OUT THE BARREL"
A FULL-FLEDGED COOPER IN 1950

Amid the last of the craftsment to retain
their ancient customs and ceremonies is the
ancient trade of Cooperage and at the
Guinness Brewery, Park Royal, Apprentice
G.R.N. BANNER was literally "put through
the hoop" when he came out of his time
and became a full fledged cooper. First
he was dumped into a new barrel of his own
making, then shavings, coloured dyes, and
all the most obnoxious brewery material his
comrades could find, tipped over him. During
the pouring an "orchestra" of tubes, pipes
and pieces of metal kept up a continuous
clamour. Apprentice BANNER was then rolled the
full length of the Brewery at Park Royal.
After the rolling, he was permitted to "come
up for air", given a drink, and then "tossed
up" by his comrades. Still smiling, he
himself up and is "sacked" and re-
engaged by the Head Cooper in the status
of a fully qualified COOPER.

PHOTO SHOWS:- Covered in muck and slush
Apprentice G.R. BANNER emerges from his cocoon (barrel)
with a broad smile. He is almost a full fledged
cooper.

File - Industry - Pottery - Misc.
1956 CP30/948

STANMORE POTTERS HOLD THEIR OWN EXHIBITION. NR/PM
Probably for the first time since it was made, about 5,000
years ago, a large Minoan vase is back in a pottery, for it
is the central exhibit in an exhibition in the Orchard Studio,
Stanmore-hill, Stanmore, now being staged by Mr and Mrs R.C.
Collyer. Mrs Collyer is better known as Pamela Nash. The Vase,
which is 20 inches high, 50 inches in circumference, and would
hold about four gallons of water, is made of a sandy-coloured
clay, and is decorated with the traditional spirals, or "bull's eyes"
of the period, which depicts the worship of the bull in the Palace
of Minos, in Knossos, Crete.

Photograph shows :- Mr and Mrs R.C. Collyer seen studying the
5,000 year old MINOAN VASE. Mrs Collyer is known as PAMELA NASH
who is an art painter and potter. She is seen holding the vase
while her husband is seen examining the design, and checking the design
with a reference book. It is on show at No.2 Stanmore Hill, Stanmore,
Middlesex.

1955-5836/5338

RESTORATION WORK AT ETON COLLEGE.
NUW/380.

Extensive restoration work is now in progress on the
Cloisters of Eton College, the cost of which is being
borne by the Eton Appeal Fund, to which the Dultzerian
Trustees have contributed the sum of Ãƒâ€šÃ‚Â£20,000 to be
expended on this work. Restoration has been made
necessary due to the following defects of general
deterioration of stonework: a) flaking of the stone
facing on the upper part of the Cloisters; b) dry
rot and death watch beetles in roof timbers; d) on
the upper part of the Cloisters, the bonding between the
outer stone facing and the brick wall behind it, was no
longer effective, resulting in bulging of the outer stone
wall which had become dangerous in places. The original
stone used on the Cloisters, believed to be some form of
Church, is being replaced by Clipsham Stone from Rutland
which is much more hard-wearing.

PHOTOGRAPH SHOWS: Brothers ALBERT and JAMES KINGH
of Amour seen working on the restoration of a stone
arch in the Cloisters of Eton College.

rot and death watch beetle in roof timbers : d) on
the upper part of the Cloisters, the bonding between the
outer stone facing and the brick wall behind it, was no
longer effective, resulting in bulging of the outer stone
wall which had become dangerous in places. The original
stone used on the Cloisters, believed to be some form of

FILE - Industries - Fuel and Power - Coal - Screening.
12. 8. 34.

PEER TO VISIT PIT GIRLS.
HJB/VM

In reply to a challenge by Viscount Hall, arising out of
controversy over the second reading of the Mines and Quarries
Bill in the House of Lords, the Earl of Selkirk, Paymaster
General, is to spend part of his holidays touring collieries
to "see for himself" conditions under which the "pit brow
lassies" work. Viscount Hall declared that there were
still about 3,000 women employed at the pit tops in conditions
almost as bad as those prevailing at the time when women were
taken out of the pits nearly 100 years ago.

PHOTOGRAPH SHOWS: A general view of "pit brow lassies" at
work on the screening of coal at Nickerpeece Colliery, Leigh,
near Manchester. Some of the women have been doing this work
for more than 20 years and all say that although the job is very
dirty, it is quite congenial. They work 8-hour shifts, 7 a.m.
to 3 p.m. or another shift finishing at 10.30 p.m. A modern
bath-house similar to the miners pithead bath is provided so that
the women can leave the colliery quite clean. Protective
clothing is also provided.
FOX PHOTOS AUGUST 7TH. 1934.
COPYRI.

THATCHED ROOF TROLLEY BUS PRESENTS PROBLEM TO D/HT
PLANNERS
The East Suffolk Planning Committee have been
presented with a tricky problem. A converted trolley
bus once used in Ipswich streets, is now occupied
by a 67-year-old smallholder, Mr W. Steward and his
wife in a field at Creeting St. Mary. Under planning
regulations it would have to be moved, but Mr. Steward
has turned the bus into a "cottage" by thatching the
roof. Now the Committee have to decide if this cons-
titutes a permanent dwelling.

PHOTO SHOWS: Mr. and Mrs Steward photographed at
the door of their thatched roof trolley bus.

FIRST PUBLICATION THURSDAY, JUNE 18th.

AUSTRALIAN PRIME MINISTER TO OPEN GAUR DAM
(pr. 17.6.53.
Mr ROBERT G. MENZIES, Prime Minister of Australia,
will open the Nth of Scotland Hydro-Electric Board's
new Dam and Power Station on the river Gaur, 3 miles
from Rannoch Station on the fringe of the dreaded moor
of Rannoch, in West Perthshire on June 20th.
The scheme is on the ancient lands of Glen Menzies, near
one of the few surviving parts of the old Caledonian Forest.
Loch Eigheach will be enlarged and raised 30' by a
crescent-shaped dam 40' high and 370' long. A 6,000 KW
power station on the River Gaur will produce 17 million
units of Electricity each year. The picture shows:-

No 1. The setting of the Gaur Dam showing Loch Eigheach
behind the rocky River Gaur in right foreground. The
ancient "Road to the Isles" now has a dam sitting on it
(see wall on right) and the road behind the dam will be
submerged. 1½ miles of new road has been built to take
its place.

PROPERTY OF
DAILY HERALD
RCD. 1 8 JUN 1953

WOMEN APPLY THE 'HEALING' TOUCH
TO BROKEN TREASURES
November 23rd 1957 PAR 67522-3 (L-R)
-----------------------------------
WOMEN APPLY THE 'HEALING' TOUCH
TO BROKEN TREASURES
COMPREHENSIVE
China and porcelain ornaments, vases and
pots flow by the hundred into the studio
in St. John's Wood, London, of Pegeen Mair
and Angela Drayson.
The women are experts in the repair and
restoration of delicate ware and some of
the pieces sent to them are valuable
antiques.
Pegeen, who comes from Dublin, is the
daughter of the late Maire O'Neill, the
Irish actress.
Angela is from Hale, Cheshire.
Helping them in their highly-skilled work
are a group of girls who are learning
the craft.
The partners-- who can mend 'anything
but a broken heart!' - first met during
the war when they teamed up to write songs.
PICTURE SHOWS:- PEGEEN MAIR
(standing) instructing some of the pupils
at the studio. They are, left to right:
JOAN WILLS from Aberdeen; PENELOPE MUSKER
from Norwich; ROBINETTE BURN from Argyll;
and APRIL BLACKWELL from Emsworth, Hampshire.
November 23rd 1957 PAR 67522-3 (L-R)

DIESEL ENGINE FOR LONDON'S DOCKS.
LOCOMOTIVE ADAPTED FOR HELPING GAS WORKS.

AT RICKMANSWORTH, PATIENT ARRANGEMENT ON THE COAL SITUATION
WILL HAVE BEEN RESOLVED BY WHICH GREATER INTEREST THAN AT THE
NORTHERN END OF THE GAS WORKS AND DOCKS GROUP, LONDON, WHICH
IS THE LARGEST GROUPING OF ITS KIND IN THE WORLD. THE WORKS ARE CAPABLE OF
PRODUCING DAILY TEN MILLION METRIC FEET OF GAS EQUALLING 800,000
THERMO. AND EVERY DAY EXPANSION IS, OF COURSE, DEPENDENT UPON THE
AMOUNT OF COAL AVAILABLE. GASWORKS IS SITUATED ON THE NORTH
BANK OF THE RIVER POST JOIN THE RIVER ALBERT DORE, AND HAS
A PLANT EQUALLING 3000 FT FOR THE HANDLING OF ITS COAL, WHICH
HAS BEEN CARRIED THITHER FROM THE GOLDFIELDS OF BORMAH. THE WORKS
COVER 105 ACRES (105 ACRES INCLUDING THE ADJOINING CENTRAL WORKS)
AND THERE ARE OVER 75 MILES OF FULL-GAUGE ROLLING TRACKS FOR
TEMPORARY TRANSPORT. THE PICTURE SHOWS LOCOMOTIVE USED BY THE WORKS
FOR TEMPORARY TRANSPORT ON TO THE COAL PIER, ALTERNATIVE REPORT BEING
TO RECLAIM COAL BY PROJECTION MACHINE ON OTHER SIDE OF RETURN
STATION. SHOWN TO ARRANGEMENT USED TO TRANSPORT COAL BY THE MAIN
STATION FROM WHICH GASWORKS SITUATION IS TO BE TEMPORARY
REGULATED.
Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/51223

Fücs - Industries. Gas.

FIRST PUBLICATION WEDNESDAY'S EVENINGS 18.12.46.

WINTER'S PROBLEM FOR WORLD'S BIGGEST GAS WORKS

Mr Shinwell's latest pronouncement on the coal situation
will have been received nowhere with greater interest than at the
Beckton plant of the Gas Light and Coke Company, of London, which
is the largest gasworks in the world. The works are capable of
producing daily 120 million cubic feet of gas equalling 600,000
therms, but actual production is, of course, dependent upon the
amount of coal available. Beckton is situated upon the North
bank of the Thames just East of the Royal Albert Dock, and has
a river frontage of 2500 ft for the handling of its coal, which
comes by water mainly from the coalfields of Durham. The works
cover 280 acres (540 acres including the adjoining chemical works)
and there are over 70 miles of full-guage railway tracks for
internal transport. The picture shows: Horizontal retort being
re-charged with coal by projector machine on other side of retort
bench. Stoker in foreground holds "stopper" in position to
regulate charge.

119, FLEET STREET, LONDON, E.C.4

SIX STANDARD EIGHT IN PRODUCTION

At the factory of the Standard Motor Co., the new Standard Eight car, will practically be which will be announced tomorrow. It is hoped that the workmanship shown in its construction will be exceptional and of a high standard. 

The new Standard Eight is from all parts of the world. The Standard Eight is a four door, four light, saloon, Blue, four speed gear box, which received advantages, and dual purpose, light weight, metal, radial tyres, etc. which are highly reliable and efficient. It is expected to be introduced next year, and will be a significant success for the company. 

A number of 4000 cars are already on order and the company intends to produce 10,000 cars per year at the start. 

The car will be available in a number of colours and finishes, including red, blue, green, and black. The interior will be finished in leather and the seats will be upholstered in cloth. The car will also come with a number of optional extras, including air conditioning, a sunroof, and a stereo system. 

The new Standard Eight is expected to be a major competitor in the compact car market. It is hoped that it will be a success.
Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/52080
XB) NEW STANDARD EIGHT IN PRODUCTION
At the Coaly (Coventry) factory of The Standard Motor
Com. say the new Standard Eight car, full details of
which will be announced tomorrow, is now coming off
the assembly lines in volume production to meet the
orders now pouring in from all parts of the world.
The Standard Eight is a four door, four light, clean
line, four-seater saloon, steel panelled, rustproofed
and dustproofed. A substantial parcel shelf is
available in the facia panel and there is a capacious
luggage boot at the rear, access to it being from the
rear compartment of the car - the rear seat squabs
folding forward. It has an overall length of 11ft.
10in., width of 4ft. 10in. and a height (unladen) of
5ft.
Photo shows:- The engine and rear suspensions on
the assembly line, with bodies overhead.

QUIVERÃ¢â‚¬â€DART
WHEN party girls are to purchase when she embarked
upon
a holiday trip
to
Malta, a chilly weather warning
from the Ministry of Civil
Aviation may upset their plans.
From an Air Ministry bulletin the
Ministry of Civil Aviation has
learned that a "cold front" is
moving in, and that for days
to come, the weather in
European countries will be
"unseasonably cold."
Mrs. V. Tudor, daughter
of Mrs. Tudor, of 12, Benares
Road, Plumstead, London, who
recently booked a holiday in
Malta, said yesterday: "The
news is not good at all."
She added: "But we still plan to
go. The party still includes myself,
Miss S. Ellis, the Misses D.
and E. Ellis, and Mrs. D. P.
Chapman. We are all booked up
for the 14th."
So my plans for a holiday in
Malta are going ahead. I believe
the weather is still good enough
for bathing. We are sailing by boat,
and plan to do a lot of sight-seeing.
We are not worried about the cold
weather in Europe, as we will have
our warmest clothes with us.
We are all looking forward to a lovely
holiday, and we are sure it will be
very enjoyable."

DAILY
HERALD
TUES
13 JAN 1957
VIBRATED
Transcribed_Text:
1953-5236 / 6005/1
Queen + Duke

WHEN you're only 23
months old, nobody's
going to mind very much if
you're a little informal with
Royalty.
Wee Jimmy Smith, wearing
his best velvet trousers, left
stuffy ceremony to the older
folk yesterday and showed the
Queen how pleased he was to
see her.
While his father, Sergeant
Harry Smith, stood to attention
outside his R.A.F. home at
Leuchars, Fife, Jimmy advanced
smartly. Result: The picture
above.
Jimmy, a lad of few words,
had two for her Majesty:
HELLO, QUEEN.
He held on to the Queen's
hand and did an impromptu
war-dance while she laughed
and chatted to him.
That was the warm, unex-
pected incident in a duty-packed
day for the Queen and the Duke
of Edinburgh.
It was a day of new experi-
ences for the Queen, too. She
had her first 450 m.p.h. jet plane
flight—in a Comet II—from
Marham to Leuchars.
As the plane brought the
Queen to earth, men of the
famous 43 Squadron stood ready
for the presentation of their
blue and gold standard.
Another thrilling moment for
the Queen was when she took
over the microphone of the air
control tower at Leuchars.
She ordered two lines of
fighters to "scramble."

A TEAM OF 84 YOUNG DRAMA STUDENTS HAVE

EGGS.

GOLIATH CRANE IN ACTION
CONCRETE BLOCKS WEIGHING 200 TONS ARE
LIFTED WITH EASE AS THE GOLIATH CRANE
WAS SEEN IN ACTION FOR THE FIRST TIME
TODAY, MARCH 19, AT THE NUCLEAR POWER
STATION NOW UNDER CONSTRUCTION AT
BRADWELL-ON-SEA, ESSEX. THE CONTROL BOX
IS SEEN AT TOP OF PICTURE, TO LEFT
OF CABLES. THE CRANE, 185 FEET HIGH AND
226 FEET WIDE, IS OF THE OVERHEAD
GIRDER TYPE, SUPPORTED AT EACH END
BY A LEG MOUNTED ON EIGHT FOUR-WHEEL
BOGIES. ITS FUNCTION AT BRADWELL WILL
BE TO LIFT INTO POSITION MAJOR
COMPONENTS SUCH AS THE TWELVE 200-TON
BOILER SHELLS AND THE HEAVY STEEL RING-
SEGMENTS FOR THE REACTOR PRESSURE
VESSELS. THE CRANE WILL COMPLETELY
STRADDLE EACH REACTOR BUILDING DURING
ALL STAGES OF CONSTRUCTION. THE BOGIES
RUN ON STANDARD GAUGE RAILWAY LINES
(LENGTH 1200 FEET) TO ENABLE THE CRANE
TO LIFT RING-SEGMENTS OF THE PRESSURE
VESSELS FROM THE SITE WELDING AREA AND
DEPOSIT THEM IN POSITION IN THE
REACTORS. GOLIATH, DESIGNED TO LIFT
A MAXIMUM LOAD OF 200 TONS DEAD WEIGHT
SUSPENDED VERTICALLY FROM A MAIN HOOK,
WILL ALSO BE USED EXTENSIVELY FOR THE
INSTALLATION OF OTHER HEAVY ITEMS OF
EQUIPMENT.
TYN/AAA.H. 5695 190358 ASSOCIATED PRESS PHOTO FROM LONDON

THE MODERN GIRL PLIES A CENTURIES-OLD TRADE
July 13th 1953 PAR 36404-3 (BKS-R)
---------------------------------------
THE MODERN GIRL PLIES A CENTURIES-OLD TRADE

For at least seven centuries, the manufacture
of nets, ropes, sailcloth and other hempen
products has been the staple industry of
the town of Bridport, Dorset.
Of Bridport's present-day population of about
6,000, over a thousand - many of them young
women - are engaged in the industry,
directly or indirectly.
At one time locally-grown flax and hemp were
used, but nearly all the raw material is
now imported.
It is recorded that all the ropes and sails
for King John's Navy (he reigned from
1199-1216) were made at Bridport. And the
expression 'stabbed by a Bridport dagger' for
a person who had been hanged was current
in 1530, when King Henry VIII reigned.
This picture was taken in the Bridport works
of Joseph Gundry and Co. Ltd., a firm founded
in 1665 and still controlled by lineal
descendants of the founder. There were
Gundrys engaged in the trade as early as 1580.
PICTURE SHOWS:- Two of the girls in the
Bridport net trade - ARINA RUNDELL (left)
and SHIRLEY WARD - rigging seine fishing-net
25 yards long. It will fish to a depth
of eight feet.
July 13th 1953 PAR 36404-3 (BKS-R)

FOR FIRST PUBLICATION IN EVENING
PAPERS OF TUESDAY, JULY 14th.

Indus, Fishing
Net Making

1955-5236/52895

ROYAL PRESENT FOR KING OF THAILAND.
26.4.50.

For their wedding present to the King of Thailand
their Majesties, have chosen a service of Worcester Royal
Porcelain. The pattern chosen is known as the Royal Lily
Pattern and is printed in underglaze blue and enriched with
gold. The design was originally adapted from the Chinese at
the Worcester factory between 1751 and 1788, and was selecte
by King George III and Queen Charlotte when they visited the
works in 1788. Throughout its 200 years history, the Worceste
factory has produced distinguished underglaze blues. The
Worcester factory was one of the first to be established in
England when, in the middle of the eighteenth century,
European potters were discovering how to produce porcelain
similar to the Chinese ware, and its early products rank wi
those of Bow and Chelsea in the "Golden age" of English
porcelain. The craftsmanship inherited from those days ha
helped to produce this royal present.

I.N.P. PHOTO SHOWS.
Harry Whittle, dishmaker, at work
on a sauce tureen for the Royal
Present. In the foreground
are two of his tools, old moulding
pitchers handed down from one generatio
to the next. These tools are so valued
by the workman that they were once
accepted as currency in the factory.

Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/57047

"GRAVEYARD OF GIANTS"
WHERE BATTLESHIPS GO FOR SCRAP DG/PR

"Abandon Hope All Ye That Enter Here" is the ironic
warning over the entrance to the jetty of Messrs.
Thomas Ward, shipbreakers, of Inverkeithing,
Scotland, and so far as warships are concerned, the
phrase applies down to the last rivet.
Wards are the biggest shipbreakers in Britain, and
one of the largest in the world. Not only are they
the biggest shipbreakers, but they break up the
biggest ships. To their yards--and to others
such as Metal Industrials, or Arnott and Young's--
come such floating giants as "Rodney", "Revenge",
"Renown", the "New York", once Hitler's "strength
through joy" liner, and many others. Mighty fighting
ships which sailed triumphantly through two world
wars, find their last resting place under scrapyard
cranes. Guns which the combined fleets of
the Third Reich and Imperial Japanese Navy failed
to muffle, are silent as hissing oxy-acetylene
cutters carve into their vitals.
Much of the valuable scrap goes to sea again in
the form of new ships, and thus fights in Britain's
export drive. Brass, copper and much needed alloys
are sent to Sheffield, while metal scrap goes to
Newcastle.

PHOTO SHOWS:- The as yet untouched forepart of
H.M.S. Royal Sovereign, showing her forward turrets,
at T. Ward's scrapyard.

ROLL OUT THE BARREL
A PULL-PLUGGED COOPER IS BORN DO/Tan

Among the last of the craftsmen to retain
their ancient customs and ceremonies is the
ancient trade of Cooperage, and at the
Guinness Brewery, Park Royal, Apprentice
O.K. H. BARRS, was literally "put through
the hoop" when he came out of his time
making, then shavings, coloured dyes, and
all the most obnoxious brewery material his
comrades could find, tipped over him. During
the pouring an "orchestra" of tubes, pipes
and pieces of metal kept up a continuous
glamour. Apprentice BARRS was then rolled the
full length of the Brewery at Park Royal.
After the rolling, he was permitted to "scuse
up for air", given a drink, and then "tossed
up" by his workmates. Still smiling, he
cleans himself up and is "sacked" and re-
engaged by the Head Cooper in the status
of a fully qualified COOPER

PHOTO SHOW:- Looking more like a circus
clown than a qualified Cooper, O.K. H. BARRS
is still smiling as he is rolled the length of
the Guinness Brewery by his comrades.

"ROLL OUT THE BARREL"
A FULL-FLEDGED COOPER IS BORN DG/Tan

Among the last of the craftsmen to retain
their ancient customs and ceremonies is the
ancient trade of Cooperage, and at the
Guinness Brewery, Park Royal, Apprentice
G. E. H. BARNE was literally "put through
the hoop" when he came out of his time
and became a full fledged cooper. First
he was dumped into a new barrel of his own
making, then shavings, coloured dyes, and
all the most obnoxious brewery material his
comrades could find, tipped over him. During
the "pouring" an "orchestra " of tubes, pipes
and pieces of metal kept up a continuous
clamour. Apprentice BARNS was then rolled the
full length of the Brewery at Park Royal.
After the rolling, he was permitted to "come
up for air", given a drink, and then "tossed
up" by his workmates. Still smiling, he
cleans himself up and is "sacked" and re-
engaged by the Head Cooper in the status
of a fully qualified COOPER

PHOTO SHOWS: Looking more like a circus
clown than a qualified Cooper, G.E.H. BARNS
is still smiling as he is rolled the length of
the Guinness Brewery by his comrades.

THE ROYAL MINT IN LONDON IS BUSY MINTING
DECIMAL COINSFOR NEW ZEALAND.
ON JULY 10, 1967, NEW ZEALAND WILL
FROM ITS PRESENT POUNDS, SHILLINGS AND
SYSTEM OF CURRENCY TO A DECIMAL SYSTEM IN
WHICH THE NEW ZEALAND DOLLAR, VALUED AT 10
SHILLINGS N.Z. WILL BE THE MAIN UNIT. THE
DOLLAR WILL BE DIVIDED INTO 100 CENTS, EACH
WORTH 1.2 PENCE.
SIX COINS ARE BEING MINTED, THE ONE AND TWO
CENT PIECES OF BRONZE, AND THE FIVE, TEN,
TWENTY AND FIFTY CENT PIECES OF CUPRO-NICKEL.
IN ADDITION ABOUT HALF A MILLION COMMEMORATIVE
DOLLAR COINS, ALSO OF CUPRO-NICKEL, ARE
BEING STRUCK.
THE DESIGNS FOR THE REVERSE OF THE COINS
WERE DECIDED BY THE GOVERNMENT AFTER A LONG
PUBLIC CONTROVERSY OVER THE SELECTION FROM
A WIDE VARIETY OF DESIGNS. ALL SIX OF THE
MAIN COINS WERE DESIGNED BY A NEW ZEALAND
ARTIST, MR. JAMES BERRY, OF WELLINGTON. THE
DESIGN OF THE REVERSE OF THE COMMEMORATIVE
DOLLAR WAS PREPARED BY MR. WILLIAM GARDNER,
A.R.C.A., F.S.I.A. OF WITTERSHAM, KENT. THE
OBVERSE OF ALL SEVEN COINS-CARRIES THE NEW
EFFIGY OF THE QUEEN BY MR. ARNOLD MACHIN,
R.A. OF LONDON, AND APPROVED BY HER MAJESTY
IN 1964.

VETERAN OF INDUSTRY.
CW/7262-29. Mrs. Baddow reads the day's news while husband,
John, aged 84, enjoys his pipe after a day's work at the
"Sons of Rest" workshop. John now earns about £4. a week.
When he was 14, he got 7/-d per week.

THE OLD FOLK OF INDUSTRY
GK/7262. Seeking to prove a man is "not too old at 70"
is the engineering firm of Rubery, Owen and Co, of Darlaston,
Staffs who have started an "Old Folks Workshop" which they
call "Sons of Rest". Situated about a mile away from the
noise and bustle of the main factory, twelve men, all over
the age of 70 work on their own with no young workers beside
them to give them an inferiority complex over their ages.
The veterans start an hour later than the main factory. They
do drilling and assembly work on office equipment and farm
implements for overseas markets. The experiment has been
going on for 10 months and has proved a great success. Doctors
who are urging more active employment for elderly people for
the benefit of their health support it. It is also a means
of saving for industry skilled hands vitally necessary these
days, which would otherwise be lying idle.

P
George Konig
