BANK CLERKS WORK BY CANDLELIGHT AS LONDON'S ELECTRICITY
IS CUT.
Work went on by candlelight in banks, offices, shops
and other business establishments when electricity
was switched off in London in accordance with the
Government's plan for dealing with Britain's fuel crisis.
With generating plants' coal stocks'desperately low,
there is no electricity at all for non-essential
industries in London, the Midlands and North-west
England. Other establishments are 'switched off'
between the hours of 9 in the morning and 12 noon,
and between 2 o'clock and 4 o'clock in the afternoon.
The Government say the 'switch off' - which comes at
a time when Britain is striving to increase exports -
will last until coal supplies, interrupted by the
severest winter weather for at least 25 years, are
restored.
PHOTO SHOWS:- Clerks working by candlelight behind
the grille of a bank in Fleet Street, London.

Industry- Boot + Shoe.

FATHER IN THE BALANCE.
PCS/RH.
Come September next and Mr. Henry Jackson will
celebrate his eightieth birthday. But perhaps
celebrate isn't quite the right word, for at
the back of his mind he will remember he's had
notice to leave his cobbler's shop in North
Road, Highgate, just a few days later. Mr. Jackson
is a man who takes a pride in his work of hand-
making shoes, and doesn't want to retire as he
applied for an extension to his lease. He is still
hoping his request will be granted. If Mr. Jackson
is forced to retire it will bring to an end a
300-year-old family tradition of shoe-making.

PHOTOGRAPH SHOWS. As the age of eighty knocks
on his door, MR. HENRY JACKSON continues his
good work, hoping he will not have to pack up.
Here he is tackling a soling and heeling job.
Nothing unusual in that perhaps, but for the
fact that the shoes being repair were made by
him for a client some twenty years ago;

not think it will come to that".

WILSON FAMILY BUILD THEIR OWN HOME AT CRAWFORD -
AND AIDED BY NEW MODIFICATIONS TO REGULATIONS.

Convinced that the only way to get a house in these days
of building shortages is to build it oneself,
ex-Demobilised pilot operator J. Wilson of Forrest Street,
Crawford, took the set about erecting his own home
in Hilton Hill Road, Crawford.
Released from the Royal Air Force two years ago and now
a Federal Minister, Mr. Wilson has enrolled his wife
(a State Registered Nurse) and their two children,
Judith, 5, and Graeme, 3, in the project.
Mrs.Wilson mixes one and six a day of concrete as well
as any professional, while both son and daughter work out
of their wheelbarrow (carrying capacity, three bricks).
Construction work is carried on in the evenings and at
week-ends. In one week-end the Wilson family laid
a total of 1,750 bricks.
Their motto:- We (the) family 'go to it' on their
housing site. An idea Mr. Wilson passed to the plan
with his three-year-old daughter, Graeme, while on right
are, Wilson mixes cement as five-year-old Judith pours the water.
Qld June 4th 1947 P.A.R.

Transcribed_Text:
WILSON FAMILY BUILD THEIR OWN HOUSE AT GRAVESEND -
DAD SWITCHED FROM BEAUFIGHTING TO BRICKLAYING.

Convinced that the only way to get a house in these days
of building shortages is to built it oneself,
ex-Beaufighter radio operator W. Wilson of Parrock Street,
Gravesend, Kent, has set about erecting his own home
in Milton Hall Road, Gravesend.
Released from the Royal Air Force two years ago and now
a foreman bricklayer, Mr. Wilson has enrolled his wife
(a State Registered Nurse) and their two children,
Robin, 5, and Frances, 3, in the project.
Mrs.Wilson claims she can mix a heap of concrete as well
as any professional, while Robin and Frances make good use
of their wheelbarrow (carrying capacity: three bricks).
Construction work is carried on in the evenings and at
week-ends. In one week-end the Wilson family laid
a total of 1,750 bricks.
PHOTO SHOWS:- The Wilson family 'go to it' on their
housing site. At left, Mr. Wilson consults the plan
with his three-year-old daughter, Frances, while (on right)
Mrs. Wilson mixes cement as five-year-old Robin pours the water.
DAW June 4th 1947 PN.r.

ROTTING BANANAS - AND A PINEAPPLE ?

Believe it or not but bananas and a pineapple are
being grown in Scotland - near Glasgow!
You see pictured is Mr David William,
head of the horticulture department at The Co-operative
Wholesale Establishment, and he has a unique hobby with
just over 200 bananas in Scots. In October last year
he harvested a pineapple - which came as big as LAST YEAR,
replacing the year his working facilities.
Mr William, who teaches and trains in the Clype
Valley College at the age of 70 looking after plants since 1928,
began growing his banana trees since 1957 (January 1957).
Much of his hobby is to see if his experiments will
bear it at a site so quite unusual to plants. He eats
almost 30 bananas during the day - with a
view to his research which he handles in his
spare time. He also gives him to grow.
Mr William is hoping to be first ever at the end
of June - and the pineapple - about 1968.

PICTURE SHOWS:
Mr David William's right hand, and his bananas.

Transcribed_Text:
SCOTTISH BANANAS! - AND A PINEAPPLE!

BELIEVE IT OR NOT BUT BANANAS AND A PINEAPPLE ARE
BEING GROWN IN SCOTLAND - NEAR INVERNESS.
THE MAN RESPONSIBLE IS 59 YEARS OLD DAVID WILSON,
HEAD OF THE HORTICULTURAL DEPARTMENT ON THE DOCHFOUR
ESTATES NEAR INVERNESS. AND HE HAS A BANANA TREE WITH
JUST OVER 200 BANANAS IN FRUIT. IN DECEMBER LAST YEAR
HE HARVESTED A PINEAPPLE - SINCE WHEN HE HAS SUCCESSFULLY
REPLANTED THE HEAD FOR ANOTHER FRUITING PERIOD.

MR. WILSON, WHO COMMENCED HIS CAREER IN THE CLYDE
VALLEY AT THE AGE OF 14 LOOKING AFTER TOMATO PLANTS, HAS
BEEN NURSING HIS BANANA TREE SINCE 19TH JANUARY, 1965,
WHEN HE PLANTED IT IN ONE OF HIS GREENHOUSES. HE HAS
KEPT IT AT A HEAT OF NEVER LESS THAN 60 DEGREES F. AT
NIGHT AND ALMOST 80 DEGREES DURING THE DAY - WITH A
HIGH HUMIDITY. THE PINEAPPLE, WHICH HE HARVESTED ON
23RD DECEMBER LAST, TOOK HIM THREE YEARS TO GROW.
HE EXPECT TH BANANAS TO BE FULLY RIPE BY THE END
OF JUNE - AND THE PINEAPPLE - ABOUT 1968.

PICTURE SHOWS:
MR. DAVID WILSON TENDERLY HANDLING HIS BANANAS.

PAKISTANI CHILDREN WITH A DANCE
AT YOUTH CENTRE DEMONSTRATION

Among the pupils on the Church of England Primary
School, Thorpe, Egbe (Surrey) are four Pakistani
children, three sisters and their brother. These
four charming children are very popular among the
other children at the school and they seem to have
won, because even fewer favourites. For they
exhibit permission to wear their colourful national
costumes to school one day recently, so that the
other children could see them. Then, to show
good dancers, the four children entertained the rest
of the school for a lesson, demonstrating various
dances of Pakistan. This was extremely popular and
we doubt they will be asked to give a repeat performance
in the very future.

PHOTOGRAPH SCENE. The four Pakistani children
seen arriving at the Church of England Primary
School, Thorpe, Egbe (Surrey), all wearing their
national costumes. The children, who entertained
their fellow pupils with Pakistani dances are (left to
right) FIRST REELS (5); ANDREA HAKIM (6); AMREN HAKIM (11)
and YASMINA HAKIM (10).

Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/31882

PAKISTANI PUPILS GIVE A TREAT
TO THEIR SURREY SCHOOLMATES.

MJH/G.8.

Among the pupils at the Church of England Primary
School, Thorpe, Egham (Surrey) are four Pakistani
children, three sisters and their brother. These
four charming children are very popular among the
other children at the school and they have
not become even firmer favourites. For they
obtained permission to wear their colourful national
costumes to school one day recently, so that the
other children could see them. Then, all being
good dancers, the four children entertained the rest
of the school for a lesson, demonstrating various
dances of Pakistan. This was extremely popular and
no doubt they will be asked to give a repeat performance
in the near future.

PHOTOGRAPH SHOWS: The four Pakistani children
seen arriving at the Church of England Primary
School, Thorpe, Egham (Surrey), all wearing their
national costumes. The children, who entertained
their fellow pupils with Pakistan dances are (left to
right) JANET HAMID (5): HICKMA HAMID (6): ANNES HAMID (11)
and MAHFUYA HAMID (10).

FOR FIRST PUBLICATION TUESDAY'S EVENING
DOLLARS LAY IN THE CLAY OF CORNWELL.
W.C.O.E. 1947
One of the most valuable of Britain's raw materials that
can be spared for export is the china clay of Devon and
Cornwall. The industry has all the orders it can cope with
on hand, and the production of 800,000 tons yearly will be
more than doubled once supplies of coal are increased.
China clay is used in an ever-climbing range of goods -
pottery, cosmetics, paper, drink, drugs, etc., and the
industry, originating in Devon some 300 years ago, today
employs over 4000 people. The following pictures were taken
at the Lower Mine Stones pit near St. Austell, Cornwall,
and show
a high pressure hose is directed at the clay, and the
resultant liquid runs into a sump, after which it is
pumped into a windmill for filtering and draining. The sticky
residue is then dried, and shipped to its final destination.

title: A photographic print of Industry, Motor, Testing, Research
description: A photographic print from the Daily Herald Archive folder: Industry ÃƒÆ’Ã¢â‚¬Å¡Ãƒâ€šÃ‚Â» Motor ÃƒÆ’Ã¢â‚¬Å¡Ãƒâ€šÃ‚Â» Testing, Research, etc.
output - gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20:
R.F.D.

The photograph shows for the first time the phenomenon
known as 'aquaplaning'. The duality technician is testing a
smooth tyre which, although under an 800 lb. load, remains
stationary while the drum beneath revolves at 30 m.p.h. The
tyre remains stationary because a thin film of water has penetrated
between the drum and the tyre, giving the tyre no grip or contact
with the rough surface of the drum.

The amount of water sprayed on to the drum, 6 gallons
per minute, is considerably less than the 8-10 pints per second
that a tyre would have to cope with at 30 m.p.h. on a wet road.
At speeds below 45 m.p.h. the tyre revolved at the same speed as
the drum, but thereafter, as the drum speed increased and as the
grip became less and less, the tyre slowed down until at between
40 and 50 m.p.h. it stopped rotating and 'aquaplaned'.

Driving with smooth tyres on wet roads involves serious
and unwarranted risks to the driver and other road users alike.

J. D. Sinclair,
Dialog Press Office,
10-12 King Street,
St. James's,
London. S.W.1.
Whitehall 6700.

Reg. No. O.P.F. 7135/31
S.F. 43/250
17.12.65

Industry...Motors... Research.
Transcribed_Text:
STANDSTILL AT 80 M.P.H.

The photograph shows for the first time the phenomenon
known as 'aquaplaning'. The Dunlop technician is touching a
smooth tyre which, although under an 800 lb. load, remains
stationary while the drum beneath revolves at 80 m.p.h. The
tyre remains stationary because a thin film of water has penetrated
between the drum and the tyre, giving the tyre no grip or contact
with the rough surface of the drum.

The amount of water sprayed on to the drum, 6 gallons
per minute, is considerably less than the 8 - 10 pints per second
that a tyre would have to cope with at 50 m.p.h. on a wet road.
At speeds below 45 m.p.h. the tyre revolved at the same speed as
the drum, but thereafter, as the drum speed increased and as the
grip became less and less, the tyre slowed down until at between
60 and 80 m.p.h. it stopped rotating and 'aquaplaned'.

Driving with smooth tyres on wet roads involves serious
and unwarranted risks to the driver and other road users alike.

J. D. Sinclair,
Dunlop Press Office,
10-12 King Street,
St. James's,
London, S.W.l.
WHItehall 6700.

REVIVAL OF VILLAGE CRAFT
Most of the children who live in the small Cotswold
villages of Laverton and Buckland, wear articles of
woollen clothing which they have made themselves from
the wool of their local sheep, which they have collected
and spun on spinning wheels, under the instruction of
Miss Mary Osburn, in her small thatched cottage at
Laverton. KKKKKK Even the dyes for the wools are made from
local hedgerow plants. Miss Osburn went to Laverton some
years ago from the Bow Settlement and began teaching the
village children the art of spinning wool and making it
into useful articles, with the result that many of the
homes in the district now have rugs, bedding and clothing
made of local wool, much of which is collected by the
children from the hedges and fences on which the sheep
have left tufts when rubbing themselves.

PHOTOGRAPH SHOWS: MISS MARY OSBURN taking a spinning
class in her cottage at Laverton. At the spinning wheels
are VALERIE BRYANT (10) and CAROL CLARKE (10), while,
on the window seat HAZEL BRYANT (10) is carding wool. Miss
Osburn instructs about 20 children a week.

20,000 AIREY HOUSES TO AID HOUSING SHORTAGE.
25.4.47.
Under one of the most modern schemes of mass prod-
uction, thousands of pre-fabricated concrete components
are being turned out weekly at the Durus Cast Stone
Company's Brentwood (Essex) factory, to mee the un-ending
demand for houses throughout the country.
Though components for 28 houses are produced weekly,
but soon production will be stepped-up to double this
quantity. Using mostly unskilled labour, each of these
Airey houses, of which 20,000 are on Government order,
takes about a week to erect, and a feature of particular
interest is that owing to the use of little mortar in them
they can be erected in all weathers. The Airey houses are
made in two styles, flat, or pitched roof. The picture shows
a view at the L.C.C. Hainault Estate, where some 160 of
these Airey houses are being erected.

Transcribed_Text:
1983-S236/40595
17 JUL 1947

WAR ON THE COLORADO BEETLE.

Drastic measures are being taken to combat the threat of invasion
of the Colorado beetle,and war has been declared by the authorities
responsible for the protection of the crops in Great Britain.
The agricultural areas around the airports, where aircraft from
overseas land, where potatoes are grown, are being sprayed as a
precaution against this pest.
Members of the National Fire Service are rendering valuable
assistance by carrying the water used to make the spray.
A solution of lead arsenate, deadly to the beetle but not harmful
to the crops, is sprayed over the halms of the potatoes from multi
jets at the back of the tractors.
The beetles stow away in aircraft from the Continent, and, as they
live only on potatoes, make for the nearest field of them.
Those photographs were taken near Staines and Harmondsworth, to
the North and South of the London Airport at Heathrow.
PHOTO SHOWS:- National Fire Service men pouring water into the
special tanks of lead arsenate mounted on the spraying tractors,
in the Harmondsworth area.
Gal. 17th July, 1947. PN-s. (FULL.)

BRITISH HOUSES FOR AUSTRALIA
TEN MILLION POUND CONTRACT

Taylor Woodrow (Building Exports) Ltd., in
conjunction with the Arcon Group, have concluded
initial negotiations with the Housing Commission
of New South Wales (Australia) for the manufacture
shipment and erection of 5,000 houses.
Two prototype houses are to be erected at
Southall by July for inspection and acceptance
by the New South Wales Government and mass pro-
duction of components will begin in September
and shipping will start in January, 1952, in
time for erection to begin in April.
The contract, estimated to be worth more than
£10 million, was negotiated in Australia by
MR. HAROLD McCUE, managing director of the
exports company of Taylow Woodrow (Building
Exports) Ltd., who was accompanied by Mr.
EDRIC NEEL, of Arcon, and Mr. A.E. WALLIS, of
Steward and Lloyds.

Photograph taken this afternoon (Tues) shows
MR. HAROLD McCUE in London with a model of one
of the many light steel-framed structures which
his firm have exported to twenty-eight countries
in the last two years.

ISSUED 13-3-51 S/N
SUPPLIED L.N.A.

1983-8736/43846
A house in the Park
Sunday for Leisure
Monday
2 cols x 8 ½" deep

There are two types of houses in
the Park. Each has been designed
to take advantage of this unique
location and the wonderful views
in a park of rolling hills and tall
woods, surrounding Beckenham
Place, a mansion nearly 200 years
old. Beckenham Place itself was
built in 1773 by John Cator on a
rise known as Stumps Hill in the
rolling country that surrounds the
house. John Cator, a man of
cultivated tastes, collected a

considerable library of books,
most of which were chosen by
his friend the celebrated Dr
Johnson.
Boswell wrote that Dr Johnson
'found a cordial solace at that
gentleman's seat of Beckenham,
which is indeed one of the finest
places at which I was ever a
guest'.
Today the mansion is used as a
Golf Club House and on part of
the park is laid out an

18 hole course.
The houses are reached through
lodge gates, along a tree lined
avenue cut through the Park.
The houses themselves are
striking – the four stilt houses
elegant and high, the five patio
houses with screened gardens
leading out onto the lawns.
The site is surrounded by tall
trees, with glimpses of the
mature elegance of the parkland
seen through the leaves.

"THE THATCHED ROOF"
GETS A NEW OLD LOOK
B/W.

Replacing a thatched roof with one of Jess Barwickson
slate or tile, is nothing new in rural architecture,
but at MuchHadham, near Bishop'sStortford, the
process reverses in taking glass-bricks to the thickness
still of two of the younger edifices in the country.
Working on the farmhouse of Parker's Dairy Farm,
MuchHadham, the brothers Peter and Burt Rowley, of
Ware, aged (21) and (20), respectively, have
not only changed the front of the house, but also the
roof, which now has its original type of thatch
instead of a brick ridge.
Both under 21, the Rowleys are among the youngest
in the Thatchers Federation. Their family has been
following the craft since 1898.

Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/56849

"THE THATCHED HOUSE"
GETS A NEW OLD LOOK. DS/PH

Replacing a thatched roof with one of less harmonious
slate or tile, is nothing new in rural architecture,
but at Humberstone, near Grimsby, Lincolnshire, the
reverse process is taking place-thanks to the thatching
skill of two of the youngest craftsmen in the country.
Working on the farmhouse of Fowler's Dairy farm,
Humberston, the brothers PETER and BERT MORLEY, of
Wimblington (Ely) and Brampton, respectively, have
not only changed the front of the house, but also the
roof, which now has its original type of thatch
instead of a brick ridge.
Both under 40, the MORLEYS are among the youngest
in the Thatchers Federation. Their family has been
following the craft since 1600.

PHOTO SHOWS: "Eave Expert", PETER MORLEY uses the
ancient eave knife for trimming. Many craftsmen have
turned over to the sheep trimmer for this work, but
PETER swears by his razor-sharp instrument.
FOX PHOTOS Nov 14th 1949

Transcribed_Text:
DAILY HERALD Feb. 25 1955 7

Tenants get 'buy or rent rise' threat

A PROPOSAL has been made to four tenants of a tenement in Wellington-street, Dundee, that they buy their houses—or pay a 40 per cent. rent increase.
One tenant, Mr. John Macbeth, aged 60, was told on a postcard from the landlord's agent, Mr. George J. Lindsay, a Dundee pharmacist:—
"You will note we have not yet added the permitted increase of 40 per cent. to the rents—but we are considering doing so after May term. "Meantime, should you wish to purchase the house before May 28, the price will be £200.
"After May the price will be based on the increased rental. The increase in your case will be 25s. per quarter."
The three other tenants have been told verbally of the landlord's plan.

PROPER WAY
Dundee's chief sanitary inspector, Mr. W. M. Smith, said yesterday: "A rent increase under the Housing and Repairs Act must be submitted to the tenant on the prescribed form, giving details of the proposed increase, the work undertaken and the amount spent over a specified period.
"It is not legal to do it verbally."
Mr. Lindsay, of Castle-street, Dundee, said: "This is a private matter. There is an Act which allows increases.
"I have done nothing yet. If anything is to be done it will be done legally."

DAILY HERALD
25 FEB 1955

BY WILLIAM J. GOOD, UPI

WASHINGTON, AUG. 26 (UPI) -- A PICTURE TAKEN
BY AN ORBITING SATELLITE SENSING THE
EARTH'S ATMOSPHERE GIVES A PREDICTION OF A CHANCE
OF RAIN IN NEW YORK IN ABOUT 24 HOURS.
IT IS ONE OF
MANY FANTASTIC THINGS BEING DONE WITH WEATHER
SATELLITES.
WEATHER MEN HAVE MADE HUGE GAINS IN THE USE
OF ELECTRONICS. WITH IT THEY CAN CHART THE WEATHER
IN THE WORLD.

"IT WAS MADE CLEAR," SAID CHARLES G. ABBOT,
CHIEF OF THE "WEATHER" OFFICE, PREDICTING A
SEVERE DROUGHT. ABBOT STATED HE WAS CONCERNED. HE
BELIEVED THE WEATHER WOULD CONTINUE TO BE RAINLESS
THROUGHOUT THE DRY STATES IN THE WEST. HE SAID
THOUGH THERE WAS A HUGE ATMOSPHERIC SHIFT, IT
WOULD ONLY BE ON THE FRINGES AND WOULD ONLY BE
FELT SLIGHTLY IN THE WEST. ABBOT STATED THAT
CLOUDS OUT WEST ARE "TOO HIGH UP AND WIDE"

PROTECTIVE WEAR FOR FACTORY WORKERS.
OPS. A flexible aluminium mask which although prevents inhalation of dust and powder allows the person wearing it to talk.

DAILY
13 MAR 1953
HERALD

1953-317-6.

Daily Herald
Copyright
Photograph.
MARSHALL.

This flexible aluminium mask prevents inhalation of dust and powder—but not talking.

SAFETY MASKS HAVE GLAMOUR NOW

GLAMOUR goes hand in hand with safety in the new protective masks shown in these two pictures.
They are the latest type of protective wear for factory workers and they will be shown, along with other specially-designed protective clothing, at an out-of-the-ordinary fashion display in London at the end of the month.
The show, part of an exhibition of factory equipment at the Royal Horticultural Hall, aims to prove that girls who do a tough job can still look feminine and attractive.
Two mannequins will parade in overalls instead of the usual elegant gowns; on their feet will be flat-heeled, steel-capped shoes instead of spike-heeled sandals.
And in place of frivolous hats they’ll wear snoods and dust masks.
The idea is to convince factory girls that there can be charm in the kind of clothing that keeps them safe and healthy while they work.

THE BATTLE goes on non-stop. Throughout the day and long into the night.
For Britain's farm workers, like these at Space Farm in West Horsley, Surrey, it is a battle to gather the remnants of their storm-thrashed harvest.
Farmer Percy Yates, who has been working in the glare of arc lamps and tractor lights, cannot remember a more difficult harvest: "We have had to work hard in appalling conditions."
He added: "We have had to take advantage of every minute during the last few days of fine weather."
"But the fields are soggy from all the rain and the corn has been beaten down. It is very hard to combine and it is thick with weeds and grass."

Excellent

At the headquarters of the National Farmers' Union in Knightsbridge, cold statistics tell the story: Somerset, only 30 per cent. of the harvest in. Wiltshire, only 50 per cent.
Said an official: "Men are harvesting in paddy field conditions. The whole harvest is two to three weeks behind.
"Even in places like Cornwall, where they have got 85 per cent. of the harvest in, the grain is light and the yield is below average."
The long-range weather forecast is far from heartening: "Cool, disturbed and occasional stormy weather. Intervals of more settled weather are likely to be brief. Rainfall totals are likely to exceed the average."
Provisional estimates for the 1965 harvest are considerably lower than last year when the good summer yielded excellent crops.

NEW JOBS FOR THE RHONDDA.

(See Feature Set Intro. No. 257)

New jobs have come to the Rhondda as 23 new factories
have been opened in the valley. During the depression
of the 1930's there was one collier to every 2.7 of the
total population and four men out of ten suffered up to
13 years of unemployment. Now the ratio is one collier
to every 7.6 of the total population and there are
alternative jobs. Not only is the economic future of
the Rhondda on a broader and safer base, but jobs are
available to those who fall victim to the dreaded dust
disease which can turn a man from the pit at any age
from 30 until he retires.

SCOTTISH ABADAN D/TAN

Erected on the same site as the old buildings dating from 1924, the new Grangemouth Oil Refinery was built on the Firth of Forth by Scottish Oils Ltd., a subsidiary of the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company. Started in 1949, it went into operation in 1951, with maximum annual crude oil capacity of 2,500,000 tons, helping to counteract the Abadan collapse. Its main objective is high-grade motor spirit, and it also supplies the raw material for the production of petroleum chemicals. To cope with its capacity of 30,000 barrels, or just over 1,000,000 gallons a day of imported crude oil, it was decided to establish an installation at Finnart, on Loch Long, and run a pipeline from there to the refinery, this being more convenient than using the old Grangemouth Docks exclusively. The approximate cost of the combined project was £15,000,000.

Dairy Queen and dairy cow in Oxford Circus
Picture: Leonard Blandford
HOW TO
ANNOUNCE A DAIRY SHOW
A NEW STAR appeared in London's West End yesterday — Fairy Bell, the Dairy Council's amazingly pretty cow.
A prize-winning Jersey of impeccable pedigree and manners, Fairy Bell, appeared in Oxford Circus to publicise next month's National Dairy Festival.
Afterwards, a Council spokesman had nothing but praise for her performance.
"She behaved beautifully. Everyone loved her. She hardly put a foot wrong," he said.
This year's Dairy Queen, 20-year-old Miss Joan Harland from Wetherby, Yorkshire, showed that she is more than just a pretty
face. She handled the problem of being upstaged by a beautiful cow (not a new situation in show business) with tact and charm.
When the photographers wanted Fairy Bell to board a London bus, she patiently co-operated, however impractical the idea.
That's what you call a trouper.
Fairy Bell
+ Joan Harland
(4th Dairy Festival)

VILLAGE POTTERY LIVES ON.
ON WAR
In June this year it looked as though the village
pottery at Compton, near Guildford, Surrey, would
have to close down, owing to financial difficulties.
This news occasioned considerable regret since the
pottery, first built in 1907 and rebuilt in 1973,
had become part of the village life. Four local
people decided to join forces to try and keep it
going. They are: Desin Duchill ("Duchill") of the
"Take it From Here" radio program), of Shalford,
near Guildford; His silversmith, Charles Dove, 1949
winner of the Federation of British Industries Prize
for Industrial Design, who lives at Puttenham; and
P.R. Smith a Guildford solicitor. On December 5th the
kiln fires were once again lit, the ceremony being
performed by the createres of Dr. George Auburnell, who
has worked with the pottery since it was founded, a
hope was rekindled for the survival of the crafts of
England.

PHOTO SHOWS: At the revived Compton Pullarian, Peter
Cowell is seen handing ware into the kiln where they
are received by Harry Vallen, who has had 30 years at
the potteries.

FOX PHOTOS A570C. Four Dec., 1951
Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236 / 52905

VILLAGE POTTERY LIVES ON                      D/VAN

In June this year it looked as though the village
pottery at Compton, near Guildford, Surrey, would
have to close down owing to financial difficulties.
This news occasioned considerable regret since the
potteries, first built in 1902 and rebuilt in 1923,
had become part of the village life. Four local
people decided to join forces to try and keep it
going. They are: David Dunhill ("Dunhill" of the
"Take it From Here" radio programme), of Shalford,
near Guildford; his wife Barbara; Charles Bone, 1949
winner of the Federation of British Industries Prize
for Industrial Design, who lives at Puttenham; and
P.B. Smith a Guildford Solicitor. On December 5th the
kiln fires were once again lit, the ceremony being
performed by the grandson of Mr. George Aubertin, who
has worked with the pottery since it was founded, and
hope was rekindled for the survival of the crafts of
England.

PHOTO SHOWS: At the revived Compton Potteries, Peter
Cowell is seen handing vases into the kiln where they

FIRST PUBLICATION WEDNESDAY'S EVENINGS AUGUST 11th.

POST-WAR PLANNING IN WARTIME -
A NEW £1,000,000 TOWN FOR WAR WORKERS.

Mr Ernest Brown, Minister of Health, recently performed
the opening ceremony of a self-contained community of
844 new houses for war workers transferred from London
for a new industry in the Midlands, which will remain
after the war. The scheme, which has been completed by
the rural district council at a cost of £1,000,000, gives
each house an eighth of an acre of garden, electric
light and power, running water and main drainage; at a
maximum weekly rent of 17/9d, inclusive of rates; nearly
700 workers already occupy these model houses, whose
construction, practically eliminating the use of wood,
solves a major problem of post-war building. 15 acres
of ground have been reserved for new junior and senior
schools, and there will be three churches, pub, cinema.
There is already a large shopping centre, bank, with
Post Office and pictures show:-

1. A type of 3-bedroom-and-parlour house, let at

   for household purposes, the floor is concrete,
   and steel-framed French windows lead to an
   eighth of an acre of garden.

What happens, said Mr. S. L. A.
Evans, to the man who has spent
all his life in the Navy, whose
only home has been his ship, and
who on his discharge finds his
parents dead, his relatives gone,
and no home to go to?

Mr. Evans was speaking at the
first annual meeting of the "Ship
Stools" Club, in Fleet Street, Lon-
don, yesterday, and he said that
this was one of the many prob-
lems the Forces Welfare Depart-
ment was trying to solve.

The Club had been started to
provide a meeting place for men
and women, formerly of the
Royal Navy, Royal Marines, the
W.R.N.S., and the Naval Auxil-
iary Services.

your husband, who grumbles
every time you eat a sandwich."

SOON there will be no Number 13, Page-crescent, in Slades Green, Kent. The local council has agreed to change the number to 11a at the request of the tenant, 36-year-old Mr. Jack Cope.
He went to the town hall and told officials of a run of bad luck since he has lived in No. 13.
First, his eldest child, John, was killed by a lorry when returning to No. 13 from school. Then his son Alan, aged eight, was six months in hospital with polio.
'A TONIC'
These two happenings gave Mr. Cope a nervous breakdown. He was recovering when his hand was caught in a circular saw.
And he has been told that
13
there was a sudden death in each of two families which lived in No. 13 before him.
He and his 35-year-old wife, Joyce, are not usually superstitious. "But it will be a tonic when we see No. 13 come down from our front door," he said.

**THE SIEGE OF Chatsworth Road**
S 11.45. "Who's there?" "Police," came the reply, and then, after a brief pause, the voice again. "There's nobody in." As one officer pushed the door open, a man inside fired a shot, which struck the door-frame. The bullet-scarred door and glass panel which was smashed as another officer forced his way in will be produced at court today. These are among the many articles which will be used in evidence by the prosecution during the trial of George Henry Stoddart charged with the murder of Detective Sgt. William Doyle while attempting to escape from a Chelsea house in Chatsworth Road. The shooting occurred after a three-hour siege, which began at 11.45 on Monday morning after he had been traced by police who had been by means of an alleged theft of a car licence in Mayfair on Sunday.
[Text on right column, partially obscured]: ...killed, ordered out of bed and stays with two dogs

**Who gets there?**
[Illegible text]

1956. yha - 2
Full History (PH) Marc Robson
Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/44449
1955. 460-1
SILAS leans out of a window, torch in hand, Bambi beside him, as a caller arrives.
Son, ordered out of house, stays with two dogs
THE SIEGE OF Chatsworth Road
Express Staff Reporter
SILAS ("Let 'em all come") Bentley is waiting for 10 o'clock this morning. For that is the hour at which he has been told by the local council to quit a house owned by his father.
West Ham Council wants to put in more tenants at 5, Chatsworth-road, Forest Gate, which it requisitioned in 1940. The last tenant moved out 10 weeks ago.
Last night 25-year-old Silas was at heavily bolted No. 5. Determined, he said, to stay. And with him were dogs Bambi, a Boxer, and Jack, a Manchester terrier.
Silas's father, Mr. Charles Bentley, made frequent requests for his son to be allowed to move into the house. To each the council said "No."
Yesterday Silas got on a bicycle at his father's shop in nearby Forest-street and pedalled with his bed on his shoulders to Chatsworth-road.
Bambi and Jack followed him yelping. The Bentley family—mother, father, sister, niece, and nephew—brought up the rear.
They carried Silas's provisions for a possible siege—five tins of meat, three tins of dog food, two tins of peaches ("I'm fond of peaches"), and four loaves of bread.
Silas came to a bedroom window to answer questions last night. The dogs began barking. It was two minutes before they stopped.
Who goes there?
Silas, a burly, curly-headed, 5ft. 8in. figure, called down, "Who goes there?"
I said I was a reporter. There was no answer. I did not have the password.
Silas's mother came to the rescue. She stumped round the corner crying "Cuckoo." This was the signal. I walked in behind Mrs. B. The dogs bounded forward. Silas shouted: "Stop." I breathed again.
"It is my father's house. I am his tenant, and here I am staying," said Silas.
"My wife Myrtle, for whom I had no home is coming up from Devon to join me."
"How long do you think you can last out?" I asked.
"A long, long time," replied Silas.
1955-460-2

188363 CHIT

BRITISH-MADE TOYS BRING IN THE DOLLARS......

London: Following Sir Stafford Cripp's recent announcement on the devaluation of the £ and the need for increased efforts on the part of exporters to produce more dollar-earning goods, manufacturers in Britain are striving for an all-out effort in the weeks left before Christmas to produce lines that sell readily during this period.
And one of the main selling lines in any country at Christmas is, of course, toys - and toys which are original in design find ready customers in the United States. Such toys are produced by Sebel Products, makers of 'Mobo' toys, which are very popular in the United States.
In order to give American and Canadian correspondents an opportunity to see how Sebel's are helping Britain on the road to recovery, the Board of Trade organized a tour of Sebel's factory at Erith (Kent).
PHOTO SHOWS: With a modern spraying unit, Jim Cullinridge, of Kinnington (South London), puts the spots on the 'Mobo Pony' - one of the toys which is bringing in the dollars.
September 21st, 1949. PN-h.

PUBLIC INQUIRY HAS FIRST MEETING.

The Royal Commission appointed to inquire into the ownership and control of the Press met for the first time at the Cabinet Offices, 52, St. George's Street, Westminster, London. Official object of the Commission is to "further the free expression of opinion through the Press and the greatest possible accuracy in the presentation of news." Amongst those present were members of the Commission at the first meeting, namely:- left to right: Mrs. Barbara Wootton, Prof. L.T. Hobhouse, Mr. Arthur L. Davies, Mr. Wickham Steed, Sir Robert Horne, Mr. Arthur J. Cummings, Sir Walter Layton, Mr. E.T. Raymond, Sir Kingsley Wood, Mr. Ivor Thomas, Mr. G.E.O. Knight, Mr. C.B. Young, Dr. H. Laski, Mr. P. G. Macdiarmid, Rev. F.R. Barry, Mr. T.W. Agar, Mr. J.L. Garvin, Sir Charles Hobhouse, Lady Violet, Miss Jean, Miss Helen, Sir Charles, Sir William, Sir Ernest, Mr. J.P. Davies, Mr. J.P. Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/58243

PRESS INQUIRY HAS FIRST MEETING.

The Royal Commission appointed to inquire into the ownership
and control of the Press met for the first time at the
Cabinet Offices in St. George's Street, Westminster, London.
Official object of the Commission is to further 'the free
expression of opinion through the Press and the greatest
practicable accuracy in the presentation of news'.
Scope of the inquiry includes 'the financial structure and the
monopolistic tendencies in control'.
PHOTO SHOWS: - Members of the Commission at the first meeting.
Seated - left to right - J.B. Priestley, 53, novelist;
Mrs. Barbara Wootton, 53, London University Reader of
Social Studies; Miss Birwen Mary Owen, 32, supervisor of
welfare services overseas of the Women's Voluntary Services;
R.C.K. Ensor, 70, historian and journalist; Alderman
Wright Robinson; Sir David Ross, 70, Master of Oriel College,
Oxford, and Chairman of the Commission; Lady Violet
Bonham-Carter, 60, President of Liberal Party Organisation;
Neil Scobie Beaton, 67, retiring chairman of the Scottish
Co-operative Wholesale Society; Sir George Waters, 67,
Editor of 'The Scotsman' for 20 years; G.M. Young.
Standing - left to right - R.A. Haldane, Assistant Secretary
to the Commission; Rev. Dr. Melbourn Aubrey, 62, Secretary
to the Baptist Union; John Benstead, 50, General Secretary
of National Union of Railwaymen; Lord Simon of Wythenshaw,68;
Sir Charles Geoffrey Vickers, Victoria Cross, 52; H. Hall;
R.H. Wilson; Gilbert Granville Sharp, 53, Recorder
(municipal judge) of King's Lynn; Miss Jean Nunn, 30,
Civil Servant from the Home Office, who is Secretary to the
Commission.

HOG, WATER.
HOG, WATER. Ploughing with an 80-h.p. track-type tractor in 1935 was one of the first ploughing and soil erosion experiments used in Texas. The agricultural engineers are now giving farmers the benefits of the very latest implements. During 1934, they were still using a few years older implements which did not fit the Blacklands very well, although using a field much larger than the average. This field was large and fairly level. One of the greatest problems is erosion by wind and water. The cultivated area has been a level-terraced field for 10 years, and there is a 30-foot drop from the cultivating area to the outlet of the terraces. Nobody knows for certain how the field was levelled, but one man on the county remembers the plowing for not more than 50 years.
Before being cultivated by Harley, cultivating the land with a 6-foot lister, was a contract between him and the landowner who will harvest the sorghum and oats by hand. Under the contract, the plowing and terracing of the field was done by the owner or renter. The owner then harvests the field on a wide scale.

HOUSING DEVELOPMENT & CONSTRUCTION LTD.
PROTOTYPE HOUSE BUILT IN THREE WEEKS

The prototype of a new system of industrialised house
building has just been completed by Housing Development &
Construction Ltd., at Stafford-upon-Avon. It is a pair of
semi-detached, three bedroomed houses, designed and built to
the full Parker-Morris Recommendations, and to the
specification of the local authority Stafford-upon-Avon R.D.C.
It only required three weeks of normal working with a very
small team of men to complete this pair of houses for occupation.
This is undoubtedly the fastest erection time of any system
of truly permanent housing for local authorities yet developed.

The kitchen is separated from the dining area by a service
hatch, provides useful storage space and allows room for a
refrigerator or washing machine. The built-in larder is to
the right of the sink. Large wall cupboards (on left but not
seen) house part of the central heating plant and service
meters; they also provide further storage space. The wall
cupboard to the left of the sink houses the Burman gas
heating unit.

A CALL TO SERVICE
A CALL TO SERVICE
PLANET NEWS
94, FLEET STREET,
LONDON, E.C.4.
TELEPHONE CENTRAL 1872.

Rented dwellings have been set ablaze in a country estate, when bailiffs, aided by police, attempted to evict tenants. The tenants, protesting the eviction, barricaded themselves in their homes, and when the bailiffs and police attempted to force their way in, they were met with a volley of bricks and missiles.

The tenants, a group of ex-servicemen, according to reports, were evicted from their homes on the estate, which they occupied for some time. They had erected barricades in and around their dwellings, and when the bailiffs and police attempted to gain access, they were met with resistance. 

Following the skirmish, some of the dwellings were set ablaze, and the tenants and their families fled into the surrounding countryside. The bailiffs and police managed to arrest some of the tenants, but others escaped. The situation remains tense, with the remaining tenants vowing to resist any further attempts at eviction. 
 
THE CHARGES ARE STILL TO BE DETERMINED. 
 
9'h & 5's

1983-5236/49541
USED 19 NOV 1932
Dagenham Rd
BATTLES BETWEEN AND UNEMPLOYED
AT EVICTION ON STATE.
Unemployed members of the Dagenham
Tenants Defence League were engaged in
battles with bailiffs and police who
attempted to gain possession of a
house on the L.C.C. estate at Becontree
Essex. When the Bailiffs tried to
break down the back door of the house
with pick-axes the unemployed retaliated
with bricks and stones. Doors of the
house were wrenched from their hinges
and floor-boards used to barricade the
doors. Boiling water was also used.
As the Police eventually broke down
the barricades, the men defending the
house, jumped out of windows and were met
by police with truncheons. Mrs. Harris
the tenant of the house collapsed and
is believed to have been taken to hospital.
Photo shows:- A fight between the defenders
of the house and the police and (on right)
an injured policeman lying on the ground.

want to see the inside of one of the dark, damp old

taking place in the rural parts of Gloucestershire under

scheme is well advanced.

FIVE hundred aged Britons who now live at home under rented roofs, having a struggle with loneliness and want. And for a month, this column will tell their story.

The subject has been a matter for research and discussion in the House of Commons. There is an increasing demand for more, not less, of the services provided at our old people's clubs. The Minister of Health, Miss Edith Pitt, M.P., indicated that voluntary organisations would eventually be in a position to handle the bulk of such services, but that it would be some time before the national scheme was working as she would wish. Even so, the Minister agreed that more of the services, particularly domiciliary home help, might be needed in certain areas. PROPERTY OF
DAILY HERALD
15 SEP 1959
PLEASE RETURN
TO
LIBRARY

By COLIN HART
FIVE hundred angry tenants whose rents are to be raised mobbed councillors leaving a housing committee meeting last night. And after a scuffle with police, two men were arrested.
The tenants live in council houses at St. Pancras. Before the monthly meeting of the housing committee, they presented Councillor Paul Prior, chairman, with a petition.
Then, while the 13 committee members talked business in St. Pancras Town Hall, a chanting, hostile crowd gathered outside.
Women with shopping bags cried: "Not a penny on the rents," "Down with the Tories," and "Prior must go." Extra police were called in.
Soon after nine o'clock, councillors began to leave. The crowd surged forward as they walked down Euston-road. Fists were waved, and two mounted police cleared the Town Hall steps.

CLEARY WANTS NO LOW PRICES
CLEARY: I agree with the spokesman for the Union
that the price for the oil, which has been
tendered by the company for refining, is too low.
However, the price of 22,250,000, which
the company quoted for the oil to be sold to the
Public is not the only thing that concerns me.
The Public will have some of the oil from the
well but not all. What they want is to have
their oil refinery, and thus they have been
trying to force the price down. But the price
of the oil itself, and the condition of the
oil, are not the only things that are going to
cost the Public money. I do not agree that
all the oil will be sold at the cost of 22,250,000
for the reason that the Public have been
forced to buy the oil from the well and not
only that, but they will have to refine it themselves.
The price that is going to be paid for the oil
for all of it, will be in the proportion of
all of the oil that is used by the Public.

FOR FIRST PUBLICATION TUESDAY'S EVENINGS, April 22nd.,

A HELP-THE-FARMER HOLIDAY
22.5.47.
The Ministry of Agriculture's scheme for volunteer workers
on the farms is meeting with enthusiastic response this
year following the long spell of bad weather which has put
the majority of farmers behind in their work. The Agriculture
camps are proving very popular, and the volunteers find, that
apart from giving the farmer a welcome hand in need, the
spell of work on the farm is a healthy break. This picture,
taken at the Elstead Volunteer Agriculture Camp near GUILDFORD,
Surrey, shows a line of volunteers helping to plant the
potatoes on a Surrey farm.

FIRST PUBLICATION MONDAY'S EVENINGS July 8th, 1946.
Revolutionary in design and of a size which necessitates
her being built on stocks just like an ocean liner, the BRISTOL
BRABAZON I is approaching completion at Bristol, England.
This magnificent aircraft is designed to fly between London
and New York or Montreal direct at a cruising speed of 350 mph
higher than 35,000 ft. Her range will be 5,000 miles. 177ft long
and 50 ft high at rudder and with a wing span of 230 ft, her
all-up weight will be 125 tons, and there will be sleeping berths
for 80 passengers for night travel.
Eight gas-turbine units coupled in pairs will drive four
airscrews, only the bosses of the latter being visible, the
power units themselves being buried in the wings and accessible
for servicing during flight.  The picture shows:
How two gas-turbine units are coupled to one airscrew
only the boss of which will be visible externally.

MEMBERSHIP
THE work of the British Standards Institution, briefly
outlined in this booklet, is financed partly by members'
subscriptions and partly by Government grant-in-aid.
Membership is open to any British subject or to any
properly constituted body in any part of the British
Commonwealth. All subscriptions are allowed by the Inland
Revenue to rank as expenses for taxation purposes.
Subscribing members secure :-
(1) Up-to-date information of new and revised British
Standards, of amendments to British Standards, of new
work started and of oversea standards received.
(2) Free copies of draft British Standards and of new
British Standards in proportion to the subscription
amount, and further copies at a discount.
(3) Free copies of the Institution's Yearbook, with its
abstract of every British Standard.
(4) Free use of the Institution's Library with its compre-
hensive collection of up-to-date oversea standards.
Non-members may buy British Standards at list prices, and
complete sets or sectional industry sets will be supplied
anywhere in the world at special rates.

244480 - A SKI
BANKSIDE POWER STATION: PRODUCTION GETS UNDER WAY
24448

London: An industrial project which has aroused
much controversy from the time of its conception
has just gone into operation.
It is the Bankside Power Station, at which
the first 60,000-kilowatt turbo-alternator of about
80,000 horse-power, has started to supply electricity.
The project was allowed on condition that oil and not
coal was to be burned. Other conditions which had to
be observed were that the building must be set back
far enough from the Thames so as not to interfere with
the projected road and promenade.
Opposition to the power station was so strong that
in January, 1947, a public inquiry was held, with the
result that the scheme was given Government sanction.
On completion the Bankside Power Station will
comprise four 60,000-kilowatt generating sets, the
oil consumption at full load (16-hour day) being
67 tons an hour, consuming in one winter's day about
850 tons.
PHOTO SHOWS; The main control room in the 543 feet
long, 240 feet wide main building of Bankside Power
Station.

MAR 10 MAR 1937
Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/47075

THE first all-in working-class
flat estate in this country—
a model village in storeys—
opened by Sir Kingsley Wood,
Minister for Health, in North
Kensington, yesterday, has:—
A nursery school, separate club-
rooms for children and the grown-
ups, workshops, playgrounds, a
concert-platform and a canteen.
Its 379 inhabitants have been salvaged
from some of the worst slums in London
—those of the Royal Borough of
Kensington—by the Gas Light and Coke
Company.
The company, operating as the Capitol
Housing Association, set out to prove
that it was possible to give working-class
people social amenities enjoyed by the
wealthier middle-class at costs they could
afford.
Rent for a three-bedroom flat is 11s. 6d.
including rates, and for a two-bedroom
only 9s. 6d.
Sixty children on the estate who are
under five are looked after by nursery-
school experts and given their meals—
all for 3d. a day, with an extra penny
for cod-liver oil.
The well-being of the community is
supervised by an executive committee of
the tenants — two representatives for
each of the seven staircases. A caretaker
looks after the general tidiness.

USED 16 MAR 1937

STATE GENERATION OF GUIVAI FAMILY
CABINET OF THE GUIVAI

MDC/P.1

Although with today's modern methods, not many people
work with the same materials and tools as did their
grandfathers, the village carpenter la one man, who,
despite modern improvements, often has to use the same
materials and tools as generations before have done.
One such man is Dr. James Felbert of Guivai (Penance Cornwall)
who is the fifth generation in his family to carry on the
old trade of village carpenter, which means that, at some
time of other, every man in the village of Guivai, must have
been familier with the trade of his family. The knowledge for this
craft is passed down from father to son and the skill is
inherent in the Felberts. The sixth generation of the family,
Mr. Felbert's son Dean, is also following the family craft and
works alongside his father in their Guivai workshop.

by the expert eye of his father, Dr. James Felbert (right)
in their workshop at Guivai, Penance, Cornwall.

SIXTH GENERATION OF CORNISH FAMILY
CARRIES ON AN OLD CRAFT.

MJH/P.1.

Although with today's modern methods, not many people
work with the same materials and tools as did their
grand-fathers, the village carpenter is one man, who,
despite modern improvements, often has to use the same
materials and tools as generations before him have done.
One such man is Mr. James Jelbert of Gulval (Penzance Cornwall),
who is the fifth generation of his family to carry on the
old trade of village carpenter, which means that, at some
time of other, every beam in the village of Gulval, must have
been fashioned by one of his family.  The knowledge for this
craft is passed down from father to son and the skill is
inherent in the Jelberts.  The sixth generation of the family,
Mr. Jelbert's son Evan, is also following the family craft and
works alongside his father in their Gulval workshop.

PHOTOGRAPH SHOWS:  Mr. Evan Jelbert, making cart wheels, watched
by the expert eye of his father, Mr. James Jelbert (right)
in their workshop at Gulval, Penzance, Cornwall.

THE PINTS!
NEXT TIME you sit swigging bitter in your homely local, think of Mr. Tony Cavelier, pictured left.
Mr. Cavelier, in his way, is pulling a pint.
His job as brew supervisor at the new Whitbread plant at Luton, Beds., is to make sure the bitter is the best it can be.
Whitbread's claim the £7million plant is the most modern in Europe. About 288-million pints a year can be produced on a computer-controlled conveyor belt system. Mr. Cavelier is at the master panel.
The plant was to have been officially opened today, but the ceremony has been postponed because of labour troubles which have affected the brewery since production started.
Earlier this month work was stopped when staff went on strike in protest at delays in pay discussions.
Yesterday a management official said: "We are involved in talks with the unions.
"We are anxious not to do anything to upset the talks."
We'll drink to that.

FIRST PUBLICATION FRIDAY'S DAILIES 21.6.46.

A NEW LONDON RISES FROM THE OLD

The West Ham Corporation's "master plan" for the rebuilding of
the Tidal Basin area, one of the worst blitzed districts in the
country, is the first implementation of the Greater London Plan
by a local authority. In what was one of the most sordid of
London's dock areas, 47 acresof land have been bought, on which
well-planned homes, parks, community centres and schools will
replace rowsof mean streets. Tenders amounting to £300,000
have been accepted for 230 of the 700 houses that are to be
built, and it is hoped that the Ministry of Health will
approve the building of a further 127 at a cost of £147,317.
The Tidal Basin area suffered severely in the Nazi raids on
London's Docks, as many as eighteen parachute mines having said
to have fallen in one night. The picture shows:
a panoramic view of the 47 acresof devastation with
transformation work in progress.

work, or live, in the Towns, choose to spend a "holiday

camp, in picturesque rural surroundings, is Oxenford

from Birkenhead; and Phil Rafter (22) of Rock Ferry (Cheshire).

THE NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF YOUNG MEN'S INSTITUTES
AND THE NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF YOUNG WOMEN'S
INSTITUTES
THE NATIONAL FEDERATION OF YOUNG MEN'S INSTITUTES
AND YOUNG WOMEN'S INSTITUTES ARE HOLDING A
JOINT EXHIBITION OF ARTS AND CRAFTS,
WITH WHICH WILL BE DISPLAYED, AT THE
ROYAL AGRICULTURAL HALL, LONDON,
FROM MAY 14TH TO MAY 19TH.
The National Federation of Young Men's Institutes
and Young Women's Institutes are holding a joint
Exhibition of Arts and Crafts which will be
displayed at the Royal Agricultural Hall, London,
from May 14th to May 19th.

The exhibition will be open to the public from
10 am to 7 pm each day. Admission is 2/- for
adults and 1/- for children.

Special facilities are being made for the
judging of the exhibits.

The exhibition is being held to fill a long
felt need for exhibiting the arts and crafts
of the Y.M.C.A. and Y.W.C.A. and is the first
of its kind to be held in this country.

FROM COTTAGE TO BOND STREET
March 13th 1951 PAR 23256-2 (I-R)
..................................................
FROM COTTAGE TO BOND STREET

A cottage industry which produces
hand-made shoes for the world's
smart women was shown in London's
fashion-conscious New Bond Street
(at Russell and Bromley's) to-day,
Tuesday, by the Roelens family -
Michel, Marie and their 15-year-old
son Erik - from the little town
of Ardoye, near Bruges, Belgium.
Shoes are made in the workers'
own homes at Ardoye, where the
shoemaker is always a man, though
his wife and family are allowed to
help with the 'uppers'.
Each craftsman has to undergo a
six years' apprenticeship with the
De Busschere family - who have been
making shoes since 1813 - and a
member of the family supervises
each process of manufacture.
There are now six De Busscheres
engaged in the industry.
PICTURE SHOWS:- M. MICHEL ROELENS, x filed
his wife, MARIE, and son ERIK, 15, res.
busy in their New Bond Street
'workshop' to-day. Erik is sewing
his name on leather, an exercise
to which each apprentice devotes
his first year.
March 13th 1951 PAR 23256-2 (I-R)

BRITAIN PRODUCES WORLD'S LARGEST PIPELINE

One of the biggest contracts for large diameter steel pipe ever placed in Britain has just been secured by South Durham Steel and Iron Company, an old established Teesside firm. The order, from the Basrah Petroleum Co. (an associate of the Iraq Petroleum Company) is for the manufacture of 350 miles of 28-inch pipe, weighing 17,000 tons, to be laid next year from the Doddy oilfield in Southern Iraq to the port of Fao on the Persian Gulf, near Basrah. In addition to enabling new and increasing outlets for our British steel industry, the contract represents also a saving of some 7 million dollars, as the next largest contract of piping has been obtained from the United States.

PRESS NOTE: Sections of 28-inch piping being 'normalized' in a heat controlled furnace after automatic welding of the seams at the South Durham Steel and Iron works.

M. P. CHECKS UP ON SCRAP METAL COMPLAINT
AFTER DOCKERS' PROTEST
Southampton: Mr Ralph Morley, Labour Member of
Parliament for Itchen, Southampton, inspects the
stacks of scrap metal which has been the subject of
protest by dockers. This scrap is due for shipment
from the Town Quay here.
An immediate inquiry into exports of armoured vehicles
is being urged by Mr Morley, to whom dockers have
protested that, while Britain's shortage of scrap is
acute, thousands of tons of steel are being shipped
in this form.
The M.P. has complained to the Ministry of Supply and
the Board of Trade and will raise questions in the House
of Commons to get these shipments banned.

say local dockyard experts, is worth thousands of pounds.

The rest, Mr. Burdett thinks, are sections from towns' arms.

THE Devices were there two years ago when Mr. Burdett took the house; have been there, in fact, for 30 years.
Well, about Coronation time the Middlesex County Council said: "What about paying the armorial bearings duty?"
Mr. Burdett refused to pay, and the Council twice hailed him before the court.
Once the case was dismissed under the Probation of Offenders Act; the second time he was fined.
Still he refused to pay, maintaining that his Devices were not, as the Bench said, armorial bearings.
* * *
SO now the Middlesex County Council has decided to press the County Councils' Association to ask for the abolition of the duty.

TEACHING HIS CRAFT TO HIS GRANDSON. WED/D. 11.

The typically English sight of the village 'smith' at work in his forge, is fast disappearing from the British scene as machines replace horses on the land in this mechanised age. In some areas of the country, however, where machinery is found impracticable and horses are still used - hilly districts for example - the blacksmith can still find plenty of work. One of these is Mr. Clive Fairclough, who still started work in his forge at Franby, Cheshire, at the start of this century (on January 1st. 1900 to be exact) and still puts in a full days work there every day, although he is now 72-years-old. He is now teaching his 13-years-old grandson, Howard Beck, his craft, hoping that the boy will follow in his footsteps as the village blacksmith.

PHOTOGRAPH SHOWS: Under the expert tuition of his 75-years-old blacksmith grandfather, CLIVE FAIRCLOUGH, 13-years-old HOWARD BECK, is seen learning how to fashion a horse shoe on the anvil in Franby forge, Cheshire.

BRITAIN'S "WINE CELLAR" - THE LONDON DOCKS.          MJH/HT.

The British people are drinking more wine these days
proved bythe fact that so far this year, with the festive
season still to come, Britain's wine consumption is 10%
higher than last year.  Sherry is almost back to pre-war
popularity - this year's consumption was 80% of the 1939
level.  This rising demand means that the London Docks are
becoming more and more Britain's win cellar, with the bonded
vaults and warehouses doing a "roaring trade".  This country
still imports most wine from France, Spain and Portugal, followed
by Germany, South Africa, Italy and Australia.

PHOTOGRAPH SHOWS:  MR. PAT BURNS of Poplar, one of the employees
in the Bonded vaults and Warehouses of the London Docks,
seen busy labelling hundreds of bottles of Spanish dark sherry.

FIRST PUBLICATION MONDAY'S EVENINGS 8th July, 1946.
BRITAIN'S 80-BERTH AIR LINER ON THE STOCKS
Revolutionary in design, and of a size which necessitates
her being built on stocks just like an ocean liner, the BRISTOL
BRABAZON I is approaching completion at Bristol, England.
This magnificent craft is designed to fly direct between
London and New York or Montreal at a cruising speed of 350 mph
higher than 35,000 ft. Her range will be 5,000 miles. 177ft long
and 50 ft high at rudder and with a wing span of 230 ft, her
all-up weight will be 126 tons, and there will/sleeping berths fo
80 passengers for night travel.
Eight gas-turbine units coupled in pairs will drive four
airscrews, only the bosses of the latter being visible, the
power units themselves being buried in the wings and accessible
for servicing during flight. The picture shows:
Interior of the BRISTOL BRABAZON I looking towards the
stern, showing her rib construction andhow the various deck
levels are taking shape.

KENT PIONEERS BUILD THEIR OWN HOMES, MJH/RS,

On a housing estate in Hawes Lane, Beckenham, (Kent) a group
of 25 pioneers are building their own homes in their spare
time. Only a few of them are builders by trade, the others
include, cashiers, clerks, shopkeepers, a Post Office engineer,
etc. but the Beckenham Housing Association, as they call
themselves, are making up in enthusiasm what they lack in skill
at present, and by working every weekend and in the evenings
by floodlight, they have several bungalows at various stages
of completion. Order of priority is worked out in a friendly
and amicable manner and while each man works with a will on a
friends bungalow, he looks forward to the time when he will
be working on his own.

homes.

GLASS-FIBRE ROOF CAR MAKES IT'S APPEARANCE.   EH/RS.

A British car with a complete all glass roof with all the
modern windows fitted in the ordinary splintex glass, is
now being tested on the streets to see if it stands up to the
weather conditions. The roof is glass-fibre cloth moulded
together with resin and taking four hours to cure. The
hood and roof can be dismantled in two minutes, making the
car a complete sports model. The weight is 45 lbs, exactly
half the weight of an ordinary car roof. The glass-fibre
has already been tested with a 4 lb hammer, and although
only 1/8" thick, no impression was made on it at all.
The Vanden Plas (England) 1923 Ltd, a famous British car
builders, have completed this roof and, although the whole
thing is moulded at first on a gig, there is no join
whatsoever.

AGRIC - MACHINERY
237180 DR 'TROLLEYBUS' TRACTOR GETS FIRST TRY-OUT
Reading, Berkshire: Something new in farming machinery is
the 'trolley-bus' tractor, an electric device invented by
Russian scientists, and now being tried for the first time in
this country.
The miniature tractor, seen being operated by 17-year-old Yvonne
Shepheard, has no engine. It is driven instead by a simple
electric motor powered from the mains, a strong, thin cable
links the tractor with a wooden pylon in the middle of the
market garden. The cable is automatically paid out as the
girl drives away. Counterweights take up the slack as she returns
The scientists at the Electrical Research Association Laboratory
near Reading, who are testing the 'garden trolley bus', claim it
has three outstanding advantages over an engine-powered tractor-
It is much cheaper to run. It needs less attention and is almost

Transcribed_Text:
1983 - 5236/40539

AGRIC - MACHINERY .

237168               DE
'TROLLEYBUS' TRACTOR GETS FIRST TRY-OUT

Reading, Berkshire: Something new in farming machinery is
the 'trolley-bus' tractor, an electric device invented by
Russian scientists, and now being tried for the first time in
this country.
The miniature tractor, seen being operated by 17-year-old Yvonne
Shepheard, has no engine. It is driven instead by a simple
electric motor powered from the mains. A strong, thin cable
links the tractor with a wooden pylon in the middle of the
market garden. The cable is automatically paid out as the
girl drives away. Counterweights take up the slack as she returns.
The scientists at the Electrical Research Association Laboratory
near Reading, who are testing the garden 'trolley bus', claim it
has three outstanding advantages over an engine-powered tractor:-
It is much cheaper to run. It needs less attention and is almost
free from breakdowns. It is much more powerful for its size.

19th August 1952 PN-b

output - gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20:
D.H. 1983-5236/910508 1.8.44.
NAT'S SCORE IS 25,000 not out.
In the tiny Hamlet of Milford situated on the
outskirts of Salisbury lives 70 year old Nathaniel
Barber, Blacksmith for 53 years. Nat belongs to
a fast dying profession, for blacksmiths are now
becoming a rarity.
Motor Engineer is the new term for where Nat used
to shoe over 200 horses six times a year, now only
20 come to him to be reshod.
Nat's father was a blacksmith as were four of his
eight brothers of whom he is the only one left.
In spite of the lack of horses to shoe, Nat
persuaded his 40 year old son to learn the craft
and now when Nat passes on, Ronald will become the
fourth generation of barber - Blacksmith.
Nat boasts of the time he shodd famous racehorses
in the district.
Nat estimates that he has made and forged 25,000
shoes in his 53 years and hopes to make a few more
thousand yet. He works from dawn till dusk six
days a week throughout the year.
There is another son, Horace, profession motor
engineer.
O.F.S.1 70 year old Nat. Barber at the forge
at Milford Hill.

RAYON INDUSTRY IN NORTHERN IRELAND.
A NEW INDUSTRY WHICH HAS SPRUNG UP IN NORTHERN
IRELAND IS THE PREPARATION AND WEAVING OF
RAYON CREPE AND OTHER RAYON FABRICS.
CREPE WEAVERS LTD., OF DERRYNOSE, CO. DOWN,
WHICH COMMENCED IN 1948 OCCUPIES PART OF THE EDWARDS
AIRPORT WHICH WAS ORIGINALLY BUILT FOR THE PRODUCTION
OF AIRCRAFT.
IT EMPLOYS 135 PEOPLE AT PRESENT BUT WILL EMPLOY
300 PEOPLE BY THE END OF THE YEAR WHEN THE MILL IS
FULLY EQUIPPED.
OWING TO THE MALE UNEMPLOYMENT SITUATION IN THE
DISTRICT IT IS THE INTENTION OF THE FIRM TO EMPLOY
40 PER CENT MEN AND 60 PER CENT WOMEN.
THE PRODUCTION TARGET FOR THE END OF THE YEAR IS
30,000 YARDS OF RAYON FABRICS PER WEEK, OF WHICH
BETWEEN 80 AND 90% WILL BE FOR EXPORT.
MOST OF THE WORKERS ENGAGED ARE TRAINEES FORMERLY
AGRICULTURAL LABOURERS AND LAUNDRY WORKERS.
CARE HAS BEEN TAKEN NOT TO EXPOSE WORKERS FROM LIMEX
TEXTILE MILLS IN THE DISTRICT WHICH WOULD HAVE ADDED
TO THE PRODUCTION OF THE NEW FIRM BUT WOULD HAVE
CAUSED DIFFICULTIES IN THE ESTABLISHED FIRMS.
GPS. A GENERAL VIEW OF THE WEAVING SHED.
Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236 / 53560 .

NEW CREPE & RAYON INDUSTRY IN NORTHERN IRELAND.
A new industry which has sprung up in Northern
Ireland is the preparation and weaving of
rayon crepe and other rayon fabrics.
Crepe Weavers Ltd., of Newtownards, Co. Down,
which commenced in 1948 occupies part of Newtownards
Airport which was originally built for the production
of aircraft.
It employs 125 people at present but will employ
200 people by the end of the year when the mill is
fully equipped.
Owing to the male unemployment situation in the
district it is the intention of the firm to employ
60 per cent men and 40 per cent women.
The production target for the end of the year is
30,000 yards of Rayon fabrics per week, of which
between 50 and 60% will be for export.
Most of the workers engaged are trainees formerly
agricultural labourers and laundry workers.
Care has been taken not to engage workers from linen
textile mills in the district which would have added
to the production of the new firm but would have
caused difficulties in the established firms.
OPS. A general view of the weaving shed.

output - gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20:
EIDER DUCK SCHOOL.

The spring season for jam-nut fishing on the Eider River has begun, and we are told that despite the long hours it has yielded so far, there are still some days left to the start of the season. Although much larger catches are expected at this time of year, owing to the development of the rather elaborate "jam-nut fishing" system, which was developed over the last 20 years, the Eider River has been experiencing rather light catches this season. Jam-nut fishing is a method of catching fish by means of a string of bait, which is cast out into the river and then drawn in by means of a pulley. The bait is generally composed of fish spawn, but other forms of bait may also be used. The jam-nut fishing system is rather elaborate, and it is said to be quite effective in catching fish. However, it is also said to be quite difficult to learn, and it is not recommended for beginners.

Paris Champs. A salmon-fisher netting one of the first fish of the season at Eider River, Norway.
Photo July 27th, '52.

USED IN EVENING PAPERS.
Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/47830

GLOUCESTERSHIRE.
CH/ 4.

SALMON FISHING STARTS.

The spring season for lave-net salmon fishing on the River Severn
is now well under way and although large catches are now expected
at this time of year owing to the lowtemperature of the water many
fish have been caught.    Lave-net fishing involves the use of an
unwieldly bow shaped net on a wooden frame. The fisher, walking
sometimes as much as two miles through the mud of the river to his
pool in the middle of the Severn watches for his prey to leap from
the water.

CIRCUS ACT TO PREPARE FOR
HOP GROWING.

NF/824

Fred Delling (23) is not rehearsing for a circus
act but he is working on stilts to prepare for hop growing
at Dormington Court Farm, Herefordshire. He works 11 feet
above the ground on stilts and although it is only a once a
year job he performs with the agility of a circus performer.
It is only in recent years that hops have taken the place
for ladders in Herefordshire. It takes the quarter the time
it would with ladders, says Mr Delling. Hop growing is big
business in Herefordshire and planting takes place very
shortly for picking in September. The better the crop the
better the beer.

Photo Shows: Mr Fred Delling (23), 11 ft above the ground
on stilts, not for the circus, but to tie down new hopwork
poles on a acres of hop fields at Dormington Court, Herefordshire.
Although he only performs on stilts once a year he displays
the dexterity of a circus act. He says it takes him only a
quarter of the time it would with ladders.

releasing the tractor automatically

Transcribed_Text:
Tudor

LIFE AT THE BLUE COAT SCHOOL.

Christ's Hospital or "Blue Coat School", was founded by
Edward VI on the site of an old Greyfriars Monastery, and down
to a few years ago was one of London's best known scholastic
institutions. It was pulled down to make room for extensions
of St. Bartholomew's Hospital and the new General Post Office,
in Newgate Street. The School is now carried on at HORSHAM in
an imposing building. Besides the usual subjects included in
any school curriculum, the boys are taught intersting things,
such as clay modelling, carpentry, weaving, spinning etc., and
have taken advantage of their move into the country by acquiring
a farm, the work on which is done by the boys. The school has
a band complete with mace bearer and this is a familiar sight
once a year in London when the school marches through the City to
their annual church service. The boys still wear the picturesque
costume of knee breeches, yellow stockings and blue coats.

O.P.S. A Blue coat boy working a picturesque spinning wheel
at the school, KEYSTONE. HD/B.

GOLD FOR PRINCESS ELIZABETH'S FINGERS?
WELSH MINE MAY PROVIDE ROYAL RING.
When, in that solemn moment on November 20th Lieutenant Phillip Mountbatten slips the ring on to the third finger of Princess
Elizabeth's left hand at Westminster Abbey, it is highly
probable that the golden band will be fashioned from
British gold, mined in the only gold mine working in
Wales. - Groigwen gold mine.
Owned by Mr. Thomas Mishellonges, Groigwen old mine
near Porthcawl, is producing very high ore -- both in gold and
silver -- and with the arrival of modern concentrators
it is likely that 90% of the metals existent in the ore
will be recovered. At present only 29% of the metals are
recovered.
Gold is richest on the top reef of the field. There the
quartz is blue ag colour. Our assay from this field. was
as much as 19 ounces per ton of rock.
PHOTO SHUS: Mr. Thomas Mishellonges works on the gold
bearing rocks in the Groigwen gold fields area. It is on the top
here, that the ore bearing rocks are richest.
Cardiff, Sept. 1947. BPgColon/Par/Cross/Sonn/

Wales.- Graigwen gold mine.

London has seen nothing quite like it since the hungry Thirties.

South Wales miners, nearly a thousand strong and backed by railways, marching to the House of Commons demanding work for the unemployed.

Their slogans and banners protesting against pit and rail closures cast a shadow from the past, even in prosperous Oxford Street.

"GETTING BAD"

One bowler-hatted umbrella-carrying Londoner said: -"I don't know quite what it is all about, but when Welsh miners do this, things must be getting bad."

A special train ran through from West Wales picking up the men for London - delegates from 110 colliery lodges, representing over 60,000 miners.

It might have looked like a danger special as they poured out into the Pad-

dington Station.

Welsh miners are like that.

Never given in their more.

inclinent moments.

A Cockney porter shouted: -"Up the Welsh."

The miners' Union had on a 30-piece brass band to greet them with Roman flags and Land of My Fathers. The roar of old Paddingtion rang with the voices of a mighty crowd.

HERALD

DAILY

1963. 333 - 7 )

LONDON has seen noth-
ing quite like it since
the hungry Thirties.
South Wales miners, nearly a
thousand strong and backed by
railwaymen, marching to the
House of Commons demanding
work for the unemployed.
Their slogans and banners
protesting against pit and rail
closures cast a shadow from the
past, even in prosperous Oxford
Street.
'GETTING BAD'
One bowler-hatted umbrella-
carrying Londoner said: "I
don't know quite what it is all
about; but when Welsh miners
do this, things must be getting
bad."
A special train ran through
from West Wales picking up the
men for London — delegates
from 110 colliery lodges, repre-
senting over 80,000 miners.
It might have looked like a
Rugger special as they poured out
into Pad-
dington
Station.
Welsh
miners are
like that.
Never
gloomy
even in
their more
serious moments.
A Cockney porter shouted:
"Up the Welsh."
The Musicians' Union laid
on a 50-piece brass band to
greet them with Sospan
Fach and Land of My
Fathers. The roof of old
Paddington rang with the
voices of a mighty choir.
MUSIC

Scoop x 3 7/8"

HERALD

WHEN COLD WEATHER MEANS "BIG BUSINESS".
BJH/TU.

A man who looks forward to wintry weather is
53-years-old Mr. Stanley Russell of Croydon.
The reason for this unusual penchant is that
Mr. Russell owns one of the oldest and largest
firewood businesses in Croydon and naturally
cold weather to him means a "boom". Mr. Russell
supplies firewood to houses, shops, hospitals,
schools, hostels etc., in an area 25 miles around
his yard and at this time of year, his staff is
extremely busy.

PHOTOGRAPH SHOWS. Lending a hand to tie the
bundles of firewood at Mr. Russell's Croydon (Surrey)
wood yards is 78-years-old MRS. LOUH ("GRAN") NORMAN.
"Gran" usually works in the office, but at busy
time, such as at present, she helps out in the tying
and packing sheds.

PROPERTY
15 APR 1968

ART LIBRARY

THE QUEEN embarrassed safety experts yesterday
for the second time in a fortnight.

She drove an estate car with Princess Margaret's
three-year-old daughter, Lady Sarah Armstrong
Jones, perched on the front seat beside the
Queen Mother.

Safety experts say the front passenger seat is
the most vulnerable spot in a car. Less than
three weeks ago Mrs. Barbara Castle, then
Minister of Transport, announced plans to launch
a campaign persuading parents to put their
children in the back seat.

That is where Prince Andrew rode yesterday,
when his mother drove the royal party back to
Windsor Castle from a polo match in Windsor
Great Park. She used a private road, but it
crosses the main Staines road.

Only a fortnight ago when Princess Anne was
at the wheel, the Queen sat in the front passenger
seat with four-year-old Prince Edward on
her lap.

15

Nearly a thousand 8-roomed flats, two-bedroomed homes in the Greater London area, have, apart from blocks of nursery flats and town houses, and occasions in the wealthy East London residential areas have become unoccupied. Fortunately, signatures had entirely occupied and vacant. Army range. Several flats, temporarily occupied at Ã‚Â£10 per week, are now unoccupied.

These are all by signatures in the purpose of shelter and evacuation. In East London, for instance, nearly 100 people are now accommodated, and have lived for many months in the homes of those in the Services, with no rent pay. The purpose of the government was to repair them and then to bring them into use.

These flats are still, falling to Housing, for the purpose of Housing, are still being repaired and now occupied by a family of 7 people.

The Minister of Housing, Mr. Lyttleton, has been busy in London on a priority list of civilians who had been waiting in the list for accommodation.

ON September 9, 1945.
Transcribed_Text:
192/D3 Post war Difficulties - Squatters DHA 2642
1983-5236/602 Flats seized by homeless - Abbey Lodge

SUITCASE IS COT IN SQUATTERS' KENSINGTON LUXURY FLAT.

Nearly a thousand persons from overcrowded homes in the
Greater London area have seized two blocks of luxury flats
and seven houses and mansions in the wealthy West London boroughs
of Kensington and Marylebone. Formerly, squatters had mainly
operated at vacant Army camps.
Forty-six flats (usually rented at £10 10s. a week and upwards)
are occupied by squatters in Duchess of Bedford House,
Duchess of Bedford's Walk, Kensington
These flats, in which several hundred people are now accommodated,
had been empty for some months and had been in the hands of
the Ministry of Works, who were preparing to repair them and
hand them over for letting.
PHOTO SHOWS:- Mrs. M. Mullins feeding Christopher (centre) and
Maureen (right) as baby Patricia sleeps peacefully in a suitcase,
which until furniture arrives, serves as a cot in the Mullins'
flat at Duchess of Bedford House.
Mr. C.J. Mullins, husband of Mrs. Mullins, is a 32-year-old
ex soldier who had been waiting 12 months on a priority list
for accommodation.
CHI September 9th 1946 PN.r.

lord’s agent.
“Is that so?” replied Mrs.
Esther Clara Garrett, of Irene
House, Flower and Dean-street,
Whitechapel, E.
She is the chairwoman of the
committee formed by 180 tenants of
tenements there, to demand rent re-
ductions and repairs.
With no schooling except that
which comes from going to work at
eight years of age and bringing up a
large family, Mrs. Garrett yesterday
made her first “public appearance.”
She left the two-room flat for
which she pays 13s. a week rent and
spoke to 250 men, women and
children.
They cheered as she told them,
“I’ll go to the landlord and whatever
there is to say, I’ll say it.”
The meeting followed a procession
from Flower and Dean-street, with
drums playing and banners flying.
Organised by the Stepney Tenants’
Defence League, the meeting decided
to send the landlord a suggested
scale of rents and repairs, with a rent
strike ultimatum if there is no satis-
faction or negotiation in seven days.
G 6727
