Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/55304

GLASS-FIBRE ROOFED CAR MAKES ITS APPEARANCE.      EH/RS

A British car with a complete all glass roof, with all the
modern windows fitted in the ordinary splintex glass, is now
being tested on the streets to see if it stands up to the
weather conditions.  The roof is glass-fibre cloth moulded
together with resin and taking four hours to cure.  The hood
and roof can be dismantled in two minutes, making the car a
complete sports model.  The weight is 45 lbs, exactly half the
weight of an ordinary car roof.   The glass-fibre has already
been tested with a 4 lb hammer, and although only 1/8" thick,
no impression was made on it at all.  The Vanden Plas (England)
1923 Ltd, a famous British car builders, have completed this
roof and although the whole thing is moulded at first on a
gig, there is no join whatsoever.

Photograph shows :-  Mr George Smith (left) and Mr J. Brooks,
both of Kingsbury, converting the sports model Austin Somerset
into a saloon. at Vanden Plas Ltd, Kingsbury works, London,
N.W. 9.

description: A photographic print from the Daily Herald Archive folder: Industry ÃƒÆ’Ã¢â‚¬Å¡Ãƒâ€šÃ‚Â» Textiles - Cloth ÃƒÆ’Ã¢â‚¬Å¡Ãƒâ€šÃ‚Â» Silk.

ONLY SILKWORMS REARED FOR PRODUCTION OF SILK, FOR SCHOOLCHILDREN'S STUDY.

The only native silkworm farm, established at Wilmington Castle, Kent, by Lady Bert Dyke, is producing the silk which will be used to make the silk velvet Cotton tea cosy for the Princesses of Gloucester and Kent.

The 3,000-year-old art of cocoon culture has been mastered at the Farm and five years ago, Lady Dyke started cultivating silkworms. The feeding and rearing rooms occupy the entire west wing of the Castle and feed the larvae 27,000 mulberry bushes are grown.

Sir Oliver & Bert Dyke, who have dedicated the last 30 years to this ancient art, has designed the feeding machines on which the silk is wound. The silkworms spin their cocoons on straw structures, producing an inch thread up to half-a-mile long in 48 hours.

PHOTO SHOWS: Gathering the cocoons from the straw structures where they spin in 48 hours on thin threads of silk up to half-a-mile in length. The cocoons remain on the straw for two days to harden off.

JANUARY 26, 1957.

26-1-57.
Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/53640

ONLY ENGLISH SILKWORM FARM PRODUCES SILK FOR
      DUCHESS' CORONATION GOWNS.
5,000-YEAR-OLD ART MASTERED AT KENT CASTLE

The only English silkworm farm, established at
Lullingstone Castle, Kent, by Lady Hart Dyke,
is producing the silk which will be used to
make the purple velvet Coronation gowns for
the Duchesses of Gloucester and Kent.
The 5,000-year-old art of cocoon reeling has
been mastered at the farm and five years after
its foundation millions of silkworms are bred.
The breeding and feeding rooms occupy the
entire west wing of the Castle and to feed the
worms 27,000 mulberry bushes are grown.
Sir Oliver Hart Dyke, distinguished engineer
husband of Lady Hart Dyke, has designed the
reeling machines on which the silk is wound.
The silkworms spin their cocoons on straw structures,
producing one thin thread up to half-a-mile long in
48 hours.
PHOTO SHOWS:  Gathering the cocoons from the straw
structures where they spin in 48 hours one thin
thread of silk up to half a mile in length.  The
cocoons remain on the straw for ten days to harden off.
      G January 3rd 1937  PN.g.

USED - 4 JAN 1937

BRITISH SILK FOR CORONATION GOWNS.—The only English silkworm
farm—established by Lady Hart Dyke at Lullingstone Castle, Kent—is producing
silk which will be used to make purple velvet Coronation gowns. Left (above):
Gathering cocoons from their straw beds, and (below) reeling the silk from the
cocoons. Above: The start and finish of the process; Lady Hart Dyke with eggs
and the finished velvet.

AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH LABORATORY.
PC/VEH.
The Agricultural Research Council Radio-biological
Laboratories, near Wantage, Berkshire, is the organisation
that carries out regular tests on milk collected from
milk sampling zones and depots in Great Britain, that
determine the amount of lodine 131 content. The fear
that the quantity of radio active content in milk may
rise because of the recent Russian Nuclear tests is
officially over, and it has been announced in the House
of Lord's by the Minister of Defence, Lord Hailsham, that
milk throughout the country is free from a dangerous
level of lodine 131 and is safe for young children.

Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/40657

AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH LABORATORY. PC/FRES.

The Agricultural Research Council Radio-biological
Laboratories, near Wantage, Berkshire, is the organisation
that carries out regular tests on milk collected from
milk sampling zones and depots in Great Britain, that
determine the amount of iodine 131 content. The fear
that the quantity of radio active content in milk may
rise because of the recent Russian Nuclear tests is
officially over, and it has been announced in the House
of Lord's by the Minister of Science, Lord Hailsham, that
milk throughout the country is free from a dangerous
level of iodine 131 and is safe for young children.

PHOTOGRAPH SHOWS:- A plastic jar containing the protein
and iodine 131 into the counter. The thick lead walls
shield the detector from natural background radiation.

BUILDING KENT'S FIRST ALUMINIUM SCHOOL
Date 18.4.49.
The first of the five schools to be built by the Kent County
Council in aluminium prefabricated sections, is now well
under way. The school will be the Greys Farm County Primary
School at St. Paul's Cray, and the walls and roofs are of
aluminium alloy supplied by the Bristol Aeroplane (Housing)
Company. The sections are delivered to the site ready for
erection, thus saving much time and labour apart from materials.
The blocks illustrated in these pictures will accommodate five
classrooms and one general purpose room. There will be another
block housing two classrooms and one general purpose room, an
administrative wing, assembly hall, canteen kitchen, dining hall,
etc., and the whole school will accommodate 360 children. The
only brickwork in the buildings will be the external gable and
walls, and the boiler house. The foundations of which can be
seen in some of the pictures, which were taken during a visit
to the site today.

File Index. Building & Plans.

DEMONSTRATION: NEW SHARVIK TRACTOR AND ASSOCIATED EQUIPMENT
FOR USE IN EAST AFRICAN GROUNDNUTS SCHEME

Demonstration, 1940. A demonstration of the new Sharvik
tractor, which has been specially designed for work on
the East African Government's East African groundnut scheme,
was held at Machakos. The tractor, built by
Messrs. - (M.L.R.), combines certain of the components
of the Sharvik "Kart" (1937), including one of the two-stroke
diesel engines.
All the tractors are fitted with a universal "U"-frame
to which a variety of implements can be fitted. "U"-frame
blades are used for digging out trees and roots. A "V"
plough and tree-rake can be quickly attached to the rear of the
tractor, and the tree-root-cutter has been used on work
in conjunction with the "V" plough. The root-cutter is also used in conjunction with a root-rake.
The "V" plough attached.
The new Sharvik tractor at work with the
root-rake, watched by Ministry of Food officials and
others who wished the demonstration.
D. C. L. 5/4/1940. J.N.O. Tel-OL45-008-OAR.
Transcribed_Text:
1983 - 5236/40451

169652(CHI). NEW SHERVIK TRACTOR DEMONSTRATES EQUIPMENT
FOR USE IN EAST AFRICAN GROUNDNUTS SCHEME.

BAGSHOT(Surrey)ENG: A demonstration of the new Shervik
tractor, which has been specially designed for work on
the British Government's East African groundnuts scheme,
was held here. The new tractor, built by
Vickers-Armstrongs, Ltd, combines certain of the components
of the Sherman Mark V tank, including one of the two-stroke
Diesel engines.
All the tractors are fitted with a universal "U"frame
to which a variety of implements can be fitted. Stumper
blades are used for digging out tree stumps with their
roots, and trees can be quickly uprooted with the use of
the treedozer. After the root-cutter has been at work
collection of the roots is accomplished with a root-rake,
16 feet in width.
PHOTO SHOWS:- The new Shervik tractor at work with the
root-raker, watched by Ministry of Food officials and
others who watched the demonstration.
20th April, 1948. PN-s. (US-CAN-Par-Stk.

INDIAN-OIL WELLS, BRITISH-I.O.W.

THE CRUDE OIL PRODUCTION IN B.I. 1s NOT SO BIG. IN FACT THE FIGURE FOR THE FIRST 6 MONTHS IS ABOUT 1.20.89.

DRILLING IN WELL No. 5 WAS SO SUCCESSFUL THAT THE DEEPER LEVELS AT WHICH OIL WAS FOUND, HAVE BEEN VERY PRODUCTIVE. SO THE PRODUCTION FIGURE INCREASED SUBSTANTIALLY IN JULY AND AUGUST. OIL HAS BEEN FOUND IN AMPLE MEASURE IN THIS WELL.

ACCORDING TO THE FIGURES WHICH ARE NOT COMPLETELY AVAILABLE, THE PRODUCTION FOR THE END OF THE YEAR IS NOT EXPECTED TO EXCEED 400 BARRELS OR TO BE MORE THAN 4000 BARRELS IN ALL. IN THE UNITED STATES, THE PRODUCTION OF OIL HAS BEEN HIGHER, AND THE AVERAGE PRODUCTION PER WELL HAS ALSO BEEN HIGHER. THE FIGURES SHOW THAT THIS WELL HAS BEEN SO SUCCESSFUL AS TO EARN RS. 3,720 IN ITS FIRST 6 MONTHS' PRODUCTION. THE LATEST REPORTS SHOW THAT THE DAILY AVERAGE IS ABOUT 26 BARRELS OF OIL, WHICH IS FAIRLY GOOD. IT HAS BEEN FOUND THAT THE GREATER AMOUNT OF OIL IS TO BE FOUND FROM THE DEEPER LEVELS.

FOR FIRST PUBLICATION MONDAY'S DAILIES... DEC. 1st.
SEARCH FOR OIL IN THE ISLE OF WIGHT
me. 1.12.52.
Drilling for oil in the Isle Of Wight by the D'Arcy
Exploration Co. (the prospecting subsidiary of the
Anglo-Iranian Oil Co.) is a project that has been
planned for several years. It has now been operating
about six weeks, and is an example of the search for
this valuable mineral that has so far resulted in
an annual production in the United Kingdom of 50,000
tons. The present site, Perreton Farm, Arreton, was
found by gravity survey and confirmed by seismic
reflection survey, and the drillers have now reached
a depth of 1,700ft. This Picture shows :-

11 JUN 1947

11 JUN 1947

'AIRBORNE' ATTACK ON HOUSING PROBLEM -
HORSA GLIDER BECOMES A HOME.

The fuselage of a Horsa glider - the type used by
airborne troops in World War II - is being converted
into a home for a London businessman by Mr. Arthur Bedford,
a building contractor at Southbourn, Bournemouth, Hampshire.
The glider-home will have three rooms - a bedroom measuring
10 feet by 7 feet, a living room 15 feet by 7 feet,
and a kitchenette 8 feet by 7 feet.
If the experiment is successful, the builder will convert
more gliders. People baffled by the housing shortage
will be able to have these homes built quite cheaply on
their own sites.
PHOTO SHOWS: - Men working on the exterior of the glider-home.
QUI June 11th 1947 PN.r.

WHAT HOUSE IN A DAY - AND FTYR
20 MINUTES TO SPARE

Two men erected a house in 8 hours
10 minutes - 20 minutes ahead of
schedule - at Llanwla in-day

1,000 workers and can produce over
50 houses a week.

NEWS AND PICTURE SERVICES: NEGOTIATION 20.3.55.

The British Jewellers' Association, which
represents nearly 2,000 manufacturing and
wholesale jewellers, has become a patron
of its own trade The central council of the
association recently decided that the ancient
art of silversmithing was in serious danger
of extinction without public support. It was
decided that the Association should commission
a special piece of modern silversmithing to be
the collection of fine silverware and, at the same
time, setting an example to similar organisations
who might become patrons to the trade. The first
piece, modern silver mace (for use upon ceremonial
occasions), has now been completed, designed by the
well-known designer, R.D. Mill, and made by a London
firm of silversmiths.

I.N.P. PHOTO SHOWS: Mr. Thomas Cabanagh of Bromley, Kent
examining the mace, which is 31 inches long
of solid silver, employs the three motifs of
the sun, moon and mercury, which figure in the
Associations coat-of-arms.

MACE FOR BRITISH JEWELLERS' ASSOCIATION 26.1.55.

The British Jewellers' Association, which
represents nearly 2,000 manufacturing and
wholesale jewellers, has become a patron
of its own trade.The Central Council of the
Association recently decided that the ancient
art of silversmithing was in serious danger
of extinction without public support.It was
decided that the Association should commission
a special piece every year, thus building up its
own collection of fine silverware and, at the same
time, setting an example to similar organisations
who might become patrons to the trade.The first
piece, amodern silver mace for use upon ceremonial
occasions, has now been completed, designed by the
well-known designer R.H.Hill, and made by a London
firm of silversmith's.

I.N.P.PHOTO SHOWS:- Mr.Thomas Cabanagh of Bromley, Kent
examining the mace, which is 21 inches long
of solid silver, employs the three motifs of
the sun, moon and mercury, which figure in the

FOUR-SECTION PREFAB: GATED ALUMINIUM HOUSE ON VIEW TO LONDONERS

An Aluminium House. Factory-made in four sections, has been put up on a bombed site outside Balfour's, the departmental store in Oxford-street, London. The lightweight hope, which may play an important part in the solution of Britain's housing problem, was designed by the Aircraft Industries Research Organisation on Housing, and built by the Bristol Aeroplane Company, of Weston-super-Mare, Somerset, and is called the Airch House. Electrical fittings are installed when the sections are constructed, being plugged in to the mains after assembly. Which can be completed in four hours. Production of the Airch House in aircraft factories ensures continuity of employment for skilled workers in aluminium, hitherto employed on making parts for aeroplanes, besides meeting a national demand for homes to replace those destroyed in the war.

PHOTO HOUSING.- Lowering the third section of the aluminium house into position on the bombed site. ANDREWS PLANET May 31 1945 21
Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/50045

FOUR-SECTION PREFABRI CATED ALUMINIUM HOUSE ON VIEW TO LONDONERS

An Aluminum House, factory-made in four sections, has been put up
on a bombed site outside Selfridge's, the departmental store in
Oxford-street, London. The lightweight home, which may play an
important part in the solution of Britain's housing problem, was
designed by the Aircraft Industries Research Organisation on Housing,
and built by the Bristol Aeroplane Company, of Weston-super-Mare,
Somerset, and is called the Airoh House. Electrical fittings are
installed when the sections are constructed, being plugged in to the
mains after assembly, which can be completed in four hours. Production
of the Airoh House in aircraft factories ensures continuity of
employment for skilled workers in aluminium, hitherto employed on
making parts for aeroplanes, besides meeting a national demand for homes
to replace those destroyed in the war.
PHOTO SHOWS:- Lowering the third section of the aluminium house into
position on the bombed site. Andrews Planet May 31 1945 PN

title: Photograph: Discs Helped to Make the '90's Gay
description:
Daily Herald photograph entitled 'Discs Helped to Make the '90's Gay'. The photograph shows Mr. A. W. Ord-Hume with a selection of music boxes displayed at the Londoner Hotel during a conference of the Musical Box Society of Great Britain. The instruments pictured are, from left to right; Symphonion (1897) with 11 3/8" disc, Regina (1898) with 27" disc and a Regina (1894) with 15 1/2" disc. Dated May 9th 1964.

Photograph from the Daily Herald Archive, indexed as Music, Instruments, Ancient, Musical Boxes.

May 9th 1984 PAR 109905-1 (M-R)

DISCS HELPED TO MAKE THE '80s GAY

If modern teenagers think they invented the record boom, here's evidence that even great-grandfather may have had his hip-hopparty.

Mr. C.W. ODD-HUME is pictured at the
Londoner Hotel, Welbeck Street, W., to-day
(Saturday) with discs from the 1890s, and
musical boxes they were played on.
The instruments are: (left to right)
a Symphonion (1892 (27Ã‚Â½in. disc);
a Regina (1898 (16Ã‚Â½-inch discs); and
a 1894 Regina (13Ã‚Â½in. discs).
The musical boxes were on display
at the conference of the Musical Box Society
of Great Britain, whose members were able
to view a selection of instruments dating
from 1990 to 1910, all in working order.
The Society, which has a membership of
nearly 200, exists to raise funds to repair
and maintain musical boxes in museums and
collections throughout Britain and to keep
alive interest in this form of mechanical
reproduction of music.

1983-5236/31649

DISCS HELPED TO MAKE THE '90s GAY
May 9th 1964 PAR 109905-1 (M-R)
-------------------------------------
DISCS HELPED TO MAKE THE '90s GAY

If modern teenagers think they invented
the record boom, here's evidence that even
great-grandfather may have had his
Top Twenty.
Mr. A.W. ORD-HUME is pictured at the
Londoner Hotel, Welbeck Street, W., to-day
(Saturday) with discs from the 1890s, and
musical boxes they were played on.
The instruments are, left to right:
A Symphonion of 1897 (11 7/8 in. disc);
a Regina of 1898 (27-inch disc); and
an 1894 Regina (15 1/2 in. disc).
The musical boxes were on display
at the conference of the Musical Box Society
of Great Britain, whose members were able
to view a selection of instruments dating
from 1790 to 1912, all in working order.
The Society, which has a membership of
nearly 100, exists to raise funds to repair
and maintain musical boxes in museums and
collections throughout Britain and to keep
alive interest in this form of mechanical
reproduction of music.
May 9th 1964 PAR 109905-1 (M-R)

CHARCOAL BURNING SERVE THE MODERN WORLD
MARCH 21st 1956 PAR BBSES-3 (R-h)
CHARCOAL BURNING SERVE THE MODERN WORLD
Equipment of the kind used for centuries
is still employed by the charcoal burners
of the New Forest, Hampshire, as they
carry on their traditional trade under
the jurisdiction of the Forestry Commission.
Though the techniques of making charcoal
is old, there are new markets for the
product in modern Industry.
Charcoal is used in the production of
drugs, chemicals (including nylons),
steel, fabrics and other commodities.
PICTURE SHOWS:- Selling TIP: 1/7,
descendant of a long line of charcoal
burners, with a stack of charcoal
fresh from the kiln in King's Hat Wood,
near Beaulieu, Hampshire.
Though charcoal dust invades
hair, teeth and throat and lies thick
on the face, Mr. Tant never suffers
from respiratory or digestive troubles.
The life of a charcoal burner is
reputed to be healthy - and long.
MARCH 21st 1956 PAR SESGS-3 (R-h)
FOR FIRST PUBLICATION IN EVENING
PAPERS OF THURSDAY, MARCH 22nd.
India C.K.

H.M.G.
BIRMINGHAM GUILDS & SCHOOL OF APPLIED ARTS.
WORK has been done in connexion by the Birmingham
Guilds of Craftsmen as works in English handicrafts in
the county and on a variety of subjects. The members have travelled
from all over the world with reference furniture, objects,
decoration, ironwork and jewellery. In addition, many of the
members are experts in painting, while a few undertake repairs
or still undertake, wood carving or etc. H.P. Perkins of
Whitburn, have toured, among others the old Guilds, works
from locally grown wood for carving and other. Mr.
Foster in Hexham & Mr. Green from the Newcastle have
articles of locally grown wood and the British Council have
selected some of his furniture for exhibition in America and
Canada. Everything used to fix up is locally procured
even to the making of the wood for the men in from local wood.

Please excuse, Mr. F.P., I am unable to make use of his
artists' articles made from local wood.
25. 19th February, 1946. GORDON.

DUPLICATE
BIRMINGHAM
MANCHESTER
Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/55487

MAINTAINING ENGLISH CRAFTSMANS IIP .
E.M./MAE.

Much has been done in recent years by the Gloucestershire
Guild of Craftsmen to revive old English handicrafts in
the County and as a result, many of the members have achieved
fame all over the world with handm de furniture, pottery,
basketwork, ironwork and fabric.  In wartime, many of the
members are engaged on war work, but a few areable to carry
on with their crafts.  Among these is Mr. F.F. Foster, of
Whiteway, near Stroud, whose furniture and articles made by
hand from locally grown wood have become well known.  Mr.
Foster is finding a big demand for his handmade and carved
articles of locally grown walnut and the British Council have
selected some of his furniture for exhibition in America and
Canada.  Everything used in his work is locally produced
even to the waxing of the wood for the wax is from local bees.

Photo shows:-  Mr. F.F. Foster at work on some of his
artistic articles made from local walnut.  269846.
FOX.  13th February, 1942.

DUPLICATE SENT
13 FEB1942 ON.
MANCHESTER.

STEPHENS. CARDIFF. 31/3/54.
FLOUR MILL RE-OPENED.
When the flour mill on the banks of the
Teifi at Cenarth was closed at the start
of the war, most people thought that its
days were ended.
But now that wheat has been de-controlled
the mill has been overhauled and is once
more producing whole-meal flour for making
into bread that is in great demand in
the local bakehouses.
OPS. Mr. Gwyn Bloom, who was the miller
before the war, and who works there
occasionally now, watches the wholemeal
flour pouring once again from the stones.

DAILY HERALD
8 APR 1954
STEPHENS

Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/19882

28.2.64.
DEAR FRIENDS ..... IN RESPONSE TO YOUR LETTER ........

     PETRA, the mongrel dog in the picture, has a large
problem on his paws, for the day that he signed some
stupid human contract to appear on B.B.C. Television's
"Blue Peter" children's programme, he naturally assumed
that the B.B.C. would provide him with a nice shapely
poodle as a secretary. Anyhow, up to now, when he hasn't
been rehearsing and learning his part, he has managed to
cope with his fan mail and keep it down O.K., but now,
some human announcer has told the children that they can
write in for a photograph of him - and what do you think?
He has received no less than 60,000 applications - and
still no secretary - so poor PETRA is just having to sit
down and write all the replies himself. Incidentally,
with the usual human incompetence, the B.B.C. had only
printed 10,000 photographs, so PETRA supposes that he
will have to print some more himself.

PHOTO SHOWS.
            PETRA sits down and starts to reply to his
mountain of fan mail.
KT          KEYSTONE             JP/766586.

SHE'S DOING FINE

Mary Higgins, who had
been missing from her
home in Woolwich, London,
since Tuesday, last week,
has been found. The girl, who
lived with her mother, Mrs.
Elizabeth Higgins, was last
seen when she went to buy
sweets. Her mother said,
"We thought she had been
drowned." The girl was found
at a hotel in London. She is
doing fine.

By "PEOPLE" REPORTER

Through the help given with the
appeal from the PEOPLE, Mrs.
Elizabeth Higgins, of Wool-
wich, London, whose seven-
year-old daughter went missing
from their home last week, has
been found. The girl, who was
last seen when she went to buy
sweets. Her mother said, "We
thought she had been drowned."
The girl was found at a hotel
in London. She is doing fine.
Transcribed_Text:
A SOBBING mother
with a mission tried to
jump aboard a depart-
ing trawler yesterday.
She failed . . . but won
a final victory.
Mrs. Lilian Bilocca
struggled with police in
the snow at Hull as she
shouted to the crew of the
trawler St. Kevern:
"Don't go without a radio
operator, lads! Don't go . . .
don't go!"
The St. Kevern sailed
SHE'S DOING FINE
Princess Margaret, who had
her tonsils out in a London
hospital on Friday, is "progress-
ing well," her doctors said
By "PEOPLE" REPORTER
through the lock gates into the
River Humber. Then it circled
—and stopped.
A dramatic radio message
was flashed ashore . . . "The
crew will not sail without a
radio operator."
And Mrs. Bilocca, mother of
a trawler deckhand, woman
with anger on her lips, had as
good as won the first stage of
her fight to improve safety
conditions for the men of the
little ships.
For the St. Kevern sailed
later—with a radioman aboard.
Mrs. Bilocca plans to try to
stop trawlers sailing in an effort
to make the owners of two
missing ships discuss safety.
Her idea was put to a bitter
protest meeting of trawlermen's
wives shortly before they went
on a march to the dockside on
THE PEOPLE
MAR 31 1968

DAIRY CUP GOES TO A WOMAN WINNER

One of the rare occasions for people to see the fair sex with eight of their horses ploughing, naturally beauty with ploughing. Success last Saturday, October 19th, was that annual County Championship ploughing match held at the Plough, Epping, Essex. The four horse turnout was won by Mrs. J. Dixon for best ploughing and best turnout, another 1st prize winner was Mrs. F. Dixon, the owner of the best turnout, another 1st prize winner was Mrs. F. Dixon, the owner of eight horses ploughing.

SOUTH ESSEX. The winners of the prize for the best turnout were the twenty-one-year-old twins, Miss C. and Miss D. Cooper, who have been in the army and were released in order to train their eight horses. Miss C. Cooper has now gone into farming and also won two other prizes at the event, Miss D. Cooper won the ploughing and best turnout. Mrs. A. Smith, who trained the horses, and her husband, Mr. R. Smith, and their children Mark, John and Peter also attended to support the twins.
Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/45808

GRAND OLD SIGHT FROM A BYGONE AGE.         KT/RS.

One of the rare chances for people to see the fine
old sight of Shire horses ploughing, combining beauty
with strength, occured last Saturday, October 10th when
the 16th Annual Sussex Championship Ploughing Match was
held at The Broads, HELLINGLY, Sussex. The four shires
that won the two prizes for best ploughing and best turnout,
working in pairs, all come from Cherry Tree Farm animal
sanctuary at LINGFIELD, Surrey, where they are living in
retirement.

PHOTO SHOWS.
               The winners of the prize for the best turnout
were the twenty-year-olds CAPTAIN and DUKE who worked on
a farm at Hereford before their retirement to Cherry Tree
Farm. Their ploughman was MR.G.EVANS of the East Grinstead
and Three Counties Branch of the Sussex Ploughing Association.

Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/57028

RELIC OF THE "RODNEY"
IN THE GRAVEYARD OF SHIPS               DC/PR

To few sailors falls the privilage of seeing
both the first days and the last of      their
ships. Chief Petty Officer pensioner ROBERT G.
ELLIS (58) can , however make this boast. A
member of the staff of Britain's biggest ship-
breakers (Thomas Ward, Inverkeithing,Scotland)
Mr. Ellis joined H.M.S. Rodney when she was first
commissioned at Devonport and is now standing by
her as she is broken up . In his 34 years 19
days in the Royal Navy Mr. Ellis served in
two world wars . He fought at Jutland and has
memories of Admiral Cunningham-then a Lieutenant,
now C.in C. Rosyth. In this recent war, Mr.
Ellis was a Landing Craft Instructor to Commandos.

PHOTO SHOWS: With overalls and cap replacing his
naval uniform, Mr. ELLIS, now crane maintenance
man, holds up the nameplate of the battleship
Rodney, a relic he hopes to keep as a souvenir.
Pall of smoke in background is from burning oil
sludge removed to facilitate cutting operations
on the battleship's hull.

A PROMINENT TASK.
NOV/8.11.
196 feet above the City of Worcester, stonemasons
are now at work restoring the weathered stone work
on the pinnacles and tower of Worcester Cathedral
(the Cathedral Church of Christ and the Blessed
Virgin Mary). Progress is at is being made for this
work and upon completion of work on the South Side
of the Tower, which is now in progress, the men
still have restoration work to do on the East Side,
which they expect to complete within two or three
years. The North and West sides have already been
restored. The contract for the restoration of all
Worcester Cathedral stone work is in the hands of a
small local firm "Don Davis".

PHOTOGRAPH SHOWS: High above the streets of Worcester,
stonemasons R. MILLINGTON (top) and W. A. TIERN (below)
are seen at work on the restoring of the weathered
stonework on the pinnacles and tower on the "South Side"
of Worcester Cathedral. Worcester stone is being used
for this work.
FOX PHOTOS AUGUST 18th. 1953.

Lee. Ludwig- Gos

is almost dry-just a little water in the middle
of masses of mud.

that hotel as captain of the barges for almost 50
years and his son Bob Rodes, aged 65, another ex-barge
skipper, discovered that coal fell out of the barges
into the canal.

FISHING FOR COAL IN THE LEEDS-LIVERPOOL CANAL.
The Leeds-Liverpool canal at Chorley, Lancs,
is almost dry-just a little water in the middle
of masses of mud.
Seventy-three-years-old Jimmy Blundell, who sailed
that canal as captain of the barge for almost 50
years and his pal Bob Davis, aged 66, another ex-barge
skipper, remembered that coal fell out of the barges
into the canal.
So Jimmy and Bob made a metal dredge. It pulls up
broken bottles and stones but coal too.
The two ex-captains are working their way along the
canal and average two bags of coal every afternoon.

Transcribed_Text:
DAILY HER
30 DEC 1960
MRS. D. ANDERSON
"A car, holidays"

WIVES go out to work first and foremost because they want the money.
But they do not usually need it for basic necessities. Nor do they spend it as "pin-money" on themselves.
They want it so that their families can have a higher standard of living than is possible on one wage alone. And if a conflict arises between the claims of their jobs and the interests of their families, they put their families first.
This new evidence on the con-troversial subject of working wives and mothers is put for-ward today in a report published by the Department of Scientific and Industrial Research.
It is based on a study of mar-ried women workers, sponsored by the DSIR, and carried out by social scientists from the London School of Economics under Professor R. M. Titmuss, at the Peek Frean biscuit factory in Bermondsey, London.
At this factory, three-quarters of the 4,000 workers are women—most of them married, more than half of them with children. Few work the full 10-hour day. Most are part-timers on shifts of 4, 5 or 6½ hours.

NOT AN ESCAPE
The investigators found that for most wives "work was un-dertaken as a means of helping the family, not as an escape from it."
Two pay-packets in the family mean that more can be spent on refurnishing the home, on more varied food, on pocket-money and toys for the children, on a small, second-hand car or on a proper family holiday.
Though many wives said they would miss the social contacts if they did not work, their first loyalty was always to their families.
The biscuit factory—abandon-

By JOYCE CHESTERTON
ing its pre-war bar against married women because of the labour shortage — has done much to make it easier for wives to work.
The 9.30 a.m.-4 p.m. shift, for instance, consists mainly of mothers with school-age chil-dren. They can leave home and get back at the same time as their families.
Mothers with under-fives work mostly in the evening, when husbands are at home to take over and put the children to bed.
Without considerable help from husbands, in fact, most of the wives would find it very hard to cope with both job and home.

TERRY FINCHER
WORKING HOUSEWIVES REPORT. (See story

biscuit factory.

BAIDIAN (ILLUS) 28.6.43.
A FORTRESS THAT DID NOT RETURN.1943-5236/91009
OPS.1. The flying Fortresses are leaving on another
daylight bombing mission to Germany. As the big
planes vault off the runway a ground crew watches
its ship leave. "There she goes!"...The bombers swim
slowly around the airdrome like trout in a pool until
the last plane is airborne. They form a loose battle
formation. The men on the ground count them one-by-
one as they cruise off. At the rendezvous point
there is another giant ring-around-the-rosy as group
after group of Fortresses arrive from East Anglian
airdromes to complete the great armada. Now the
Fortresses close in tight together so that no fighter
dare break through between the wingtips. In each
B17 there are ten men. These ten men, multiplied by
hundreds of great machines, and thousands of fifty
calibre guns, are moving in close-packed battle
formation into the sub-stratosphere over Europe.
The ground crew men will wait for their ship and their
ten combat men.

TEEN-AGE GIRLS WILL TAME THE WOLVES.
Two 17-year-old hostesses at Whipsnade Children's
Zoo have been given the job of taming two three-
month-old wolf cubs. It is the first time Whipsnade
has tried to tame wolves. The hostesses, Adrienne
Wheeler xxx (dark) and blonde Joyce Shury, have
to cuddle and pet them so that in time they will
be tame enough for visiting children to handle.
A Zoo official said "They are still very wild. We
hope they will respond to affection from the girls."
To catch the cubs, which were running wild in an
enclosure with a pack of Canadian wolves, keepers
had to make a surprise raid by van and grab the
two cubs. But, it is feared that when they
show their teeth, the girls may be a little shy
of them.

COMMONWEALTH OF AUSTRALIA
ROYAL MINT MELBOURNE BRANCH
SEIGNIORAGE.

The Royal Mint Melbourne Branch charges
no seigniorage on Australian
coinage. 1957. Two-and-a-half
million pounds worth of silver coin,
representing 50 per cent of Australia's
holdings of silver, stored at the
dollar will be withdrawn from U.S.A.
holdings in the next two years.
This represents just under half the
total pieces of silver, for the next
twenty and thirty years or fifty
million pounds worth of Commonwealth
silver will also be withdrawn from
the States.

The reason for the holding of this
huge amount of silver is that after a
large public outcry the Australian
Parliament passed a law prohibiting
the melting down of silver coin.
Australia, during the Commonwealth
Conference of 1936, in London,
pledged to a glittering display
of silver, but after London no
actual steps were taken toward
this end.

THE ROYAL MINT IN LONDON IS BUSY MINTING
DECIMAL COINSFOR NEW ZEALAND.
  ON JULY 10, 1967, NEW ZEALAND WILL CHANGE
FROM ITS PRESENT POUNDS, SHILLINGS AND PENCE
SYSTEM OF CURRENCY TO A DECIMAL SYSTEM IN
WHICH THE NEW ZEALAND DOLLAR, VALUED AT 10
SHILLINGS N.Z. WILL BE THE MAIN UNIT. THE
DOLLAR WILL BE DIVIDED INTO 100 CENTS, EACH
WORTH 1.2 PENCE.
  SIX COINS ARE BEING MINTED, THE ONE AND TWO
CENT PIECES OF BRONZE, AND THE FIVE, TEN,
TWENTY AND FIFTY CENT PIECES OF CUPRO-NICKEL.
IN ADDITION ABOUT HALF A MILLION COMMEMORATIVE
DOLLAR COINS, ALSO OF CUPRO-NICKEL,        ARE
BEING STRUCK.
  THE DESIGNS FOR THE REVERSE OF THE COINS
WERE DECIDED BY THE GOVERNMENT AFTER A LONG
PUBLIC CONTROVERSY OVER THE SELECTION FROM
A WIDE VARIETY OF DESIGNS. ALL SIX OF THE
MAIN COINS WERE DESIGNED BY A NEW ZEALAND
ARTIST, MR. JAMES BERRY, OF WELLINGTON. THE
DESIGN OF THE REVERSE OF THE COMMEMORATIVE
DOLLAR WAS PREPARED BY MR. WILLIAM GARDNER,
A.R.C.A., F.S.I.A. OF WITTERSHAM, KENT. THE
OBVERSE OF ALL SEVEN COINS CARRIES THE NEW
EFFIGY OF THE QUEEN BY MR. ARNOLD MACHIN,
R.A. OF LONDON, AND APPROVED BY HER MAJESTY
IN 1964.

LUMBERJACKS OF BRITAIN'S WEST
July 5th 1955 PAR 50364-2 (BKS-R)
------------------------------------------------
LUMBERJACKS OF BRITAIN'S WEST

Buzz of power saws, the roar of the
bulldozer and the ring of the big axe
echo through the shaded depths of
the Quantock Forest, which clothes
the hillsides to the west of Bridgwater,
Somerset.
For the forest, covering 2,750 acres,
supplies most of the pit props for the
Somerset coalfield, and also sends them
to the Forest of Dean and South Wales.
Ninety per cent of the timber produced
is used for this purpose.
Fifteen or more six-ton loads, with
500 props in a load, leave in a week.
Each prop costs two or three shillings.
Seedlings are planted to replace the
trees cut down.
The Quantock Forest, one of the
Forestry Commission's oldest stretches
of woodland, is worth £150 to £200
an acre. Its income target for the
coming year is £150,000.
PICTURE SHOWS:- Pit-props being cut
to length on a mobile electric
circular saw by Quantock Forest workers.

FOR FIRST PUBLICATION FRIDAY'S EVENINGS, Jan 31st.,
SHADOW FACTORY WILL AID WORLD FOOD PRODUCTION
31.1.47.
A considerable contribution towards the solution of the world
food shortage is being brought about by a revolutionary
agricultural machine, the Fergusson Tractor, which is now being
produced in large numbers at the former wartime shadow factory
of Standard Motors at Banner Lane, COVENTRY. Full scale pro-
duction of 500 daily will mean employment of 10,000 men and
women. The tractor is of lightweight specially treated alloy
steels, designed to pull great loads with ease, and has finger-
tip hydraulic depth control, etc. Half the present output is
now being exported to the eastern hemisphere, and this will
increase as large-scale production commences. The picture
shows completed Fergusson tractors filling the bays at the
Banner Lane Factory of Standard Motors.

LAUNCHING OF THE "REGENT LIVERPOOL" PC/

A new oil tanker, "Regent Liverpool", was
launched today, Thursday, at the Belfast Ship-
yard of Harland and Wolff by Mrs. Charles C.
Oom, wife of the managing director of Regent
Oil Company Limited. With a dead weight of
47,600 tons, and an overall length of 745 feet,
"Regent Liverpool" is the biggest tanker ever
built in Belfast. She is powered by Harland
and Wolff geared turbines developing 16,500
s.h.p. at a service speed of 16 knots. "Regent
Liverpool" is the 218th vessel in the Regent/
Texaco/Caltex Group fleet which links a world
wide network of more than 80 ocean terminals.
The tanker will also serve the new refinery
that Regent plans to build at Milford Haven.

PHOTOGRAPHS SHOW:- Crowds of the men who
have worked on the tanker "REGENT LIVERPOOL"
watch her glide away down the slipway at the
launching today, Thursday.
FOR PHOTOS 5TH. APRIL, 1962.

LAUNCHING OF THE "REGENT LIVERPOOL"   PC/

    A new oil tanker, "Regent Liverpool", was
launched today, Thursday, at the Belfast Ship-
yard of Harland and Wolff by Mrs. Charles C.
Dunn, wife of the managing director of Regent
Oil Company Limited.  With a dead weight of
47,600 tons, and an overall length of 746 feet,
"Regent Liverpool" is the biggest tanker ever
built in Belfast.  She is powered by Harland
and Wolff geared turbines developing 16,500
s.h.p. at a service speed of 16 knots. "Regent
Liverpool" is the 218th vessel in the Regent/
Texaco/Caltex Group fleet which links a world
wide network of more than 80 ocean terminals.
The tanker will also serve the new refinery
that Regent plans to build at Milford Haven.

ROYAL ARMY PAY CORPS.
O.P.S. Log exercises. Men toss log from one team to the
other. Log weighs 180 pounds. They also lie flat on
backs and throwing throw log as though it were a
matchstick, although men say "in my private opinion it
weighs 260 lbs."

SAIDMAN (ILLUS.) 12.5.42.
ROYAL ARMY PAY CORPS.
O.P.S. 1. Cadets get the barrack room atmosphere and
discipline at the O.C.T.U. of the R.A.P.C. Cadets have
occupied this room in hotel over a year. Note good
condition. On mantlepiece is bottle of gargle which is
part of equipment of every room. There is also running
water. In picture are Cadets Wade, Thomson and Taylor.
Wade is Lance Cpl from Pay Office at Leicester. In
civilian life was cost accountant. Had some O.T.C.
training at school. He likes football. Thomson is S1
and comes from Gallaenshield. He is a banker employed
with the Royal Bank of Scotland. Golf and rugger
are his games. Taylor was an accountant in civilian
life; has a damaged leg.

16 MAY 1946 REC'D
16 MAY 1946
1983-5236 / 16402

FOR FIRST PUBLICATION THURSDAY'S EVENINGS 16.5.46.
THE "FIVE TOWNS" ARE BOOM TOWNS.
16.5.46.
From all over the world orders are poring into the
five towns of the Staffordshire pottery industry,
Hanley, Burslem, Stoke-on-Trent, Fenton and Longton,
and despite the difficulties of conversion from war
time work the potteries are today turning out some
of the finest pottery-ware of the world. Much of this
is hand-made and hand-painted in delicate colours
such as the housewife of present-day Britain has never
seen as it is all going for export. She still has to
make do with the drab utility stuff. This is one of
a series of pictures taken at the factory of Messrs Copelands
of Stoke, makers of the world famous "Spode" china and
earthenware every piece of which is handmade. The picture
shows
a view in the warehouse where the finished products
are awaiting sortment before packing and despatch overseas.

THE YEAR'S CHRISTMAS FESTIVAL.

10/12/54

First concert of the 1954 London Festival Christmas Concerts Festival. As rising star ruby ballet at the Central Hall, Westminster. I started order of over 10,000 children from now to the end of it will to all parts of London are seeing part in this festival. I think a series of six concerts, on December 15th, 17th, 19th, 22nd, 24th, and 27th. The first last evening's ballet at the Central Hall and the last was at the Royal Festival Hall.

PROGRAMME NOTES. The young choristers were taking part in the first concert of the 1954 London Festival - Christmas Carol "Rabbit) at the Central Hall, Westminster this morning. They are (from the left): John Smith (aged 11), David Smith (aged 10), Ian Black (aged 12), Michael Morrell (aged 11), David Morris (aged 11), Nicholas Morris (aged 10), Peter Morris (aged 9). One of them is standing on a stool to reach the organ. The concerts are all conducted by Dr. Leo G. Russell.

Fp. London, Christmas Carols.
Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/19983

12

LONDON SCHOOLS' CHRISTMAS FESTIVAL BEGINS. MJH/HA.

The first concert of the 1955 London Schools' Christmas Carol
Festival, is taking place today at the Central Hall, Westminster.
A massed choir of some 16,000 children from more than 550 schools
in all parts of London are taking part in this Festival, which
comprises a series of six concerts, on December 6th, 7th.
8th, 9th, 12th, and 13th., the first two being held at
the Central Hall and the last four at the Royal Festival Hall.

PHOTOGRAPH SHOWS: Six young choristers seen taking part
in the first concert of the London Schools' Christmas Carol
Festival at the Central Hall, Westminster this morning.
They are (back row left to right): CHARLES PAGE (11) from
Burdett Coutts School; BABLU MUKHERJI of Colville School,
Kensington(11); PAMELA DUNCAN, COLVILLE School, (10);
Front row: MARY JANE MILNER (10) of Highgate; OWEN MASON (10)
Westbourne Park: ANN RUMALRES (11) of Eltham.
The concerts are all conducted by Dr. Leslie Russell, the L.C.C's
Senior Inspector of Music.
FOX PHOTOS DECEMBER 6TH. 1955.

CHRISTMAS. . . It was mentioned yesterday in Sydenham children's hospital, Kent. Two-year-old John Cheesman heard. "Ooh, Christmas," he cried. "I'll help." Now he is happily entangled in a paper chain. The inspiring thought also floated into Central Hall, Westminster. A choir of 16,000 children from more than 550 London schools was giving the first concert of the 1955 London Schools' Carol Festival. To see the thought's effect, study these choristers' faces.

NIXON D.M. 28.6.45
MR. BARNETT JANNER, LABOUR CANDIDATE FOR WEST
Leicester.
O.P.S. Mr. Barnett Janner talking to Mrs. M.Ellmore.
Mrs Barwick and Mrs. Duddle in the communal yard
of their cottages, 14 Ruding Street.
Some of the cottages in the block have only two
rooms, one room upstairs, and one room downstairs,
and the rents of these vary from 5/6d to 8/2d
per week, although they are practically the same
size.

There is no water supply in the houses at all.
There is one tap in the yard for the use of 5
houses, and one lavatory outside for three houses.
Just across the road is a similar block of houses
where 10 families live under similar conditions.
Mr. Barnett Janner is the Honorary Rent Adviser
to the Labour Party. He deals with numerous
questions arising under the Rent Restrictions
Act throughout the length and breadth of the country
for the Labour Party. He is giving the housing
problem and the Rent Restriction Problem a very
important place in his campaign.

H.R.H.
The Guards Depot, Caterham, today. H.R.H. The Duke of
Kent(who presented leeks to the Welsh Guards, in accordance
with the traditional St. David's Day custom) was inspecting keen
young Welsh recruits with Lt. Gen. Sir Oliver Leese, the Colonel of the

first official visit to Caterham, and his first visit to be shown Colonel of the
Welsh Guards. It is also the 11th. anniversary of the Regiment,
founded 1915.

HERALD

By PAUL HOPKINS

ALL black and white poster showing the Queen in her now-famous miner's suit and safety helmet has been published without Palace permission.

And yesterday the British Safety Council, which has made the poster, said the Duke of Edinburgh had stopped it using a similar picture of himself in a miner's helmet.

The Duke told the council last December that it was "rather inappropriate that a member of the Royal Family should be used in this manner."

The new poster of the Queen in the clothes she wore when she went down a mine in Scotland last week has the slogan: "Follow Her Majesty's Example. Wear Safety Clothing."

When the International Hotel and Catering Exhibition
opens at Olympia, London, tomorrow, two striking scale
models in icing sugar will be on view, the culmination
of months of work by the staff of the RAF School of
Catering, Hereford. The premier exhibit is a model of
St. Clement Danes Church, official Church of the RAF in
the Strand, London, which measures 2ft. 6ins. long, 18ins.
high and has a 3ft. high tower. To symbolise the RAF's
link with the City of Hereford, is a scale model of the
Old House, a black and white timbered museum which stands
in the City centre. Both models are in true colours and
were prepared from architects' plans.

PHOTOGRAPH SHOWS: The model of St. Clement Danes
Church of the Royal Air Force, in edible icing sugar,
is touched up by two members of the RAF School of
Catering, as it is positioned at Olympia, where it will
remain for the Exhibition's duration on January 28th.

HE IS TO WEAVE PRINCESS ELIZABETH'S WEDDING TRAIN..
WORKING ON THE HAND-LOOM AT BRAINTREE...
4-10-47

Preparations are going ahead for
the wedding of Princess Elizabeth and Lieut. Philip
Mountbatten. MR. RONALD LAMB of Braintree, Essex
is the man who will have the honour of weaving-
on the hand loom, the material for the bride's
beautiful wedding dress. The silk is woven on a
hand loom - a very highly skilled craft which
takes many many years to learn, It is one of
those arts which has been handed down from father
to son for generations. Mr. Lamb has worked at
this craft for 14 years and spent six years with
the R.A.F..

KEYSTONE PHOTO SHOWS:- MR. RONALD LAMB seen working
on the hand loom on which he will weave the
beautiful silk for the train of the Royal Wedding
Gown, at Messrs Warners, Braintree... Essex..

Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/57125

CLYDESIDE BUSY ON THE "CORONIA"
14.5.47.

A masive hulk of rivet-studded rust-
stained steel is creeping up to the blitzed-
scarred roof tops of bustling Clydebank.
Alongside the John Brown's cradle which fostered
her big sisters, Queen Mary and Queen Elizabeth,
a new Cunarder is being born. The "CORONIA",
largest ship being built at present in the world,
is only 32,000 tons. But several hundred men
are determined that when she leaves the Clyde
this "little" liner will be no ordinary "baby"!
Already, four months before the scheduled launching,
her raw steel plates from bow to stern present
a streamlined grace which veterans say no other
ship possesses. When completed the new Cunarder
will have delicately coloured plastic instead of
hardwood planking on her decks. She will do the
6000 mile trip to the United States and back
without refuelling.

WEDGWOOD TEA SERVICE TO BE PRESENTED
TO THE QUEEN.
Expert workers at the famous factory of Passrs. Josiah
Wedgwood & Sons, Ltd. at Barlaston, near Stoke-on-Trent,
are now busily working on a bone china tea service,
for 12 people, which will be presented to H.M. The Queen,
when she visits the factory on November 2nd. The pattern
of the tea service is one known as "Appledore", designed
in the Wedgwood Studios in 1956, which is now in current
production and available to housewives all over the
country. It will be decorated with a laurel border, enamelled
in turquoise on an ivory band and an early-Victorian
centre design will take the form of a fruit basket,
hand enamelled. Her Majesty has requested that tea
service should contain some specially large cups.

PHOTOGRAPH SHOWS. MR. LILY SAVAGE, who has been at
Wedgwoods for 25 years and rrives at Stoke-on-Trent, been
furnishing a cake plate, similar to those in the Royal
tea service.
FOHOTODATE OCTOBER 17TH. 1955.

Indus Pottery.

1983-5236 / 16413 F195 / DI Industry potteries - making only (Post nov)

WEDGWOOD TEA SERVICE TO BE PRESENTED
TO THE QUEEN. MJH/HT.

Expert workers at the famous factory of Messrs. Josiah
Wedgwood & Sons, Ltd. at Barlaston, near Stoke-on-Trent,
are now busily working on a bone china tea service,
for 12 people, which will be presented to H.M. The Queen,
when she visits the factory on November 2nd. The pattern
of the tea service is one known as "Appledore", designed
in the Wedgwood Studios in 1936, which is now in current
production and available to housewives all over the
country. It will be decorated with a laurel border, enamelled
in turquoise on an ivory band and an early-Victorian
centre design will take the form of a fruit basket, also
hand enamelled. Her Majesty has requested that her tea
service should contain some specially large cups.

PHOTOGRAPH SHOWS: MRS. LILY SAVAGE, who has been at
Wedgwoods for 25 years and lives at Stoke-on-Trent, seen
burnishing a cake plate, similar to those in the Royal
tea service.

They’re shining up partizans
and axes

GLITTERING swords . . . shining partizans and axes . . . they’ll all play their part in the grand pageantry of the Coronation next year.
And at the Acton, Middlesex, factory of the famous sword makers, Wilkinsons, 1,000 swords are being made for Guardsmen, Cavalrymen, Lord Lieutenants of Counties, diplomats, statesmen and officers of the three services.
Hundreds of other swords, handed down for generations, are being repaired and repolished.
Mrs. Mary Fry (in the picture below) is seen giving the final polish to some of the completed swords. In another small room, Charlie Webb, 39-year-old embosser, works on thep artizans—the broad spear-heads carried on tasseled poles by Yeomen of the Guard and Yeomen Wardens of the Tower.
He is cleaning off the late King’s arms and cypher and re-etching them with those of Queen Elizabeth. He is also regilding the axes carried by the Gentlemen at Arms.
★
SIX Prime Ministers will attend a meeting of the Coronation Commission at St. James’s Palace on Friday. The Duke of Edinburgh will preside.
In addition to Mr. Churchill they are the Prime Ministers of Canada, Australia, New Zealand, Pakistan, and Ceylon, who were all appointed members of the Commission when it was set up in April.
Friday’s meeting probably will discuss the part the Commonwealth forces will play at the Coronation and also the question of television.
It is likely to be the only meeting that the Prime Ministers can attend, although their High Commissioners are also members of the Commission.
★
WORKMEN yesterday moved into Westminster Abbey to begin preparing it for the Coronation. The nave and west door are now closed to the public.
The public will be allowed in for services up to and including Christmas, but the whole Abbey will be closed from January 1.
Five days after the Coronation the public will be able to visit the Abbey to see the Coronation trappings.

28 JUL 1937
DAILY HERALD
NEWS DEPT.
BARGE FULL OF EELS
TO HOLD FLOATING EELS.
36/83

The home of 100,000 live eels, a barge full of
eels, has been built in Essex. The barge will
be moored at Heybridge Basin, Malden. The barge
named the "Johan" is believed to be the first of its
kind to be built in this country. The owner is
Mr. N.D. Ruijten, an importer of live eels.
The centre part of the barge is perforated
so that water can flow in freely. Watertight
compartments support the craft fore and aft, with
the deck no more than 10 inches above water
level. Fifty tons of eels will live in the

BARGE FULL OF HOLES
IS EELS FLOATING HOME
DG/FM

The home of 1000000 live eels, a barge full of
holes has been built in Essex. The barge will
be moored at Heybridge Basin, Malden, The barge
named the "Johan" is believed to be the first of its
kind to be built in this country. Its owner is
Mr. H. G. Kuijten, an importer of live eels.
The centre part of the barge is perforated
so that water can flow in freely. Watertight
compartments support the craft fore and aft, with
the deck no more than 18 inches above water
level. Fifty tons of eels will live in the
perforated hold.

PHOTO SHOWS:- A general view of the specially
built eel barge at Heybridge Basin, Malden, Essex.
Eels come from between Norway and Corsica, are graded
and despatched to Billingsgate as required.

reopened last year.

of Eatonville Rd., Upper Tooting, S.W.17, for

out through the ordinary channels of distribution,
and was served by the shop manager, Mr. WILLIAM
PICKLES.
A case of 360 eggs meant for the recipient
of this wooden, has been sent to Great Ormonde
Street Hospital (London), and Mrs. BOWIE, will
receive a token from the Polish Commercial Attache,
on Monday.

116

TRUNING GOLD INTO BOOKS.

In spite of thousands of years of scientific research
a machine has not yet been invented to beat gold, with
the delicate manipulation which is essential to success,
and so the job is performed by hand in much the same way
as it was in the days of Queen Victoria, carying only
in the fact that the bronze hammers used by the ancients
has been replaced by a steel one today, and thst now
machinery forms a small part of the early stages in the
work.
O. .S.  Making the gold into a ribbon. The bar of gold
hardened in a mould is rolled into a ribbon by
being passed repeatedly between highly burnished
steel rollers with an ever increasing pressure.
This is the only 'mechanised' part of the process
for the rest of the work is done by hand.

output - gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20:
The following is a report on the present condition of the U.S. Navy's
Sea Water Distillation Program.

The Multi-Stage Flash Distillation (MSF) program,
which is being built at the Brooklyn Navy Yard and for
the Newport Naval Base, is progressing according to schedule.
The Newport installation will have a capacity
equivalent to launching thirty million gallons per day.
The Brooklyn Navy Yard will have a total capacity of
sixty million gallons per day. The MSF units are
expected to go into operation in October, 1968.

The MSF units will be capable of distilling
salt water by using the heat generated from nuclear
reactors. The purpose of this program is to make the
U.S. Navy less dependent on shore-based facilities
for fresh water. The units will also be able to produce
up to ten thousand gallons of distilled water per day,
which can be used for drinking, cooking, and other
household purposes. The U.S. Navy is committed to the
successful completion of this program.
Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/51274
SELF-ELEVATING DRILLING RIG FOR NORTH
SEA LAUNCHED AT CLYDEBANK
CNS H 11 78 9. 11. 65.
THE SELF-ELEVATING DRILLING RIG " CONSTELLATION", THE
SECOND TO BE BUILT AT CLYDEBANK BY JOHN BROWN AND CO.,
WAS LAUNCHED TODAY. THE "CONSTELLATION" WILL JOIN THE
NORTH SEA SEARCH FOR OIL AND NATURAL GAS, AND IS
EXPECTED TO COMMENCE DRILLING OPERATIONS IN JANUARY,
1966. THE RIG HAS ACCOMMODATION FOR FIFTY-TWO MEN,
ARRANGED IN TWO AND FOUR BERTH CABINS. IT WILL
NORMALLY BE SERVICED BY TWO SUPPLY VESSELS. CREWS WILL
BE FLOWN OUT BY HELICOPTER.
THE RIG IS FITTED WITH FOUR LEGS 387 FEET LONG,
WHICH WILL GIVE HER A MAXIMUM OPERATING DEPTH OF 275 FT.
OF WATER. SHE IS DESIGNED TO WITHSTAND THE SEVEREST
NORTH SEA WEATHER CONDITIONS. THE RIG WILL BE TOWED BY
OCEAN-GOING TUGS TO THE NORTH SEA DRILLING SITE, AND WILL
THEN LOWER THE FOUR LEGS TO THE SEA BED. EQUIPPED WITH
THE LATEST TYPE OF DRILLING MACHINERY, THE RIG WILL BE
ABLE TO DRILL DOWN TO 20,000 FEET BENEATH THE SEA.
PHOTO SHOWS: WORKERS WATCH AS A TUG FUSSES AROUND THE
"CONSTELLATION" AFTER THE LAUNCHING TODAY.

UNTIL they joined the Land Army, Joan Tester, who is driving the tractor, and Esme Coker, who is seen with her, knew nothing about land work. Joan, who comes from East Finchley, was a shop assistant, and Esme was a housemaid at Henley-on-Thames. Now they are working a robot-like hedge cutter, complete with circular saw, as though they had been on the land all their lives. Until they became Land Girls they had no idea that modern farming was so mechanised. These girls are now working on a Buckinghamshire farm.

ELLEN, 18, WALKS TO THE AID OF SCIENCE
September 20th 1928 PAX 51798-1 (B68-8)

ELLEN, 18, WALKS TO THE AID OF SCIENCE.

miles after miles, day after day.
18-year-old ELLEN TOFIELD walks about
her cuties in a shoe factory at
Street, Somerset.
She is employed by the firm
I.C. and J. Clark, Ltd., as an
inter-departmental post girl, collecting
and delivering mail in the various
sections of the factory.
But strapped to Ellen's waist - she is
seen wearing it in the picture -
is a pedometer which measures the
distance she walks each day.
At the end of the day's work, she
records the mileage - usually eight
or nine miles - in a log book. When
she has covered a prescribed number
of miles, her shoes (made in the
factory) are taken over by the firm's
research workers. The experts derive
valuable information from the condition
of the shoes and the rate of wear.
September 20th 1928 PAX 51798-1 (B68-8)
FOR FIRST PUBLICATION IN EVENING
PAPERS OF WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 21st.

records the mileage - usually eight
or nine miles - in a log book.  When
she has covered a prescribed number

research workers.  The experts derive
valuable information from the condition
of the shoes and the rate of wear.

NEW FLATS MAKE HOUSEWORK A PLEASURE.
A new block of luxury flats at Aspen Gardens,
Hammersmith is to be opened by Mr A. Bevan, Minister
of Health. It is Hammersmith Labour borough council's
first post-war big-scale housing scheme.
Mr Bevan will see how housewives can do their washing
without effort in the shilling in the slot washing and
drying machines.
Sun balconies, tiled kitchens with plenty of cupboards,
electric fires and built in wardrobes, are some of the
luxury fittings.
There are passenger and goods lifts, immersion heaters
in each flat to provide constant hot water. And the
babies have their own pram garage.
The rents of the flats range from 15/11d to 36/8d per
week.

Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/42672
Indus- Fuel & Power- Coal--Accidents- Cambrian Colliery, Rhonda,
May 1965
AN explosion tore through a colliery yesterday and blasted 31 men to pieces. Last night, as the Rhondda Valley lay silent and numbed with shock, the cause of the disaster was still a mystery.
Weeping wives and mothers stood at the pit-head of Cambrian Colliery in Clydach Vale, Glamorgan, as the remains of their men were brought out of the black hell 800ft. below.
It was lunchtime when the blast hit the mechanised plough face of the colliery’s No. 1 Pit.
The miners working there had no chance. Men 500 yards away were knocked off their feet and injured.
The doomed men were in a slender tunnel only 2ft. 8in. high.
A grey-faced, shaken rescue worker said: “The sight down there was terrible.
“Some men were decapitated, others without arms and legs. Their clothing was ripped to shreds.”
Among the dead were colliery manager Ernest Breeze and under-manager Les Williams.
IN HOSPITAL
17 MAY 1965

HU' HOUSING SITE AT SASWOOD VILLAGE. WY/KS

North of the A.40 trunk road between High Wycombe & "N.T." Wycombe and west of Pinner Hill, on a site covering 6 acres of rolling hills overlooking the National Trust property of East Wycombe Park, a new housing site is going up on Sashwood Village. There will be 600 dwellings, with a shopping centre, playing fields and a village hall. The dwellings will consist of linked, detached and terraced houses with 3-4 bedrooms. There will also be one record Mini House and a variety of flats. The development is divided into four stages and is expected to take a further five years to complete.

Photo Show: The mini house at Dashwood Village, consists only of a kitchen, bathroom, and large living/bedroom, and is designed primarily for retired people. TV is wired into all houses. The kitchen has a waste disposal unit.

PREFABRICATED HOUSES

Latest prefabricated bungalow by
the Unity Building System is now
being lived in by Mr and Mrs L.
Sanders and their baby daughter
Shirley, who are seen on the veranda
of their new home in Crowthorne,
Berkshire. The bungalow is the
latest prefabricated type of house
with which Britain is supplied from
Overseas markets, and is a fine
example of how prefabrication has
been rationalised. The flexibility
of the prefabricated system allows
these unilinear backed houses to
be modified to suit the purchaser.
Doors and windows can be moved
and partitions placed to alter the
scope and design of the rooms. It is
claimed that the bungalow of this type
is equal in permanence to a brick or
stone built house. It can be erected
in a week.

A.J.Tanner.    D.H.    Oct 7th, 48.
EAST ANGLIAN HERRING SEASON OPENS.
An "Armada" of brightly-painted steam and motor herring
drifters have just begun to collect what promises to be
a "bumper" herring harvest off the coast of East Anglia.
The Scots contingent totals 350 boats, representing
more than two thirds of the whole fleet.
The Inverness boat "Fair Morn" was one of the first to
dock at Yarmouth with more than 50 cran on board which
sold at 22/3 per basket on the dockside.
The little ships are entering the Yarmouth Harbour at
the rate of one every 10 mins. In answer to Harbour
Masters call "How many mate" the answer was always be-
tween 45 and 60 cran. To deal with this huge haul,
hundreds of fishworkers have left Northeast Scotland
by special trains for the fish-wharves of Yarmouth.
The girls are now "gutting" and "kippering" the fish.
O.P.S. A general view shows a line of drifters unload-
ing their catches at the Yarmouth fish wharves.

WEDGWOOD TEA SERVICE TO BE PRESENTED
TO H.M. THE QUEEN.

Expert workers at the famous factory of Josiah Wedgwood
& Sons, Ltd. at Barlaston, near Stoke-on-Trent, are now
busily working on a new china tea service which will be
presented to H.M. the Queen when she visits the factory
on November 2nd. The pattern of the new tea service is
one known as "Appleblossom" designed in the Wedgwood style
in 1936, which is now in current production and available
to housewives all over the country. It will be decorated
with a laurel border, enamelled in turquoise on an ivory
band and an early-Victorian centre design will take the
form of a fruit basket, also hand-enamelled. Her Majesty
has requested that her tea service should contain some
specially large cups.

PHOTOGRAPH SHOWS: ALBERT SHINKLEY of Barlaston Park, who
has been with Wedgwoods for 30 years, seen turning one of
the fine bone china cups, for which new factory is famous.
PHOTO DATE: OCTOBER 17TH, 1955.

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE

3rd May, 1961.

FORD CARS TAKE TO THE RAILS

First new 'liner' Train to Scotland

A new British Railways service used exclusively to carry Ford
cars and commercial vehicles to Scotland began running this week.

This high speed 'express belt' service will comprise three
trains a week from Dagenham to the Ford Distribution centre at
Coatbridge in Scotland, and two trains from the Ford Halewood plant
near Liverpool.

The first train, seen here, left Dagenham last night (Tuesday,
May 2) and arrived at mid-day today. Each train carries 65 to 70
cars which are then distributed throughout Scotland by road
transporter or delivery drivers.

The benefits of the new system are far reaching - it will
speed up deliveries, keep mileage to a minimum, substantially
reduce the rise of damage and ultimately reflect lower costs to
customers.

ISSUED BY PUBLIC AFFAIRS STAFF, FORD OF BRITAIN.

Industry-Motor- Completed Cars, including Delivery.

First new 'Liner' Train to Scotland

A new British Railways service used exclusively to carry Ford
cars and commercial vehicles to Scotland began running this week.

This high speed 'conveyor belt' service will comprise three
trains a week from Dagenham to the Ford distribution centre at
Bathgate in Scotland, and two trains from the Ford Halewood plant
near Liverpool.

The first train, seen here, left Dagenham last night (Monday,
May 4) and arrived at mid-day today. Each train carries 65 to 70
cars which are then distributed throughout Scotland by road
transporter or delivery drivers.

The benefits of the new system are far reaching - it will
speed up deliveries, keep mileage to a minimum, substantially

By PETER HOPKIRK

irm of cut-price estate agents claim
e selling four times as many houses
ls.
who opened three months ago, undercut
charges. And they have developed a new
lling their houses.
sending out details of dozens of homes to
yers, the firm—Trident Home Centre, of
dlesex—invite clients to their "gallery"
graphs of 200 houses are displayed around
the walls.
In this way interested
buyers do not waste hours
visiting houses they might
turn down immediately on
sight.
Mr. Peter Halliday, aged 30,
one of the firm's partners, told
me yesterday: "Our fees for
selling a house are exactly half
what other estate agents charge.
For example, we charge only
£68 10s. on a £5,000 house.
Other agents would charge £137.
"We are able to charge less
because of our greater turnover.
We have sold about 70 houses
since we opened.
"Most estate agents of similar
size to ourselves are lucky at
the moment if they sell six
houses a month. Yet, despite
the present slow-up, we are
selling at the rate of six a week.
"It is because they sell so few
that the others have to charge
twice what we ask in fees.
Mr. Halliday, who once worked
for an estate agent for a short
time to gain experience added:
"Eventually we hope to link up
with other firms using similar
streamlined methods and charg-
ing our scale of fees in other
parts of the country.

the war. There are now 136 members of the British Breeders
Non-Group of the Fur Trade Export Group, and a few years
ago there were 15. A family living in Hertfordshire, where
the largest mink farm in England is run, keep two hundred vegas
holding the male and female animals, fed daily by the daughter
who is to have place shortly. Mr Bernard Nieve who runs his own

April 1951 for his daughter Bency, who is 20, and his son
David, age 17, also helps.

FAMILY MINK FARM AT TOTTERIDGE GREEN. EH/RS

Mink-breeding has developed dramatically in Britain since
the war. There are now 136 members of the British Breeders
Sub-Group of the Fur Trade Export Group, and a few years
ago there were 15. A family living in Hertfordshire, where
the largest minv farm in England is run, some two hundred cages
holding the male and female animals, fed daily by the daughter
and cared for by the son and manager. They are preparing some
two hundred pelts for the large auction at Beaver House which
is to tave place shortly. Mr Bernard Hicks who runs this minv
farm at Strathearn Nursery and Fur Farm at his home at
Totteridge Green, North Finohley, started the fur farm in
April 1951 for his daughter Nancy, who is 20, and his son
David, age 17, also helps.

Photograph shows :- Mr Bernard Hicks and his daughter Nancy
seen hanging out pelts to dry after the animals have been
villed. Some two hundred of these little minv animals have
been villed this veev, and the pelts will realise four to
eight pounds per svin.

HELP-YOURSELF SHOE-REPAIRERS                              D/HT

Appreciating that footwear repair costs are becoming
altogether too high for many people, Jim Clennell (60)
and Fred Smith (40) who run a repair shop at Seven Kings,
Essex, have begun a new service. They have installed
five lasts and sets of tools and invite customers to come
and do their own mending. They estimate what the full
cost of the job would be, and charge 2d in the shilling
for use of the equipment. They sell the customer the
leather at wholesale price and the result is that the job
costs one third less. Jim and Fred give their advice
free and charge 6d extra for professional finishing if
required. They remain open until 9 pm, and are planning
a special ladies night, since so many women do their
repairs at home.

PHOTO SHOWS: Jim Clennell supervises Miss Audrey Newham
as she trims the leather round the sole of her show which
she is mending herself.

/ FOR FIRST PUBLICATION WEDNESDAY'S EVEN INGS, August 20th.

HA VESTING ON THE SUSSEX PRAIRIES"
20.8.47.

The present crisis has brought about the biggest Government drive
for a great increase in the production of home-grown food, and
the Prime Minister has called for a £100,000,000 step-up in this
direction by 1950-51. Since the War Office handed back to the
East Sussex War Agricultural Committee, many acres of land
formerly used for Artillery Training purposes, a thousand acres
of corn have been grown and are now in process of being harvested.
In this picture, one of the biggest single "Fields" in the
country, stretching for more than 200 acres over the rolling
Sussex Downs, is being harvested of its corn. The binders are
starting on the work which will be taken over by the combine
harvesters, at a later stage.

Transcribed_Text:
1983-5286 / 65032

CALCRAFT     Illus.                    20.1.43
ORANGES AND LEMONS GROWN IN ENGLAND.
When Oranges and Lemons were sold at Maidenhead
to aid the local War Prisoners Parcels' Fund
everyone was asking "where did they come from?".
78-year-old Alfred Bayley knew the answer.  He
grew them!    In his greenhouse at Burnham Buck's,
even now he has some still growing.
Formerly a diamond miner in South Africa and friend
of Wells who found the Cullinan diamond, they
both worked at the Premier Mine in the Transvaal.
Bayley had the orange trees sent from South Africa
23 years ago;  each year he grafts a bud to another
plant in order to form a further plant.  Now he has
over twenty miniature orange and lemon plants.
The original plant cost 2/3, including the freight
charges from South Africa.  Bayley thinks more of
his oranges and lemons that he does of the world's
largest diamond.  He can afford to smile!!!
      O.P.S.  Alfred Bayley with his orange and
      lemon plants in his greenhouse.

pipes ever placed in Britain has just been secured by

Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/55806

DURHAM PRODUCES DOLLAR-SAVING PIPELINE D/ TAN

One of the biggest contracts for large diameter steel
pipes ever placed in Britain has just been secured by
South Durham Steel and Iron Company, an old established
Teeside firm. The order, from the Basrah Petroleum Co.
(an associate of the Iraq Petroleum Company) is for the
manufacture of 80 miles of 24-inch pipe, weighing 17,000
tons, to be laid next year from the Zubair oilfields in
Southern Iraq to the port of Fao on the Persian Gulf,
near Basrah. In addition to opening new and increasing
markets for the British steel industry, the £900,000
order will mean a saving of some 2 1/2 million dollars, as
hitherto most large diameter oil piping has been obtained
from the United States.

PHOTO SHOWS: Some of the 80 miles of 24-inch piping is
seen stacked at the South Durham Steel and Iron Company's
works ready for shipment to Basrah.

"Orient Cricket Camps for the New Villa

Drawing to a close is the first cricket season on the island. For seventy-six-year-old Mr. Wallis, chairman of the National Cricket Association, it has been a rewarding one. The veteran umpire, who has been making cricket bats for the past sixty years, says that the demand for his handcrafted cricket bats is really just starting. The 120-acre estate, which is owned by the United Dominions Trust, is being converted into a holiday resort for the Australian cricket team, who are here on a tour of the island. The villa, the centrepiece of the estate, is a magnificently preserved Georgian mansion, and is said to be the largest privately owned house in Britain. The estate will also feature a golf course, a swimming pool and a tennis court. The cricket ground itself is also being renovated, and a new pavilion is being built. The resort is expected to open its doors to the public in the spring of next year."
Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/57686

XM)          CRICKET SEASON KEEPS OPEN FOR MRS WILLOW

Drawing to a close of the Cricket Season means no
respite for 64year-old Mrs.Nellie Cochrane of Lewes,
Sussex, for her the season of manufacturing Cricket
bats is really just starting. Turning out 3 dozen
bats a week, Mrs. Cochrane with the help of her husband,
William, claims to be the only woman making Cricket bats
in the country. For 35 years the Cochrane s have been
making Cricket bats, 75% of their production going to
Australia, Pakistan, New Zealand and the Tonga Island.
Some of the machinery has been hand made by Mr. Cochrane
which he has trained his wife to use.

position.

1983-5236/42271

BRITAIN' S BIGGEST LAND PLANE.

The BRISTOL TYPE 167 low wing cantilever monoplane, 
sometimes unofficially referred to as the BRABAZON I, 
is the biggest land plane yet to be built by the 
British aircraft industry and is now taking shape in the 
Bristol Aeroplane Company's factory at Filton, Bristol. 
Estimated to cost £4,000,000 the 167 is being 
built solely for flight development work and is expected 
to fly in the early summer of 1947. 
The aircraft with an all up weight of 285,000 lbs, 
- approximately 126 tons - will have a maximum level 
speed of more than 300 m.p.h. at 25,000 feet, a cruising 
speed of 250 m.p.h., at 25,000 feet, and a still air 
range of 5,000 miles.

THE BRISTOL TYPE 167 LW-WING CANTILEVER MONOPLANE - 
SOMETIMES UNOFFICIALLY REFERRED TO AS THE BRABAZON I.

Picture shows:- Connecting the high tension wires to 
sparking plugs on a Centaurus 20 in process of 
assembly. Eight of these 18 cylinder piston engines 
will be used to power the first prototype. About 
2800 lbs dry weight.

CONTINENTAL SPECIALITIES OF HOLLOWAY.
Continental specialities such as macaroni, noodles, ravioli
and spaghetti are produced at the factory of Messrs. J. Tym, Ltd.
in Seven Sisters Road, Holloway. Keen rivalry exists between
the foodstuffs of Britain and the pasta-makers of Italy and whilst
corn and more pasta from Italy is arriving every day in this country,
there is stiff competition from the home market as the British
manufacturers make great efforts to boost the home products.
One person who definitely prefers the new produced goods is 7-
years-old Lian Yau (daughter of the director of the Holloway
factory) who she likes nothing better than a plate of freshly made
spaghetti at the factory.

29-2-60.

NEW TECHNIQUE SPEEDS UP RECONSTRUCTION OPERATION AT LONDON HOTEL..

For the first time, 111 new bed- bathroom suites are being built into a big London Hotel (Strand Palace) by stop-watch techniques - which are reducing building times from seven months to 96 days - and saving up to one third of the costs... During the operation - the hotel business carries on - unaffected.. Every key-man on the job - carried a miniature radio in his waistcoat pocket - whereby he is in constant call from the control centre - by means of which there is no delay for materials - assistance etc.. all operations can be dovetailed - and every man is continually occupied - and can be switched from one point to another - with minimum delay..

KEYSTONE PHOTO SHOWS:- MR. SIDNEY WILLIAMS, foreman Carpente answers the house telephone - after receiving a call on his pocket radio (seen in his breast pocket) as a paperhanger is busy in one of the hotel room.

luxury dwellings, and the families are unable to afford
the high rents there. 14 of the families have received
alternative accomodation, but the remaining 25 will be
forced to return to 'Halfway House' community centres,
where up to 14 families share the limited facilities of

has taken advantage of their work into the morning or afternoon.

Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236 / 53974

Tudor

LIFE AT THE BLUECOAT SCHOOL.
...........................

Christ's Hospital, or "Blue Coat School", was founded by
Edward VI on the site of an old Greyfriars Monastery, and down
to a few years ago was one of London's best known scholastic
institutions. It was pulled down to make room for extensions
of St. Bartholomews Hospital and the new General Post Office,
in Newgate Street. The School is now carried on at HORSHAM
in an imposing building. Besides the usual subjects included in
any school curriculum, the boys are taught interesting things,
such as clay modelling, carpentry, weaving, spinning etc., and
have taken advantage of their move into the country by acquiring
a farm, the work on which is done by the boys. The school has
a band complete with mace bearer and this is a familiar sight
once a year in London when the school marches through the City to
their annual church service. The boys still wear the picturesque
costume of knee breeches, yellow stockings...

O.P.S. A Bluecoat boy learning weaving on a hand loom at
       the school.            HD/B. KEYSTONE.

output - gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20:
THE GULCH AND THE GARDEN

Mr. J.V. Kelly, of Oxley, Widnes, has built a house single-handed. It has taken him two and a half years. Every bit of the work he has done himself from glazing the fanlights to putting on the tiles. Three years ago he knew nothing about building, but after studying local art to work. He has introduced several novel ideas, including window and door frames of concrete. He intends to sell the house.

He has also built a garden wall, which has taken him a great deal of time. He says he is hoping to sell it to a collector who will appreciate his work. The wall itself is made of local stone, and it has been carved with intricate designs. He says he hopes that the buyer will also appreciate the history and craftsmanship that has gone into the wall.

It is remarkable that this self-taught artist has managed to produce such beautiful and unique work. His dedication and passion for his craft are truly inspiring.
Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/44668

AW/FM

THE HOUSE THAT ONE MAN BUILT.

Mr. J.W. Kelly, of Cowley, Middlesex, has built a house single
handed. It has taken him two and a half years. Every bit of the
work he has done himself from digging the foundations to
putting on the tiles. Three years ago he knew nothing about
building, but after studying books set to work. He has introduced
several novel ideas including window and door frames of concrete.
He intends to sell the house.

SHOWS --
FOX JULY 11th. 30. ... finishing touches to his house.

RO.H. 4.7.40. 1983-3236/B9B16
EMBRASURES FOR SANDBAGGED BUILT BLOCKHOUSES.
The weak feature in all rapidly constructed blockhouses
is the wooden framing used to form the opening. The
opening does not protect the rifleman because the rim
can be penetrated by a bullet, also the splintered wood
carried away by the bullet can produce nasty wounds.
The present suggestion is to pre-cast the embrasure
opening of the desired aperture and angle, the outer
extremity having a light sheet steel framing embedded
in the face to prevent the concrete edges shattered by
a bullet from being detached and forming missiles.
The embrasure weighs less than 1 1/2 cwt. and can easily
be lifted into place by two men. Manufacture can be made
in quite simple wooden moulds by any local building
contractor, breeze block manufacturer, in Corporation
yards, and so on; using the quick setting concrete
and be produced ready for installation within 24 hours.
