MUSICAL BLANKET TO ARRIVE NEW YORK BY UNION LINE.
Possibly the largest order for shirt goods ever placed
by a shipping company has been given to Bedford Fibre by
the Cunard-White Star Company in partnership with the Uni-
on Line, Cunard's first, Bedford being a all-round exhibitor for
his linen and cotton goods. The firm intends to ship 50,000
shirt, blouse and socks, i.e. men's, ladies' and children's, at the
end of November or sooner. These will be the cheapest. As a
tie-in regular with Cunard line and the Union Line, all these shirt
and blouse have been branded.
(This photo is ready. Orders complete lists for frame by submittals.)
With 25,000 shirt and blouses ready for shipping, it is ex-
pected they will be shipped on the 10th October. For the
other 25,000, it's expected to be shipped on the 12th November.

3/8/35
C. N.

Transcribed_Text:
1988-5286 / 53460

BELFAST.
CH/Lo
BELFAST MAKES THE LINEN FOR THE " QUEEN MARY ".

Possibly the largest order for linen goods ever placed
by a shipping company has been given to Belfast firms by
the Cunard-White Star Company in connection with the outfit
of the Queen Mary; Belfast being solely responsible for all
the linen and union goods. The list includes 31,000 pillow
slips, 30,000 sheets, 21,000 table cloths 210,000 towels
and thousands of dusters, linen bags and napkins. To ensure
that fresh supplies will always be available triplicate
stocks have been ordered.

Photo shows- Girls examining linen for flaws by transmitted
light at Richardson Sons and Owden, Belfast, who secured part
of the contract.

THE PUBLISHING AND "NEW HOUSES". STRUCTURE OF PLASTICS (BLOCK BUILDING METHOD).

M.L.A. O.L.

London: The L.C.C. is nearing action to be completed this week, officially handing over to the fourteen thousand inhabitants of Council flats, by the Leader of the Council, Sir I.J. Gaman, J.P.

The eight blocks of flats built on the plastics system. The new flats, ranging from one to five rooms each, cost about Ã‚Â£15,000,000. The 1,300 flats, when completed, will be 14,000.

Each flat has its own front door leading to a balcony and a number of flats share a common stairwell opening on to private balconies.

Provision is made for internal open door.

Plans to take the fullest advantage of light and air and equipped with fitting attachments and easily operated and with cells occupied with specially designed wallpaper.

Thirteen room blocks. Several flats of two or three rooms each.

The eight blocks of flats.

Public relations.
Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/44960
3 0 APR 1948 REC'D
THIS PRINT IS THE PROPERTY OF THE
"DAILY HERALD" ART LIBRARY
AND MUST BE RETURNED UNCHANGED.
261 FAMILIES GET "SUN" HOMES -
OPENING OF MINERVA STREET HOUSING ESTATE.
29. 4. 48.
London's first big housing scheme to be completed
was officially opened today in the Minerva-street
area of Bethnal Green by The Leader of the Council,
Mr. I.J. Hayward, J.P.
It consists of eight blocks of flats built on the
Monolith system. The 261 flats, ranging from one
to five rooms each, and with accomodation for
1,400 people, were completed in 14 months.
Each flat has its own front door opening on to
balconies and a number of flats also have french
windows opening on to private sun balconies.
Playrooms are provided for children under five,
planned to take the fullest advantage of light and
air and equipped with fitted blackboards and play
apparatus and with walls decorated with specially
designed wallpaper.
KEYSTONE PHOTO SHOWS:- General view of one of
the eight blocks of flats.
JW/KEYSTONE.532291.
AN. E.O.A

Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/55803

DURHAM PRODUCES DOLLAR-SAVING PIPELINE          D/ TAN

One of the biggest contracts for large diameter steel
pipes ever placed in Britain has just been secured by
South Durham Steel and Iron Company, an old established
Teeside firm.  The order, from the Basrah Petroleum Co.
(an associate of the Iraq Petroleum Company) is for the
manufacture of 80 miles of 24-inch pipe, weighing 17,000
tons, to be laid next year from the Zubair oilfields in
Southern Iraq to the port of Fao on the Persian Gulf,
near Basrah.  In addition to opening new and increasing
markets for the British steel industry, the £900,000
order will mean a saving of some 2 1/2 million dollars, as
hitherto most large diameter oil piping has been obtained
from the United States.

PHOTO SHOWS: A view of 24-inch pipes being stacked by
overhead crane ready for shipment to Basrah from the
South Durham Steel and Iron Company's works.

output - gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20:
AFT (ILLUS.)
"TIME BABIES".
15.6.43
1941-512/445-A
Ash Southgate British Legion during their
"tion Week" organised a baby show. Classes ranged
m birth to 3 years. This covers all babies born
ring World War 2.
One wonders which Minister they have to thank for
ne hefty bonny lads and lasses that were entered,
olton or Hudson.
Competition was keen for the many prizes but a
feature was the fact that each and every competitor
received a present in the form of a 'soft' toy.
Fathers on leave from the services were seen
nursing their offspring during the judging. Most
appeared as proficient at mothercraft as the ladies
themselves.
The number of twins entered caused comment, no
less than six pairs were among the contestants.
So fit and healthy were these that individually they
also took prizes.
Rain showers stopped the proceedings on occasions,
ut the least perturbed were the babies, gurgling in
ompetition with the downpour.

AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH LABORATORY.
The Agricultural Research Council Radio-biological
Laboratories, near L'antage, Berkshire, is the organisation
that carries out regular tests on milk collected from
milk sampling sites and depots in Great Britain, that
determine the amount of iodine 131 content. The fear
that the quantity of radio active content in milk may
rise because of the recent Russian Nuclear tests is,
officially over, and it has been announced in the House
of Lord's by the Minister of Defence, Lord Hailsham, that
milk throughout the country is free from a dangerous
level of iodine 131 and is safe for young children.

PHOTOGRAPH SHOWS:- Milk being curdled by a special
treatment. The iodine goes into "solid" cheese or
protein.

The Agricultural Research Council Radio-biological
Laboratories, near Wantage, Berkshire, is the organisation
that carries out regular tests on milk collected from
milk sampling zones and depots in Great Britain, that
determine the amount of iodine 131 content. The fear
that the quantity of radio active content in milk may
rise because of the recent Russian Nuclear tests is
officially over, and it has been announced in the House
of Lord's by the Minister of Science, Lord Hailsham, that
milk throughout the country is free from a dangerous
level of iodine 131 and is safe for young children.

AUSTRALIA BUYS BOATS.

George Sims, who makes boats for the Oxford and Cambridge
University crews at his Richmond Road boat-house, maintains
that wooden boats need to make a roaring eight-boat race with
Galway, Perth, Australia. The boat is built of Honduras

presented to the Gallery by S.R. Bale, of Cairo. It will
be used in Australian Heads-of-the-River and inter-college
races. It the export boats are being made for export only,

AUSTRALIA BUYS BRITISH.

George Sims, who makes boats for the Oxford and Cambridge
boat-race crews at his Hammersmith boat-house, considered
it an honour when asked to make a racing eight for Scotch
College, Perth, Australia. The boat is built of Honduras
Cedar, with English Oak ribs. It is 61 ft. long, 3/8" short

races. At the moment boats are being made for export only,

title: The flag of the United States of America on the moon
description: Gelatin silver print of the flag of the United States of America on the moon, a NASA photograph from the Daily Herald archive, 29 July 1969. It shows the American flag, surrounded by footprints in the dust on the moon surface. The shadow of the Apollo 11's Lunar Module 'Eagle' can be clearly seen across the picture.

Transcribed_Text:
E179/D7
SCIENCE - ROCKETS & INTERPLANETARY - APOLLO 11.
1983-5236-11216
FOOTPRINTS ON THE MOON
SUN USED 31 JUL 1969
MOON
THEY stand out sharply. Like some weird footprints in the snow on a holiday beach — the footprints of the First Men on the Moon. In the centre, the American flag "flutters" in the airless atmosphere, with the help of a wire device attached to its golden standard.
And the shadow of the moonbug Eagle, which took astronauts Neil Armstrong and Edwin Aldrin on man's most historic journey casts its shadow across the surface at Tranquillity Base.
The picture, taken from Eagle, is one of hundreds brought back by the astronauts and one of four released last night after being "cleared" in an elaborate decontamination process at the Houston Lunar Receiving Laboratory where Armstrong, Aldrin and Michael Collins are living in isolation.
The astronauts sat up until midnight to see the pictures—and colour film released to world television last night—at a special preview on Monday. Their verdict: spectacular.
July 29

output - gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20:
24.10.52.
THREE MEN TRAPPED AND SUFFOCATED EQUATOR.
Three men were trapped in a coupled unit of steel sway, from a 60-foot hoist of scaffolding, Colacogavich, Victoria, yesterday, when the men were being used by workmen building the new Geelong harbour. 
Bomber station, 
Melbourne, Victoria, 
Australia.

The men who were working at the base of the steel sway, had gone into the unit to carry out repairs, when the base gave way.

The men who were trapped were John Anderson, 26, Robert Henderson, 24, and Barry Jones, 22.

The men were unable to escape from the unit as it tipped and fell to the ground. The unit then rolled down a steep embankment, trapping the men inside.

The men were freed by rescue workers from the local fire brigade and ambulance service. They were taken to Colacogavich General Hospital, where they are being treated for their injuries.

None of the men's injuries are thought to be life-threatening.
Transcribed_Text:
24.10.56.

THREE MEN TRAPPED WHEN SCAFFOLDING COLLAPSES.

Three men were trapped in a tangled mass
of steel today, when a 50-foot tower of scaffolding
collapsed at Finsbury.    The scaffolding, which was
being used by workmen building the new 12-storey
Peabody Donation Buildings in Golden-lane, suddenly
collapsed.        As the scaffolding fell, workmen ran
for their lives.

          of the injured men away from the collapsed

"FORD MAGIC TRACTION D.F.V."

DURHAM, DEVIZES, WILTS. A remote
controlled tractor, capable of working
under conditions too hazardous for human
beings, was demonstrated here today.

In use on a farm near Devizes, Wilts., the tractor,
which is remotely controlled from a distance, is seen here
being used for ploughing operations at the rear of an open
field. It is the first of its kind to be produced by Ford,
and is a Ford 3000 with Ford-Goodyear "traction-master"
transmission. Fordson Products Ltd., in conjunction with S.B. Developments Ltd., and P.M.I. & Comden Ltd., have provided the driver
with a radio-controlled, multi-channel, simultaneous
controlled system, a human "switchboard operator," and the tractor.

This latest radio-controlled tractor would well be the shape of
things to come, both in industry and down on the
farm.

1965 Oct, 1965-08-08

The thought of jigsawing an old Victorian house into the shape of 1965 is enough to give many a modern architect the shudders. Yet the fact that such a conversion can be done with a minimum of space wastage is superbly illustrated by this house overlooking the Rugby football ground at Twickenham. This modernisation is one of the most impressive pieces of building surgery I've seen. It began when the owner, Mr. Smith, was faced with the need to take his parents in with the family. He and his wife had often complained about the shortcomings and inconveniences of living in a house planned and built in Queen Victoria's day. Now, with more room needed, they determined to alter and extend the house, at the same time wiping out all the irritating features inherited from the past Ã¢â‚¬â€œ narrow kitchen, shortage of power points, aged electric wiring, etc.

output - gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20:
AND while at the Central Library
the young actors, laughing
and talking, were making up for their
parts, in another part of Bermondsey
there was tragedy.
At the corner of Dockley-road and
Rouel-road, I came upon a house where
the upper windows had been boarded up.
A charred settee, a burnt and smashed
door, had been flung in the front garden.
Small groups of people were gathered
around, talking in low tones.

SOME of them told me the story of
tragedy and heroism which ex-
plained the scene.
Bill West, aged 81, a retired railway
porter, went downstairs early yesterday
morning to make a cup of tea for his
schoolteacher daughter. He had a
seizure, collapsed across a settee-that
charred settee. It was set afire by the
candle he was carrying.
Bill's daughter, trying to save him from
the blaze, was dragged away by neigh-
bours only just in time to prevent her
being badly burned.
And Bill himself died in the hospital.

title: A photographic print of Glass
description: A photographic print from the Daily Herald Archive folder: Glass.
output - gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20:
ON the stained glass windows of Mr. John Burdell's home at Alderman's Hill, Palmer's Green, N., there are 14 Devices. One is a Union Jack, another a Red Cross flag, a third a part of the arms on the reverse side of a silver coin.

The rest, Mr. Burdell thinks, are sections from towns' arms.

THE Devices were there two years ago when Mr. Burdell took the house; have been there, in fact, for 30 years. Well, about Coronation time the Middlesex County Council said: "What about paying the armorial bearings duty?"

Mr. Burdell refused to pay, and the Council twice hailed him before the court.

Once the case was dismissed under the Probation of Offenders Act; the second time he was fined.

Still he refused to pay, maintaining that his Devices were not, as the Bench said, armorial bearings.

SO now the Middlesex County Council has decided to press the County Councils' Association to ask for the abolition of the duty.

that his Devices were not, as the Bench

Councils' Association to ask for the
abolition of the duty.

The oldest sword maker in England
is Tom Beasley, aged 82, who has been
working with the same firm for 56 years.
He started in a forge at the age of 8
years. The craft of sword making has
been handed down in the Beasley family
from father to son for generations
for more than 250 years.
Tom Beasley has made swords for five
Sovereigns. In the last war he made
bayonets. During the years of peace
he returned to his swords. Now he has
gone back to bayonets - and commando
knives. His two daughters have joined
him in the business and are now busily
employed helping war production.
He has no sons to carry on the family
tradition.

SCHOOL FOR STOCKMEN (AND WOMEN). MUM/HT.

Arranged experimentally for the first time last year, a residential school for stockmen is being repeated at the Kent Farm Institute, Sittingbourne. This course is for working cowmen, shepherds and pigmen from all parts of Kent, who wish to bring themselves up to date in the technique of their work. Women employed on the care of stock can also enrol. The course is organised as a series of self-contained sections sections, dealing in turn with dairy cattle, pigs, sheep and beef cattle and each section covers management, feeding and prevention and control of diseases of stock.

PHOTOGRAPH SHOWS: Instructor MR. W.G. HONEY of Tonbridge seen lecturing on the use of an electric milking machine during the course for Stockmen at the Kent Farm Institute, Sittingbourne. Listening are (left to right) MISS MARGARET ANGUS of Eynsford; MRS. MARY WALKER and her husband MR. WALKER of Charing.

"SQUATTERS" HUT HOMES WRECKED.
EVICTED FAMILIES - "NOWHERE TO GO."

Chichester, Eng: "Squatters" sort out their
furniture and belongings after a demolition
squad had wrecked their Royal Air Force hut
homes at Crocker Hill here. Another gang of
workers was sent to demolish the huts after
some Chichester workmen given the job downed
tools and refused to wreck the two huts because
the families of squatters to be evicted had
nowhere to go.
At a Chichester Rural Council meeting it was
said, after one of its members had accused the
Council of disgraceful behaviour, that the people
had no right in the huts, and that they had been
given notice to move a number of times.    They
had been given ample time to make other
arrangements, and they had always been gipsies.

A WALL TO LANT.
UM/HE.
Oxfordshire County Council stone masons - John Williams and
S. Townsend are busy at present building a long length of
Cotswold dry wall, traditional to the district, skirting a
widened stretch of the A.40 London-Wales road between Witney
and Burford. A feature of the new wall is that the outer faces
are uncemented, but the centre is filled with concrete instead
of loose rubble, as is customary with these walls. The concrete
will prevent stones becoming dislodged and also enables the
wall to be built of less thickness than the completely "dry"
type. One advantage farmers get when they lose land for road
widening is often a new wall.

Photograph above:- The two stone masons John Williams and
S. Townsend busy filling the centre of the wall with concrete,
which will make a more lasting job than the old rubble filled
type, before carefully placing stones.

526991.

seas to export markets and to the windows of fashionable
London shops. Recently, the brickmakers discovered a
strong seam of clay. It proved suitable for making
pottery of high quality which they were able to fire in
the kiln alongside the bricks. An old outhouse of the
brickworks is being used by two potters, and a girl
models figures from the same clay. Using only their
skill, and without the aid of modern machinery, the
potters are producing works of individual stamp which
bear the hallmark of the English craftsman.

coffee jug at Bulmer. This is a difficult task which
takes twice as long as making the actual jug.

DOING A SPEECH ON STILTS
John Purser of Brighton can afford to smile. His
job is easier and less tiring. By wearing these stilts
he moves through the houses being built at Hemel, Garney,
by Vates Built Homes Limited. There are no awkward
corners for John - he can add up to two and a half feet
to his height. Of alloy and sprung for easy walking,
his stilts take the backache out of stretching. Step
ladders and planks are old hat.

John and his partner Ken Bettskamp were at first
mistaken for invalids by a bricklayer who saw their
stilts propped against a wall. "He thought they were
artificial limbs", said John.

Vates are the first company in Britain to use
stilts.

Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/44246

Mr
FAITH FULL

HERALD
1 FEB 1956
DAILY

Pl 1 col x 2 1/4

SUBST

ONE moment Mrs. Phyllis Faithfull, aged 32 (above), was emptying a dustpan in the scullery yesterday. The next moment she had vanished.
Where the scullery had been there was a crater 20ft. wide and 130ft. deep. Unknowingly, the scullery extension of the Royal Oak Hotel, Yattendon, Berks, had been built over an ancient well.
With bricks and masonry falling all round him, Fire Officer Leslie Evans was lowered by rope down the hole (arrowed).
Sixty feet of rope had been paid out when his muffled voice was heard: "I'm afraid there's no hope." He could go no farther; the well was blocked by the debris that had fallen.
As he spoke a burly, fair-haired man at the crater's edge sobbed and turned away. He was Percy Faithfull, husband of Phyllis. They lived in a cottage nearby with their 12-year-old daughter Betty.
At nightfall rescue work was halted.

1983-5236/40533

INDUS - AGRIC - MACHINERY - TRACTORS.

11. 12. 58.

THE "GEARLESS" TRACTOR DEMONSTRATED
IN LONDON.

A last-minute surprise addition to the interest of the
Smithfield show was a demonstration today of the
new experimental "gearless" tractor. Following the
great public interest in the radical new hydrostatic
drive for tractors at the show, Dowty Hydraulic Units
Ltd. decided to remove the security wraps and give
a demonstration of their experimental "gearless"
tractor in London today. The control is effected with just
one lever. Move it one way and you travel forward. The
            further you push the lever, the faster you
travel. Move the lever the other way; you slow, stop
(wheels locked), then move backwards. No gears to
clash - you can even change from full speed forward
to full speed reverse in one easy movement.

PHOTO SHOWS   MISS GILLIAN FLINT, a farm worker tries
               out the new "gearless" tractor during a
               demonstration in London today.

MAKING OARS FOR THE BOAT RACE.                                 MJH/RS.

Oars are made each year for the Inter-'Varsity Boat Race at the
Putney workshops of Messrs. E. Ayling and Sons, oar, scull
and paddle makers for clubs all over the world.  This family
business was established 99 years and oars for the Boat Race
has been made there for the past 89 years, a tradition carried
on by each succeeding generation of the family.  During their
training (from October to March), both Oxford and Cambridge
get through about two sets of oars (sometimes more) and receive
a final set about ten days before the date of the race.

PHOTOGRAPH SHOWS:  Inspecting completed oars before varnishing
are MR. PETER AYLING (31) fourth generation of the family , to carry
on this craft, and MR. WALTER COTAN (72) of Putney, who has had
25 years experience at varnishing and finishing oars, at the
Ayling workshops at Putney.

BROADCASTING FOR SPRING SOWING
BATTLE FOR THE HARVEST BEGINS IN BRITAIN.

With the first few sunny, warm days of spring machinery, farmers
all over Britain are ploughing and sowing with all speed to gain
the valuable time lost through floods and tempest throughout the
year. More than six weeks have been lost through severe
Winter weather, and the farmers and their labourers toil from
dawn till dusk in the great battle for the much-needed harvest
which is to follow their present efforts.
Seen on Sir Peter Grenfell's estate at Caterham, Surrey, the
ground, still heavy with moisture, would not be ready for sowing
by mechanical means for several days to come - but due is precious
and the sowing is being done by hand to spin valuable hours.........
PHOTO GREN.- Mr Alfred Creen, 63-years-old Farm labourer,
broadcasting barley seed by hand at WIllingdon Farm, Caterham, Surrey.
13th April, 1947. P.B.-6.

1983-5236/55428

FOR FIRST PUBLICATION FRIDAY'S EVENINGS 19.9.47.

Britain's carpet industry is to aim at an export target of 60%
as against 27%, in the new drive to close the gap between imports
and exports.
The accompanying photographs were taken at the Kidderminster
factories of Carpet Trades Limited, the extent of whose trade can be
judged by the fact that it has warehouses and agents in Australia,
New Zealand, USA, Canada, Canary, South America, Central America,
South Africa, Scandinavia, Holland, Switzerland, Egypt, Kenya, Uganda
Zanzibar, Belgian Congo, East Indies, Iceland and Malta.
The designers have to bear in mind the different types of design
which are popular in each country. For instance, the preference in
Australia and New Zealand is for floral patterns and very bright
colours, whilst at the other extreme the Scandinavian market calls
for subdued tones and more severe styles.
Carpet Trades Limited comprises five factories manufacturing
felts and woollen and worsted yarns as well as all types of machine-
made carpet. During the war they turned over to the production of
small-arms ammunition and other items apart from adapting their
textile plants to the manufacture of webbing, duck, blankets, felt
for rubber substitution, etc.
3,000 workpeople - as against 5,000 pre-war - are producing
thousands of yards of carpet alone per week. The picture shows:

20 SEP 1947

7/8 The carpets are joined together for the purpose
of passing as an endless stream through the large
brushing machine (seen in the background)

THIS PRINT IS THE PROPERTY OF THE
"DAILY HERALD" LIBRARY
MUST BE RETURNED
19 SEP 1947

A FROZEN FOOD firm un-
wrapped a scandal, nothing
less, when they started to open
a consignment of 349 frozen
Christmas turkeys. They
found, to their horror, that the
birds were about 15 months old
and that they had been par-
tially thawed then refrozen.

In one of the boxes there was no
turkey, but a shapeless yellow mass,
ominously labelled: Not for human
consumption.

The turkeys, which were to have
been packed with other produce into
Christmas hampers, have now been
written off.

Which leaves this question: How on
earth could they remain in circulation
all that time and then, clearly unsuit-
able for family Christmas dinners, be
put back on the market?

That's what I have been trying to
find out.

A FROZEN FOOD firm unwrapped a scandal, nothing less, when they started to open a consignment of 349 frozen Christmas turkeys. They found, to their horror, that the birds were about 15 months old and that they had been partially thawed then refrozen.
In one of the boxes there was no turkey, but a shapeless yellow mass, ominously labelled: Not for human consumption.
The turkeys, which were to have been packed with other produce into Christmas hampers, have now been written off.
Which leaves this question: How on earth could they remain in circulation all that time and then, clearly unsuitable for family Christmas dinners, be put back on the market?
That's what I have been trying to find out.

FROM CURRENT POTENTIAL. MINISTRY OF HOUSING & LOCAL GOVERNMENT.
Four prototype houses built for the SHEFFIELD City Council by the
Public Works Department under the UK system of construction devised
by the Research and Development Group of the Ministry of Housing
and Local Government. This system, which marks a new attempt to
bring the advantage of industrial-allocation into the field of house-
building, has been derived from the 54 CLASP system used at
Stevenage for a group of old people's flats. The new system
is called 56, because of Stevenage. It is based upon a planning
grid of 1' 8" (1 is the module of 4'). The object has been to
modify the CLASP system which has been shown to have advantages in
the reduction of site labour and building time, to suit the
performance standards, and the levels of cost, of 2-storey housing.

Ministry of Housing & local government. January, 1964.

SHEFFIELD
Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/44785

- 3 MAY 1963

CROWN COPYRIGHT RESERVED. MINISTRY OF HOUSING & LOCAL GOVERNMENT.
Four prototype houses built for the Sheffield City Council by the
Public Works Department under the 5M system of construction devised
by the Research and Development Group of the Ministry of Housing
and Local Government. This system, which marks a new attempt to
bring the advantages of industrialisation into the field of house-
building, has been derived from the 5M CLASP system used at
Stevenage for a group of old people's flatlets. The new system
is called 5M, because as at Stevenage, it is based upon a planning
grid of 1' 8" (5 x the module of 4"). The object has been to
modify the CLASP system, which has been shown to have advantages in
the reduction of site labour and building time, to suit the
performance standards, and the levels of cost, of 2-storey housing.

Ministry of Housing & Local Government. January, 1963

CITY
OF

DISPLAY OF NEW MODELS IN UTILITY FURNITURE RATING HIGH TO MEET
13,000 APPLICATIONS A DAY.

More than 13,000 applications a day for permits to buy utility
furniture are being received by the Board of Trade. While furniture
production has nearly quadrupled in the last year, supplies are still
insufficient to meet the increasing demand, and new designs are being
added to the existing range as well as two new ranges being
devised with a view to making the fullest possible use of the
country's productive capacity. An exhibition of some of the new
models has been opened at the Board of Trade building in London.

0.10.30.
MINISTRY OF SUPPLY SCIENTISTS AT WORK.
Compared with a group of 40 scientists engaged
in research and experimental work for the War Depart-
ment in 1914, the Ministry of Supply today, under
its Directorate of Scientific Research, has a
permanent staff of about 800. They include
specialists in practically every branch of applied
physics, chemistry and engineering. In addition to
this permanent staff, the Ministry of Supply has
mobilised specialised resources in industry, the
Universities and other laboratories throughout the
country.
Teams of scientists directed by leaders are engaged
in dealing with special problems affecting every
branch of munition and other supplies.
The Ministry of Supply's War Emergency Scheme
represents the most comprehensive mobilisation of
scientific and technical talent in the national
service that has ever been attempted.

P.A. - HOLSTEDERS.

REVIVAL OF WEAVING IN ESSEX TOWN.
OS/85
Thaxted, in Essex, has been known for its weaving industry since
the days of Queen Elizabeth but the number of weavers has
considerably decreased. There is now a revival of the industry
and the Thaxted weavers are flourishing again. All the work is

MINISTRY OF SUPPLY SCIENTISTS AT WORK.
Compared with a group of 40 scientists engaged in
research and experimental work for the War Department
in 1914, the Ministry of Supply today, under its
Directorate of Scientific Research, has a permanent
staff of about 800. They include specialists in
practically every branch of applied physics,
chemistry and engineering. In addition to this
permanent staff, the Ministry of Supply has
mobilised specialised resources in industry, the
Universities and other laboratories throughout the
country.
Teams of scientists directed by leaders, are engaged
in dealing with special problems affecting every
branch of munition and other supplies.
The Ministry of Supply's War Emergency Scheme
represents the most comprehensive mobilisation of
scientific and technical talent in the national
service that has ever been attempted.

DOING IT ALL HIMSELF. FOR/MR.
There's nothing like doing it yourself providing you can.
Many people find they can't, but not so Mr. Robert Penting.
Mr. Penting is at 50 a carpenter and joiner, and he is not
only building his own two-storeyed houses at Gravesend, but he
is making his own furniture also. He began the venture in
1955 and as each room becomes completed so he makes the
furniture for it. The house is of his own design and apart
from some assistance from his wife Mr. Penting is doing every-
thing completely alone. Best survey is expected completion

house to be proud of.

September 17th, 1960 PAR 88500-1 (PRH-B)

HOLIDAY AMONGST THE HOPS
Most young girls of to-day think of
Summer holidays in terms of Continental
motoring in fast cars, bikinis and sun-
drenched beaches, but not these
two youngsters.
WENDY MILLAR, 11, (left) and DOREEN
BAXON, 13, both of Goudhurst, Kent,
both decided to earn a little extra
cash for themselves during the holidays
and so took themselves off down the road
to nearby Spelmonden Farm to offer their
services with the hop-picking.
Once a regular occupation for holidaying
London East-enders, the advent of
machinery into the wire-covered fields
of the Weald has put a stop to a
healthy and highly lucrative type
holiday. Few hops are now picked by
hand.

STRAW HATS AT LUTON.
PCH/ML.
Luton (Beds) was once famed for its straw hat making industry, and even the Luton Town football team are known as "The Hatters". Now however, the demand for such hats has fallen off, and only one firm still remains at work, and half of its products go abroad. A temporary boom is with them at the moment through, for with the winning through of Luton Town to the F.A.Cup Final at Wembley on May 2nd., supporters are buying. It appears that for a Luton Town supporter to attend a cup final without a straw boater is unforgivable.

Nineteen-year-old MICHAEL CLAYT - son of the owner of A.R.Clay and Co.Ltd., the last straw hatters in Luton - is seen sweating and straightening the seam lines of straw hats. Michael is the only one of three sons to enter the family business.

It was furthermore when the blast hit the mechanised plough No. 1 Pit.

The miners working there had no chance. 300ft. yard away were blown out of their feet and blown apart.

The trapped men were in a stupor before the blast. They were in a stupor before the blast.

A pre-fab, stacked by a roadway, collapsed. Then the roof fell, and the men were buried in debris.

Transcribed_Text:
AN explosion tore through a colliery yesterday and blasted 31 men to pieces. Last night, as the Rhondda Valley lay silent and numbed with shock, the cause of the disaster was still a mystery.
Weeping wives and mothers stood at the pit-
head of ambrian Col-
liery in Clydach Vale, 
Glamorgan, as the 
remains of their men 
were brought out of 
the black hell 800ft. 
below.
It was lunchtime 
when the blast hit the 
mechanised plough face 
of the colliery’s No. 1 
Pit.
The miners working 
there had no chance. Men 
500 yards away were 
knocked off their feet and 
injured.
The doomed men were in 
a slender tunnel only 2ft. 8in. 
high.
A grey-faced, shaken 
rescue worker said: “The 
sight down there was 
terrible.
“Some men were decapi-
tated, others without arms 
and legs. Their clothing was 
ripped to shreds.”
Among the dead were 
colliery manager Ernest 
Breeze and under-manager 
Les Williams.

Indus-Fuel & Power-Accidents- Cambrian Colliery-Rhonda, May 1965

The women: At the Cambrian pithead wives, mothers and daughters wait for news.

Transcribed_Text:
A HERTFORDSHIRE STEEL WORKS.                                AW/O

Steel works are usually associated with South Wales or the industrial North, but it is a surprising fact that the steel foundry with the largest output of carbon or plain steel castings in the country is situated at Letchworth, Herts, only 30 miles from London. It provides employment for 1,500 work-people, many hundreds of whom have migrated from the North and distress areas. The work on hand is for a variety of industries ranging from ship building and locomotives to Power stations and cigarette machinery. The flow of steel means a flow of prosperity to thousands of homes in Hertfordshire and it is hoped to find employment for several hundred more by the end of 1937.

FOR FIRST PUBLICATION FRIDAY'S EVENING DECEMBER 19th.

SPINNING THE ARTERIES OF OUR CIVILISATION
19.12.41.
This is one of a remarkable series of photographs
taken mainly by the natural light of the processes
by which a British Ironworks produces rails upon rails
of cast iron pipes for public services of gas
and water which are a prime necessity of civilised life.
A large percentage of these pipes are spun by a
centrifugal process which eliminates defects and gives
a close-grained metal, easily worked and with
a high degree of resilience and resistance to impact.
In addition to its own requirements, the plant also
produces pig-iron for steel manufacture, contributing
largely therefore to the country's output of armaments.
After tapping the blast furnace the molten iron
begins to run down the "ace" (main channel)
into the "pigs" (sand casts). Hence the ingots
are known as "pig iron".
Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/55931

FOR FIRST PUBLICATION FIRDAY'S EVENINGS DECEMBER 19th.

SPINNING THE ARTERIES OF OUR CIVILISATION
19.12.41.
This is one of a remarkable series of photographs
taken mainly by the natural light of the processes
by which a British ironworks produces mile upon mile
of cast iron pipes for public services of gas
and water which are a prime necissity of civilised life.
A large percentage of these pipes are spun by a
centrifugal process which eliminates defects and gives
a close-grained metal, easily worked and with
a high degree of resilience and resistance to impact.
In addition to its own requirements, the plant also
produces pig-iron for steel manufacture, contributing
largely therefore to the country's output of armaments.
After tapping the blast furnace the molten iron
begins to run down the "sow" (main channel)
into the "pigs" (sand casts). Hence the ingots
are known as "pig iron".

BUSINESS NEWS SERVICES
NEG. NO.
HOTEL Guests at the DUPLEX Restaurant tonight held their red, white and blue banners aloft in a patriotic demonstration of welcome as they enjoyed a gala night, dining and dancing. Their party lasted from midnight until 3 A.M.

The demonstrations of patriotism, which had been encouraged by the management, continued throughout the evening as the guests cheered for their respective flags and national anthems.

The DUPLEX Restaurant, which recently opened its doors, has become quite popular with the younger set in Manhattan.

The banquet rooms were decorated with national flags and bunting in red, white and blue. The tables were also decorated with small flags of the United States and other nations.

THE ONLY FLAX PLANTATION IN ENGLAND
3.11.37.
In the village of CHARLETON, near Knightsbridge, in the heart of Devon, will be found the only Flax plantation in England. The plantation, the like of which can only be found in tropical countries, extends over 300 acres, and was planted 10 years ago. It was only this year that the product was marketed. The picture shows the cutting of the flax in progress, which is of a New Zealand variety.

PN 4/11/37

used 4/12/37. M.f.c.

Looking like pioneers cutting a road through the jungles of Darkest Africa, these men are harvesting flax at Charleton, near Kingsbridge, Devon. Three hundred acres of a New Zealand variety of flax were planted ten years ago, but the crop is being marketed for the first time this year.

SCOTTISH ARABIAN D/TAN

Created on the same site as the old buildings dating from
1903. The new Grangemouth Oil Refinery was built on the
Firth of Forth by Scottish Oils Ltd., a subsidiary of the
Anglo-Iranian Oil Company. Started in 1950, it went into
operation in 1951 with maximum annual crude oil capacity
of 7,500,000 tons, helping to counteract the Anglo-
Iranian Oil Company. The with its capacity of 50,000 barrels, or
just over 7,000,000 tons, helping to counteract the Anglo-
Iranian Oil Company's objective is high-grade motor spirit, and it also
supplies the raw material for the production of petroleum-
chemicals. The refinery will have its capacity of 50,000 barrels, or
just over 7,000,000 tons, helping to counteract the Anglo-
Iranian Oil Company's objective is high-grade motor spirit, and it also
supplies the raw material for the production of petroleum-
chemicals.
Transcribed_Text:
SCOTTISH ABADAN                                  D/ TAN

Erected on the same site as the old buildings dating from
1924, the new Grangemouth Oil Refinery was built on the
Firth of Forth by Scottish Oils Ltd., a subsidiary of the
Anglo-Iranian Oil Company. Started in 1949, it went into
operation in 1951 with maximum annual crude oil capacity
of 2,500,000 tons, helping to counteract the Abadan collapse.
Its main objective is high-grade motor spirit, and it also
supplies the raw material for the production of petroleum
chemicals. To cope with its capacity of 30,000 barrels, or
just over 1,000,000 gallons a day of imported crude oil, it
was decided to establish an installation at Finnart on Loch
Long, and run a pipeline from there to the refinery, this
being more convenient than using the old Grangemouth Docks
exclusively. The approximate cost of the combined project
was £15,000,000.

PHOTO SHOWS: The mass of gigantic pipes which for the
boiler feed pumps and steam receivers at the Grangemouth
Oil Refinery.

LOCAL TO THE NORTH OF THE CENTRAL AERODROME.
"The movement of the permanent army to Europe is
being hailed with much joy at Liverpool, and also at
Macclesfield. About half the number of 350,000 British troops
will be returning as passengers when the new aerodrome
is ready for use. The opening of the new aerodrome
service is being made much of, and operations are in full swing.
The service is being conducted by Government Railway Company
at Derby, and is being operated by the Government railway
company, and is now established as a passenger service.
Passengers are being brought here and additional on the route
already show considerable progress. All passengers on the route
will be taken care of. It is expected that the aerodrome
will be used during the year.
A hangar is being erected for the machine.

FOR FIRST PUBLICATION THURSDAY'S EVENS. 3.6.48.
VITAL TO THE SUCCES OF THE AFRICAN GROUNDNUT SCHEME.
Mac. 3.6.48.
The movement of the groundnuts crop in Nigeria is being held up through lack of sufficient rolling stock. About half the 1947/8 crop of 250,000 tons up country will still be awaiting transport when the new crop begins to move in the Autumn. The urgency of the new locos to replace those worn out ones now operating is vital; all haste is being made in production at the Vulcan Foundry at Newton-le-Willows (Lancs) and additionally to the 20 already sent, another 42 are expected to go during the year.

A FEW MILES FROM LONDON. WS/RS.
These striking pictures, taken only a few miles from
London, show the activity at the Letchworth Steel Foundry,
the largest of its kind in the country. New Year prosperity
is assured for the 1500 workers of this foundry, where contracts
are in hand for practically every industry, such as locos,
electrical plant, ships' davits, cranes, etc. The firework
display is provided by the "cleansing" process whereby iron is
converted to high grade steel. Many of the workers are from
the Distressed Areas, and have migrated here with their families,
making their homes near the steelworks.

FOR FIRST PUBLICATION WEDNESDAY'S EVENINGS, June 25th.
PROGRESS ON BRITAIN'S AERIAL GIANT
25.6.47.
At the Bristol Aeroplane Works at FILTON, progress is being
made on the huge 125-ton "Brabazon I" landplane - the largest
ever to be built in Britain - which when completed will carry
100 people direct from London to New York. A special runway,
for which a complete village had to be demolished and which
will cost £2,000,000, and an assembly hall, are being con-
structed to get this giant into the air. She will have a wing-
span of 230ft (30ft longer than between the main structures
of Tower Bridge), and will be powered by eight Centaurus gas-
turbines of 2500 h.p. each. The picture shows

A picture which gives some idea of the tremendous size
of the "Brabazon". Inside the wing centre section.

A CRICKET CRAFT MJH/BER.

Within a stone's throw - or more appropriately
a cricket ball's throw- of the famous Lord's
cricket ground, the skilled staff of Messrs. B.
Warsop and Sons, Ltd., are busy making bats for the
new cricket season. In these workshops craftsmen
have made cricket bats for over 86 years and the "old
hands" are passing on the knowledge gained by experience
to newcomers, so this is one craft which will not die.

PHOTOGRAPH SHOWS: 81-years-old MR. GEORGE HUNT
of St. John's Wood, who has been in this craft for
65 years, seen giving trainee RONALD PERRY (17) of
St. Pancras, a few tips in the art of making cricket
bats, as he shows him how to plane down a bat in the
St. John's Wood workshops of Messrs. B. Warsop.

HIGH AND DRY, MJH/RS.

Visitors to a new housing estate in Shenfield (Essex)
might be forgiven for thinking that they had come
across the 1954 version of Noah and the Ark, for in
Kilworth Avenue alongside the new bungalows and houses is
"Golden Lily" a cabin cruiser, standing on improvised
stocks, miles from any river. A few enquiries to the
contractors on the site (Jackson and Curtis of Mayfair
London) reveals that they are not pessimists expecting
the floods, however. The cruiser, which belongs to one
of their Directors, Mr. Lewis Jackson of Hanover Square
(London) has been taken to the site from her Thames mooring
to be re-conditioned during the workers' spare time. When
finished she will be moved to Maldon.

PHOTOGRAPH SHOWS: A general view of the "Golden Lily" on
her improvised stocks, miles from any water, on the new
housing estate at Shenfield (Essex).

HOPS FOR "ARMY IN THE FIELD"
Hop-picking is a real family affair to the Ayres of Pitchfield
(Banta) who turn out in strength each year for "hopping".
Providing quite a "maidan's army". For there are 35 of them
in all from the heat of the family, 81-years-old Mrs. Socky
Ayres through three generations to the latest addition to
the family, her great-grandson, John Doe, aged 7 months.
who will turn men in force to pick hops in the Petersfield area
every year. Any additions to the family are introduced to this

Hop-picking is a real family affair to the Ayres of Titchfield
(Hants) who turn out in strength each year for "hopping",
providing quite a formidable army. For there are 33 of them
in all from the head of the family, 81-years-old Mrs. Selby
Ayres through three generations to the latest addition to
the family, her great-grandson, John Doe, aged 7 maknz months,
who all turn out in force to pick hops in the Petersfield area
every year. Any additions to the family are introduced to this
family affair at the earliest possible moment.

PHOTOGRAPH SHOWS: A characteristic study of MRS. SELBY AYRES,
the 81-years-old head of a family of 33, seen at her bin
in a hop field at Petersfield (Hants). Mrs. Ayres has been hop-
picking in this area for more than 50 years.

INLAND TELEPHOTO
240540 RS
QUEEN OPENS BRITAIN'S BIGGEST DAM.

Rhayader, Radnorshire: Queen Elizabeth and the Duke
of Edinburgh pictured when the Queen officially
opened the Claerwen dam - newest and largest dam
in the British Isles in the Elan Valley here
today.
From the reservoir behind the dam the water is
piped to serve the City of Birmingham.
The dam, it is about 200 feet high, will contain
some 10,860-million gallons of water in the four-
mile-long reservoir.
Extra precautions were taken since an explosion
occurred on the pipe-line about ten miles from
the dam some days ago.
23rd. October, 1952 PR-d.

all over the Middle and Far East, find their way for repairs
to an amazing workshop in London's Brompton Road. A small team

ITALIAN MARBLE SUNK IN 1881 BEING RAISED BY SALVORS.
The shore of Bowness Creek, near Kingbridge, Devon rings
with the sound of chain and tackle and sledge hammers. Large
seaweed-covered blocks are lying in the sun and on the shore
scrubbed and polished to a glistening whiteness. There are
worth
thousands of pounds. The great stones are pure Italian marble
which have lain at the bottom of the creek defying all efforts
of salvage since 1881. 55 years ago a small Italian sailing
vessel was wrecked there. On board were over 200 tons of
Italian marble. Demotions affecting the price and supply of
marble have now caused Mr. Cartridge, of Palamaha, owner of
the wreck to salvage the marble.
Photo shows- One of the huge blocks of Italian marble
catching over 100 tons ready for shipment to London.

output - gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20:
"WHEN IT'S NIGHT TIME IN NIPPON"
"TOURING JAPANESE CLOCK"

DG/NY

MR CHARLES WEIR, clockmaker of Hatton street,
Belgravia, London, is thinking of taking a trip
to Japan, to solve the mystery of his unique
Japanese seasonal clock. He easily restored the
mechanics of the timepiece, but the system (based
on a six hour day) is still baffling.

Whatever the time of year, the day clock sets the
daylight up into exactly six hours. However the
hours are voiced in signs of the Zod-iac. Mr Weir
breakfasts at "hare-hour", is sound asleep by
"rat hour" (midnight), and alone for lunch at
"foxes hour". Clock employs a "G.L.C."
sequence which has Mr Weir's head "ringing".

PHOTO CAPTION: "Honourable Glona is posie". MR
CHARLES WEIR is perplexted by the Japanese
seasonal clock. He may present it to the Goverment.
FOR PHOTOS Nov 15th 1947. GJS/GL

Isle. India. Clocks & Watches.
Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/47292

"WHEN IT'S NIGHT TIME IN NIPPON"
PUZZLING JAPANESE CLOCK                      DG/HT

Mr CHARLES WEIR,clockmaker of Motcomb street,
Belgravia, London, is thinking of taking a trip
to Japan, to solve the mystery of his puzzling
Japanese Seasonal clock. He easily mastered the
mechanics of the timepiece, but the system (based
on a six hour day) is still baffling.
   Whatever the time of year, the Jap clock cuts the
daylight up into exactly six hours. Moreover the
hours are marked in signs of the Zodiac Mr Weir
breakfasts at "hare-hour", is sound asleep by
"rat hour" (midnight), and stops for lunch at
"horse hour. Clock strikes in a 1.2.9.1.8
sequence which has Mr Weir's head "ringing".

PHOTO SHOWS:- "Honourable Clock is puzzle". MR
CHARLES WEIR is perplexed by the Japanese
Seasonal clock . He may present it to the Government.

THIS COULD WRECK THE RADIO SHOW.

This unusual looking electronic device appears to be harmless but if it were set at the suitable frequency resonance it could cause the stand to disintegrate completely and all other stands within a radius of 100 yards at the Radio Show.

The machine is the V-1000 Vibrator. It is used for fatigue and vibration testing which has come very much into the fore recently with high speed supersonic planes and guided missiles and rockets, and electronic vibrating has become the accepted form of fatigue testing in these industries.

The machine was used to test the Comet II.
Today USA delegates from Shafa visited the Radio Show and had a close inspection of this machine which could be a "secret weapon" of a future war. Tomorrow Russian visitors are expected to see the V-1000.

(BARNETT'S 22nd August, 1954).

WATCH THE WAR ON BEACH FLIES.

        The plague of flies which has been threatening
to ruin the South Coast as a holiday centre is reported to
be seeping inland.  The flies, which feed on, and breed
in, seaweed, have so far defied all human efforts to
exterminate them.  Today MR. HAROLDMACMILLAN, the
Minister of Housing and Local Government went to Brighton
to see the invasion of flies at close quarters.  He was
shown the methods which have been used in the attempts to

CHRISTMAS CERON REVIVAL AT BEER FACTORY
Aug. 6th.
In old custom, to celebrate Christmas, has revived today
at the Whitbreads Glassworks, Bedstone (Beds.). In 200
year, glassmakers working in the ancient beat of the Fostoner
cone in the bands of "drinking beer" to quench their thirst, but, in
recent years water has been available. This Christmas, however,
thanks to the generosity of a brewer (Whitbread), it is
responsible for the glassmakers to revert, temporarily to the heavy
costing of the past and today they are enjoying their hobby
with ale from a variety of drinking vessels of their own making.

PERSONAL CHRON. Entering His ninetieth year is 90, Mrs. Eleanor
Wood, 90, who has been in the glass industry for 70 years.
73 years of which have been in the service of the Whitbreads
Glassworks. Born by birth, Mr. Heart lives in Wedgerton,
by Astor Diamond, 1890.
Transcribed_Text:
1983-5236/55201

CHRISTMAS CUSTOM REVIVED AT GLASS FACTORY. MJH/HT.

An old custom, to celebrate Christmas, was revived today
at the Whitefriars Glassworks, Wealdstone (Mddx). In olden
days, glassblowers working in the intense heat of the furnaces
were in the habit of drinking beer to quench their thirst, but in
recent years water has been substituted. This Christmas, however,
thanks to the generosity of a brewers (Charringtons), it is
possible for the glassblower to revert temporarily to the happy
customs of the past and today they are quenching their thirst
with ale from a variety of drinking vessels of their own making.

PHOTOGRAPH SHOWS: Enjoying his Yard of Ale is MR. BEN SMART
78-years-old, who has been in the glass industry for 64 years,
33 years of which have been in the service of the Whitefriars
Glassworks. Scottish by birth, Mr. Smart lives in Wealdstone.

PENRHEOL, R.D. 23-7-36
Landslide at TAFF MERTHYR COLLIERY, TRELEWIS, GLAM.
The railway lines which used to carry more than
1,000 tons of coal per day from the colliery from the
Taff Merthyr Colliery, Trelewis, were swept away
in a landslide a week ago.
Workmen are now busy driving a way through the
mass of motion earth.
G.P.O. General views.

Landslide at TAFF MERTHYR COLLIERY, TRELEWIS, GLAM.
The railway lines which used to carry more than
1,000 tons of coal per day from the colliery from the
Taff Merthyr Colliery, Trelewis, were swept away
in a landslide a week ago.
Workmen are now busy driving a way through the mass

AGRICULTURA - POULTRY - EGGS

INLAND TELEPHOTS
LBH 35975                       ABH                       LONDON BUREAU
DEMONSTRATION OUTSIDE EGG COURT.
MANCHESTER, LANCASHIRE : POLICE WERE CALLED TO THE
FIRST SITTING OF THE EGG MARKETING BOARD DISCIPLINARY
COMMITTEE HELD IN MANCHESTER TODAY. EGG PRODUCERS HERE
EXHIBIT PLACARDS AGAINST THE EGG BOARD OUTSIDE THE HOTEL
WHERE THE COMMITTEE ARE SITTING, DURING THEIR FIRST
DISCIPLINARY CASES ARISING OF QUOTAS IMPOSED TODAY.
A POLICEMAN WAS CALLED TO THE INQUIRY, ATTENDED BY NUMPY
FARMERS WITH BARRERS, WHO THROUGHOUT TODAY, UNDER HEAVY
WEIGHT, WHO HAD HAD MANY BATTLES WITH THE TOBACCO BOARD
HAD PERSISTED IN MAKING A RATTLE IN THE COURTROOM. LATER
THREE POLICE SERGEANTS AND THREE CONSTABLES ARRIVED AND
WAITED OUTSIDE THE ROOM.
13TH MARCH, 1958 PL.4

PROPERTY OF
DAILY HERALD
14 MAR 1958
PLEASE RETURN
TO
ART LIBRARY

MANCHESTER, LANCASHIRE : POLICE WERE CALLED TO THE

COMMITTEE HELD IN MANCHESTER TODAY. EGG PRODUCERS HERE,
EXHIBIT PLACARDS AGAINST THE EGG BOARD OUTSIDE THE HOTEL
WHERE THE COMMITTEE ARE SITTING, HEARING THEIR FIRST
DISCIPLINARY CASES AGAINST OFFENDING PRODUCERS TODAY.
A POLICEMAN WAS CALLED TO THE INQUIRY, ATTENDED BY ANGRY
FARMERS WITH BANNERS, AND YORKSHIRE TOMATO GROWER HARRY
WRIGHT, WHO HAS HAD MANY TANGLES WITH THE TOMATO BOARD,
HAD PERSISTED IN WAVING A RATTLE IN THE COURTROOM. LATER
THREE POLICE SERGEANTS AND THREE CONSTABLES ARRIVED AND
WAITED OUTSIDE THE ROOM.
